article.name: Binary_Options_Trading_Strategies
article.title: Binary Options Trading Strategies
article.description: A brief description of four popular trading strategies in online binary options trading, to assist online traders in finding an effective trading method.
article.keywords: binary options, options trading, trading strategies, trading strategy

content-body.text: There are many different binary options trading strategies that are used by traders. This article focuses on four of these strategies: Directional Trading Strategy, Martingale Strategy, Price Action Trading Strategy, and the Graphic Trend Analysis Strategy.

First a trader chooses an asset with a predictable pattern. He then follows and analyzes the specific asset's trend, recent performance and overall direction. Then the trader predicts whether the value of an asset will go up or down. After these steps are completed, the trader makes the trade. The upside of this strategy is that assets will follow patterns more often than not. The downside of this strategy is that there is still a significant likelihood that even a predictable asset will deviate from its pattern.

The Martingale strategy is based on the Martingale probability theory. With this strategy, trading is defined as a cycle. The cycle proceeds as follows:  A trader makes an initial trade with a base amount. If the trader makes a win on an initial trade, the trader cashes in on the win and the cycle ends. However, if the trader makes a loss on an initial trade, the cycle continues in the following manner: the trader includes the following formula in his next trade: (the value of the loss) + (the value of the previous trade) + (the value of the previous trade - the return being offered by the broker). The trader utilizes this formula as many times as the trades finish with a loss. At the point when the trade makes a win, the trader cashes in on the win and this cycle ends. Each win denotes the end of a cycle, the trader withdraws the win and starts the cycle anew. With every cycle, the trader starts again with the base amount. The upside of this strategy is that trader can offset all loses by further trading until a win occurs, providing the necessary funds are available. The downside of this strategy is that funds can run out before a win occurs and the trader can lose everything.

The Price Action Trading Strategy is a trading strategy in which the trader makes trading decisions purely based on monitoring current and recent price movements. This is usually accomplished by analyzing price charts of the assets being traded.

The main purpose of the Graphic Trend Analysis Strategy is to win with the majority of trades. With this strategy, the trader analyses a graph showing the performance of any specific asset and identifies 1 of 3 trends. These trends are the upward trend, the downward trend, and the neutral trend. If an asset is identified with an upwards trend, the trader predicts that the asset will go up. If an asset is identified with a downward trend, the trader predicts that the asset will go down. If an asset is identified with a neutral trend, the trader avoids trading because it is very difficult to predict in which direction the asset's value is likely to go.

There are numerous trading strategies that are present on the internet. Whichever strategy a trader selects, it should be one that is consistent with his personality and trading goals. In the end all trading strategies are just that: strategies. The reason for using a strategy is to maximize your wins and minimize your loses, but strategies are not infallible. Therefore it is the trader who is always responsible for the trade and not the strategy. The trader should always maintain control and exercise appropriate caution in trading. Working through all the trading strategies on the internet is neither practical nor even preferable, however the intention of this article is to explain these four strategies which are applicable to binary options trading.

article.name: The_Role_of_Support_and_Resistance_in_Binary_Options_Trading
article.title: The Role of Support and Resistance in Binary Options Trading
article.description: Support and resistance are the prices that an asset rises above or below and is often used by technical analysts to interpret chart patterns.
article.keywords: Binary Options Trading, Support And Resistance, Supply And Demand, Market Volatility

headline.title: Support and Resistance in Binary Options
The Role of Support and Resistance in Binary Options Trading

content-body.text: Technical analysis in binary options trading is based on using historical statistics to predict future market activity and price trends. It is predicated on the fact that historical patterns usually foretell future market directions. Technical charts, moving averages and oscillators are all tools that are used in this analysis method along with support and resistance. Technical analysts often speak of the pressures of supply and demand or the bulls and bears, which is often reflected in the prices an asset moves above (resistance) or below (support).

Support and resistance levels are significant determinants of supply and demand. Support levels indicate a point at which traders are more likely to buy a stock; whereas resistance levels indicate a stage at which traders are most likely to sell a stock. When such trend lines are broken, supply and demand is also thought to have shifted, which in turn creates new levels of support and resistance. These levels are closely tied with round numbers such as 50, 100, 150 or 200. As prices begin to fall towards a round number, such as $50, investors are more likely to buy large amounts of stock because it’s unlikely prices will drop further. When prices begin to rise towards a round number, investors are most likely to sell a stock.

Anytime a support or resistance level is broken, its role is said to be reversed. If a price sharply falls below support, then that level becomes resistance. If a price strongly surpasses resistance, then that level becomes support. This can occur frequently with major publicly traded companies, contrary to the belief of many investors. Being aware of all factors relating to support and resistance helps traders to identify levels that have been tested many times, but never broken. In the event that a stock has tested a support level many times, but never gone below it, a trader may decide to take profits as the security moves towards the point because it’s unlikely it will drop any further. All traders using technical analysis need to monitor such levels at all times because as long as shares remain between support and resistance then a trend will likely continue.

It’s important to note that if a price surpasses a certain support or resistance level, it does not mean that it is a reversal. For example, if a price moves above resistance in an upward trending channel, then it has accelerated, not reversed. Avoid placing trades at such volatile points because it’s likely they’ll change rapidly once more. If you do feel confident placing trades very close to support and resistance, then at least make sure to never place trades directly at support or resistance levels. This is because prices often approach whole numbers, but rarely pass them. For instance if you’re bullish on a stock that is approaching support, do not place a trade directly at support. Instead, place your trade above support by a few points.

The main purpose of the Graphic Trend Analysis Strategy is to win with the majority of trades. With this strategy, the trader analyses a graph showing the performance of any specific asset and identifies 1 of 3 trends. These trends are the upward trend, the downward trend, and the neutral trend. If an asset is identified with an upwards trend, the trader predicts that the asset will go up. If an asset is identified with a downward trend, the trader predicts that the asset will go down. If an asset is identified with a neutral trend, the trader avoids trading because it is very difficult to predict in which direction the asset's value is likely to go.

As we’ve explained in this article, support is the price level at which a stock rarely falls, whereas resistance is the price level a stock rarely exceeds. Monitoring these values gives a general picture of supply and demand psychology in financial markets around the globe and is useful to anyone using technical analysis for trading strategies.

article.name: What_Are_Indicator_and_Oscillators?
article.title: What Are Indicators and Oscillators?
article.description: While technical analysis makes use of charts, chart patterns and moving averages, it also is greatly impacted by a number of technical indicators and oscillators.
article.keywords: Oscillators, Relative Strength Index RSI, Stochastics, Asset Price Momentum, Security Closing Price

content-body.text: Indicators are calculations that are based on the price and the volume of a security that identify trends, volatility and momentum amongst other things. Indicators are another way to determine price movements while adding useful data to securities analysis. They are primarily used to verify price movements, the quality of chart patterns and to form buy and sell signals. Indicators are also effective at times when a trend cannot be ascertained. This is generally the case when a company’s stock is trading horizontally or sideways.

The two types of indicator formations either fall in a bounded or unbounded range. The ones that do fall in a bounded range are known as oscillators, and are the most common. There are also two primary classes of indicators known as leading and lagging. A leading indicator presages price movements while a lagging indicator follows price movements. The former has a predictive effect while the latter is confirmatory. Indicators, which also consist of oscillators, include the relative strength index (RSI), average directional index (ADX), accumulation/distribution line, aroon indicator, aroon oscillator, on-balance volume (OBV), moving average convergence divergence (MACD) and stochastics.
Compares recent gains to recent losses to forecast an asset’s price momentum that can be up or down.
ADX measures the strength of a current trend, but not the direction. Measured on a scale between 0 and 100, readings below 20 indicate a weak trend while readings above 40 signal a strong trend.
The accumulation/distribution line measures money flow. It is a way of calculating the ratio of buying to selling through the comparison of price movement of a period to the volume of that period.

Illustrates whether a security is on an upward or downward trend and the strength of the trend. This indicator is made up of two lines, an “Aroon up” line (#4f81bd) and an “Aroon down” line (red dotted line). The Aroon up line calculates how long it has been since the highest observed price during that time period. The Aroon down line measures the lowest observed price. The number of dots that are used are related to the specific timeframe.
Calculates the difference between the Aroon up and down lines by subtracting the two lines.

The OBV reflects movements in volume and is one of the simplest indicators to understand. If prices are up during a trading period, then volume is a positive value. When a negative value is specified then the price is down.

The MACD is the difference between two moving averages plotted against a centerline. The centerline is the point at which the two moving averages are equal. When the MACD is positive, it means the shorter term moving average is above the longer term moving average, thus signaling an uptrend. When the MACD is negative then a downtrend is in effect.

Compares a security’s closing price to its price range over a specified time period. In an upward trend, prices usually close near the highs of the trading range and indicate a rising momentum in a security. In a downward trend, prices close near the lows of the trading range and specify a declining momentum.

article.name: What_are_Moving_Averages?
article.title: What are Moving Averages?
article.description: Technical analysis is multi-faceted, so when interpreting reports it’s important to take all related criteria under consideration.
article.keywords: Moving Averages, Fibonacci Retracement, Moving Average Convergence-Divergence MACD, Bollinger Bands

content-body.text: As we discussed in a previous article, the majority of chart patterns fluctuate widely in terms of price movement, which makes it challenging to identify clear trends. To streamline analysis, moving averages are used as a way to represent the average price of a security over a period of time. By mapping a security’s average price, fluctuations become clearer along with a trendline. Moving averages are thus used to identify trends, trend reversals and to set support and resistance levels. They are also used to determine uptrends and downtrends depending on the direction of the moving average. There are numerous moving averages, but the main types include simple moving average, linear weighted average and exponential moving average.

This is the most common moving average. It takes the sum of all past closing prices over a specified period of time and divides the outcome by the number of prices used in the calculation. For instance, a 7-day moving average consists of the last 7 closing prices added together and divided by 7.

Linear weighted moving average is calculated by taking the sum of all closing prices over a specified time period and multiplying them by the position of a specific data point then dividing by the sum of the number of periods. As an example, for a 7-day linear weighted average calculation, today’s closing price is multiplied by 7, yesterday’s by 6 and so on until the first day in the period is found. All these numbers are added and divided by the sum of the multipliers.

For this moving average, a smoothing factor is utilized to place a higher weight on recent data points. This means the exponential moving average is influenced by new information, making it a preferred choice amongst many technical traders.

With MACD, traders reference two moving averages of an underlying asset over a period of time in order to identify a trendline. This approach is influenced by the theory that the price of traded asset usually reverts back to a trendline.

This refers to support and resistance levels. A Fibonacci retracement is the potential retracement of an asset’s past price moves. Horizontal lines reflect areas of support and resistance across specific Fibonacci levels before continuing in the original direction. Levels are identified by drawing trend lines between two extreme points and dividing the vertical distance by the Fibonacci ratios of 23.6%, 38.2%, 50%, 61.8% and 100%.

First developed by John Bollinger, this technical analysis method is used to identify market volatility. Bands usually become wider (farther away from the average) during more volatile periods and narrower (closer to the average) during less volatile periods. If the bands contract, it is an indication that volatility will soon begin to edge higher.

article.name: What_to_Look_for_in_a_Binary_Options_Broker
article.title: What to Look for in a Binary Options Broker
article.description: If you don’t have a good broker, trading binary options will always be a losing proposition. Fortunately, we have some easy tips to help with choosing a broker.
article.keywords: binary options, binary options broker, binary options trading, choosing a broker

headline.title: What to Look for in a Binary Options Broker
What to Look for in a Binary Options Broker

content-body.text: Binary options trading is something that can seem a bit simple at first. Sure, you’ll definitely have to learn the ropes, but once you do, it’s easy to fall into the trap of thinking that this method comes with so many advantages, it would be nearly impossible to fail. One aspect that far too many traders definitely don’t take seriously enough is choosing a broker. Without a quality binary options broker, you’ll definitely never see impressive profits. Fortunately, we have some tips to help you find one.

Right now, there is still a lot of competition amongst brokers as the world of binary options is blowing up. It’s a fairly cutthroat market with every broker doing their best to collect as many clients as possible. This is why it’s so common to see crazy deals like brokers promising they’ll match your initial deposit.

Ignore these deals completely when choosing a broker. For one thing, as the old saying goes, if it seems too good be true, it probably is. A lot of these deals have fine print that immediately ruins any promise they may have once had. Furthermore, a one-time offer is not a good reason to choose a binary options broker you will most likely be working with for years to come.

Regulations regarding binary options are a bit complicated at the moment because trading them isn’t actually legal in every country. However, just because binary options trading is illegal in a certain country doesn’t mean it’s also illegal to be a broker. See what we mean by complicated?

When choosing a broker, make sure they hold a license from a country where this type of trading is legal. This will ensure they play by the rules, or the country might revoke their license and levy a punishment against them.

By the very nature of what they do, a binary options broker makes money on every one of your trades. Although they should want to see you succeed in order to ensure you always remain a client, that doesn’t always seem to be the case. A good example of this is the number of limitations some brokers will put on your trading activity. Sadly, a lot of rookies don’t notice these issues until it’s too late.

Be sure to take the time to read through the conditions that come with every trade when choosing a broker. Otherwise, you may find out too late that your binary options broker isn’t actually too concerned with your investments.
It can be extremely easy to take for granted that a broker’s trading software will be easy to use. Why wouldn’t it be? In the digital age, isn’t all software essentially user-friendly?

To be sure it is, test out any binary options trading software before signing with a broker. When you consider that you’ll be using this software for every single trade, it should quickly become clear that it’s as important as the broker you’re going to be using.
Also, if a particular broker can’t even provide you with user-friendly software, how easy do you think it’s going to be to trade with them?

Choosing a broker isn’t something you should be doing in a rush. This step could easily take you several weeks, but it’s worth this initial investment of time to ensure you make the right decision. Once you have a solid broker on your side, everything else concerning binary options will become much easier.

article.name: Making_Sense_of_the_Brexit
article.title: Making Sense of the Brexit
article.description: Britain's vote to leave the EU, the Brexit, has sent shockwaves through global financial markets. The pound and Euro dropped sharply in the aftermath.
article.keywords: Brexit, pound, Euro, haven asset

content-body.text:
Last Thursday, June 27, the British public voted in a popular referendum to leave the European Union. The immediate result of the vote was uncertainty in the political, economic, and financial spheres. The EU is the world's largest, and longest running, practical experiment in international political and economic union, and there is simply no precedent for understanding the impact of one country's decision to cut those ties.

Political polling leading up to the vote showed that the "Remain" camp had a small lead in a tight race; the actual vote result was 51.9% to leave and 48.9% to stay, a 3.8 point margin in favor of the Britain's exit. When that result broke in the news, financial markets went crazy.

The pound sterling lost more than 10% against the US dollar, falling from a pre-vote level of $1.49 to $1.34 today. Sterling's losses were across the board; the pound fell against all of the major currencies. The Euro also fell, but not as dramatically, from $1.13 to $1.11. The drops in both currencies were predicted by analysts before the vote, in the event of "Leave" winning; neither drop is surprising, as the Britain's choice guarantees that a wide variety of trade, commerce, customs, and currency exchange agreements will have to be renegotiated or reworked in the near future, perhaps as early as next fall, when the UK government invokes Article 50 the Maastricht Treaty and extricates itself from the EU. The changes in those treaties will affect all economies and currencies with exposure to them, and this past week's market gyrations were a panicked reaction of traders to the anticipation of greater uncertainty to come.

The major European currencies were not the only ones to make such shifts in the last few days. Where the pound fell against all of the majors, the US dollar gained against most, benefitting from investors flight from sterling and the Euro. The one currency that the dollar did not gain against was the yen, itself a traditional safe haven asset. The Japanese currency has gained nearly 4% against the dollar, and the USD/JPY pair is not at 102.80, the yen's strongest showing in two years.

Currency markets don't exist in a vacuum. They are interconnected with commodity and stock markets, forming a financial trading network that resembles a spider web more than a set of ladders. Touch one part, and the whole web shakes. Stocks dropped sharply after the vote, but some indexes have since regained the whole of their losses. Gold, the most traditional of tradition haven assets, rose $60 to trade at $1,319.80 per ounce, and the stronger dollar helped to push the price of oil down 6%, although crude has since made up most of that drop.

The immediate market shockwaves of the Brexit vote are likely fading. The British are glad that sterling hasn't fallen further, the Eurozone sees the Euro as stable for now, and the Japanese have decided that their exporters can live with the yen at 102 to the dollar. The summer will likely be more stable than the last 10 days, and market fundamentals will no longer be overwhelmed by singular political events. The next big items on the calendar: the US election in November, and, as mentioned above, Britain's execution of the exit at about the same time.

article.name: Looking_Ahead_at_the_NFP_–_Part_One
article.title: Looking Ahead at the NFP – Part One
article.description: The Non-Farm Payroll report is the big event in upcoming data releases. But what is it, and how does it matter to the markets?
article.keywords: payroll report, labor market, data releases

headline.title: Looking Ahead at the NFP – Part One
Looking Ahead at the NFP – Part One

content-body.text:
We'll see three major data releases from the US this week, which taken together could produce a bigger effect on markets than Britain's Brexit vote.

First, and of least potential impact, on Wednesday the Federal Reserve will release the minutes of June's FOMC meeting. These documents are usually carefully parsed by investors looking for clues as to the Fed's future monetary policy. Consensus this time is not to expect much enlightenment. The FOMC met just a week after a historically poor jobs report, so their decision to hold steady was no surprise. All the minutes can do is confirm that, and possibly add that they don't think it's wise to hike any time soon. Markets already assume that, however, and futures traders put the odds of a rate hike this month at zero, prior to the November election at a mere 6%, and as far out as February 2017 at only 14%.

So much for last December's vaunted "Fed liftoff," when they switched from a low rate policy to a policy of monetary tightening.
The bigger news will come regarding the labor market in the States. On Thursday we'll see two data sets: the weekly initial jobless claims, which give a running tally of the number of newly unemployed seeking benefits; and the ADP payroll report. The first is subject to high fluctuations and tends to lag actual conditions. The second is more important.

ADP is the USA's largest private payroll process, meaning they calculate and issue payroll checks for employers large and small throughout the country. Every month they release their compiled payroll data to the public. These data releases show, among other things, the total number of jobs in the US and the increase or decrease from the month prior. The monthly ADP report is usually taken as a preview of the Big Event, release on the first Friday of every month.

That Big Event is the NFP, or Non-Farm Payroll report. This is the detailed report, released by the US Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics, giving the official details on the labor market situation in the US. The headline numbers of this report are the total number of jobs created and the official unemployment rate. Both numbers are usually simultaneously taken as holy writ and with a very large grain of salt.

They're the official numbers from the US government, and so the pundits and policy makers tend to see them as the accurate snapshot of the current jobs situation. At the same time, it's a case of "everybody knows" that the Bureau of Labor Statistics carefully manipulates the numbers before releasing them, and that the media will just as carefully decide which part of the report to emphasize in the news coverage. The true data – and news – is usually buried deeper in the report and surfaces a one to three days after the official release date, when analysts have had time to read and digest the full document.

article.name: Looking_Ahead_at_the_NFP_–_Part_Two
article.title: Looking Ahead at the NFP – Part Two
article.description: Tomorrow's NFP report, compiled by the US Bureau of Labor Statistics, is seen as the definitive rundown of the labor market in the United States.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Hedgestone, binary options, payroll report, labor market, data releases, NFP, non-farm payroll

headline.title: Looking Ahead at the NFP – Part Two
Looking Ahead at the NFP – Part Two

content-body.text:
Friday will see the US Department of Labor release the June Non-Farm Payroll report. The report, compiled by the Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics, is seen as the definitive rundown of the labor market in the United States. The upcoming report's greatest impact will almost certainly be felt in the two headline numbers of "jobs created" and "official unemployment," the full report will be carefully parsed for clues as to the health of the US economy and the prospects for financial market investors.

It's important to note here that last month's NFP, reporting the May numbers, was a disaster. The top number showed only 38,000 jobs created during the month, far below the consensus forecast at the time for 168,000, and while the unemployment rate did tick down that as due entirely to a large decrease in the labor force participation rate. In short, May's numbers were awful and investors, as well as policy makers, are dreading a repeat.

So what can we expect?

The general consensus regarding the upcoming jobs report is that between 175,000 and 200,000 jobs were created in June. This consensus number is exactly what is needed for the US economy to keep up with population growth – a jobs gain of that magnitude will show that the economy is growing, but not expanding, at the same rate as the population. It would be a big improvement, however, over the 38,000 jobs in May and the downwardly revised 123,000 in April. It is also more than double the 81,000 average from March to May.

The upcoming report is complicated, however, by some statistical factors. First, was the relatively low response rate to the BLS' May survey. That could have artificially depressed the total jobs numbers. Second, is the return of 30,000 Verizon telecomm workers to their jobs. These workers were striking at the time that the last NFP was compiled and their absence from the workforce may have been significant. With both of these factors returning to "normal," the June numbers may end up looking inflated next to May.

Data and statistical fluctuations of this sort are why the BLS also reports longer-term averages. March, April, and May, however, showed a three-month rolling average of only 81,000 jobs; this was partly a reflection of the poor May report but also a reflection of decreases in March and April. So much discussion was focused on the poor May numbers that analysts may have lost sight of the fact that May was third month in a row that the NFP had missed expectations. In fact, May was the eighth month of the last twelve that the month-over-month jobs growth was reported as negative. In addition, while the 12-month jobs average is 200,000, the 6-month average is 170,000, showing that the numbers have been falling off recently.

While the NFP focuses on the jobs market, it is frequently taken as a proxy report for the general health of the US economy as a whole. Investors use it to gauge their exposure to risk assets and need for haven assets; policy makers use it as an indicator policy efficacy. In each case, prognosticators try to determine what the report might say, and how it will impact future market prices and economic/monetary policy. In this respect, the divergence between the report's actual numbers and the consensus forecast can be as important as the actual data released.

article.name: Pokemon_Go_Straight_to_Profits?
article.title: Hedgestone Blog: Pokemon Go Straight to Profits? July 25, 2016
article.description: Can you follow the Pokemon Go craze all the way to the bank? What will you catch there if you do?
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Hedgestone blog, Pokemon Go, stock markets, share prices, earnings report, Nintendo

content-body.text:
Can you follow the Pokemon Go craze all the way to the bank? What will you catch there if you do? The answer to that might depend on whether or not you're a shareholder in Nintendo, Inc.

The game maker had its name on the wildly popular new Pokemon Go app, which has players getting up and going outside to locate, capture, and trade the eponymous pocket monster characters. An app that popular has got to be a cash cow for someone, and Nintendo's stock skyrocketed after the July 6 release. At the top of the jump, share prices reached $193 and the company added $7.5 billion to its total capitalization in just five days.

What goes up, must come down, and share prices are no exception. On Friday, the company announced that, due to its minority shareholder status in the relevant holding companies, the success of Pokemon Go will have only a "limited" impact on Nintendo's bottom line. With quarterly earnings reports looming, Nintendo refused to revise its earnings expectations upwards.

The immediate result was an investor pullback from Nintendo – to the tune of 18% coming off the share price. The rout likely would have been larger, but trading rules in Tokyo's equity markets take shares out of circulation if they fluctuate more than 18% in one day. In currency terms, every share lost about 5000 yen - $47 at current exchange rates. It was Nintendo's worst stock rout in 26 years.

The outlook for the company, however, is hardly as grim as the sharp drop in share price may indicate. Nintendo's shares are still 60% higher than they were before the app release, and as stock and industry analysts have noted, the company's "limited" exposure to the success of Pokemon Go comes from its 32% stake in the Pokemon holding company, owner of the successful franchise.

Yep, Nintendo owns one dollar out of every three that Pokemon brings in, and that's a limited stake. Would you mind a 32% stake in anything as big as Pokemon?
Nintendo also owns – although the total holdings remain undisclosed – a piece of Niantic, Inc., the Google spin-off that actually developed Pokemon Go. It's another finger in the pot, of the "limited" impact.

So what will that impact actually be? We should have a better idea shortly, when Nintendo delivers its earnings report. So far, expectations are for substantial increase in profits, to 35 billion yen from 16.5 billion last year. Estimates range as high as 60 billion yen. Pokemon Go in contributing strongly to the upside, despite Nintendo's "limited" stake. The only downside is the stronger yen, which has a tendency to reduce earnings from outside Japan.

It's a strange move from Nintendo, making this statement. It's not like the nature of the company's take from the Pokemon profits is a secret – it's all there in the public record. This may be a case of the company working to downplay one piece of good news (the earnings report) in an effort to increase the benefit (the expected share price increase after the earnings report is released), and traders simply overreacting. We’ll see what happens when all the numbers are in.

And the trader's lesson in all of this? It's not so much, buy Nintendo, as it is, "Look for what isn't said in the press release." A company's statements are sometimes designed to generate a reaction as much as they are to disseminate information. Don't be fooled.

article.name: Interest_Rates_Increase_in_2016
article.title: Interest rate increase has been an important subject for in 2016.
article.description: Hot debates were spurred by the Fed’s intention to increase rates. Until now, these intentions are not carried out. The Fed’s next meeting might be a game changer.
article.keywords: rates increase, Federal Reserve, Federal Reserve Committee, Brexit, Jackson Hole summit, job reports, economic growth.

headline.title: Interest Rates Increase in 2016: An Event That Might Not Materialise.

content-body.text:
A rate increase has been an important subject for discussion during the whole 2016 year. Since last December, when Federal Reserve pushed rates a quarter percent higher, everyone concerned with the state of the global economy has lived in expectation of the next rate hike. Various reasons for and against rate increases have constantly been put forward by economists; various occasions have been proposed as the most likely date for implementing the Federal Reserve’s intentions. Even now, three months before the end of the calendar year and two month before the Presidential Election in the U.S, monetary policy makers and economists are still wondering whether to wait or not wait for a rate hike, never closer to finding a definite answer to this question.

Great Britain’s decision to part company with the European Union made the debates over the Federal Reserve’s monetary policies even more heated. Before the vote, the majority of analysts estimated a rate increase as almost inevitable, saying that it would happen at least once in 2016. Immediately after Brexit’s victory, the probability of a rate hike was reduced to zero. Everyone thought in June that Britain’s separation from the European Union would wreak havoc with economy and markets and would create an atmosphere highly unfavourable to any changes in rates. Yet Britain’s vote proved to be less dramatic and troublesome in reality than it had been imagined. No crisis ensued in the world; and no sooner the shock caused by the vote had subsided, the British economy began to show signs of resilience. The British market never collapsed. The British pound, though still low, has never been rendered worthless as was feared.

When everyone understood that Britain’s exit from the European Union did not lead to turmoil, the odds that Fed policymakers would boost rates in 2016 significantly grew. Within a few months, the possibility of a rate hike this year moved up from 8 percent to 30 percent and, immediately after Fed Chair Janet Yellen’s speech, climbed to whooping 60.2 percent. The closer the world approached the date of the central bank’s annual Jackson Hole summit, the more confident some analysts and traders became about the inevitability of a rate increase. On the twenty fifth of August, however, Janet Yellen failed to sound unequivocal about this inevitability. She optimistically praised the current state of the labour market and expressed hopes in the further economic growth of the country. Yet vague about the possible dates of rates increase, Professor Yellen left her listeners no more enlightened than they had been before her speech. In effect, she said in Jackson Hole what everyone suspected all along: that a rate increase could happen before the year’s end. The anxiety that everyone felt during the biggest part of 2016, therefore, continues to overwhelm analysts and investors even now.

Other analysts from the Federal Reserve Committee tried to fill in the gaps that Janet Yellen left in her speech. Like the Federal Reserve Chairwoman, Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer also praised the solid performance of labour market and added that August job reports would influence their decision whether to push rates higher and when to do so. Other voting members of FOMC chimed in with Mr Fischer’s opinion and speculated that, probably, September 20-21, at which the Federal Reserve Committee is scheduled to meet, would be the right time to increase rates. Since Janet Yellen had given her speech in Jackson Hole, several significant events occurred but did not shed more light on the time of the next rates hike. The August job reports came out and, instead of confirming everyone in their opinion that rates would be pushed up, strengthened the uncertainty surrounding the issue. August job reports were painfully disappointing; and however enthusiastically everyone tried to put the insufficient creation of jobs down to the notoriety of the month August, during which little happens at the job market, low numbers – only 151,000 jobs created instead of 180,000 predicted by economists – eloquently pointed to an economy that was ailing. Despite the forecast that the unemployment rate would drop to 4.8%, it stubbornly remained at 4.9%. Wage growth, too, showed itself weaker than everyone expected. The disappointing job report again only confused everyone instead of enlightening with regard to the time of rate increase.

The meeting of the Federal Reserve Committee is approaching in a few days. The world is again breathlessly waiting for a remarkable rate hike, wondering whether the Federal Reserve will risk increasing rates before the Presidential Election in November or will put doing this off until December, as some analysts foresee. It well may be that in a few days the anxiety that everyone feels over Feds’ decision will not subside but will continue overwhelming the world. It well may be that 2016 will be written in history as the year not only in which the forty fifth U.S. president was elected but also in which Federal Reserve kept economists and investors continuously on edge never clearly revealing its plans concerning rates increase.

article.name: The_London_Metal_Exchange
article.title: The London Metal Exchange.
article.description: Metals – especially the precious metals – are a commonly traded commodity. The London Metal Exchange is the world's largest platform for trading in metals.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, commodity trading, London Metal Exchange, precious metals, gold, copper

content-body.text: 22 March 2017
22 March 2016

The London Metal Exchange (LME) is a global commodity and futures exchange based in London, United Kingdom. It was founded in 1877 as an exchange that specifically traded copper. It is an international platform for buyers and sellers of 500 listed LME approved types of mainly non-ferrous metals including copper, aluminum, steel, nickel, zinc and tin that are produced in 55 different countries. It does trade some ferrous metals such as steel billet, but does not trade ferrous metals that easily corrode.

It is the world's leading trading exchange in terms of trading industrial metals, futures, and options, accounting for 80% to 90% of global trading in those assets. Alongside its modern electronic trading platform and its telephone trading services, it is the last exchange in Europe that still has an open outcry trading floor. This trading floor is known as 'The Ring.' LME's annual trading is USD 14.5 trillion and 40 times the annual global metal production volume.

The Importance of LME

Across the globe, the ability to buy metals in advance at a guaranteed price is essential for the viability of many different types of companies, especially manufacturing and construction companies. LME is seen by many economists as a vital aspect to such commerce, due to the widespread need for metal in many different products, ranging from mobile phones, to computers, and to the cars, trains and buses that ordinary consumers use on a daily basis.

LME has a global network of 700 LME approved metal storage warehouses. The warehouses function mainly to provide places for delivery of metals traded on the LME, to store the abundance of metal in times of oversupply, and to ensure a steady supply of metal during shortages.

How Metal Prices are Determined

The prices of different metals are mainly determined by a combination factors including the current supply and demand and investor speculation on future metal supply and future metal demand. The costs of mining, transportation, and storage are also factors in determining metal prices. The activity on the trading floor at the LME's Ring often sets the trading price of different metals traded in other exchanges and countries around the world.

The metal market is largely divided into 4 different categories with uniquely different market conditions. These categories are base metals, steels and Ferro alloys, minor metals, and precious metals.Base metals include copper and tin. Alloy is metal made up of a mixture of different metals. Minor metals includes many metals used in electronics such as tungsten, gallium, and indium. Precious metals include gold, silver, and platinum.

Current Ownership of LME

In 2012, Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased London Metal Exchange for GBP 1.4 billion. This sale has immensely helped the LME make inroads into markets in mainland China over the last 5 years.

article.name: The_2017_Dutch_Elections
article.title: The 2017 Dutch Elections
article.description: he recent Dutch elections impacted the politics of the Eurozone and the Euro currency in the markets. It's worth taking a look at what happened.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Forex trading, Euro, Eurozone, Netherlands, 2017 Dutch elections,

content-body.text: 30 March 2017
30 March 2017

On 15 March 2017, the Netherlands held their National elections. What happened in the Dutch elections and in the Dutch economy had a significant, but nevertheless minor, impact with the value of the Euro and the performance of the general European economy. Leading economists and analysts say that what happens in the Netherlands is likely to have an indirect impact on the electoral outcome of the upcoming 2017 elections in France and Germany, as well as the 2018 Italian election. Germany, France, and Italy are the largest economies in the Eurozone, and their electoral and economic fortunes will have a greater impact than that of the Dutch. It can still be informative to look at the Dutch elections, in light of forecasts and results, and their impact on the Euro and the financial markets.

Predictions before the election

In the lead up to the Dutch elections, polls indicated a strong performance by the Dutch nationalist Party for Freedom (PVV), whose platform is highly skeptical of the European Union and the Euro. Polls estimated that the PVV would win 30 out of 150 seats in the National Parliament of the Netherlands. These polls, combined with the emergence of many other EU and Euro skeptical political parties in other EU countries, made a significant number of investors wary about the future of the Euro and the European economy.

Performance of the PVV in Dutch elections

After the final vote count, the PVV won 20 out of 150 seats in the National Parliament of the Netherlands, giving it less influence than expected. It won 13 seats fewer than Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte's People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD). At the same time, the PVV could point to real achievements in the election: an increase from 15 to 20 seats, and a populist platform that other parties copied in an effort to peel off votes, and the now-weaker influence of the VVD.

Leading analysts and economists are playing down the significance of the VDD whose focus and support is mainly driven by non-economic issues such as immigration and are instead focusing on the political and economic impact of future electoral success of the French National Front (FN) in France and the Italian National Front in Italy whose focus and support is mainly driven by the financial and unemployment difficulties experienced by major segments of the population of France and Italy.

Performance of the Euro in the aftermath of the Dutch elections

The value of the Euro against the US dollar has slightly strengthened since the Dutch elections. On 14 March 2017, the day before the Dutch election, the exchange rate was EUR 1.00 = USD 1.06. On 16 March, the day after the Dutch election, the exchange rate was EUR 1.00 = USD 1.07. On 22 March, one week after the Dutch election, the exchange the exchange rate was EUR 1.00 = USD 1.08. There are many indications that the outcome of the Dutch election has boosted investor confidence, however, given that the Netherlands shares the Euro currency with 18 other countries, each with economies that also influence the value of the Euro, it is difficult to conclude that that the slight rise in the value of the Euro against the US dollar is a direct result of the outcome of the Dutch elections.

Performance of the Amsterdam Stock Exchange (AEX) following the Dutch elections

On 16 March 2017, the day after the Dutch election, the Amsterdam Stock Exchange Index (AEX) hit a 9 year high at 514.53. The next day, 17 March, the AEX closed even higher at 516.24. According to leading economists and analysts the reason behind the good performance of the AEX was a result of the overall pro-European vote and the poorer than expected performance of the PVV in the Dutch elections. The leader of the PVV, Geert Wilders had promised a referendum on the question of whether the Netherlands will remain part of the EU or leave the EU. The reelection of Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, combined with the poorer than expected performance of the PVV, created greater certainty in the minds of investors about the future of the Netherlands remaining part the Euro and the EU.

article.name: Brexit_Case_Scottish_Independence
article.title: Brexit and the Case for Scottish Independence

headline.title: Brexit and the Case for Scottish Independence

content-body.text: 5 April 2017

headline.title: Brexit and the Case for Scottish Independence

content-body.text: 5 April 2017

Brexit and the Case for Scottish Independence

On 31 March 2017, the First Minister of Scotland and leader of the Scottish National Party, Nicola Sturgeon, formally asked the government of the United Kingdom (UK) for a referendum for Scottish independence following motion S5M-04710 being passed by Scottish Parliament on 28 March 2017. The motion favours of a second referendum for Scottish Independence. This follows the recent 2014 Scottish independence referendum in which, under difference circumstances, 55.3% of Scottish voters rejected the idea of Scotland being independent from the UK.

The Difference between 2014 and 2017

In the 2014 Scottish independence referendum, a strong case was made that Scotland would economically be better off as part of the UK than it would as an independent country. A major part of that argument was that Scotland was automatically part of the European Union (EU) by being part of the UK, whereas if it became an independent country there was no guarantee that Scotland would be accepted as an EU member. According to many analysts, the uncertainty about an independent Scotland's future in the EU was the deciding factor in the 2014 independence referendum.

On 23 June 2016 the UK held a referendum about the future of the country's membership in the EU, and the majority of British citizens who voted in the referendum (52%) voted for the UK to leave the EU. However 62% of voters in Scotland, including the majority of voters in all of Scotland's 32 local government areas, voted to remain in the EU. Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon publicly said that Scotland was being taken out of the EU against the will of Scottish voters.

The process of the withdrawal of the UK from the EU is commonly known as Brexit. On 29 March 2017, the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, Theresa May triggered Article 50 of the Treaty of European Union which formally started the 2 year negotiation process of the withdrawal of the UK from the EU.

The proposed second referendum for Scottish independence is a direct result of Brexit and the determination of Scotland to remain part of the EU after the UK is no longer an EU member state. Unlike the first referendum, in which voters in Scotland were choosing between certainty about remaining part of the EU and the uncertainly if an independent Scotland would be accepted as an EU member, in the proposed second referendum, voters would be choosing between the certainty of automatically being withdrawn from the EU and the possibility of an independent Scotland being accepted as a member of the EU.

The Connection Between Scotland and EU

In addition to doing a lot of business with the rest of the UK, many Scottish businesses conduct a lot of trade with EU countries. Additionally, many Scottish people benefit from the rights of being an EU citizen. These rights include the ability to live and work in other EU countries. Scottish businesses, educational institutions, medical services and various other organisations employ and often depend on the skills and labour of non-British EU citizens.

Opposition to a Second Scottish Independence Referendum

The Secretary of State for Scotland, David Mundell, said that it is not fair to hold an independence referendum during Brexit negotiations while the terms, conditions, and timetable of Brexit are still being negotiated and the alternative to Scottish independence is still not clear. Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davison said that another referendum would increase the uncertainty facing Scotland. The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, Theresa May, said that now is not the time for a referendum. Some Scottish businesses and economists argue that Scottish independence would not be economically beneficial because they believe that the benefits of the integration of the economy of Scotland to the rest of the UK outweigh the benefits of integration to the EU.

Other 'Break from the UK' Movements Triggered by Brexit

In the Brexit referendum the majority of voters in Northern Ireland, London, and Gibraltar also voted to remain part of the EU.

As a result of Brexit there is a move in Northern Ireland to create a special EU status where the current situation of people being allowed to move freely between Northern Ireland, part of the UK, and the Republic of Ireland, an EU member which shares a border with Northern Ireland, would continue. If this move is not successful, there is a good chance that Northern Ireland would hold a referendum about becoming part of the Republic of Ireland or remaining part of the UK. If Northern Ireland were to become part of the Republic, it would automatically become part of the EU. As a result of the bilateral Good Friday agreement on Northern Ireland between the UK and Republic of Ireland in the late 1990s, the people of Northern Ireland have the right to determine their own future in terms of choosing to remain part of the UK or choosing to become part of the Republic of Ireland.

London, as a city, has an economy that is heavily integrated with the economy of the EU. London has a lot to lose as a result of the Brexit process, as it would put the city outside of the EU. As a result of this situation, a movement called 'Londonpendence' was created which advocates creating London as an independent City State, based on the model of Singapore, with EU membership.

Gibraltar is a low tax, self-governing, British Overseas Territory located in a strategic location at the entrance to the Mediterranean Sea. As a result of its low corporate taxes, its economy is dominated by the financial services industry. It also has large tourism, online gambling, and shipping industries. It shares a land border with Spain, an EU member, and 96% of Gibraltar voters preferred for the United Kingdom to remain part of the EU. There are many person-to-person links between Gibraltar and Spain, including the employment of many people from Spain by companies in Gibraltar. Due to Brexit, Gibraltar's future remains unclear.

The majority of voters in Wales voted for Brexit even though the First Minister of Wales, Carwyn Jones had advocated, due to economic benefits to the Welsh economy, for the UK to remain a member of the EU prior to the Brexit referendum.

article.name: Brexit_and_the_Irish_economy
article.title: Brexit and the Irish economy

content-body.text: 12 April 2017
12 April 2017

Brexit and the Irish economy

The economic impact of the withdrawal of the United Kingdom (UK) from the European Union (EU) is expected to have a major impact on the Irish economy. The withdrawal is commonly known as Brexit and expected to be completed in 2019. The UK is the largest trading partner of the Republic of Ireland and USD 1.3 billion worth of goods and services criss-cross the border between the Irish Republic and the UK every week. This trade supports an estimated 200,000 Irish jobs. The Republic of Ireland is the 5th largest market for British exports. Currently there are no tariffs on this trade because both the Republic of Ireland and the UK are automatically part of a customs union as a direct result of both countries being members of the EU. When the UK leaves the EU, the current customs union situation between the Republic and the UK will automatically come to an end unless a trade deal is otherwise negotiated as part of the Brexit process. This will mean an increase to the cost of doing business between the two countries.

It is very difficult for many Irish businesses to plan ahead due to the future uncertainty created as a result of Brexit. Irish economist Alan Barrett estimates that non-Irish companies with regional headquarters in Ireland have 15% of their exports geared towards the UK whereas Irish owned companies have 40% of their exports geared towards the UK.

Many Irish businesses depend on exporting their goods and services to the UK and importing goods and supplies from the UK. If these goods and services exported to the UK are subject to tariffs, many of these businesses will become unsustainable. If these goods and supplies imported from the UK are subject to import duties, many of these small businesses will likely find alternative suppliers in places like France or Germany, EU member countries that are part of the EU customs union and not subject to tariffs on trade with Ireland.

Irish agriculture would be heavily affected by tariffs caused by Brexit. The export of Irish dairy products to the UK would be subject to a 40% tariff, for example, which will increase their cost proportionately. These and other tariffs will make a broad cross section of the current trade between the two countries unsustainable.
The Irish tourism industry expects a downturn in tourists who visit the Republic of Ireland from the UK.

EU member states can't have their own Free Trade Agreements

Due to EU rules of member countries, it is impossible for the Republic of Ireland and the UK to negotiate their own free trade agreement. The Irish Republic can only be part of a free trade agreement between the UK and the EU following the completion of the Brexit process. However the process of negotiating and implementing such an agreement between the UK and EU can take many years, and in the meantime, trade between the Republic and the UK would be subject to the standard rules and tariffs of the World Trade Organisation (WTO).

Common Travel Area

Since 1923, the UK and the Republic of Ireland have maintained a Common Travel Area (CTA), under which British and Irish citizens can travel, live, and work in either country without a passport. Since both countries joined the EU in 1973, neither has previously had the challenge of maintaining the CTA with one country being a member of the EU and one not. The CTA agreement will also have to be renegotiated as part of the Brexit process. It remains to be seen if that will happen during the overall process or after the Brexit is completed.

Northern Ireland

Northern Ireland is located on the island of Ireland; however it is not part of the Republic of Ireland but is rather part of the UK. The economies and societies of the Irish Republic and Northern Ireland are heavily integrated, with 40,000 people crossing the border – the only land border between the UK and an EU member state – each day. As a result of Brexit there is a move in Northern Ireland to create a special EU status whereby the current situation of people and commerce moving freely between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland can continue. If this move is not successful, there is a good chance that Northern Ireland would hold a referendum about becoming part of the Republic of Ireland or remaining part of the UK. If Northern Ireland were to become part of the Republic of Ireland, it would automatically become part of the EU because the Republic of Ireland is an EU member country. As a result of the bilateral Good Friday Agreement on Northern Ireland between the UK and Republic of Ireland in the late 1990s, the people of Northern Ireland have the right to hold a plebiscite to determine their own future; remaining part of the UK or to becoming part of the Irish Republic are the choices at the heart of that future.

A Potential Advantage for Ireland

Despite the uncertainty involved in the Brexit process, and the clear dangers for Ireland, there is potential for an upside. As a country with a low corporate tax rate, a similar legal system to the UK, and its status as the only English speaking country that will be left in the EU after Brexit, many multinational companies, especially companies in the hi-tech, banking, and financial services industries are expected to look at Irish cities such as Dublin as a launching pad into the European market and a place to set up European headquarters. Such a move would come at the expense of London. How much it would impact London is another open question, as even with the Brexit London remains the world's second largest financial centre.

article.name: 2017_French_elections_and_the_French_economy
article.title: 2017 French elections and the French economy - MM

content-body.text: 20 April 2017
20 April 2017

The 2017 French Elections

What happens in the upcoming 2017 French elections could have a significant impact on the French economy, the overall European economy, and the value of the Euro. Economists and investors are being cautious due to the current uncertainty as to the outcome of the vote.

2017 French Presidential Election

On 23 April 2017, France will hold its Presidential election. Incumbent French President François Hollande is not a candidate in this election, as he has declined to run again. He represents the French Socialist Party, has been President since 2012, and on the economic front has implemented centrist free market policies. If any candidate wins more than 50% of the vote, he or she will be the next French President. If no single candidate secures more than 50% of the vote, as is increasingly likely, the top 2 candidates will compete for the French Presidency in a second round of voting, known as a run-off, on 7 May 2017.

Based on polls, there are 5 candidates with a realistic possibility of making it to the second round. Investors, analysts, and economists are paying close attention to the economic policies of these candidates.

Former French Minister for the Economy, Industry, and Digital Data, Emmanuel Macron of the newly formed En Marche (Forward) political party is pro-European Union (EU), pro-immigration, pro-free market, and pro-free trade, and is widely seen by many economists and investors as having the good economic policies. However many other economists and investors feel more confident supporting former French Prime Minister François Fillon of the mainstream center-right French Republican Party who has promised to increase the retirement age to 65, to decrease the French civil service by 500,000 personnel, and whose decades of political and ministerial experience far exceeds the experiences of Emmanuel Macron.

Former French Minister of Vocational Education, and current member of European Parliament, Jean-Luc Mélenchon of the newly formed La France Insoumise (Unsubmissive France) political party is very popular with significant segments of the French population. Due to his Euroscepticism, his anti-free trade and anti-globalisation stances, his former membership of the international Communist organisation, his promises to expand welfare programs, increase wages and redistribute wealth, and his advocacy for expanded labor rights, the possibility of France electing a 'President Mélenchon' is viewed as being disastrous for the French and European economies by most economists and investors.

Current member of European parliament Marine Le Pen of the French National Front is also very popular with significant portions of the French population. Many of her policies, including her Euroscepticism and her advocacy for the withdrawal of France from the EU, her opposition to free trade, her anti immigration stance, her criticism of free markets, and her criticism the privatisation of state owned enterprises such as utilities, are well known and are viewed with great scepticism by most economists and investors.

Former Minister of National Education and Former Minister of Social Economy Benoît Hamon of the center-left mainstream French Socialist Party advocates for major investments in renewable energy, a 35 hour work week, and a basic income for all French citizens. He has publicly said that environmental protection is more important than economic growth. He has been critical of what he describes as the abandonment of a socialist agenda in favour of a centrist free market agenda under the leadership of President Hollande and former French Prime Minister Manuel Valls, both of his own political party. Most of his economic policies are viewed with great scepticism by most economists and investors.

2017 French Parliamentary Election

On the 11 June 2017, France will hold the first round of its Parliamentary elections. In any of the French Parliament's 577 constituencies where no single candidate secures more than 50% of the vote, the second round of the French Parliamentary elections will be held on 18 June 2017 where the top 2 candidates will compete to represent their constituency in the French Parliament. If any single political party secures a majority of 289 seats in the French Parliament, the leader of that party will become the next French Prime Minister. Otherwise the next French Prime Minister will be elected based on which political party is able to achieve a majority by forming a coalition or minority government with the support of other French political parties and independents.

There is a realistic possibility that the French Prime Minister and the French President will be from different political parties. If this happens, the Prime Minister and President will need to compromise on their political positions and negotiate with each other in order to be able to reach a consensus and be effective in implementing legislation and governing France. Compromise and political negotiations between different political parties will also be needed if no single political party secures 289 seats in order for the French Parliament to be able to function and pass legislation.

Frexit - The Unlikely Withdrawal of France from the EU

f either Marine Le Pen or Jean-Luc Mélenchon wins the French Presidency, there is a very high likelihood that there will be a referendum about the future of France's membership of the EU. It is even a central part of Marine Le Pen and the National Front's pre election promises. Current polls suggest that the majority of French citizens want France to remain a member of the EU. However in the lead up to the 2016 EU membership referendum in the United Kingdom (UK), polls suggested that the majority of British citizens wanted the UK to remain a member of the EU. Therefore the possibility of the withdrawal of France from the EU cannot be ruled out.

Unlike the UK, which joined the EU when it was known as the European Economic Community (EEC) in 1973, France was a founding member of the EEC and a signatory to the Treaty of Rome in 1957. The French economy is significantly more integrated into the economy of the EU than the British economy. Additionally, France uses the Euro as its national currency, whereas the UK does not and retains its own currency, the pound sterling, as its national currency.

Many economists and analysts say that a withdrawal of France from the EU would severely hurt French trade within the EU and French industries that depend on skilled and seasonal workers from other EU countries as well as having many other economic implications likely be disastrous for both the French and European economies.

video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: May 18, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_May_18_2016
video.author: saar

content-body.text: Global stocks are mainly down today, as are most commodity prices. The US dollar is showing some strength in the currency markets..
In the world's currency markets, the US dollar has been improving its position. The greenback has rose against all of its major peers, reaching its strongest level since the last week of April.
Looking at the broad picture, the US dollar index is up to 94.954, after bottoming out on May 2 at 92.626. The index measures the dollar against a basket of trade-weighted major currencies.

Taking a look at individual currencies, we see the dollar is improving against all of the majors. The EUR/USD pair is trading at 1.1262, the GBP/USD has edged down to 1.4417, and the AUD/USD is down at 0.7272. The USD/JPY is up at 109.51, the USD/CHF is moving closer to parity at 0.9837, and the USD/CAD stands at 1.2973.
The dollar is supported by recent statements from Federal Reserve branch presidents that the central bank could raise interest rates twice, or maybe even three times, in the second half of this year.
Major commodities – oil and precious metals – have edged down in recent days.

Oil prices are holding steady just below the $50 mark. In the long-term outlook, the fundamentals of high supply and only moderate demand are likely to keep prices low, but in the short term a variety of factors are pushing for a modest increase. Among the factors supporting oil prices are production disruptions in Nigeria, Libya, and Venezuela; a decline in shale field output from the US; and a decline in Canadian output as a result of the Alberta wildfires. There is also speculation that US crude inventories will show a drop of nearly 3 million barrels when last week's data are released later today.
Looking at current prices, we see the US benchmark, West Texas Intermediate, selling for $48.09 per barrel, and Brent crude, the global benchmark, selling for $48.99.

Turning to precious metals, prices are down from their May 2 peak when gold reached $1,303 per ounce. Gold is currently selling for $1,271.45, and has been selling in a $30 range, between $1,260 and $1,290, for the last three weeks. Silver and platinum are showing similar patterns, selling in a narrow range over the last three weeks. Silver is currently going for $17.09 per ounce, and platinum for $1,041.59.

Metals, especially gold, are finding some support in investor worries over the possibility of the "Brexit," a British exit from the EU, and the political rise of Donald Trump in the US. Both events have stoked some fears over future geopolitical instability, of the sort that encourages investors to look for safe haven assets.
US stock markets were down yesterday, with the major indexes all posting losses. The Dow Jones fell 1.02%, the Sj&P 500 dropped 0.94%, and the NASDAQ lost 1.25%.

Stocks here hurt by statements from several Federal Reserve branch presidents indicating that the Fed is looking to accelerate its interest rate increases later this year. Rising rates tend to draw money into dollar assets and away from stocks as investors seek the highest returns. The next Fed FOMC meeting is scheduled in June, and investors will be watching it carefully.

Looking at some individual stocks, consumer shares were mixed. Home Depot reported that it beat profit and revenue expectations for the first quarter and even raised its forecast for year, but still showed a loss in share price, dropping 2.50%. On the other hand, TJX Companies, the owner of the TJ Maxx department stores, gained 0.47% after beating first quarter share earnings expectations.
European markets opened to price increases and high volatility yesterday, but closed with most of the major indexes down for the day. They are continuing their losses in early hours trading today.
Right now, the FTSE 100 in London is down 0.45%, the DAX is down 0.26%, and the French CAC 40 is down 0.31%. Spain's IBEX 35 is showing a modest gain of 0.08%.
European manufacturers are down, with automakers showing share price losses. BMW has fallen 1.08% and Renault is down 0.91%. British telecom company Vodafone is up slightly, showing a 0.95% gain.

In the Asian markets, Japan was basically flat today while China and Australia both posted losses. In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 fell by 0.05% and the TOPIX gained 0.19%. Shanghai's CSI 300 index dropped 0.58% and the Hang Seng fell 1.45%. In Australia, the Sj&P ASX lost 0.74%.

Japanese shares got some slight support from an upbeat economic report, showing that Japan has managed to avoid a recession and is showing the fastest growth rate in a year for the first quarter. The Japanese economy grew by an annualized rate of 1.7% in Q1, beating by far an expectation of just 0.2%, and coming off of a 1.7% contraction for Q4. One dark spot, however: private consumption only grew at 0.5%, and it makes up 60% of the economy. The weak consumption has spurred speculation that further stimulus policy may be in Japan's near future.

The biggest item on the calendar for today is the release by the US Federal Reserve of the minutes from the last FOMC meeting. Investors will be watching closely for insight into the Fed's possible forward monetary policy, especially after the hints dropped recently that the bank may increase the rate of interest hikes later this year.

video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_May_19_2016
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: May 19, 2016
video.author: saar

content-body.text: Global equities are mixed today, after volatile trading as investors were cautious in the lead-up to the release of the Fed's meeting minutes. The dollar jumped on speculation that the Fed will raise rates again in June, and the stronger dollar has pushed commodities down. The British pound is stronger on reduced expectations of a "Brexit" next month.

The US dollar is up again in the currency markets, rising against most of its major peers on indications that the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates again in June. The US dollar index is up to 95.255, a four-week high.

Looking at specific currency pairs, the EUR/USD has fallen slightly to 1.1215 and the AUD/USD is down at 0.7213. The USD/CHF rose to 0.9879, and the USD/CAD is up to 1.3063. Perhaps most importantly, the USD/JPY has broken above 110, and now stands at 110.06. It's a three-week low for the yen.

The British pound is the exception to this pattern of dollar strength, with sterling gaining slightly on the greenback as the GBP/USD pushed up to 1.4570. The pound is finding support as investors price in lower expectations that Britain will exit the European Union at the June referendum.

Turning to the commodity markets, the stronger US dollar is putting a downward pressure on prices across the board. Most commodities are priced in dollars, so as the greenback gains, it takes fewer of them to buy commodities. That's not the only factor hitting the markets, however.

In oil markets, investors have a lot to watch. Saudi stockpiles have fallen five months in a row, as production has been flat – at more than 10 million barrels per day, but still basically flat – and exports have remained high. The Kingdom essentially used its stockpiles to meet customer orders while putting a de facto cap on production. Saudi stockpiles peaked at 329.4 million barrels last October; they are currently at 296.7 million barrels.

The overall OPEC oil strategy since mid-2014, and the reason that Saudi Arabia has been using stored oil to meet orders without increasing production, has been to defend market share at the expense of price.

Global oil stockpiles remain high, and production remains at near-record levels. In addition, Iran is increasing output faster than experts had predicted – it is up by almost 60% year over year and now stands at 2.1 million barrels per day – and these factors are also helping to push prices down. Rising US crude inventories haven't helped the oil bulls, either.
Right now, oil prices are edging down. US oil, the WTI trading price, is going for $47.40 per barrel, while Brent crude, the global price, stands at $48.07.

Precious metals are also feeling pressure from the stronger dollar, but even more from the hints that the Fed may raise rates. Higher interest rates tend to draw capital away from metals, as gold and its allies do not pay interest. Gold is trading near a three-week low, selling for $1,255.06 per ounce. Silver is going for $16.72, and platinum for $1,023.93.

US markets were volatile yesterday, and ended the day either basically flat or showing modest gains, after the FOMC minutes release showed that the central bank officials are leaning towards raising interest rates next month.

As you recall, they raised interest in December, reversing a long standing policy of near-zero rates. Now they're ready to hike again if the economy grows enough to justify it. The minutes release followed several speeches from Fed branch presidents which all hinted towards a preference for a June rate hike.

The economy, however, might not be obliging. The Q1 growth rate came in at only 0.5% annualized, following a poor Q4. April retail sales rose, however, so investors Fed officials will be watching the rest of Q2 very carefully.

With this as background, the Dow Jones is down 0.02%, the S&P 500 gained 0.02%, and the NASDAQ picked up 0.50%. Some retailer share prices show a bit of gloom, however, with Target losing 7.61% and Walmart dropping 3.01%.

In Europe, the markets opened on the down side yesterday, and stayed there for much of the day. They did pick up towards the end of the trading session, and most finished the day in positive territory. The European markets are once again in the down side in early trading today, with the FTSE 100 down by 1.12%, the DAX down 1.17%, and the CAC 40 down by 0.53%.
Right now, the FTSE 100 in London is down 0.45%, the DAX is down 0.26%, and the French CAC 40 is down 0.31%. Spain's IBEX 35 is showing a modest gain of 0.08%.

Brewing giant SABMiller is down by 0.20%, indicative of consumer's hesitance to spend, and mining corporation Anglo American is down 5.94%, feeling pressure from the strong dollar's downward push on commodities.

In the Asian markets, Japan was basically flat today while China and Australia both posted losses. In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 fell by 0.05% and the TOPIX gained 0.19%. Shanghai's CSI 300 index dropped 0.58% and the Hang Seng fell 1.45%. In Australia, the Sj&P ASX lost 0.74%.

Asian stocks have been having a bad few days, although the Nikkei 225 did manage to post a gain in today's session, finishing with a positive 0.01%. The TOPIX was down 0.14%, the Hang Seng was down 0.67%, and Shanghai's CSI 300 was down 0.18%. In Australia, the S&P ASX fell 0.61%.
Continued worries about China's economy and its clear slow-down, combined with lower expectations of further easing policies, weighed on investors and helped to push the Asian shares lower.
Later today we'll see the weekly initial jobless claims from the US. As usual, it's a one-week lagging indicator that gives some evidence of the labor market in the States.

video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: May 22, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_May_22_2016
video.author: saar

content-body.text: The US dollar continues its overall rally in the currency markets, despite recent dips against the Euro and the yen. This makes three weeks of gains for the greenback, its longest advance run since January. The prospect of tighter US monetary policy combined with the possibility of more easing Japan and Europe, is pushing the dollar higher in the markets.

By the numbers, the EUR/USD rose slightly, to 1.1224, and the USD/JPY has slipped to 110.15. The pound has eased back, bringing the GBP/USD to 1.4502. The AUD/USD is down, at 0.7222, while the USD/CAD is up to 1.3113 and the USD/CHF is nearing parity again at 0.9903.

The US dollar index currently stands at 95.334, and is trending upwards. The Japanese yen, while it has shown a slight gain in weekend trading, is generally down as demand for haven assets has weakened.

Prices in oil edging down again, as traders begin to realize that despite production drops in the US and strong demand in China and North America, the global oil glut remains out there. Dozens of tankers are holding offshore at Galveston, Texas and Singapore, holding tens of millions of barrels of crude, and investors are starting to realize that that oil will have to come ashore sometime, and when it does, prices will fall again.
Right now, crude is edging down slightly. WTI, the US trading benchmark, is selling for $48.41 per barrel while Brent, the global benchmark, is going for $48.72.

Precious metals are looking volatile right now. Gold is edging down, but silver and platinum are both up slightly. Gold is selling for $1,251.98 per ounce, silver for $16.55, and platinum for $1,022.70. Metal prices are softening as investors see an increased probability of higher interest rates in the US dollar later this summer.

US markets were volatile yesterday, and ended the day either basically flat or showing modest gains, after the FOMC minutes release showed that the central bank officials are leaning towards raising interest rates next month.

As you recall, they raised interest in December, reversing a long standing policy of near-zero rates. Now they're ready to hike again if the economy grows enough to justify it. The minutes release followed several speeches from Fed branch presidents which all hinted towards a preference for a June rate hike.
