The economy, however, might not be obliging. The Q1 growth rate came in at only 0.5% annualized, following a poor Q4. April retail sales rose, however, so investors Fed officials will be watching the rest of Q2 very carefully.

With this as background, the Dow Jones is down 0.02%, the S&P 500 gained 0.02%, and the NASDAQ picked up 0.50%. Some retailer share prices show a bit of gloom, however, with Target losing 7.61% and Walmart dropping 3.01%.

Global equity markets are also noticing that the US Federal Reserve is hinting at a June rate increase, and it has helped to boost stocks worldwide. The stronger dollar has also meant a weaker yen, which provided an extra boost to indexes in Tokyo. Finally, the G7 finance chiefs, meeting in Japan, all expressed disapproval of the possible “Brexit,” as pundits are calling the prospect of Britain leaving the EU. With most of the world’s establishment against the move, traders see it as less likely to pass the June 23 referendum, and London’s stocks have reacted.

So, as we head for a new week, we see that all of the global equity markets finished in the green on Friday. The Dow Jones in New York gained 0.38%, London’s FTSE 100 picked up 1.70%, and Tokyo’s Nikkei 225 gained 0.54%.

video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: May 23, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_May_23_2016
video.author: saar

content-body.text: The global equity markets are mostly down, with a few bright spots in Asia. A fall in metals has led a general decline in commodities. Japan's yen is stronger today. The US dollar is easing back slightly in the forex markets.

The US dollar is for the most part holding its own in currency trading, falling or stable against the Euro, pound, yen, and Aussie, but rising against the Canadian dollar and the Swiss franc. The US dollar index remains relatively high; at 95.317 it is close to Friday's three-week high reading of 95.510.

Looking at particular currency pairs, the USD/JPY is down at 109.41, the EUR/USD has also edged down and shows 1.1212, and the GBP/USD is slightly weaker at 1.4476. The dollar is up against the Canadian currency (USD/CAD 1.3155), and approaching parity with the Swiss franc (USD/CHF 0.9900).

The global supply glut is back on the minds of oil traders, as Iran has said in advance of the June 2 OPEC meeting that it will not consider reducing or freezing oil output. Combined with the continued record levels in global crude storage facilities and the news that the US rig count did not drop last week, ending nearly two straight years of declines in active rigs, this has traders and investors thinking seriously again about the supply glut that never went away, the basic laws of supply and demand, and the effect these will have on prices.

Looking at numbers, we see Brent crude, the global trading benchmark, at $48.30 per barrel and West Texas Intermediate, the US trading benchmark, at $47.89. Oil prices are showing a pattern similar to last summer – rising from a mid-spring trough to reach a plateau. Last summer, prices were fairly stable through June and then fell again. It remains to be seen what oil prices will do this year.

Turning to precious metals, we find that the traditional safe haven investments are down. Gold as slipped from the $1,300 mark it reached at the end of April and is now selling for $1,247.76 per ounce. Silver is also down, selling at $16.41 as compared to its April 29 peak of $17.83. Platinum has also fallen, and its price now stands at $1,015.35.
The US markets closed on an up note Friday, with all of the major indexes showing modest gains. The Dow Jones picked up 0.38%, the S&P 500 gained 0.60%, and the NASDAQ advanced by 1.21%.

One interesting piece of economic news, closely concerning the US, came out of India. Apple Inc.'s CEO, Tim Cook, wrapped up a visit to that country, at which he discussed a variety of tech topics with Prime Minister Modi.

Apple is interested in India for that most basic of reasons – the country has a large and growing middle class consumer segment that is very interested in smartphones. Apple recently failed to open India as destination for refurbished products, but it is good to see the company continuing to take a serious interest in one of the world's remaining untapped customer markets. Apple's stock is currently selling for $95.22, flat since Friday's close.

Mixed economic reports from the Eurozone hurt the common currency. Eurozone PMI, a measure of manufacturing and service sectors, dropped slightly to 52.9, despite an expectation for a rise to 53.2. The drop came despite reasonably good news from Germany and France, which both showed increases in private sector activity.
In early trading, the main European indexes are all down. The FTSE 100 has shed 0.25%, the DAX is down 0.75%, and the CAC 40 has fallen 0.78%.

Turning to Asia, data showed Japan with a much higher trade surplus than expected, a development that helped to boost the yen. The surplus comes along with a severe contraction in Japanese manufacturing activity. The Nikkei 225 and TOPIX both fell, by 0.49% and 0.35% respectively.
In China, the CSI 300 gained 0.29%, while the Hang Seng fell 0.22%. Australia's S&P ASX dropped 0.60% in today's trading.

video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: Jun 20, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_Jun_20_2016
video.author: saar

content-body.text: On Friday, the 17th of June, US stock market slid and finished the whole week also low. Shares of technological stocks fared worse than those of other companies. Investors were not inclined to make drastic moves, and trading was largely uneventful. The Dow Jones Industrials shed 0.3% for the day and 1.1% since the previous Friday. The S&P also lost 0.3% on the day and dipped 1.2% for the week. The NASDAQ retreated 0.9% on Friday and dropped 1.9% from a week ago. In Europe, trading was more vigorous, despite investors’ worries over the suspension of the Brexit campaign caused by the death of Labour MP Jo Cox, who was supportive of the decision to stay in next week’s referendum. The FTSE soared 1.2% on Friday but slid 1.5% from a week ago. The DAX advanced 0.8% and declined 2.1% overall on the week. The SMI jumped 1.0% on the day and, like other indices, slumped 2.6% since the previous Friday. Stocks in the Asia-Pacific region continued climbing on Friday helped by the rising oil prices and weakening yen.
The US dollar lost against all its major counterparts – the pound, the yen, the Australian and Canadian dollars, the euro, the Swiss Franc.

Looking at particular currency pairs, the USD/JPY is down at 109.41, the EUR/USD has also edged down and shows 1.1212, and the GBP/USD is slightly weaker at 1.4476. The dollar is up against the Canadian currency (USD/CAD 1.3155), and approaching parity with the Swiss franc (USD/CHF 0.9900).
Gold had a slide US$20.05 to US$1,290.70. Copper futures appreciated 0.15% to US$2.05. WTI spot crude rose US$1.77 to US$47.98. Dated Brent spot crude gained US$1.98 to US$49.17.

Because of some patent misunderstandings in China that could lead to the problems with iPhones in the country, Apple sank. After Revlon had promised to buy Elizabeth Arden for US$419.3 million, shares of Elizabeth Arden climbed. Having revealed good quarterly revenue, Oracle, an American multinational computer technology corporation, added.

Banks -- Deutsche Bank, Commerzbank, Société Générale, Crédit Agricole, and BNP Paribas – did better on Friday than on the previous day. RWE and E.ON surged, and so did Technip and Total. Siemens had said that it planned to merge some of its operations with Gamesa Corporación Tecnológica and edged up. British Standard Life increased having said that HDFC Standard Life Insurance, Max Life Insurance, and Max Financial Services might merge. Lloyds Banking Group, Standard Chartered, Barclays, and Royal Bank of Scotland gained. Randgold Resources and Fresnillo drifted lower.
In early trading, the main European indexes are all down. The FTSE 100 has shed 0.25%, the DAX is down 0.75%, and the CAC 40 has fallen 0.78%.

The Shanghai Composite added 0.4% on Friday. It was, however, lower 1.4% from a week ago. The Hang Seng soared 0.7% for the day and dipped 4.1% for the week. The Nikkei was 1.1% on Friday but declined 6.0% since the previous Friday. Its huge drop was caused by the jump of the yen that hit to a 22-month high, the event that, in turn, was precipitated by the Bank of Japan’s decision not to change its monetary policy. Canon, Mazda Motor, Nissan, Panasonic, and Toyota advanced. Inpex and JX Holdings rose. The S&P/ASX edges up 0.3%. The All Ordinaries added as much. The S&P/ASX sank 2.8% from a week ago, while the All Ordinaries shed 2.7%. Mining companies peaked, and the big banks did too. The Kospi rose 0.1% on Friday and declined 2.1% since the last Friday. The Sensex did not change for the week, though it gained 0.4% on Friday.
On the 20th of June, Germany is publishing May Producer Price Index. Japan is reporting on May Merchandise Trade.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: Jun 21, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_Jun_21_2016

content-body.text: The big UK referendum on EU membership will be happening this Thursday, and it's already reverberating through the markets. Global stock indexes rallied yesterday when new polling showed the "remain" vote gaining ground, although the yen and gold – traditional safe-haven investments – remain at high levels

The new strength in the "remain" camp gave a boost to the pound. Sterling rose sharply yesterday, with its best daily gain in the last seven years. The pound has been rising steadily since June 14, and the GBP/USD no trades at 1.4709

The yen is also trading from strength these days, boosted by safe-haven trading from investors worried about volatility. Last week, the Japanese currency hit a 22-month high level of 103.55 to the dollar, and while it has eased slightly since then, the USD/JPY remains at 104.49

The strength in the pound and yen, while due mainly to factors specific to those currencies, also reflects a general easing in the US dollar. The dollar index, the broad measure of the greenback against a basket of its major peers, has fallen to 93.565, its lowest level since the May 2 trough of 92.626

Looking at some specific currency pairs, the EUR/USD stands at 1.1330, the USD/CHF has fallen to 0.9609, and the USD/CAD has eased to 1.2786. The Canadian dollar has also received support from the recent gain in oil prices.

Oil hit a trough on June 16, but has been rising since then. Both major trading benchmarks closed on the $50 handle yesterday, with Brent breaking above that level. Prices have eased back since then, mainly on supply concerns.

Regarding oil supplies, it's important to remember that there is still a general supply glut in the global oil markets. It has eased in recent months, but supplies are still outweighing demand, and putting a downward pressure on prices. Adding to the supply pressure, the US reported in increase in the number of active drilling rigs last week, making it the third week in a row of such gains. In Saudi Arabia, production in April reached 10.262 million barrels per day, 38,000 more than in the previous month. And finally, Iran has increased the export capacity of their main oil cargo facility at Karg Island, allowing it to handle up to eight oil tankers at one time.

It's important to note that despite the high production in Saudi Arabia, the kingdom's oil exports showed a slight drop recently. The development suggests that the supply-demand imbalance which has pushed prices down continues to plague the markets.
With all of that as background, WTI, the US benchmark, is trading for $48.96 per barrel, and Brent crude, the global benchmarks, is selling for $50.16. Both prices are trending downwards.

In the precious metals markets, gold reached as high as $1,295 yesterday before easing back on the news that "remain" was gaining on "leave" in the Brexit polling. Gold has been trading above $1,200 since February 10, and has challenged $1,300 twice in the last two months. Currently, gold is selling for $1,283.59 per ounce.
Silver followed a similar path, hitting $17.54 yesterday before easing back to $17.47. Silver has been trading above $17 since June 8.

A weekend poll showed a close vote in the upcoming referendum on the UK's EU membership. The "remain" camp hit 45% in the poll, with the "leave" group showing 42%. The news boosted global stock indexes. Investors have been wary over the past month, fearing financial, economic, and political chaos that could ensue if the UK leaves the EU, and stock markets hit a one-month low levels last Thursday. Markets have rallied since, and the Betfair gaming and betting site has put the odds of "remain" vote at 78%

As a reminder that the markets are naturally volatile, in Europe, the stock trading is just opening as of this writing, and the main indexes showing losses in early hours trading. The FTSE 100 in London is down 0.52%, the DAX has lost 0.21%, and the CAC 40 has retreated 0.31%

In the Asia-Pacific region, where markets are closing, stocks mostly rose in the day's sessions. The Nikkei 225 gained 1.28%, TOPIX picked up 1.15%, and the S&P ASX in Australia advanced 0.33%. Markets in China were mixed, with the Hang Seng gaining 0.54% while Shanghai's CSI 300 fell 0.20%.

In the American markets, all three major indexes declined during the day but still finished in the green. US stock investors may be holding back to see what Fed Chair Janet Yellen has to say to the US Congress. Her appearance before the legislative body begins today and will continue tomorrow. Her remarks will be carefully parsed, especially in light of this month's decision by the Federal Reserve to hold interest rates steady. Futures markets have lowered the odds of a rate hike, essentially discounting any Fed movement this summer. Some savvy investors have remembered to look at the calendar and are discounting any move on rates until December, the month after the US elections.
As for the market indexes, the Dow Jones ended yesterday with a gain of 0.73%, the S&P 500 finished up by 0.58%, and the NASDAQ gained 0.77% for the session.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: Jun 22, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_Jun_22_2016

content-body.text: Stocks advanced yesterday, ahead of the tomorrow's Brexit vote in the UK. In today's markets, the European indexes are off to a good start while the Asian markets were decidedly mixed. Gold and silver both eased back as the "remain" camp gains ground in Britain.

The US dollar eased back slightly in the currency markets, falling against the yen, the Swiss franc, the Aussie dollar, and the Canadian dollar. The pound posted modest gains, while the Euro fell overnight and is now rebounding slightly. Both currencies are supported by investor assumptions that the UK will vote to remain in the EU.
Looking at the numbers, we see the EUR/USD edging up to 1.1290 and the GBP/USD also slightly higher at 1.4676.

The other major pairs are trending down for the US dollar. The AUD/USD moved up to 0.7498, while the USD/JPY edged down to 104.52, the USD/CHF is down at 0.9593, and the USD/CAD has retreated to 1.2775.

The US dollar index, a measure of the dollar compared to a basket of trade-weighted major currencies, is down slightly at 93.794. The index touch 94 yesterday, during Janet Yellen's testimony before the US Congress.

The upcoming Brexit vote has had its impact on gold and silver, too. Both metals rose when it looked like the UK would vote to leave; now that a "remain" vote is appearing more likely, precious metals are falling in the markets. Investors are wary of the possibility of a "Brexit," and were using precious metals as a safe haven to hedge against market losses.
Gold is currently down 0.30% from yesterday, at $1,264.36 per ounce, and silver is down more than half a percent, at $17.23.
Oil prices have rebounded on expectations of a large drawdown in US crude inventories. Both major benchmarks are back above the $50 handle today.

The US Energy Information Administration is scheduled to issue data today on crude stockpiles in the States. Analysts expect to see a drop in supplies of more than 1.5 million barrels. Preliminary reports from API, an industry analysis group, showed an inventory drop of more than 5.2 million barrels.
Oil prices rose on the news, with US West Texas Intermediate reaching $50.17 and Brent crude climbing to $51.19.

In the global stock markets, most of the major indexes finished on a positive note yesterday. In today's trading, the Asian markets were mixed, with Chinese stocks ending the day in the green and Japanese stocks finishing in the red. The European markets are off to a good start in early hours trading. The US markets haven't opened yet, but are resting on yesterday's modest gains.

By the numbers, in New York we see the Dow Jones and NASDAQ both up 0.14%, and the S&P 500 up 0.27%. In Europe, the FTSE 100 in London and the CAC 40 in France have both gained 0.31%, while the German DAX is up by 0.53%. Turning to China, Shanghai's CSI 300 index is up 0.89% and the Hang Seng in Hong Kong is up by 0.61%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 is down 0.64%.

The gains in Europe come as investors feel more confident about the results of tomorrow's UK referendum on Britain's EU membership. The political polling is currently too close to call, but the bookies and gamblers appear to be putting their money on the "remain" vote winning. The Ladbrokes bookmaker site puts an 82% probability on Britain staying with the EU; the Betfair predicts "remain" will win with a total of 50% to 55% of the final vote tally.
The political polling shows that 45% of British voters support remaining in the EU, 44% want the UK to leave, and 11% are undecided. We'll know the final results on Friday morning.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: Jun 23, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_Jun_23_2016

content-body.text: The pound is at a six month high level, its strongest this year, as investors grow more confident that the UK will vote to stay in the EU. The voting started this morning, and results should start coming in late tonight. The confidence negatively affected haven assets, and the yen and gold both eased back overnight.

The US dollar is flat against the Swiss franc (USD/CHF 0.9586), but down against the other majors. The dollar's sag comes after Janet Yellen spoke before both Houses of the US Congress, giving statements that hinted strongly at a delay for the Fed's new policy of monetary tightening and interest rate hikes. The Fed raised rates in December but not since, and it looks increasingly likely that it will not do so again before next December.

The Japanese yen has also eased back, feeling some pressure as investors see less need for a safe haven today. The yen remains at strong levels, with the USD/JPY trading at 104.38. In light of the currency's rise this year, Japanese government and bank spokesmen have hinted that, should the dollar-yen exchange rate break below 100, the government will take active intervention to weaken the currency and boost the rate. A stronger yen tends to have a negative impact on the Tokyo stock markets, as it makes exports more expensive. The Japanese economy is highly export dependent, and its stock markets are exquisitely sensitive to export prices.

The pound sterling rose sharply overnight, as the GBP/USD reached 1.4778 for its strongest showing this year. Cable found support in the strength of the "remain" camp ahead of today's Brexit referendum vote. Pre-vote polling shows a race that his too close to call, but with a very slight lead for "remain." We all know, however, that the only poll which really counts is the one from the ballot box. Those results should be in tomorrow.

The Euro is also gaining, and for the same reasons as the pound. The EUR/USD is currently trading for 1.1340. The AUD/USD is up to 0.7536, and the USD/CAD has slipped to 1.2789. Definitely not a good day to be trading US dollars.

Currencies are not the only trading instruments hit by the repercussions of the Brexit vote. Precious metals have seen sharp drops in recent days, as the "remain" camp gained and investors took profits from metals rather than holding them as the traditional safe haven. Gold, silver, and platinum are all down today.

It's gold's fourth day in a row of retreating prices. The metal is selling for $1,268.82 per ounce, while just five days ago it was challenging the $1,300 mark. Silver is also down, at $17.37 per ounce, and platinum has fallen to $978.40.
Oil prices dipped overnight, falling back below the $50, although Brent crude has managed to climb back up and now trades at $50.20 per barrel.

The drop came as the US government reported a smaller than expected drop in crude oil stockpiles, with oil stocks shrinking by only 917,000 barrels despite a forecast for a 1.5 million barrel drop. The report has pushed West Texas Intermediate, the US trading benchmark price, down to $48.85 per barrel.

In other oil-related news, the OPEC cartel reported that its revenue has hit a 10 year low, dropping by $483 billion dollars last year. OPEC, led by the Persian Gulf states, has tried to boost output to maintain market share, but their increased exports have not been able to compensate for the lower prices inherent in their production strategy. The record production levels combined with falling profits simply highlight the bind that global oil producers find themselves in, as their marketable commodity is no longer covering their required expenses.

Today's biggest news, of course, is the UK referendum on Britain's EU membership. The latest polls show that the race is too close to call. "Remain" had a narrow lead yesterday, but polls released this morning showed "leave" slightly ahead. Many Britons listed themselves as undecided. There's only decisive poll, however, and we won't see those results until tomorrow morning.

In the meantime, bookmaking and betting websites have been showing a strong bias by betters in favor "remain." It's an interesting development, but there is also this: since yesterday, long lines of people have been forming up outside currency changers across the UK, as nervous citizens rush to change their pounds for dollars or Euros. Clearly, they have heard that a "leave" vote will drive sterling down and are looking to preserve their cash. According to the Royal Mail, sales of foreign currency are up by 79% year over year.

The stock markets, however, seem sanguine. The European markets opened to gains in early hours trading, with the DAX rising by 0.60% and the CAC 40 by 0.53%. Of special note: the FTSE 100 in London is up by 0.47%.
In the US, the markets are still showing yesterday's numbers, so we have small losses in the New York indexes. The Dow Jones closed down 0.27%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.17%, and the NASDAQ fell 0.22%.

The Asian markets, in today's session, were somewhat mixed. Tokyo showed gains after the strong yen caused losses yesterday, and the Nikkei is now up 1.07%. The TOPIX gained 1.10%. In China, the Hang Seng picked up 0.32%, but the CSI 300 lost 0.53%. The Australian markets posted a modest gain, of 0.18%.

The UK votes on the Brexit referendum. Polling results should start to come in tonight, with final results available before the weekend. In the US, the weekly jobless claims will be released. These are the initial unemployment claims, and will be watched carefully this week in light of the poor jobs report from the beginning of the month.

video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: Jun 26, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_Jun_26_2016
video.author: saar

content-body.text: The financial markets changed dramatically on Thursday as Britons voted to leave the EU. All the global stock markets fell sharply, as did the pound and the Euro. The dollar and the yen gained, and the price of gold jumped nearly 5%.

Start with sterling. The British pound fell to its lowest level since 1985, with the GBP/USD touching 1.35 before bouncing slightly to 1.3679. This is an 8% drop for sterling, and the results of it will be slow to come in. In the long run, look for UK exports to grow more competitive, but the immediate result may be painful for UK residents on fixed incomes.

The Japanese yen saw the second largest jump among the major currencies, gaining almost 4% on the US dollar. The USD/JPY fell to 102.22, the yen's strongest showing since August, 2014. The sudden strength in the yen will make Japanese exports more expensive, a hard blow to Japan's export-dependent economy, and it was reflected in Japan's stock markets.

The dollar also spiked against the Euro, as the EUR/USD pair fell as low as 1.0919 before stabilizing at 1.1117. That was a 2.35% fall for the Euro, to a one-month low. The EUR/USD has been volatile since March, but trading mainly in a range between 1.10 and 1.14, so Friday's drop in the pair remained in that ballpark. It looks like investors are not expecting the Brexit to inflict as much short term pain on the EU as it will on the UK.

The other major currency pairs also showed gains for the dollar, of about 1.5% to 2%. The AUD/USD fell to 0.7466, while the USD/CAD rose to 1.3004. The USD/CHF rose to 0.9760. The US dollar index, a broader measure of the greenback's strength in the currency markets, jumped two points to 95.448.

None of the currency fluctuations were completely unexpected, given the "Leave" win in the UK. With drops in the pound and Euro, the dollar was bound to gain, and the yen is a traditional safe-haven investment when markets show extreme volatility.

A stronger dollar and investors' safe-haven trading also pushed up the price of gold, sending the metal up almost 5% to stand at $1,315.75 per ounce. Silver also rose, to $17.77, and platinum, which had been in the doldrums, has climbed back to $985.40.

There's nothing special to report in the metal prices; like the yen, precious metals tend to do well when markets are volatile. Gold had been rising all month, with only a slight easing the day before the Brexit vote when polls showed "Remain" more likely to win. The metal reacted predictably to the final vote results.

Oil prices dropped sharply, with Brent crude, the global benchmark losing 4.9% in the markets to trade at $48.41 per barrel. West Texas Intermediate, the US benchmark price, fell similarly, and is down to $47.64. The sudden spike in the dollar and the overall market volatility following the Brexit vote overshadowed the usual production, supply, and demand concerns for the oil markets. It will be a few days before the oil markets return to normal.
Equity markets are down across the board today, as investors pulled back after the Brexit vote, mainly on uncertainty over what the vote will mean for the international trade and finance in Europe.
In London, the FTSE 100 dropped 3.15% on Friday, but the Continental markets fared even worse. The DAX fell 6.82%, the CAC 40 lost 8.04%, and the IBEX 35 retreated a whopping 12.35%.

Tokyo's markets saw similar losses, with the Nikkei 225 falling 7.92% and the TOPIX losing 7.26%. The losses were smaller in China and Australia; Shanghai's SCI 300 fell 1.29%, the Hang Seng fell 2.92%, and the S&P ASX lost 3.17%.
The American markets were also down, with losses similar to London's. NASDAQ fared the worst in New York, falling 4.12%. The Dow Jones lost 3.39%, and the S&P 500 fell 3.59%.
Overall, it looks like Monday will be a very interesting day in the world's financial markets.

video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: Jun 27, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_Jun_27_2016
video.author: saar

content-body.text: The British voted for the Brexit on Thursday, and the results are still rippling through the world's financial markets. The pound is trading at its lowest levels in 30 years, and stock markets around the world tumbled on Friday. It's possible that markets may stabilize early this week; Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, released a statement early today assuring the public that there are contingency measures in place to ease the economic pressure on the international financial system. It doesn't always seem so reassuring, though, if the government has to say it. We are in for interesting times.
Friday's trends are continuing the currency markets. The pound and Euro continue to lose ground, while the dollar remains strong and the yen continues to gain on haven trading.

The Euro has also fallen, as whatever fallout happens with the Brexit, the Eurozone and the common currency are sure to feel the effects. At this writing, the EUR/USD is trading at 1.1041, the Euro's lowest level since March.
The dollar also continues to gain on the Swiss franc, Canadian dollar, and Australian dollar, although movements against those currencies have been less extreme than with the pound and Euro.

The Japanese yen is the exception to the dollar's market gains, as the currency is one of the financial world's traditional safe-haven investments. The yen has seen sharp gains since the British referendum results came in, with the USD/JPY reaching as low as 99 overnight. The pair is now trading at 101.98, the yen's strongest level in two years.

Oil markets have been shaken but not stirred by the Brexit vote. Prices are down for crude, mostly on investor caution as they look to put their money in less volatile assets. Oil has lost about $2 per barrel since the vote. Right now, US West Texas Intermediate is selling for $47.64 per barrel, and Brent crude is going for $48.57.
The metals markets have seen more, and more extreme, movements. Both precious and industrial metals have reacted to the British vote.
Copper, a widely used industrial metal that is a good proxy for the industrial metal market generally, is up, and now selling at $2.13 per pound.

Gold and silver saw strong gains on Friday, but are diverging a bit today. Silver is relatively flat, at $17.79 per ounce, while gold is continues to rise at a slower rate and is selling for $1,326.35. Platinum, which also has industrial uses, is also still appreciating, and is trading for $992.05 per ounce.
Taking Friday's demand into account, gold is up 25% for the year to date, its strongest performance in 30 years. Like the yen, gold is gaining on demand for haven assets.

The biggest market news, of course, is the Brexit vote and its fallout. The most immediate effect of the vote was the resignation of British PM David Cameron. Cameron had put his political credibility on the "Remain" campaign, and shortly after the referendum results were made official he announced that he will step down come October. His decision, plus the clear desire of the British people to leave the EU, increased investor anxiety over the global economic outlook and set off a wave of sharp drops in the major stock markets.
European markets saw major losses on Friday, and are showing losses again in early trading today. London's FTSE 100 is down 1.34%, the DAX is down 1.47%, and the CAC 40 has fallen 1.42%.

In the Asia-Pacific region, the shock waves plus the stronger yen sent Tokyo's markets into a tailspin on Friday, but today the Nikkei 225 closed with a gain of 2.39% and the TOPIX was up by 1.77%. A former Bank of Japan official has stated that if the market turbulence proves temporary, and the yen gives back some of its gains, than the central bank can hold off on another stimulus effort. The statement added that Japan reserves the right to intervene in the currency markets to prevent the yen from appreciating too much, as a stronger yen is a severe drag on Japan's export dominated economy. Such a move would be strongly opposed by Washington, and market watchers are skeptical that Tokyo would follow through. The BoJ next meets to review rates and monetary policy at the end of July, but there is speculation that the bank will hold an emergency session sooner.
Elsewhere in Asia, Shanghai's CSI 300 index gained 1.41% while the Hang Seng continued to fall, losing 0.16%. Australia's S&P ASX is up 0.47%.
In New York, the markets have not opened yet, but the futures markets are predicting further losses for the Dow Jones.

A number of coming events will touch on market volatility this week. On Tuesday, the US government will release a revision of the Q1 growth estimates, and the American Petroleum Institute will give supply data on crude oil storage. Wednesday will see the Federal government's official oil stockpile report, as well as statements by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen, who will be speaking at a European Central Bank event in Portugal. Yellen's statements will be carefully parsed, as it will be her first since the Brexit vote.

video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_Jun_28_2016
video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: June 28th, 2016
video.description: The Brexit referendum, and Britain's vote to leave the EU, have hammered markets worldwide over the last few days, but there are signs that the chaos may be easing.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, Commodities, Currencies, Stock Indexes, Individual Stocks.

content-body.text: The Brexit referendum, and Britain's vote to leave the EU, have hammered markets worldwide over the last few days, but there are signs that the chaos may be easing. Safe haven assets – gold, bonds, dollars, and yen – have done well as traders looked to protect their investments.

The currency markets appear to be stabilizing, at least for now. The pound and Euro have both risen from overnight lows, with the EUR/USD trading at 1.1065 and the GBP/USD at 1.3303. The pound dipped as low as 1.31 overnight, a level not seen since 1985.
While the pound and Euro fell, the yen gained sharply as the USD/JPY fell as low as 99 on Friday. The pair is currently trading at 102.14, a two-year high for the yen.

The dollar eased back a bit overnight. The Aussie, the Canadian loonie, and the Swiss franc are all slightly higher against the greenback today, although not enough to erase all of gains the dollar has made since Friday.

The dollar's easing can best be seen in the US dollar index, which peaked at 96.86 yesterday and now stands at 96.094. It's important to put the currency shifts in perspective, however, and to realize that the dollar index stood at 100.02 in December, and even with the recent gains it is still down more than 3%.

Oil priced dipped below the $48 mark overnight, marking a sharp drop from their June 8 high over $50. The oil markets were not pummeled as badly by Brexit as the pound was, but investors still sold off in a search for safer purchases.

Currently, global benchmark Brent crude is selling for $47.93 per barrel and US WTI is selling for $47.15. While both prices have fallen, they are still up some 65% since February when they hit 13-year low levels. Both benchmarks are trending upwards at this writing.

Metals rose sharply in the wake of the British vote, filling their usual role as haven assets, have retreated slightly, as investors paused in their buying to take profits. Gold is currently down 0.85%, and selling at $1,313.28 per ounce. Silver is also down, at $17.69 per ounce, for a 0.33% decline.

Platinum has managed to post a modest gain, rising 0.05% to $979.98 per ounce, but that may be related to its status as a precious metal with industrial uses. Copper, a good proxy for industrial metals generally, is up 1.72% and selling at $2.16 per pound.

As if Britain's vote to leave the EU and the subsequent shock to the world's financial markets weren't enough of a blow to the British economy, two major ratings agencies reduced the UK's credit rating yesterday.

Standard & Poor's dropped the UK's AAA down to AA, and gave the Brits a "negative" outlook, while Fitch's cut their AA+ to plain AA, also with a "negative" outlook. Both agencies cited the possibility of the Brexit vote sparking a contagion and prompting other member nations to reconsider EU membership, as well as the now-greater risk that financial markets will collapse further. In S&P also cited the chance that Scotland or Northern Ireland could consider secession from the UK.

Another unexpected consequence of the Brexit came in Japan, where the government reported a slightly lower than expected annual tax revenue. The slight miss came in as the yen rose in the currency markets, making exports more expensive and hurting corporations' bottom lines. End result – lower than expected profits, and lower than expected tax collections. It's a squiggly line from the Brexit, the connection is real.

The connection will also ripple outward. Japan's lower tax collection means that the government will have less money available to budget for financial stimulus, should that become necessary to weaken the yen. It's impossible to tell where these paths will lead.

Turning to the numbers, we saw both a general improvement and mixed results in the Asia-Pacific markets during today's session. Equities generally gained, although not every index finished in the green. In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 gained a modest 0.09% and the TOPIX fell by the same amount. Hong Kong's Hang Seng dropped 0.27% while Shanghai's CSI 300 picked up 0.51%. In Australia, the S&P ASX lost 0.66%.
In Europe, the markets finally posted gains at the start of early trading today. London's FTSE 100 is up 1.96%, the DAX has risen 2.18%, and the CAC 40 is up by 2.52%.

The American markets have yet to open for today, but Wall Street's main indexes fell yesterday. The Dow Jones lost 1.50%, the S&P 500 fell 1.81%, and the NASDAQ retreated 2.41%. The American futures markets are in the green, however, so it may be a good day in New York when trading opens.
Overall, it seems investors are seeking to buy, looking for bargains now that prices are low.

Looking at the economic news today, we'll hear from European Central Bank President Mario Draghi, who will be speaking at the ECB conference in Portugal. US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen will be speaking at the same venue tomorrow; both central bank chiefs' statements will be carefully parsed to get a feel for their reactions to the Brexit vote.

Also later today, the US government will release the final numbers on Q1 GDP and corporate profits. It won't have as much of an impact as the Brexit vote, but it may still make for some interesting reading.

video.author: saar
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_Jun_29_2016
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: June 29th, 2016
video.description: Global equity markets seem to have regained their footing since the Brexit vote, while the currency markets are only beginning to stabilize.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, Market Fundamentals, Currencies, Stock Markets, Haven Asset.

content-body.text: Global equity markets seem to have regained their footing since the Brexit vote, while the currency markets are only beginning to stabilize. Gold has shown the strongest gains, on its status as a haven asset.

The exchange markets are still a bit crazy in the wake of the Brexit vote. Overall, the dollar remains strong, but most other major currencies have yet to find a new equilibrium.

Cable eased overnight but has gained in early trading today, bringing the GBP/USD to 1.3399. The Euro has also climbed from overnight lows, with the EUR/USD reaching 1.1073. These two currencies have the most intimate exposure to the looming Brexit, and it remains to be seen how they will stabilize.
The US dollar index, the broad measure of the greenback used to get a big-picture look at the currency's standing, has dipped to 95.976, a bit below Monday's peak of 96.544 but still two full points above its pre-referendum level.
Accounting for normal variability, the index shows a broadly stronger dollar which has gained as investors pulled their money out of the UK and the Eurozone and put into perceived safer assets.

The other currency that gained from the Brexit vote was the Japanese yen, which has also traditionally been used as a safe haven. The yen is now near 2-year highs against the dollar, as the USD/JPY is trading at 102.39. It actually touched 99 on Friday, but has eased back and it may be that the yen is the first major to find a post-Brexit trading level. If so, it won't make the Japanese happy, as their export-dominated economy prefers a weaker yen.

Oil prices are caught between Brexit fallout and market fundamentals, making price forecasts difficult. Crude dropped initially after the vote, getting down to the $47 handle yesterday, but has now rebounded. US West Texas Intermediate is trading for $48.53 per barrel and Brent is up to $49.21.

The higher prices come as the American Petroleum Institute showed US stocks declining by nearly 3.9 million barrels, including a 1.2 million barrel drop at the States' largest oil storage and distribution facility in Cushing, Oklahoma. Another boost to crude came from Norway, where 7500 oil and gas workers in one of Europe's largest oil producers are threatening to go strike starting Saturday, over a new wage and labor deal.

It's important to remember that these factors, as well as other recent news that pushed oil up slightly, are only partly compensating for the underlying weak market fundamentals that have been impacting oil trading. OPEC and Russia are still producing at record levels; US fracking and shale producers have grown more efficient in the face of lower prices and learned how to maintain production while reducing the number of active rigs; global storage facilities are still near record levels; demand is weak in major consumers such as China; and the International Energy Agency is predicting a global oversupply averaging 1.5 million barrels per day looking ahead through 2017. In short, nothing has changed among the basic reasons why oil prices fell in the first place. Look for continued volatility in the oil markets.

The real winner in the post-Brexit market chaos has been gold. The metal is near a two-year high, despite easing back after reaching $1,362 last Friday. Gold is currently trading at $1,321.15 per ounce, putting it up about 25% for the year to date. Haven asset demand has fueled the metal's gains.

Silver has also gained, for the same reasons and almost as dramatically. It's selling at $18.31 per ounce, also a two-year high. Platinum, which like silver has industrial demand that has been swamped by asset trading, is now going for $989.20.

The Japanese are clearly concerned by the ripple effects of the Brexit vote, despite gains in Tokyo's stock markets in today's trading session. Prime Minister Abe stated today that the government is ready to use all policy tools at its disposal to keep the economy moving in this time of market uncertainty.

Japan, which has been facing a decades-long economic slump, is feeling the effects of a stronger yen that makes exports more expensive and tends to depress the stock markets, corporate revenues, and even tax collections. In addition, a report on May's retails sales showed a drop for the third straight month. Overall, policy makers are under heavy pressure to engage in a further round of monetary stimulus programming.

With that as background, the Nikkei 225 gained 1.59% today and the TOPIX picked up 1.88%. In Shanghai, the CSI 300 increased by 0.48% while Hong Kong's Hang Seng advanced by 1.31%. Australia's Sj&P ASX is ahead by 0.77%. Of the major Asia-Pacific markets, however, only Shanghai is showing gains for the month, of 2.90%.
In Europe, stock markets appear to have turned around, posting gains yesterday and opening to gains again in early hours trading today. The FTSE 100 in London is up 1.74%, the DAX has gained 1.15%, and the CAC 40 has advanced 1.65%. It remains to be seen if the European markets can hold on to these gains, as economists are predicting that Britain's move to leave the EU may prompt a mild recession in the UK.

The US markets also advanced yesterday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average picking up 1.57%, the Sj&P 500 gaining 1.78%, and the NASDAQ gaining 2.12%.
Some data releases today will impact the US markets, especially data on personal income and spending for the month of May. Also to be released are government data on oil stockpiles.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: June 30th, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_Jun_30_2016
video.description: Markets continue to stabilize today. Equities are on their third day of rallies, and the yen and pound appear to have levelled out in forex trading.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, pound sterling, US dollar, haven trading, oil inventories

content-body.text: A full week after the Brexit vote, and the British people's historic decision to leave the EU, there are real indications that the markets are stabilizing. Global equities have rallied two days in a row, and the currency markets appear to be leveling out.

The pound sterling was hammered hard in the immediate aftermath of the Brexit referendum, losing nearly 10% of its value against the dollar. Cable's sharp drop seems to have halted, and the currency appears to have leveled off (with the natural daily volatility, of course) with the GBP/USD pair now at 1.3388. This is still very close to the 31-year low levels the pound reached last Friday.

The US dollar, which made strong gains among the major currencies as the pound fell, is generally holding its position. The EUR/USD, which had dipped as low as 1.09, is now at 1.1101, the USD/CHF is up slightly at 0.9806, and the USD/JPY has been fairly steady this week, having remained in the 102 range since Monday and trading now at 102.58. The yen gained sharply on safe haven trading after the vote.

It may be hard to see the overall strength of the dollar by looking at the individual currency pairs, with their constant shifts and changes. The US dollar index provides a big-picture view of the greenback by comparing it to a basket of trade-weighted currencies. The index now stands at 95.911 and is trending upwards. The index peaked at 96.544 on June 27, and while it has eased it is still at a 3-month high level.

Like the dollar and the yen, gold also made strong gains on safe haven trading in the past week. The metal touched a high last Friday, at $1,360 per ounce, and has since pulled back to $1,315.65. Even accounting for that, gold is still $60 higher than before the Brexit vote, making a gain of 4.5%. Overall, gold has appreciated more than 20% since January 1, making this its best first half in more than ten years.

Silver and platinum have also made gains. Silver is trading at $18.41 per ounce, and is challenging the $18.50 level. Some analysts expect that it will break that resistance in the near future and possibly climb as high as $25. Platinum has broken above $1,000 for the first time since June 9, and is now trading at $1,007.55.
Oil declined in trading right after the British results came in, falling to the $47 handle, but has since regained the lost value. Crude picked up nearly 4% overnight as investor fears over the Brexit have eased and a combination of data releases and news reports have eased worries over supply issues. Currently, the US West Texas Intermediate benchmark price stands at $49.41 per barrel and the global markets' Brent price is at an even $50.

On the supply side, the official US report on oil inventories showed that crude stocks fell by 4.1 million barrels last week, beating early expectations by a wide margin. In addition, talks between the Nigerian government and guerillas in the Niger Delta are showing signs of success which may portend a resumption of Nigerian oil production and export.

It's important to remember that despite the positive news regarding supply, there is still a tremendous oversupply in global oil markets. Worldwide, production is exceeding demand by about 1 million barrels per day, and oil storage facilities around the world are nearing their maximum capacity. In the US, oil inventories total 526.6 million barrels, an 80-year high level for this time of year. Despite day-to-day or week-to-week fluctuations, this is the basic supply and demand issue that is dominating oil markets right now and holding prices down.

As mentioned above, equities around the world are having a good day, and rallying from the past weeks' losses.

At this writing, the Asia-Pacific markets are wrapping up their trading day, and showing another session of positive results. In Japan, the Nikkei 225 is up 0.48% and the TOPIX has gained 0.41%. The rally here comes despite a poor industrial production report, which showed May's output plunging 2.3%. Japanese stocks may be reflecting an adjustment to the now-stronger yen, an acceptance of its new level in the 102 range, and an easing of fears that the currency could strengthen further. The Japanese markets are highly sensitive to exports, which are negatively impacted when the yen appreciates.

In China, the CSI 300 index managed to squeak out a 0.14% gain for the day, while the Hang Seng picked up 1.74%. Australia's Sj&P ASX gained 1.70%. It's important to remember that even though the Asian markets have posted gains over the last several days, they are all still down significantly for the month of June.

From the US, there have been some mixed economic reports. Housing data missed expectations with a 3.7% decline in pending home sales, and the April data was revised downwards. Personal spending, however, showed a rise in May of 0.4% and April's number was revised upward slightly to 1.1%. The rise in spending came even as personal income rose at a slower pace than expected.

In New York, the Dow Jones Industrial Average finished yesterday with a gain of 1.54%, the Sj&P 500 ended up 1.70%, and the NASDAQ picked up 1.86%. While all three are still down for the month of June, the Dow and the Sj&P are showing year-over-year gains.

In Europe, the main indexes had an excellent day yesterday, with the FTSE 100 in London recouping all of its losses since the Brexit vote. The FTSE gained 3.58% yesterday, and is up 2% for the month. The DAX gained 1.75% and the CAC 40 advanced 2.60%. Both are down for June.

Today the UK will release its final estimate for Q1 GDP growth. This will make an interesting data point in light of the past week's market volatility. From the US, we'll see the weekly initial jobless claims, which will be of particular interest as the official jobs report for June will come out in just eight more days.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 3, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_3_2016
video.description: Markets are calming as the worst short-term fears of the Brexit vote proved to be overblown. The major currencies are trading at stable levels.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, haven asset, non-farm payroll report

content-body.text: Markets are calming as the worst short-term fears of the Brexit vote proved to be overblown. The major currencies are trading at stable levels, and stocks have recouped most of their post-vote losses. Precious metals continue to show gains.

The currency markets appear to be returning to stable patterns, and the shockwaves of the Brexit vote seem to be fading.

The US dollar and the Euro have both returned to stable patterns, with the EUR/USD trading at 1.1136. The AUD/USD has appreciated slightly to 0.7498 and the USD/CHF has dipped slightly to 0.9733. The USD/JPY has fallen from Thursday's high level of 103.20 to stand at 102.52 today. The GBP/USD, while the worst performer among major currencies in the last week, and of course, at the epicenter of the whole blow-up, is trading at 1.3267. The pound has traded in a fairly narrow range (1.3225 to 1.3429) in the last 5 sessions.

Precious metals were the big winners after the Brexit vote, with gold, silver, and platinum all gaining heavily on safe haven asset grabbing.

Gold is currently trading at $1,341.35 per ounce, and platinum at $1,058.95. Silver made a bigger splash in recent days, however. The metal gained only modestly (from $17.41 to $17.89) in the three trading sessions after voting results, but since June 28 it has risen sharply and is now trading at $19.86 per ounce.

Oil markets were initially pushed down by stronger dollar after the Brexit fluctuations, but recent news on supply squeezes help bring the price back up. Overall, oil has been gained since April on news that falling US supplies may ease the global oversupply situation. Even taking the Brexit fluctuation into account, the oil markets have been fairly level – near the $50 mark – since mid-May.

Currently, a barrel of West Texas Intermediate crude, the US benchmark price, sells for $48.99, and a barrel of Brent crude, the global trading benchmark, is going for $50.35.

There is not a lot to report in world financial markets on a Sunday. Markets around the world tended to rally last week, mostly on investors' speculation – backed by a few semi-official statements from banks and governments – that central banks will act if necessary to limit financial confusion from the UK's upcoming EU exit.

In New York, the main indexes finished Friday on a positive note, with the Dow gaining 0.11%, the Sj&P 500 adding 0.19%, and the NASDAQ gaining 0.41%. The New York markets will be closed on Monday for the July 4 holiday, a happy Independence Day to our friends in the US.

European and Asian markets also finished well last week. London's FTSE 100 gained 1.13%, the DAX picked up 0.99%, and the CAC 40 added 0.86%. Spain's IBEX 35 advanced 1.29%.

In the Asia-Pacific, the Nikkei 225 added 0.68% and the TOPIX gained 0.69%. These were welcome developments for the Japanese, as the now-stronger yen is likely to have a depressing effect on exports which in turn will tend to push Tokyo's equity markets down. Those markets, like the ones in London, have recouped their early losses, however, and appear to be making a good adjustment to the new conditions. Shanghai's CSI 300 index gained a tiny 0.01% in volatile trading, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng put on 1.75%. The Sj&P ASX in Australia added 0.25%.

There's quite a bit of news coming up in the markets this week. Bank of English will release its financial stability report on Tuesday, taking a close look at the UK's banking sector, especially in light of the decision to leave the EU. The report will be carefully picked over by investors seeking some future guidance.

From the US, there are two major releases scheduled for the week. On Wednesday, the Federal Reserve will release the minutes of the last FOMC meeting, at which they held rates steady. As with the BoE report, it will be carefully parsed for future guidance.

Of greater importance will be Friday's Non-Farm Payroll report. Last month's report, giving the June numbers, was one giant whiff, but the consensus forecast for the June numbers is a jobs gain of 175,000 and headline unemployment ticking up to 4.8%. The Non-Farm Payroll report is generally taken as a proxy report for the overall health of the US economy, so it matters whether or not the report meets, exceeds, or misses expectations.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 5, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_5_2016
video.description: Precious metals are having their best year in a long time, as investors seeks safe havens. The Japanese yen has gained on the same type of trading.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, price of silver, Japanese yen, haven trading, oil markets

content-body.text: Precious metals are having their best year in a long time, as investors seeks safe havens. The boost in gold and silver comes even as markets appear to be stabilizing after last week's Brexit volatility.

In the currency markets, the Japanese yen remains strong, with the USD/JPY slipping to 102.13. It's a two-year high for the yen against the dollar, and a 0.4% overnight gain for the currency.

Japan has an export-dominated economy, and maintains a strong surplus in current accounts which boosts the yen as a haven asset. Ironically, that boost to the yen threatens Japanese exporters, as the stronger currency makes their goods more expensive overseas which will in turn depress Tokyo's equity markets and in turn depress the yen. At least, in theory. Markets don't always comply with theory, and the yen remains high today.

The Australian dollar also made some news overnight, dropping slightly to bring the AUD/USD to 0.7520. The dip came after the Reserve Bank of Australia held its base rates at record lows.

In the meantime, the US dollar rose again, breaking a 5 day losing streak in the exchange markets. The EUR/USD slid to 1.1132, the USD/CAD rose to 1.2882, and the USD/CHF steadied at 0.9712. The GBP/USD slid a quarter percent, to 1.3258. Sterling has been the worst performer this year among the major currencies, losing 10% against the dollar. All of that loss has come since the Brexit vote.

Precious metals are making quite a splash in today's currency markets. Gold and platinum, which had both seen steep increases in the sessions after the Brexit vote, retreated, with platinum losing 1.29%. Gold now stands at $1,343.25 per ounce and platinum at $1,055.77. In both cases, investors' profit taking was the likely source of the overnight drop. Gold remains up 27% for the year to date.

Silver, however, was the bigger newsmaker. The white metal jumped in price at the end of last week, and has continued gaining since. For the year to date, silver has gained 44%. It currently stands at $20.01, and actually broke above $21 in intraday trading on Monday.

The gains in metals, and also in the Japanese yen, came on haven trading, as investors chose safety and pulled out of riskier assets while the markets were in turmoil.
Elsewhere in currencies, oil prices dipped back below $50 last night. The fall in prices came as Nigerian oil producers revealed in increase in output last month. Their increase was due to infrastructure repairs following attacks by militant groups in the Niger Delta oil region.

In the North American markets, analysts are waiting for stockpile data to be released on Tuesday and Wednesday.
Right now, Brent crude, the global trading price, is going for $49.55 per barrel. West Texas Intermediate, the US benchmark, sells at $48.17.

Market analysts are still talking about the Brexit vote and its aftershocks, and policy makers are still working to devise the correct reactions. Investors, meantime, are trying to work out the odds that Bank of Japan and the European Central Bank will increase monetary easing, or to divine when, if ever, the US Federal Reserve will hike rates again.

In the US, markets will reopen today after a long holiday weekend. Happy Independence Day to our friends in the States!
In Europe, market watchers are focused on the Italian banking sector. The major Italian banks are basically insolvent, weighed down by an enormous backlog of bad loans, and unable to continue operations without a bailout. Italy's historical method of dealing with a situation like this was to devalue the currency, bail out the banks, and let everyone deal with the new exchange rate. That option is not available in the Euro regime.

The problem, however, is that after the Greek debacle, northern European countries are in no mood to permit any further bailouts. Greece was the world's 44th largest economy, and bailing them out nearly tore apart the Eurozone. Italy is the world's 8th largest economy. Europe hasn't got the resources to make this bailout happen, even if the political will did exist.

In the meantime, in the UK, the Bank of England's Governor has hinted that the central bank may push a monetary stimulus policy over the summer, to deal with the Brexit fallout.

The European markets reflected the gloom, with FTSE in London losing 0.84%, the DAX falling 0.69%, and the CAC 40 dropping 0.91%.
In the Asia-Pacific markets, Australia made the headlines. The Reserve Bank of Australia announced its decision to hold interest rates steady at their record low of 1.75%. The Bank's board cited the ongoing market volatility as well as the Parliamentary issues after the indecisive Aussie Federal elections. Economic data releases from Down Under were not bad, showing a 1% rise in exports and 0.2% gain in retail sales for the month of May.

In the stock markets, Tokyo reflected the stronger yen with a 0.66% drop in the Nikkei 225. The CSI 300 in Shanghai gained 0.05%, but the Hang Seng fell 0.71%. Australia's Sj&P ASX lost 1.02%.

Looking ahead, watch the oil markets this week. Today will see the API crude and refined product stockpile estimates, and tomorrow will bring the official US Department of Energy estimates for the same. The numbers have a direct bearing on the supply situation in global oil markets, and so on the price of oil.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 6, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_6_2016
video.description: Brexit fears are rising as evidence shows that British and European economies are facing rough times. Anxiety pushed global markets and sterling down overnight.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, Japanese yen, financial markets, oil markets, risk assets

content-body.text: Brexit fears are rising again as evidence accumulates that the British and European economies are facing rough times ahead. Investor anxiety propelled global equity markets and the pound sterling down overnight, while gold rose sharply on haven trading.

Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, admitted yesterday that while the BoE will act as needed to maintain the currency, the bank's actions will not completely offset the volatility that has roiled markets since the Brexit vote. His statements set off a wave of selling that pushed the pound down to 1985 levels. Sterling lost nearly 2.5%, bringing the GBP/USD pair down to 1.2920.

The US dollar and the Japanese yen, on the other hand, both benefited as investors pulled out of risk assets and looked for safe havens. The dollar rose against all of its major peers except the yen, while the USD/JPY pair dropped to 100.95. It's a fresh two-year high for the yen, which last saw this level for six months in the first half of 2014.

In other currency pairs, the EUR/USD is down to 1.1060, and some analysts see the pair reaching 1.05 by year's end. The USD/CHF is stronger at 0.9781, and the USD/CAD rose to 1.3020. The Aussie saw pressure after the RBS decision to hold rates steady, and the AUD/USD has dipped to 0.7440.

The US dollar index, a broad measure of the currency's strength, has risen modestly overnight, to stand at 96.197.

Most commodities fell, on risk aversion, but the traditional safe havens of gold and silver both saw significant price increases. Silver gained more than 2%, to break back above the $20 mark, and the metal now trades at $20.33 per ounce. Gold's gain was smaller, but it is still selling for $1,366.69. This is the highest level for gold in 33 months.

A combination of factors pushed oil prices down overnight. Indications from the OPEC countries showed that the cartel's June production hit a record high, while reports from the US indicated that the major storage hub in Cushing, Oklahoma – already filled to historically high levels – experienced an unexpected build in stocks last week.

Both items renewed fears of the global supply glut in the oil markets. Those fears are justified; oil supplies remain at record high levels, and demand has not been strong enough to cut into them. Additionally, producers are pumping about 1 million barrels per day more than demand requires.

The result is obvious to anyone who took Econ 101 – supply and demand in this case pushes the prices down. Brent crude, the global trading price, is down to $47.91 per barrel today, while the US benchmark, West Texas Intermediate, has fallen to $46.55.

Financial markets are showing weakness across the board today, with a few notable exceptions.

Starting in Europe, the major indexes finished yesterday in the red and are starting today's early trading with more losses. The exception is London's FTSE 100, which is up 0.08% despite the Brexit vote, the general fall in stocks, and the sharp drop in the pound. Most financial analysts and economists expect that the UK will slip into at least a mild recession in the near future, as the Brexit policy is implemented.

Also hurting markets in Europe are the travails of the Italian banks, which have more non-performing loans than they are capable of carrying on the books. Italy has no chance of getting a Greek-style bailout, however, and it is the world's 8th largest economy. We're about to get a close up view of a major bank implosion with no one willing or able to help. Should be interesting.

The prospect is not pleasing to investors. The DAX is down 0.82%, the CAC 40 has fallen 0.93%, and Spain's IBEX 35 is down 1.10%. Italy's MIB lost 1.1% yesterday.

The Asian markets finished today's session with more losses than gains. Tokyo's markets fell, with the Nikkei 225 losing 1.85% and the TOPIX dropping 1.79%. No surprise there, since the stronger yen was bound to hurt Japanese exporters and then their equities. The Hang Seng lost 1.23%, and Australia's Sj&P ASX fell 0.58%. China's CSI 300 index showed a small rise, of 0.29%.

US markets reopened after the July 4th holiday and promptly fell. The Dow Jones lost 0.61%, the Sj&P 500 dipped 0.68%, and the NASDAQ fell 0.82%. A gloomy economic data release did not help the markets any, as factory orders for May fell 1% - worse than the 0.8% expectation – and orders for durable goods dropped 2.3%. Tesla Motors, the electric luxury car makers, showed a share price loss of 1.2%, after reports of "autopilot failures" resulting in fatal accidents. Hmm.

Two big data releases today will come from the US. The Fed will release their last FOMC meeting minutes, which will be carefully parsed, as usual, for hints on future rate policy. Also, the Department of Energy will release its weekly report on crude oil stockpiles, and is expected to show a 2.5 million barrel draw in US supplies. On Friday we'll see the important Non-Farm Payroll report from the US Department of Labor.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 7, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_7_2016
video.description: Stock markets posted mixed results yesterday. The US dollar weakened slightly, except against the pound, and the yen remains at high levels.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, oil stockpile, European markets, US dollar

content-body.text: US stock markets posted gains yesterday, while the European markets fell and the Asian markets showed mixed results. The US dollar weakened slightly, except against the pound, and the yen remains at high levels. Brexit concerns are sinking in now in investors' minds, increasing fears of a global tip to recession and boosting haven assets.

The dollar slipped back slightly in currency trading, with the EUR/USD edging up as high as $1.1100 before steadying at $1.1094. The Aussie is also higher, at 0.7518, the USD/CHF has edged down to 0.9749, and the USD/CAD retreated to 1.2956. The US dollar index, the broader measure of the dollar against a trade-weighted basket of major currencies, slipped 0.2% to 96.013.

The pound and the yen made bigger news. The pound dipped to another 31-year low, actually getting below the $1.28 level before bumping back up to its current $1.2982. Sterling's drop comes as investors are dropping the currency on fears that Britain, and then Europe, could tip into recession during the upcoming implantation of the Brexit. The British currency has taken the harder hit, falling 15% since the referendum.

While the dollar gained strength on the weakness the pound and Euro, the yen saw stronger gains. The Japanese currency has appreciated some 5% against the dollar, getting a boost from its role as a safe haven asset. The yen's reputation comes from Japan's institutional stability, but ironically its gains tend to undermine its haven asset role by depressing Japanese exports and then consequently hurting Japanese equities. Right now, the USD/JPY is trading at 100.76, and trending downwards. The yen has not been this strong since November of 2013 – 31 months ago.

It's important to note that the yen has been appreciating for the last six months. For the first half of this year, global economies have been showing signs of slowing, and investors have been seeking haven assets. The yen, as well as gold, has strengthened on that sentiment, and Japanese policy makers are having difficulty countering it.

Reports showed that the overall US crude oil stockpile drew down for the seventh week in a row, giving some support to oil prices in the face of downward price pressures. The inventory draws as the summer driving season in the US reaches its height, increasing demand for petroleum products. The drawdown report came from the trade group American Petroleum Institute, and showed a reduction of 6.7 million barrels.

The downward pressures on oil prices haven't relented, however. Stockpiles of refined products remain high, and slowing economic growth with its tempered demand for oil has weighed on traders. In light of this, Brent crude is selling for $48.89 per barrel. West Texas Intermediate is going for $47.57.

Precious metals are up, gaining on their reputation as haven assets while investors are pulling out of riskier instruments such as oil and equities. Gold rose slightly overnight and now stands at $1,366.55 per ounce. Silver and platinum both gained yesterday but eased slightly as trading began today. Silver is selling for $20.16 per ounce and platinum for $1,086.34.

European markets retreated yesterday, but are showing small rebound gains in early trading today. Bank stocks are feeling serious pressure, as the German banking giant Deutsche Bank is scrambling for funds to avoid insolvency, Credit Suisse's share price has hit an all-time low, and the Italian banks are in even worse shape, with 17% of their outstanding loans being non-performing. A full blown banking crisis is taking shape in Europe, and it's only a matter of time before it can no longer be kicked down the road.

Right now, the FTSE in London is up 1.18%, the DAX is up 0.80%, and the CAC 40 is up 1.03%. Yesterday, they lost 1.2%, 1.7%, and 1.9% respectively. It will likely be an interesting day for the European equity markets.

As today's session comes to an end in the Asia-Pacific region, the major indexes are decidedly mixed. Tokyo is down, and no surprise given the yen's appreciation and Japan's sensitivity to exports. The Nikkei 225 lost 0.67% and the TOPIX fell 0.66%. China's CSI 300 rose towards the end of trading, but still finished with a loss of 0.21%. The Hang Seng, however, put up a gain of 1.07%. Australia's Sj&P ASX also gained, 0.59%.

In New York, the US markets opened to losses yesterday but rallied posted gains by session's end. The DJIA gained 0.44%, the Sj&P 500 advanced 0.54%, and the NASDAQ was up by 0.75%. These gains came despite a data release showing that the US trade deficit increased to $41.14 billion in May, well over the expectation for $40 billion. The widening trade deficit can be traced to the dollar's recent gains making US exports more expensive overseas.

Investors had a chance to look over the Fed's June FOMC minutes, and the futures traders lowered the odds of an interest rate hike before December to just 12%. That's down from 44% before the Brexit vote. It may be that they are being generous; a casual glance a calendar should make it obvious that there will be no further rate hike this year; with the election coming up in November, the Fed will not move until the next Administration is sworn in.

Look for the European Central Bank's last governing council meeting minutes, their equivalent to the FOMC minutes from the States. Don't expect any surprises there. The US government will release official crude oil stockpile numbers. More importantly, ADP, the US' largest private payroll processor will release their employment report, which will be carefully watched as it is widely seen as a precursor of the official government report due out tomorrow.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 10, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_10_2016
video.description: Stock markets posted mixed results yesterday. The US dollar weakened slightly, except against the pound, and the yen remains at high levels.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, oil stockpile, European markets, US dollar

content-body.text: Friday's jobs report in the US far exceeded expectations, showing nearly 300,000 jobs created in June. Stocks in the US and Europe soared in response.

The US dollar responded to the jobs report with a series of gains and losses. The greenback appreciated against the Euro, the Canadian dollar, and the Swiss franc, but lost against the yen, the pound, and the Australian dollar.

By the numbers, the EUR/USD stands at 1.1050, the USD/CAD rose to 1.3044, and the USD/CHF is up to 0.9833. The GBP/USD showed a brief respite for the beleaguered pound, rising a third of a percent to 1.2954, and the AUD/USD jumped to 0.7569. The yen posted further gains, bringing the USD/JPY down to 100.54.

The Bloomberg survey projects the US dollar making further gains on the Euro, and recouping against the yen, with the EUR/USD pair hitting 1.08 and the USD/JPY pair reaching 105 by this year's end.

The jobs report had an immediate effect on precious metal prices, sending them down sharply. Gold, silver, and platinum have all recouped their losses, and then some, as investors remain cautious and continue to buy haven assets.

Gold is currently selling for $1,366.33 per ounce, silver for $20.35, and platinum for $1,097.35. All three metals are higher than they were before the release of the jobs report.

Copper, an important industrial metal and a useful proxy for the industrial metals market, continue to slide and is now down to $2.12 per pound.
Oil prices are also falling, with the drops mainly driven by continued worries about supply and demand – global supplies remain high while demand is only moderate, and on a global level daily production is exceeding demand by about 1 million barrels. It's a situation made for low prices.

It's not helped any by the OPEC cartel's deliberate strategy of overproduction in pursuit of market share despite lower prices. Saudi Arabia – the largest producer and exporter in OPEC – initiated the strategy about two years ago, with several objectives in mind. They were looking to push high cost North American shale and tar sand producers out of business; they were looking to increase Asian and North American market share; they were meeting the production challenge posed by Russia; and they hoped that low prices would put pressure on their geopolitical rival in Iran. To a large extent, the Saudis have achieved these goals.

It's an interesting background to an oil market in which crude is once again approaching the $45 mark. Overall, prices this year have paralleled the pattern we saw last year, with an increase in spring, a plateau in June, and drop in July. It remains to be seen in that parallel will hold.
At the end of last week's trading, Brent crude was selling for $46.76 per barrel and WTI was going for $45.41.

The big market news from last Friday, of course, was the official jobs report – the NFP – from the US Department of Labor. The report was widely anticipated, as last month's jobs numbers were nothing less than atrocious.

The June numbers were better, far better. At 287,000 jobs created, the report exceeded expectations by more than 100,000 and showed the highest monthly increase since last October.

One point of caution in lauding the numbers: May's already bad result was revised further downwards, to just 11,000, and the three month moving average, even with the excellent June print, is only 147,000, actually lower than this time last year.

The unemployment rate edged up slightly, as did the labor force participation rate. A close look at the demographics of the jobs gains shows that 90% of all the new jobs went to workers over age 55. This may be a sign that aging workers are deferring retirement, or that employers are seeking experience first. In either case, it's a hard blow to younger workers.

Markets liked the news, however, and the overall impression of a growing US jobs market. The Dow gained 1.40%, the S&P 500 picked up 1.53%, and the NASDAQ advanced 1.64%.

In Europe, there was also a positive reaction, with the FTSE 100 showing a pickup of 0.87%, the DAX gaining 2.24%, and the CAC 40 showing a rise of 1.77%.
Asian markets had closed before the release, and showed losses. The Japanese markets were especially hard hit, as the stronger yen weighed on them. The Nikkei 225 lost 1.11% and the TOPIX fell 1.32%. The Hang Seng lost 0.69% and the CSI 300 in Shanghai dropped 0.55%. Australia's S&P ASX managed to squeak out a gain of 0.05%.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 11, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_11_2016
video.description: The dollar gained strength overnight, as did the Tokyo stock markets. Oil prices continue to retreat, and gold remains near recent high levels.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US markets, oil markets, British pound

content-body.text: The dollar gained strength overnight, as did the Tokyo stock markets. Oil prices continue to retreat on global supply fears, and gold remains near recent high levels, although it has dipped slightly on profit taking.

In the forex markets, the US dollar showed gains overnight, and consolidated its strength. The dollar index, the broad measure of the greenback against a basket of six major currencies, rose a quarter percent to stand at 96.654.

Drops in oil prices, and commodities generally, took a toll on commodity-linked currencies, and the New Zealand and Australian dollars are both down today. The NZD/USD retreated from recent 14-month highs to trade at 0.7244 and the AUD/USD fell to 0.7539.

The Japanese yen, which has posted strong gains recently on safe haven trading during market uncertainty, also slipped, losing 1.4% against the dollar in the wake of Japan's parliamentary election. PM Abe's win there raises the chance that Japan may see additional stimulus measures. The USD/JPY is currently trading at 101.95. The yen also fell against the Euro, bringing the EUR/JPY to 112.42.

The British pound has taken a heavy beating in the aftermath of the UK's vote to leave the European Union, losing nearly 10% against the dollar since the June 23 referendum.
