Sterling appeared to have stabilized a bit recently, however, and the currency actually edged up overnight. Those gains are gone now, and the GBP/USD has slipped again to 1.2884. It looks like volatility and losses are the name of the game for the pound, at least in the medium term, as the UK and the EU start to work out the terms of the Brexit and new terms for mutual trade relations.

Oil prices fell again yesterday, pushing WTI below $45 and Brent down to $46 as increases in the US rig count indicate that the North American shale drillers have adapted to today's low price regime. Poor economic data from Asia also weighed on the demand side.

From Saudi Arabia, the energy minister gave a statement saying that the oil market is finally balancing supply and demand and that prices are stabilizing. It's important to note that while US production has fallen in recent months, OPEC countries have more than picked up that slack.

Right now in the oil markets, Brent crude is selling for $46.02 per barrel and WTI, the US benchmark, is going for $44.60.
Gold is inching down in trading, but remains just below a 28-month high it reached last week. The metal is facing a bit of uncertainty as to the US Federal Reserve's future rate policy, especially in light of the awful May jobs report and the strong June report. The UK's EU vote and the consequent market turmoil tended to boost gold, as does expectations that there will be additional monetary stimulus in the EU and UK.

Overall, gold remains a bullish prospect, having gained nearly 30% year-to-date. The metal is now selling for $1,359.45 per ounce.
Silver and platinum have also retreated from recent peaks but remain at high levels. Silver is selling for $20.36 per ounce and platinum for $1,095.27. All three precious metals have gained on haven trading as investors seek safe assets and a hedge against inflation.

Asian markets posted strong gains in today's session, despite some downbeat economic data releases.

In Japan, a drop in machinery orders bodes ill for the manufacturing sector, which pushed down the yen. Tokyo's stock markets responded to the weaker currency with a gain of nearly 4%. The Nikkei 225 picked up 3.98% and the TOPIX gained 3.79%. The strong win for PM Abe's party in the parliament, and the possibility that he may now be able to push through his economic stimulus policies, also helped to boost the stock markets.

In China, a consumer inflation measure came in lower than the government's target rate, which may indicate weak demand for goods and services. The markets rose, however, with the CSI 300 in Shanghai gaining 0.35% and the Hang Seng in Hong Kong rising 1.54%. Australia's S&P ASX gained 2.04%.

European markets are taking a "wait and see" attitude to the Bank of England, which may pursue a monetary easing policy for economic stimulus purposes. Such a policy would also depress the pound. Right now, the FTSE 100 is up in early trading, with a gain of 0.49%. The DAX is up 1.27%, and the CAC 40 has gained 1.08%.

US markets are not open yet, but got a boost on Friday from the strong June jobs report. The report showed a gain of 287,000 jobs created for the month, but it also revised the May numbers down to an anemic 11,000. Taken together, the May and June reports show that the economy was performing at its average rate for the last 6 months, and the wide divergence between the reports is likely a statistical fluke.

Market traders remain unconvinced that the Federal Reserve will hike rates again this year, despite the jobs situation, and have priced in only a 24% chance of a rate hike by December. A glance at the US election calendar, however, should convince anyone that 24% is far too high – Janet Yellen is not likely to take any move that could unbalance the November elections. Don't expect a rate hike this year.

In the meantime, the Dow finished Friday up 1.40%, the S&P 500 finished up 1.53%, and the NASDAQ gained 1.64%.

Looking ahead, Thursday this week will bring us a rate decision and monetary policy minute from the Bank of England. With all of the turmoil in the UK financial world recently, this may provide some welcome carity. From the US, we'll see retail sales and inflation data. Also, this week marks the start of the second financial quarter earnings reporting season in the States.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 12, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_12_2016
video.description: Equity markets rose across the board, with Wall Street seeing record high levels. The Euro and pound rose on expectations of political stability in Europe.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, European markets, monetary stimulus, safe haven

content-body.text: Equity markets rose across the board, with Wall Street seeing record high levels. The Euro and pound rose on expectations of political stability in Europe.

Currency markets showed volatility overnight, as several factors pulled the majors in different directions. Compared to the US dollar, the yen, the Canadian dollar, and Swiss franc all dipped, while the Euro, pound, and Aussie dollar all rose.

Looking at the numbers, the USD/JPY rose to 103.03, the USD/CAD is up to 1.3097, and the USD/CHF stands at 0.9824. The EUR/USD moved to 1.1085, the GBP/USD is at 1.3083, and the AUD/USD is trading at 0.7587.

The broader dollar measure, the US dollar index, fell slightly, and now stands at 96.354. Despite the dollar's recent slip, the index shows that it remains fairly strong.

Gold, everyone's favorite safe haven hedging asset, dipped slightly overnight and is now selling at $1,355.84 per ounce. Gold is widely used by investors to protect their funds during market volatility, as it tends to hold value even though it does not bear interest. Its overnight dip may reflect improving market sentiment after Britain's ruling Tories chose Home Secretary Theresa May to succeed David Cameron in the premiership and Japanese PM Abe's party victory in parliamentary elections.

Platinum also dipped, falling to $1,094.80 per ounce, while silver held its gains better and advanced 0.74% to $20.46.

In the oil markets, crude rose overnight, but remains below last week's highs. Oil prices are under pressure from continuing (!) concerns over the long-term global oversupply, but found some support in expectations of another stockpile drawdown to be reported in the weekly storage data from the US.

Production data has also impacted oil prices, as US output has fallen for 23 of the last 24 weeks and now stands at its lowest level in the last year. Normally, a fall in output of that magnitude would be reflected in higher prices, but the OPEC nations have more than made up for the drop.

In terms of price, we see global benchmark Brent crude selling for $46.38 per barrel and West Texas Intermediate, the US benchmark, going for $44.84.

Equities are having a good time overall, with the Asian markets hitting a two-month high point today after Wall Street had record closes yesterday. Sometimes a rising tide will lift every boat.

The combination of the upbeat US jobs report and expectations for further monetary stimulus efforts in Britain, the EU, and Japan helped fuel the Asian markets. In Tokyo, the weaker yen also helped, and the Nikkei 225 rose 2.46%. The TOPIX also rose, showing a gain of 2.38%. Investors are more sanguine of Japanese markets now that PM Abe has a clearer path toward implementing his 10 trillion yen stimulus package.

In China, the CSI 300 index rose 1.46% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng gained 0.94%. Australia's S&P ASX joined in the general gains, and posted an increase of 0.30%.
European markets ended well yesterday, after the British Tories chose Theresa May, currently the Home Secretary, to the Conservative Party leadership. Prime Minister David Cameron is expected to step down in coming days, at which point the Queen will formally ask May, the new majority leader in the Commons, to form a government. May is widely expected to maintain the UK's cordial trade relations with the EU as she navigates the complicated procedure for pulling Britain out of the single market.

Both the pound and the Euro rose on news of her planned succession. It's a rare instance of most parties being pleased by a result – "Remain" supporters know that she is in favor of close ties with the EU, while "Leave" supporters know that she'll invoke the exit clauses of the Maastrict Treaty.

Markets reflected the happy feelings. In London, the FTSE closed 1.40% higher, the DAX gained 2.12%, and the CAC 40 advanced 1.76%.
In the US, Wall Street saw some record closing. The S&P 500 set an intraday record high during the session, and closed with a gain of 0.34%. The Dow gained 0.44%, and the NASDAQ picked up 0.64%.

Market watchers are feeling sanguine after the strong June jobs report, and are pricing in increased odds – at 30% – of a Fed rate hike by December this year. Still, with the US election coming up, most futures traders doubt that the Fed will move before next January's inauguration of the next President.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 13, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_13_2016
video.description: Gold is edging back up, as is the US dollar. The pound is gaining on news of political stability in the UK. US and Asian markets are up today.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, Brexit, gold, pound sterling

content-body.text: Gold is edging back up, as is the US dollar. The pound is gaining on news of political stability in the UK. US and Asian markets are up, but the European markets are mixed in early trading today.

The pound rose overnight, boosted by the news that Home Secretary Theresa May will succeed David Cameron to the Tories leadership and the PM position. While May has stated that she will invoke Britain's right to leave the EU ("Brexit means Brexit."), she is expected to pursue a cautious course.

Sterling gained as much as 0.1% on that sentiment, reaching as high as $1.3270 before the GBP/USD pair dipped back to 1.3231. Just one week ago, the pound was at a 31-year low of $1.2798.

The pound also gained on the Euro, as the EUR/GBP reached 0.8343.

The yen fell 4% since reaching a two-year high earlier this week. The dollar gained on positive sentiment towards the US economy and the slightly higher chance that the Federal Reserve will pursue further monetary tightening in the near future. The USD/JPY currently trades at 104.30.

The dollar is also up slightly on the Euro, with the EUR/USD at 1.1056, and the Canadian dollar, with the USD/CAD advancing to 1.3058.

Oil prices are edging down again, after Brent tested the $48.50 level yesterday. Crude was just above $50 earlier this month, but is facing significant pressure from supply and demand issues – specifically, the global supply glut that just won't go away is crossing demand that just won't increase as much as expected.

The supply side issues are more immediate. The American Petroleum Institute's estimate that US stockpiles expanded by 2.2 million barrels last week hasn't helped prices any, nor has the International Energy Agency's admission that oversupply is pushing down prices and that May inventories, worldwide, increased by more than 13 million barrels to a record high of 3.074 billion. The IEA expects inventories to continue rising in June, including oil stored on tankers at sea.

Price-wise, all of this has Brent at $47.72 per barrel, while the US benchmark WTI is selling for $46.20.

Oil is generally considered a risk asset. Gold, on the other hand, is used as a safe haven by investors when riskier assets are showing too much volatility. Gold tends to advance when other markets go haywire, and to drop on news of stability.

Gold took such a hit yesterday, falling to two-week lows on the news about Theresa May's planned succession to 10 Downing Street. Gold fell as low as $1,330 before ticking back up to $1,340.90, for a recoup of about half the total loss. The yellow metal is still up about 27% for the year to date.

Silver has also done well, and is selling for $20.43 per ounce. Silver has important industrial uses that gold lacks, so it is instructive to compare it with copper. Copper has also gained, reaching $2.24 per pound, for a 4% gain this week.

Stock markets worldwide have rallied this week, and pushed back to the levels they held before the Brexit referendum sparked market turmoil. That rally is showing signs of a slowdown. In their most recent sessions, both the American and Asian indexes, while they closed with daily gains, showed the same pattern of starting high and falling during the trading day. European stocks are opening to mixed results and volatility in today's session.

In the US, part of the pushback comes from the Federal Reserve, whose members have been hinting that despite the strong June jobs report the Fed will not likely rush to raise rates. The hints, while they had a market impact, were not exactly unanticipated; traders put the likelihood of a rate hike this year at less than 50%. Many analysts, including this writer, believe that the US election cycle effectively precludes any rate hike before February of next year.

Taking a look at the market numbers, the Dow Jones gained 0.66% yesterday, while the S&P 500 and NASDAQ both gained 0.70%. In Asia, Japan's Nikkei 225 was up by 0.84% in today's trading, the Hang Seng had gained 0.46%, and the CSI 300 in Shanghai was up 0.30%. Australia's S&P ASX gained 0.66%.

The UK decision to leave the EU fed uncertainty in the markets, but with the selection of Home Secretary Theresa May to succeed to the Premiership, things seem to be calming down in Britain. May has supported the Remain camp, but is on record saying, after the vote, that "Brexit means Brexit." She is expected to take a slow and cautious course while invoking Article 50 of the EU treaty.

In the meantime, European investors are wary today, and markets are volatile. The FTSE 100 in London has been up and down; it is currently up 0.07%. The DAX has fallen 0.08%, and the CAC 40 is up 0.19%.

Market traders will be watching May's selection for Chancellor of the Exchequer, the British finance minister, for clues as to how she will trigger the mechanics of the Brexit.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 14, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_14_2016
video.description: Stocks rallied in recent days, but that may be ending as traders look to lock in profits. The US dollar is retreating while the pound sterling is rising.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, us dollar, pound, stock rally, oil prices

content-body.text: Stocks rallied in recent days, but that may be ending as traders look to lock in profits. The US dollar is retreating in the currency markets while the pound sterling is rising. A general increase in risk appetite is putting pressure on haven assets, pushing down the yen and precious metals.

The US dollar has been easing in currency trading, losing ground to all of the majors except the yen. The dollar index, a broad comparison of the greenback to a basket of six currencies, is down only slightly at 96.209.

Looking at specific pairs, we see the EUR/USD at 1.1115 and the GBP/USD at up to 1.3250. This strength for the pound, as the EUR/GBP has slipped to 0.8388. The USD/CHF edged back to 0.9837, and the USD/CAD is down at 1.2936.

The US dollar did gain against the Japanese yen, bringing the USD/JPY back up to 105.41.

Oil prices dipped yesterday, and while they are edging up today they remain more than one dollar – about 2 percent – below Tuesday's high point. Any gains are likely to be modest, as fears mount that the oversupply issues are simply not going away.

Reports from the US showed that American stockpiles declined less than expected last week, while storage inventories of gasoline and other refined products increased by the most since January. It's an ominous sign of weak demand in the busy summer driving season.

In another sign of the ongoing supply glut, nine major oil tankers are simply sitting in the North Sea, keeping some 9 million barrels of crude in "floating storage." This is up 2 million barrels from May, and is only a drop in the 95 million barrel bucket of crude oil stored on tankers at sea worldwide. It's the highest volume stored this way since the 2009 recession.

Perhaps a bigger problem than just the volume of crude oil at sea is that most of the floating cargoes are not on contract – they haven't got buyers yet. With demand softening in Europe and China, that situation is not likely to change.

What all of this means for traders is the likelihood of lower prices for at least the near future, despite today's slight uptick. Brent crude is currently selling for $46.80 per barrel, and in the US West Texas Intermediate is priced at $45.37.

Elsewhere in commodity markets, precious metals are edging down as investors find a renewed appetite for risk. The move is helping stocks, but gold is turning back down, dipping to $1,333.80 per ounce. Silver and platinum are also down, to $20.36 and $1,089.65 respectively. Industrial copper is doing better, staying stable near $2.25 per pound.

On Wednesday, Theresa May received her appointment as Prime Minister of the UK. The move has helped to calm investor fears of political chaos, as May has pledged to respect the result of the Brexit referendum and execute it in a manner both cautious and conciliatory. In economic news from the UK, the Bank of England is expected to initiate another rate cut (down to 0.25%) in its policy statement today. Investors will also watch BoE's statement for hints as to any future quantitative easing policy.

The upshot of this was both a stock rally this week and increased volatility in the markets as the rally spurred risk appetite among traders. Market rallies slowing down now, and some indexes are showing mixed results, but without great nervousness on the part of market traders.

In Europe, the FTSE 100 ended down 0.15% yesterday, as the DAX lost 0.33%, and the CAC 40 gained 0.09%.

Turning to Asia, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 is up 0.95% and the TOPIX is up 0.84%. Australia's S&P ASX gained 0.43%. In China, the Hang Seng index increased 0.97% while Shanghai's CSI 300 index posted a loss of 0.32%. Asia watchers will be keeping a close eye on Bank of Japan's policy meeting this month, to see if they initiate further monetary stimulus.

In the US, market watchers are expecting less and less form the Federal Reserve. The central bank's stated policy of rate hikes and monetary tightening appears to be on hold – a sentiment that has helped hold the dollar down recently – and Fed officials' public statements have been decidedly dovish on the hike policy.

With interest rate increases less likely, investors are looking to stocks for a better return, a move which feeding into the general increase in risk appetite we've seen recently. The Dow Jones showed a modest increase of 0.13% yesterday, while the S&P 500 was nearly flat with a gain of just 0.01%. The NASDAQ slipped slightly, by 0.34%. Trading has been more volatile in New York recently.
Watch for Bank of England's policy statement today, as well as the regular weekly initial jobless claims from the States.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 17, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_17_2016
video.description: The dollar and the yen are stronger as we head into a new week, while prices for oil and gold remain soft.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, stock markets, dollar

content-body.text: The dollar and the yen are stronger as we head into a new week, while prices for oil and gold remain soft. Equity markets weakened on Friday, but remain near record high levels.

The dollar and the yen both gained at the end of last week and over weekend trading. The chaos in Turkey, with implications for both Europe and the Middle East, boosted appetites for haven assets, which benefitted both currencies.

As we look toward the new week, we find the USD/JPY trading at 104.88. The EUR/USD and the GBP/USD both slipped, to 1.1035 and 1.3192 respectively. This slip puts the Euro basically flat for the week, ending where it began.

The US dollar index, the big-picture measure of the dollar against a trade-weighted basket of six peer currencies, added half a point and stands at 96.580, its highest level this month.

Oil prices remain soft, but are up since Friday on the news from Turkey. Brent crude edged back up to $47.61 per barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate remained low at $45.95. Monday should be an interesting day in the oil markets.

Precious metals were down on Friday morning, but rose sharply after the news from Turkey broke. Gold and silver both finished with gains, while platinum rose but not enough to cancel a daily loss.

Gold is now selling for $1,337.45 per ounce, silver for $20.30, and platinum for $1,091.90. Copper, a purely industrial metals, dipped to $2.23 per pound.

US stock markets are holding near record high levels, as the major indexes have rebounded strongly from their post-Brexit vote lows. They got a boost from recent June economic data, including a stronger than expected jobs report, good retail sales numbers, and unexpectedly strong industrial production numbers.

Not only did the upbeat data give a boost to stocks in New York, they also have traders thinking seriously again about the chance that the Federal Reserve will institute an additional interest rate hike before the end of this year. According to futures markets, the odds of such a hike have increased to 38%. Other analysts, however, believe that 38% is too sanguine, as the US election is coming up. The electoral cycle effectively precludes any Fed action before November, and simple inertial makes it unlikely that there will be any further monetary policy changes – easing or tightening – before the next Presidential Administration is sworn in at the end of January.

In the meantime, the US stock markets will face another test this coming week with the regular release of Q2 company earnings reports. Investors will be watching closely for evidence of the Brexit vote's impact on the bottom line.

In the UK, the Bank of England kept key rates steady last week at 0.5%, taking a cautious path in the wake of the Brexit vote. The BoE did hind that it could act at its next meeting in August – a string of conditional tense verbiage there – but will decide when the data from the next Quarterly Inflation Report become available.

With the background there, a look at market numbers shows mixed results last Friday. In the State, the Dow Jones finished up 0.05%, while the S&P 500 and NASDAQ both eased back by 0.09%. London's FTSE 100 added 0.22% (traders liked the BoE stance!), Germany's DAX lost 0.01%, and in France the CAC 40 lost 0.30%, unsurprising, really, after the tragedy in Nice. Japanese markets finished up, with the Nikkei 225 adding 0.68% and the TOPIX gaining 0.45%. China's markets were mixed: the CSI 300 in Shanghai fell 0.01% but the Hang Seng in Hong Kong picked up 0.46%.

Investors will be watching Thursday when the European Central Bank meets, to see Draghi and Company increase their monetary stimulus policy in light of the negative outlook after the Brexit vote.

In addition, this week the Eurozone will issue data on business activity and German business confidence, the first such reports since the Brexit vote.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 18, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_18_2016
video.description: Oil prices are primed to decline, as supply and demand issues come to the forefront of the market. Gold and the yen both slipped on lower haven demand.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, dollar, oil prices, gold, brexit

content-body.text: Oil prices are primed to decline, as supply and demand issues come to the forefront of the market. Gold and the yen both slipped on lower haven demand. Stock traders are looking at volatility in the markets.

With the failure of the coup attempt in Turkey, the country's lira currency rebounded in the markets, gaining almost 3% to trade at 2.9318 to the US dollar. The Japanese yen retreated slightly as safe haven demand dissipated with improving market sentiment, and the USD/JPY pair rose to 105.58.

That was one of two bright spots for the dollar, the other being the USD/CHF pair, which rose slightly to 0.9835. The dollar fell against the other majors; the EUR/USD improved to 1.1052, the GBP/USD advanced to 1.3255, and the AUD/USD increased to 0.7595.

The US dollar index, a broad measure of the greenback compared to a basket of peer currencies, fell back almost 1% and now stands at 96.585. The index is trending upwards.

Looking at some emerging market currencies, we see the South African rand climbing in the markets, pushing the USD/ZAR to 14.3408. Mexico's peso also firmed, as the USD/MXN dipped to 18.4728.

Gold has dipped to a two-week low price, as Turkey returns to stability and investors see less need for safe-haven asset trading. Gold got a heavy boost from the Brexit referendum in the UK, rising from $1,256 reaching a peak price of $1,366 on July 8.

Despite recent losses, which have brought the metal down to a price of $1,329.03 per ounce, gold is up about 25% for the year to date. It is receiving ongoing support from low expectation that the US Federal Reserve will hike interest rates again this year and from increasing expectations that central banks in the UK, EU, and Japan will embark on another round of monetary easing. Both factors increase the appeal of gold as a store of value.

Silver, which also made big gains after the Brexit vote, has also slipped in recent days. It is now selling for $19.97 per ounce and trending downwards.

Oil markets have seen a number of developments recently. Oil prices gained slightly after news of the Turkish army's coup attempt, but only slightly. Turkey is not a major oil producer; rather, it is a conduit for other Middle Eastern countries' energy, and the quick defeat of the coup, combined with the Turkish government's need for an income stream, promised stability and reliability in the flow of oil and oil products through Turkey.

The bigger factors affecting crude oil prices are the usual ones: supply and demand. Gasoline inventories in the US are reaching max storage capacity, and recently five tankers full of fuel have been turned away from New York harbor; they could not unload because there was nowhere to put the gasoline. It's the summer driving season in the US, normally the time of peak demand for gasoline, but so far that demand has been weak and has not dented the oversupply.

The oversupply of gasoline will impact demand for crude oil, as refiners will have less need for crude to work with, especially with US crude oil stocks also near record levels. The oversupply has industry analysts predicting that crude oil prices could dip back to $40 per barrel.

Additional bad news for oil bulls comes from the supply side. There were a number of supply disruption this spring and early summer, but those events are clearing up. The wildfires that temporarily shut down the Alberta oil sands are out, and Canada's production is returning to normal. Nigeria has resumed output after coming to an agreement with militants in the Niger Delta, and Libya has said that the state oil company may be able to increase exports later this month. Finally, OPEC's core Gulf nations are producing oil at record levels. With storage facilities full, and global supply exceeding demand, it is not an environment that encourages a long-term rise in prices.

With that as the background, we see that Brent crude, the global trading benchmark, is at $47.69, while the US benchmark, WTI, is selling for $45.98 per barrel.

In global stock news today, Tokyo's markets are closed for a national holiday in Japan. They'll be reopening tomorrow. Other Asia-Pacific markets are mixed. Hong Kong's Hang Seng is up slightly, 0.56%, while Shanghai's CSI 300 is down 0.44%. Australia's S&P ASX has gained 0.53%.

The European markets opened up to gains today, but have slipped in what promises to be a volatile session. The FTSE 100 is up 0.33%, the DAX slipped into the red earlier, but is now up 0.07%, and the CAC 40 has lost 0.07% despite a strong opening.

In the US, markets are not open as of this writing, but futures traders expect a good session today. The optimism comes after a set of upbeat economic news at the end of last week. Reports showed both retail sales and industrial production increasing more than expected. On a possible gray note, banks Wells Fargo and Citigroup both reported lower Q2 revenues, and lost share value in response. The second quarter revenue reports will bear watching this week.
The biggest news will be Thursday's meeting of the European Central Bank's policy committee. Investors will be watching for hints toward stimulus policy in the wake of the Brexit vote.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 20, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_20_2016
video.description: Stocks had a bad day yesterday, as most global indexes retreated on profit taking. Commodity prices dropped. The US dollar rose in the currency markets.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, dollar, stocks, currency markets, price of gold

content-body.text: Stocks had a bad day yesterday, as most global indexes retreated on profit taking. Commodity prices also dropped. The US dollar rose in the currency markets.

The US dollar is moving up across the board, gaining on all of its major peers and pushing the dollar index up to 97.317, its highest level since March.

Against the Japanese yen, which in recent days has been strengthening, the dollar gained 0.29% and the USD/JPY advanced to 106.43. The USD/CAD rose to 1.3062 and the USD/CHF is up to 0.9878.

The Euro and pound both slipped to the dollar, with the EUR/USD dipping to 1.0994 and the GBP/USD falling back to 1.3100. The dip in the pound/dollar pair, at 0.08%, as the smallest shift in the major dollar pairs; the dollar's gains on the currencies were in the range of one third percent.

Oil prices are down, despite large draws on crude stockpiles. Gasoline inventories in the US have increased due to weak demand in the summer driving season, and the number of active drilling rigs in the US has increased for six of the last seven weeks. The combination of lower than expected demand, increases in gasoline stockpiles, and increased drilling activity has renewed oil traders' worries over the global supply situation. Daily oil production is already exceeding demand by upwards of 1 million barrels per day, and crude storage facilities around the world are at or near maximum capacities.

With that background, it's easy to understand why West Texas Intermediate, the US trading benchmark, has dropped below $45 to sell for $44.65 per barrel. Brent crude, the global trading price, is down to $46.82.

Precious metals are also trading down, partly on profit taking and partly on increased appeal of stocks as indexes hit record high levels. Gold is currently selling for $1,326.69 per ounce, silver for $19.84, and platinum for $1,085.00.

Nevertheless, despite the recent drops, metals are finding support in current events: persistently low expectations for another interest rate hike by the US Federal Reserve; expectations that the Bank of Japan and the ECB will pursue additional monetary easing; the International Monetary Fund's reduced forecasts for global economic growth. Gloomy news

Recent upbeat economic data releases from the States has futures traders putting a 50/50 chances on a Federal Reserve rate hike by December. Some analysts, however, see that as too high given the US election cycle with its November polling day andJanuary inauguration of the next Administration. A move – in any direction – is more likely in February than December.

In Asia, Japan's Nikkei is down for the first time in a week, mainly as investors took profits from last week's rally. Oddly enough, the drop in Japanese stocks coincides with a weakening of the yen, a reversal of the usual pattern.

Watch closely for the Bank of Japan's policy meeting at the end of this month, as they are expected to announce further monetary easing and stimulus policies.

Overall, there is caution in the markets today, as investors are somewhat wary since the IMF cut its forecast for global growth in 2016. Even so, risk appetite has returned since the Brexit vote and stocks are generally showing it – the New York markets recently touched on record high levels.

In Europe, the markets are getting off to a good start today. London's FTSE 100 is up 0.46%, the DAX as risen 1.16%, and the CAC 40 is up 1.17%.

The Asian markets mostly declined in today's session. The Nikkei 225 lost 0.25%, the TOPIX slipped 0.05%, and Shanghai's CSI 300 was down 0.33%. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong was up 0.97%, and Australia's S&P ASX gained 0.69%.

On Wall Street, the main indexes are still down from yesterday. The NASDAQ lost 0.38% and the S&P 500 fell by 0.14%. The Dow Jones did post a modest gain, of 0.14%.

Looking at some particular stocks: Netflix is down after reporting fewer subscribers, Philip Morris – the tobacco company – reported a weak Q2 result and lost share value, and Johnson & Johnson advanced on strong earnings and a good profit forecast.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 21, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_21_2016
video.description: Stocks are high, boosted by positive earnings, and the high equity values are reducing demand for haven assets like the yen and precious metals.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, stocks, gold, dollar

content-body.text: Stocks are high, boosted by positive earnings, and the high equity values are reducing demand for haven assets like the yen and precious metals. Oil prices are edging up from overnight lows.

The currency markets are basically stable right now, without many dramatic shifts. The US dollar has retreated slightly, on the general pullback from safe haven trading. The EUR/USD has edged up to 1.1032, the GBP/USD has advanced to 1.3222, and the USD/CHF has dipped to 0.9850.

The exception was the USD/JPY – the Japanese currency has weakened in recent days and the pair now trades at 107.15 yen to the dollar.

The US dollar index, a broad measure of the dollar's value against a basket of major currencies, stands at 97.004, down slightly from an overnight high of 97.201, but still near a 4-month high level.

The gains in stocks and the dollar are putting downward pressure on precious metal prices. Metals — especially gold, silver, and platinum — are traditionally used as hedges when markets are uncertain or volatile, and the investors' recent moves back toward stocks has reduced demand for havens.

Gold is now selling for $1,317.24 per ounce, down nearly $50 from its July 8 peak but still up more than 25% for the year to date. Silver and platinum are also both down, selling for $19.41 and $1,082.84 respectively.

Copper, a purely industrial metal with wide applications in everything from home construction to consumer electronics to jewelry, has ticked up slightly to $2.26 per pound.
Oil prices are edging up today, mostly on news from the States showing a drawdown of 2.342 million barrels of crude oil in the nation's storage facilities. The same report, however, also showed some ominous factors for oil bulls going forward: a buildup in gasoline stocks of more than 900,000 barrels, and build (within the overall drawdown of stocks) at the Cushing storage facility of almost 190,000 barrels of crude. The Cushing facility is the US' largest oil storage depot, and it is already near its maximum capacity. A storage overflow there will reverberate throughout the North American oil industry.

In the markets, Brent crude is currently selling for $47.54 per barrel. The US benchmark WTI is showing more volatility, and is currently priced at $44.94. The gasoline and Cushing builds are weighing heavily on the US oil price, as is weak demand for the summer driving season. It looks like the oil markets are still being driven by the fundamentals of supply and demand.

The International Monetary Fund lowered its forecast for global growth, cutting the 2016 estimate from 3.2% to 3.1%. The US projection was reduced to 2.2%. The IMF expects that the Brexit will have a limited impact on US economic conditions.

In Japan, markets got a boost as PM Abe, using his recent election victory as leverage, has told his government to put together a list of stimulus measures. According to reports, the government is preparing a 20 trillion yen ($190 billion) package of measures. Direct government spending is projected to be a little less than half of the total package.

Looking at markets, Tokyo saw a predictable rise in stocks, buoyed by the weaker yen and anticipation of the stimulus. The Nikkei 225 gained 0.77%, and the TOPIX added 0.65%. In China, both the Hang Seng and the CSI 300 gained, adding 0.68% and 0.46% respectively. In Australia, the S&P ASX advanced 0.43%.

Europe's markets closed in the green yesterday but are opening mostly lower today. In early trading, London's FTSE 100 is down 0.32%, and the CAC 40 has dropped 0.03%. The DAX is up slightly, by 0.15%. It remains to be seen if the others will turn around before the end of today's session.

As of this writing, the US markets have not yet opened, but Wall Street ended on a positive note yesterday. The Dow gained 0.19%, the S&P 500 picked up 0.43%, and the NASDAQ made larger gains of 1.06%. Futures markets predict a similar performance today.

The European Central Bank will publish its decision monetary policy. Watch this closely, as they are expected to announce stimulus to counter any adverse effects of the Brexit vote. In the US, watch the weekly initial jobless claims.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 24, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_24_2016
video.description: Global stocks were mixed dragged down by the weaker yen and by investors’ concerns over the ECB monetary policy announcement and a disappointing earnings report.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, stocks, gold, dollar

content-body.text: The major events that negatively affected investors’ moods and sent stocks down were the earning reports that had failed to live up to everyone’s expectations and the announcement of the European Central Bank. Professor Mario Draghi said that the European Central Bank had no intention to change its present monetary policy and that it would keep rates at a present or, perhaps, even at a lower level. In the wake of these events, industrial and material companies suffered most in the US. In Europe, it is travel companies who took the biggest plunge on Thursday thanks to the poor reports from EasyJet and Lufthansa. In the Asia-Pacific region, trading was influenced by investors’ worries about the falling yen and the increasing oil prices. The most of indices dropped. Dow Jones industrials and the S&P dipped 0.4%. The NASDAQ retreated 0.3%. The FTSE decreased 0.4%. The SMI shed 0.2%. The CAC sank 0.1%. The DAX was the only index that ended in the positive territory, though its gains were minor: it was only 0.1% up.

Save Dated Brent spot that lost $1.12 to reach $46.05, other commodities appreciated. Gold gained US$12.25 to US$1,082.25. Copper futures rose 0.3% to US$2.26. WTI spot crude was $0.29 higher to reach $44.94
Turning now to currencies, the USD advanced against the GBP and the CAD. It retreated against the JPY, the CHF, and the AUD. It was virtually unchanged against the Euro.

US Market. Having announced that its profit in the last quarter was twice higher that its profit last year, General Motors climbed. After it showed good quarterly results, United Rentals also moved to the positive territory. Thursday was a good day also for EBay. The company boasted high earnings that had suppressed everyone’s expectations and ended higher for the day. Because its earnings growth was lower that has been predicted, Southwest Airlines slid. Delta and United Continental followed suit and sank. Thanks to its disappointing revenue, American Express also drifted lower. Qualcomm, an American multinational semiconductor and telecommunications equipment company, published an unexpectedly good forecast and ended the trading day in the green.

European Market. Lufthansa did poorly on Thursday, dropping because it had diminished its 2016 profit forecast. EasyJet showed bad quarterly revenue and declined as well. It also refused to make predictions concerning its full-year revenue, viewing its future as uncertain due to the recent terrorists attack and the failed attempt to overthrow government in Turkey. Having reported a 7% increase in second-quarter net income, Daimler climbed. French Publicis Group reported 0.9% rise in second quarter revenue and immediately advanced. International Consolidated Airlines Group that owns British Airways slid. Ryanair Holdings ended lower. TUI tumbled along with Thomas Cook. Land Securities Group deplored customers’ weak demand for commercial property and retreated. SABMiller was among few companies that gained on Thursday.

Asia-Pacific Market. Thanks to the falling yen, the Nikkei appreciated 0.8%. Exporters Honda Motor, Hitachi, and Panasonic, therefore, were up. Fast Retailing, Fanuc, and Inpex ended also higher. DeNa rose. In Australia, the S&P/ASX added 0.4%. The All Ordinaries gained as much. The banks ended in the green. Cochlear and CSL rose. Wesfarmers and Woolworths continued raising. Qube Holdings were up. The Shanghai Composite soared 0.4%. The Hang Seng gained 0.5%. The Kospi shed 0.2%. The Sensex slipped 0.7%.

G20 finance ministers and central bankers are meeting in China. Japan, France, Germany, and the US are publishing Flash July PMIs. The UK is giving flash indices. Canada is issuing May retail sales and June consumer price index.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 25, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_25_2016
video.description: Investors are back in the mood for risk, as fears of the Brexit fade. Stocks and the dollar are benefitting, while precious metals are down.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, economic reports, oil market, gold, us dollar

content-body.text: Investors are back in the mood for risk, as fears of the Brexit fade. Stocks and the dollar are benefitting, while precious metals are down. Oil remains volatile, and faces downward price pressure from continuing oversupply.

The US dollar rose against both the Euro and the yen, posting gains against both currencies even as it slipped slightly against the pound and the Aussie. The USD/JPY pair is trading at 106.30, and the EUR/USD at 1.0973.

Sterling gained as much as 0.20% overnight, bringing the GBP/USD to 1.3137. The Canadian dollar and Swiss franc both slipped, as the USD/CAD rose to 1.3159 on the falling price of oil and the USD/CHF edged up to 0.9878 on the general strength of the greenback.

The US dollar index, a broad measure of the currency versus a basket of its major peers, currently stands at 97.393, down from 97.496 on July 22 but still near a four-month high.

The stronger dollar, combined with investors' increased moves toward risk assets, has been weighing on precious metals for nearly two weeks now. At Friday's close, gold finished the week down 0.26%, marking its second consecutive weekly loss. Gold hasn't had two weeks in a row of losses since May.

Despite the recent losses, gold is still above $1,300. It's currently selling for $1,316.35 per ounce, and is up about 24% for the year-to-date. The metal has been boosted by lower expectations for a US Federal Reserve rate hike and by concerns over global economic conditions.

Silver and platinum have been showing similar price patterns, and are also down from recent highs. Silver is trading for $19.57 per ounce, down from its peak above $20 but still up 41% for the year. Platinum is selling for $1,074.75, a gain of 20% year-to-date.

We've been talking in the space for a while about oil market supply and demand issues. This may sound basic, and it is, but it has been the main driver for prices for some time. Simply put, due to overproduction on a tremendous scale there has been a supply glut in the markets for nearly two years now. A supply glut of that magnitude cannot help but push prices down, especially when shaky global economic conditions are keeping demand modest at best.

However, it is the summer driving season in the US, and higher demand, combined with production cuts spurred by lower prices, finally started making a dent in the US crude oil stockpiles. There has been hope among oil traders that the supply draws and lower production together could start pushing prices back up. There may be a brief bump to that effect, but don't bet too much on it. Demand is about to fall.

Oil demand in the US is seasonal, and August/September are typically low-demand months. People are returning from vacations, and driving less. In response, refineries use less oil. And it's important to note that while overall US crude supplies have drawn down somewhat, US gasoline inventories have actually risen, due to weak demand even for the driving season. Expect the refiners to start their maintenance cycle early this year.

So much for the demand side. On the production side, the OPEC countries have been making up for the States' slack with a production increase to 32.9 million barrels per day in June. Russia, the largest non-OPEC supplier, is expected to increase output by nearly 600,000 barrels per day by 2019, and even in the States there are signs that production may increase soon. US drillers have brought an additional 41 rigs online in the last month.

With that background, the slipping oil prices start to make more sense. US crude, the WTI benchmark price, is down to $44.04 per barrel and Brent, the global trading benchmark, has fallen to $45.58 per barrel. Both prices are trending downwards.

Stock markets on Wall Street had a good day Friday. The Dow Jones posted a gain of 0.29%, the S&P 500 added 0.46%, and the NASDAQ advanced 0.52%. Telecom and utility companies helped drive the market gains, with Q2 earnings reports that exceeded the forecasts. Yahoo and Verizon were both among the winners, with share prices advancing on leaked news that Verizon would offer $5 billion to purchase Yahoo. Both companies declined to comment on the news.

Recent upbeat economic reports have also buoyed US markets. The reports showed US economic reliance in the face of global conditions that are flat or flashing red. The June jobs reports, retail sales numbers, and a measure of the service industries have all beaten the forecasts. One positive result of this: investors are more sanguine now that the Federal Reserve will indeed raise interest rates again before the end of the year. The Fed will meet this month, and while traders have only priced in less than a 10% chance of hike now, they put the odds by December at 45%. A glance at the US election cycle calendar should be enough to disabuse anyone of that notion, however; the election is on November 8, and the new Presidential Administration will take office on January 20. Don't expect the Fed to act before February.

In Asia, the main markets were mixed. Tokyo's markets dipped slightly, while Chinese and Australian markets rose. The Nikkei 225 showed a drop of 0.04%, while the TOPIX dipped 0.16%. In Shanghai, the CSI 300 gained 0.18% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng added 0.13%. Australia's S&P ASX added 0.64%.

Nintendo seems to have been the biggest weight on Tokyo's stocks. The game company lost 18% after it announced that his has only a limited stake in the wildly popular Pokemon Go app, and that the financial impact of the app on the company's bottom line would be modest. At the same time, Nintendo is forecast to announce an annual profit of 35 billion yen, up from 16.5 billion last year. It's an interesting definition of a limited impact.

In Europe, the main indexes are opening to gains today. London's FTSE 100 is up by 0.27%, despite some gloomy reports on the UK service and manufacturing sectors. Germany's DAX is up 0.86%, and the French CAC 40 has gained 0.70%.

Coming up this month, the US Federal Reserve meets on Tuesday and Wednesday this week for their regular FOMC meeting to set monetary policy. Don't expect too much from them, but watch for Janet Yellen's statement Wednesday evening.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 26, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_26_2016
video.description: The yen is up and the pound is down, while equity markets are mixed. Oil prices continue to fall on basic issues of supply and demand.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, us dollar, oil markets, stimulus package, bank policy

content-body.text: The yen is up and the pound is down, while equity markets are mixed. Oil prices continue to fall on basic issues of supply and demand. Gold hovers near one-month low levels.

In the forex markets, the US dollar retreated slightly against the Euro, the yen, the Swiss franc, and the Australian dollar, while gaining on the pound and Canadian dollar.
The yen's move was fueled by speculation that Japan's expected stimulus package will be smaller than hoped for – in the range of 6 trillion yen, rather 10 or higher. The prospect of less easing drew investors in to the Japanese currency, pushing the USD/JPY pair down to 104.34, the yen's strongest level in a week.

The pound slipped, for opposite reasons. Bank of England is widely expected to push for stimulus measures, faster, at its August meeting, and the expectations have weighed on sterling. The GBP/USD eased back to 1.3099.

The mixed measures for the dollar breathed some life into the Euro, and the EUR/USD gained to 1.1007. The Canadian dollar slipped along with the price of oil, and the USD/CAD advanced to 1.3229.

Despite the dollar's recent easing, the dollar index remains near its recent peak of 97.467. The current reading is 97.060.

Prices for gold are hovering near a one-month low. The precious metal is pressured by improving sentiment on the Fed's rate hike policy. An increase in dollar asset interest rates is bearish for gold, since the metal pays no interest and does incur a small holding cost. Gold is finding some support, however, in the expectation that Asian and European central banks will increase stimulus measures.

Price-wise, gold is selling for $1,324.45 per ounce. Silver is selling for $19.75, and platinum for $1,088.52. All three metals are up for the year.

Oil markets remain shaky, with both Brent and WTI seeing further losses in today's trading. WTI, the North American trading benchmark, broke below $43 to sell at $42.65 per barrel, while Brent remains soft at $44.40. Continued concern over supply and demand issues is pushing crude down in the markets.

Simply put, supply is rising while demand is weak. WTI prices are facing pressure from a rising count of active rigs in the US, foreboding an increase in supply, at the same time that weak demand has led to an increase in gasoline stockpiles despite the summer peak driving season. Brent prices are pressured by high OPEC production, and the prospect of increased exports from Iraq and Libya. On top of all of this, demand is slowing in Asia as China's economy starts to sputter. Don't look for a reversal in oil's fall any time soon.

In Japan, investors were not impressed by reports that the government plans on a 6 trillion yen stimulus packages to run for the next few years. The markets was looking for at least 10 trillion yen, with some analysts hoping for a 20 trillion yen package. The Bank of Japan will meet later this week, and is widely expected to push interest rates further into negative territory.

The equity indexes in Tokyo dipped on the expectation, with the Nikkei 225 losing 1.43% and the TOPIX falling 1.39%. Chinese and Australian markets remained in the green, as the CSI 300 added 1.20%, the Hang Seng gained 0.62%, and the S&P ASX advanced 0.07%.

In Europe, markets opened broadly lower today, and have only partially regained the ground. The DAX is up, but only 0.12%, the CAC 40 remains down 0.18%, and in London the FTSE 100 is up 0.29%.

Watch the European markets next month; there is wide expectation that the Bank of England will push for rate cuts and other stimulus after its scheduled policy meeting.
In the US, central bank policy clearly wants to diverge from Europe and Asia. The Fed is obviously leaning toward monetary tightening, but is taking a cautious path toward further interest rate hikes. The central bank will hold its meeting today and tomorrow, and will market players will watch the post-meeting statement closely for hints as to the direction and pace of future monetary policy.

On Wall Street, the main indexes all lost ground yesterday. The Dow ended down 0.42%, the S&P 500 lost 0.30%, and the NASDAQ fell 0.05%.

For the week ahead, the big news will be the Federal Reserve and Bank of Japan policy meetings. Look for the Fed's statement by Janet Yellen on July 27 and the BoJ statement on July 29. The banks' policies are widely expected to diverge, perhaps quite sharply.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 27, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_27_2016
video.description: Oil is turning bearish, having lost 15% since its June price peak. Gold is weaker, as investors are pulling out of haven assets and moving toward stocks.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, Federal Reserve, Bank of Japan, price of gold, price of oil

content-body.text: Oil is turning bearish, having lost 15% since its June price peak. Gold is weaker, as investors are pulling out of haven assets and moving back toward stocks. The US dollar remains strong in the currency markets.

The Euro has edged up from overnight lows, but is still soft, with the EUR/USD pair currently trading at just 1.0998.

The dollar gained on the other majors. Sterling slipped, pushing the GBP/USD down to 1.3116, and the AUD/USD dipped to 0.7489. The USD/CHF advanced to 0.9940.
The bigger news came in movements of the yen and Canadian dollar. The yen weakened as the Japanese government announced a larger than expected stimulus package, ahead of the Bank of Japan's policy meeting. The USD/JPY reacted by moving to 105.49. The Canadian dollar sank on lower oil prices, with the USD/CAD edging up to 1.3191.

The US dollar index is trending upwards, at 97.225.

In commodities, the price of gold moved back down overnight as Asian traders decided to pull back and wait for tonight's policy statement from the US Federal Reserve regarding monetary policy.

Gold is currently selling for $1,319.01 per ounce, down 0.09% from yesterday. Silver is also down, at $19.65 per ounce. Platinum managed to post a small gain, of 0.16%, to $1,095.70 per ounce. Platinum has industrial uses that gold does not.

Oil markets are also dealing with falling prices, but without the natural support that gold has. In recent days, oil has dropped to three-month lows as traders grow concerned again about the global oversupply that has driven the oil price collapse of the last two years.

Don't look for price support from the US government's stockpile data. While crude stocks are expected to see a large drawdown, inventories of gasoline, diesel, and heating oil are all expected to increase. The increase in refined products, combined with low demand, bodes ill for future oil prices, as refiners will have less need of crude in the winter months.

Overall, oil prices are down 15% from their June peak. West Texas Intermediate, the US benchmark grade, is selling for $42.68 per barrel. Brent crude, the global trading benchmark, is going for $44.38.

In the Asia-Pacific region, stocks are mixed today. Australia is flat, mainland China is down, Hong Kong posted modest gains. Tokyo, however, saw strong gains in the markets after PM Abe announced a large stimulus package – more than 28 trillion yen, well over expectations for 10 to 20 trillion yen – to try and boost the Japanese economy. The Nikkei reacted with a closing gain of 1.72%, while the TOPIX added 1.13%.

The announcement of the stimulus plan puts pressure on the Bank of Japan, which holds its regular policy meeting tomorrow and Friday. BoJ is widely expected to increase its monetary easing policy when it releases its statement on Friday.

In the US, the stock markets had a mixed day yesterday, with the Dow losing 0.10%, the S&P 500 picking up a modest 0.03%, and the NASDAQ gaining 0.24%.
Trading has been lighter than usual as investors are waiting to see the Federal Reserve will do. The Fed is wrapping up its regular policy meeting today, and will release its policy statement this evening. Fed chair Janet Yellen's statement will be carefully parsed, with an eye toward future interest rate policy. With the election coming in November, traders do not expect another rate hike this summer (the odds for September are only 25%), but December is still in play with markets pricing in a 42% chance of higher rates before the end of the year.

European markets opened to gains in early trading today, and are holding on to them. London's FTSE 100 is up 0.30%, the DAX is up 0.84%, and the CAC 40 has gained 1.46%.

The banking sector in Europe is under pressure, with Italian and Portuguese banks hoping for a bailout as happened in Greece. Even Germany is not immune, as Europe's banks are generally undercapitalized. Deutsche Bank reported a drop in net profits, to 20 million Euros, as well as a 20% reduction in Q2 revenues. The bank's stock has dropped nearly 5%.

The big event today is the Federal Reserve's policy statement, after the FOMC meeting closes. The statement will give the Fed's stance toward future monetary policy and interest rates. On Friday, the Bank of Japan will be releasing a similar statement.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 28, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_28_2016
video.description: The Federal Reserve held rates steady but gave little guidance on future policy. The dollar sank after the announcement while haven assets gained.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, Federal Reserve, Bank of Japan, price of gold, price of oil

content-body.text: The Federal Reserve held rates steady yesterday, but gave little guidance on future policy. The US dollar sank after the announcement, while haven assets – gold and the yen – gained. Oil prices continue to fall on oversupply.

Taking a look at currencies, the US dollar dipped after the Fed statement held firm on interest rates. The dollar index, a broad measure of the greenback, has fallen to 96.527, down from yesterday's 97.053. It's the lowest reading in 10 days, but still near its four month high.

In individual currency pairs, the EUR/USD is up at 1.1091, the GBP/USD rose overnight but has since slid slightly to stand at 1.3188, and the AUD/USD is up at 0.7526.
The USD/CAD is down to 1.3140, despite lower oil prices putting continued pressure on the loonie. The USD/CHF slipped back to 0.9849. The bigger news was in the Japanese yen – the yen showed the largest change in the exchange rate, with the USD/JPY dropping to 104.69.

The yen's sudden strength came on haven trading after the Fed announcement, as well as expectations that Japan will institute an aggressive stimulus policy. The yen also gained on the Euro, pushing the EUR/JPY down to 116.03.

Oil prices are still sliding, as oversupply and overproduction continue to glut the markets. US government data showed that crude stockpiles in the States actually increased last week, by 1.7 million barrels. Analysts had expected a 2.3 million barrel draw, and the unexpected build pushed the WTI price below the $42 mark. Right now, the US West Texas Intermediate benchmark is selling for $41.94 per barrel, and the Brent global benchmark is going for $43.47. These prices are a three-month low for crude oil.

Gold fell recently on lower demand for haven assets, but jumped last night after the Fed held tight on rates and indicated that any hikes would be slow and gradual. Gold hit a 28 month high level in the panic after the Brexit vote, so this past week's 2% slide didn't really hurt the investors much as the metal was still up about 25% for the year. Gold, and precious metals generally, is looking to post a very strong year.

Price wise, gold is now selling for $1,341.36 per ounce, up more than $20 from yesterday. Silver also jumped, reaching a current price of $20.46 per ounce. Platinum showed the largest gains, and is now selling for $1,150.14. Precious metals are also finding support from expectations that Bank of Japan will increase its monetary easing packages in its policy statement tomorrow evening.

In the Asia-Pacific region today, markets in Tokyo and Hong Kong are down while mainland China and Australia are seeing gains.

The Nikkei 225 is 1.13% lower, the TOPIX is down 1.11%, and the Hang Seng has fallen 0.56%. In Shanghai, the CSI 300 picked up a modest 0.09%, and in Australia, the S&P ASX is up by 0.30%. The drop in Tokyo's markets comes along with the rise in the yen, as a stronger yen tends to put downward pressure on Japanese stocks.
PM Abe's announcement of an aggressive economic stimulus package has given some support to Japanese equity markets, however, which may limit the impact of the stronger currency. Investors now will be watching for the Bank of Japan's policy statement tomorrow, to see if the central bank pushes the expected monetary easing.

In the US, investors are digesting the Fed's policy statement from yesterday. The Fed held interest rates steady at 0.5% – where it has been since December's hike marked the end of nearly a decade of easing policy – but did not indicate whether there would be one or two hikes later this year. Hints in Fed chair Janet Yellen's statement seem to indicate that the bank will pursue a slow and gradual pace in monetary tightening.

Wall Street's markets dropped after the statement. At yesterday's close, the Dow was just into negative territory, with a loss of 0.01% and the S&P 500 had lost 0.12%. The NASDAQ also dipped after Yellen spoke, but remained in the green with a 0.58% gain for the day.

Looking at some individual stocks, Apple rose more than 6% on news of better than expected iPhone sales. Twitter fell sharply, losing almost 15% on poor revenue forecasts, and Coca-Cola fell more than 3% on poor sales reports.

In Europe, markets are opening lower after posting gains yesterday. The FTSE 100 in London is down 0.04% and the DAX is down 0.16%. The CAC 40 has bucked the trend, and gained 0.19%.

Looking ahead, Bank of Japan is meeting today and tomorrow, with their policy statement to be announced tomorrow evening. The Bank is widely expected to pursue some additional economic stimulus – further QE, or even pushing rates deeper into negative territory. Look for the yen and Tokyo's markets to respond on Monday.

Further ahead, Reserve Bank of Australis will be conducting its policy meeting on Tuesday next week, and on August 26 the US Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen will be speaking at the Jackson Hole symposium. It will be Yellen's first major statement after yesterday's policy announcement, and she is expected to give her review of current monetary policy.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: July 31, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_July_31_2016
video.description: US economic growth came in far below expectations for Q2 and Bank of Japan refused to expand monetary easing to fund the government's fiscal stimulus plan.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, haven assets, gold, bank of japan, economic news

content-body.text: US economic growth came in far below expectations for Q2, and Bank of Japan refused to expand monetary easing to fund the government's fiscal stimulus plan. The combination pushed the dollar down and the yen up. Haven assets – gold, silver, platinum, and the Swiss franc – all saw large gains.

In forex markets, the US dollar tumbled on the news GDP news, and the yen and Swiss franc – both common haven assets – saw sharp gains. The USD/JPY fell to 102.06, and the USD/CHF dropped to 0.9695. The Euro and Australian dollar also posted strong gains, with the EUR/USD reaching 1.1174 and the AUD/USD hitting 0.7596.

The US dollar index, a broad measure of the greenback that compares it to a basket of six trade-weighted major currencies, fell to 95.530, the lowest level in just over a month.

The yen and franc were not the only haven assets to see gains from the US and Japanese economic news. Gold finished with its second straight week of increases, giving it a 27% rally for the year to date. Gold is currently selling for $1,351.28 per ounce. Silver, also a traditional form of money and a haven asset, saw smaller gains, rising to $20.39 per ounce. Silver has gained over 9% for the month of July.

The big winner among the precious metals, however, was platinum, which jumped to $1,148.58 per ounce. The white metal has important industrial uses (in the catalytic converters that help control car emissions), is sensitive to ongoing labor disputes in South Africa, and has also gained as a haven from central banks' monetary easing. Platinum is up 28% for the year, giving it a slight edge over gold in terms of return on investment.

Oil, on the other hand, is moving the other direction, and has lost nearly 20% since the beginning of June. This puts the fuel on the path to an official bear market.

Supply and demand issues have dominated the oil markets lately, and even though much excess production is slowing down, global stockpiles are still nearly overflowing. It's estimated that there are more than 3 billion barrels of crude oil in stockpiles around the world. The persistent glut in supply has badly upset the market, and consistently defied predictions that oil markets will return to a normal balance between supply and demand.

In terms of price, we see WTI, the US trading benchmark, at $41.60 per barrel, and Brent, the global price, at $43.53.

The US saw some gloomy economic news last week, when the Commerce Department released the Q2 GDP growth data. The headline number of 1.2% was far below expectations; economists has predicted 2.6%, but the actual number was less than half that value. In another hit, the Q1 number was revised down to just 0.8%.

The next major data release coming up is the July non-farm payroll report, due out on Friday, August 5. The last two NFP releases were opposites – May's report was disastrously low, while June's report was unbelievably high. The two together matched the six month average. The forecast for July is for 180,000 jobs created, enough to meet the pace of population growth, but the poor GDP growth casts some doubt on that rosy prediction.

The gloomy news had immediate repercussions. The prospect of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike is now seen as much lower, and the US dollar dropped sharply in the markets.

US stocks finished Friday with mixed results. The Dow was down 0.13%, the S&P 500 gained 0.16%, and the NASDAQ picked up 0.14%.

Bank of Japan also disappointed investors on Friday, when it refused to increase its monetary easing activities with further purchases of Japanese government bonds or by pushing interest rates deeper into negative territory. The BoJ announcement casts doubts, or at least concerns, over how the government plans to fund PM Abe's aggressive 28 trillion yen economic stimulus plan, and has spurred speculation that the central bank will resort to some form of simply printing money – so-called helicopter money – and releasing it into the general public.

Japanese stocks were volatile on Friday, but ended in positive territory, as the Nikkei 225 0.56% and the TOPIX added 1.20%. Australian stocks showed a similar pattern, and the S&P ASX gained a modest 0.10%. In China, however, stocks were down. The Hang Seng lost 1.28%, and on the mainland Shanghai's CSI 300 fell 0.53%.

In Europe, markets were similarly volatile. London's FTSE 100 and France's CAC 40 both traded in the red during the session, but finished with gains of 0.05% and 0.44% respectively. The DAX was green all day, and ended 0.61% ahead.

Look for US factory data to be released tomorrow, US personal spending data on Tuesday, the ADP private employment payroll data – a preview of the NFP – on Wednesday, Bank of England's monetary policy decision on Thursday as well as US weekly jobless claims, and the Non-Farm Payroll report from the US Dept. of Labor on Friday. It will be a busy week for economic data.

If you prefer sports to economics, the 2016 Summer Olympics will be starting on Friday in Rio de Janeiro.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_August_01_2016
video.description: Global markets are mixed after gloomy economic reports and currency volatility. Precious metals are gaining on demand for haven assets.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, NFP, non-farm payroll, gold, oil, global markets

content-body.text: Global markets are mixed after gloomy economic reports and currency volatility. Precious metals are gaining on demand for haven assets

The US dollar dropped sharply after Friday's news, but is mostly stable today, posting modest gains that do not recoup the full losses. The EUR/USD stands at 1.1170, the GBP/USD at 1.3172, and the AUD/USD is trading at 0.7576. The USD/CAD is trading at 1.3077. The Canadian dollar is feeling pressure from low oil prices. The yen and Swiss franc have gained on haven trading, with the USD/JPY at 102.28 and the USD/CHF at 0.9683.

Oil is down near three-month lows. Oversupply and indications of increasing US and OPEC production are combining to push prices down.

In the States, the number of active rigs for the fifth week in a row, and the eighth time in the last nine weeks. It's a likely a lagging response to the summer's bounce in oil prices – drillers sold product on higher futures prices which allows them to increase production despite a price decline now. The higher production, however, cuts into oil prices and that will depress production later.

Oil stockpiles are also high, underlining fears of global oversupply. Again, looking at the States, crude stocks increased by 1.67 million barrels two weeks ago, and are only slightly off their 97-year high of 543.4 million barrels from April. Petroleum product stocks are also up, as gasoline inventories rose to 241.5 million barrels.

Brent crude is below $43, selling at $42.98 right now, and WTI, the US benchmark grade, is selling for $41.12 per barrel. Expect the high stockpiles of refined products to keep crude oil demand weak and prices down, at least through the end of the year.

Gold hit a daily peak above $1,360 on Friday, as haven demand fueled purchases. The demand was spurred by the overall gloomy economic news, the slow growth in the US, and the BoJ decision not to push monetary easing right now. Precious metals all showed gains.

Right now, gold remains high but has eased slightly to $1,347.91 per ounce. Silver is selling for $20.52, and platinum for $1,147.56.

It's earnings reporting season, and so far the news has not been good. Corporate earnings are down worldwide, marking the fifth straight quarter of declines in the US. The slowing global economy is hurting sales figures in many industries, impacting the bottom lines.

Earnings in the States, with two thirds of the S&P 500 members having reports so far, are down 3.3% from Q2 last year. Asia and Europe are in worse shape. Among companies in Asia that have announced results, earnings are down 19%, while Stoxx Europe 600 members have reported an average 14% decline so far.
The gloomy picture isn't relieved by growth forecasts, as the world economy is only predicted to grow by 2.9% this year. It's the lowest growth forecast since 2009. The US, EU, and China are expected to slow down this year, as are major emerging players such as Mexico.

Among the factors casting shadows on growth forecasts are the British decision to leave the EU, and the upcoming Brexit process; the US Presidential election in November, with widespread dismay at the available choice of candidates; and the increase in global terrorism. It's not a pretty picture.

The current data are not giving any better impression. In the US, Q2 Gross Domestic Product grew at an anemic 1.2% rate, and the Q1 figure was revised down to 0.8%. The poor GDP growth has put a damper on expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike; futures traders put the chance of an increase by September at just 12%, and have reduced the December chances to 33%.

The US stock markets responded with a mixed day on Friday, as the Dow lost 0.13%, the S&P 500 gained 0.16%, and the NASDAQ edged up 0.14%.

In Asia, news from Japan and China was also disappointing. The Bank of Japan chose not to increase its monetary easing policies – not to increase government bond purchases or to push interest rates further negative. The decision came after PM Abe's government announced an aggressive economic stimulus package, totally 28 trillion yen and well above the 10 to 20 trillion yen expected. However, only some 7 trillion yen of the stimulus is expected to be direct fiscal measures, so investors are taking a wait and see approach to Japan's future monetary and economic policy.

In China, meantime, manufacturing data showed more reason for concern about the slowdown in the second largest global economy. The manufacturing PMI dipped to 49.9 for July, showing the first monthly contraction in five months.

Stock markets in Asia reacted to the news with mixed results. In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 gained, advancing 0.40%, while the TOPIX fell 0.07%. China's CSI 300 index lost 0.85%, but Hong Kong's Hang Seng gained 1.09%. Australia's S&P ASX gained 0.45%.

Turning to Europe, investors are waiting for Thursday's Bank of England policy decision announcement. BoE is expected to cut interest rates by 25 basis points – the first cut since 2009 – but not to increase bond buying.

The European equity markets opened to gains today, but have dipped since. The FTSE 100 is down by 0.04% and the CAC 40 has fallen 0.42%. The DAX is still up, by 0.29%.

Coming up this week is the monthly non-farm payroll report from the US Department of Labor. The NFP is regularly seen as a proxy for the US economy as a whole. After the poor GDP growth, the NFP will be closely watched. The forecast is for 175,000 jobs gained and no change in the 4.9% unemployment rate.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 2, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_August_02_2016
video.description: Global markets are mixed after gloomy economic reports and currency volatility. Precious metals are gaining on demand for haven assets.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, NFP, non-farm payroll, gold, oil, global markets

content-body.text: Stock markets were mixed in the US and Asia and low in Europe on Monday, 1 august 2016. Crude hit the lowest level since April, sinking lower than $40. Concerned with oversupply, investors avoided making significant movements. Energy stocks declined and brought the Dow Jones industrials and the S&P down. The former shed 0.15%; the latter inched 0.1% lower. Because technological companies did well on Monday, the NASDAQ fared better: it climbed 0.4%. In Europe, investors were in a gloomy mood because of bad manufacturing data. Negatively affected by the UK’s willingness to part company with the European Union, manufacturing industry gravitated to its lowest level since 2013. The FTSE retreated 0.5%. The CAC lost 0.7%. The DAX edged 0.1% lower.
The US dollar advanced against the euro, the pound, the yen, the Canadian dollar, and the Australian dollar. It remained the same against the Swiss franc.
Gold increased US$7.65 to US$1,349.65. Copper futures dropped 1.55% to US$2.19. WTI declined US$1.61 to US$39.99. Dated Brent spot crude lost US$1.37 to US$42.16.

US Market. Energy stocks dipped. Exxon Mobil declined along with Chevron. Devon Energy also finished in the red. Tesla offered $2.6 billion in stock for SolarCity, which is more than its first offer of $2.5 billion made a month ago. Verizon made a deal to purchase Fleetmatics Group, a maker of software for vehicle fleets, for $2.4 billion. As a result of the deal, Verizon decreased. Shares of Fleetmatics Group, by contrast, gained. Ionis Pharmaceuticals advanced thanks to a good development of its new drug for spinal muscular atrophy in infants. Having admitted that it would sell its social and mobile games business for $4.4 billion, Caesars Entertainment rose.

European Market. In the wake of the release of the EU stress test, banks jumped. The test revealed that Monte dei Paschi di Siena, Austria's Raiffeisen, Allied Irish Banks, and Spain's Banco Popular were the weakest. Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank were also among the losers, as were Barclays, Royal Bank of Scotland, and HSBC. RWE and E.ON slipped, and Air Liquide in France did, too. Veolia Environment, water and waste utility, gained. Société Générale, BNP Paribas, and Crédit Agricole also finished the trading day in the red. Petrofac rose in London. GlaxoSmithKline jumped as well, having revealed its desire to join a unit of Alphabet. Taylor Wimpey, Berkeley Group, Barratt Developments, and Persimmon had a slide. Anglo American moved into a positive territory.

Asia-Pacific Market. Because of contradictory reports about the Chinese economy, the Shanghai Composite lost 0.9%. The Hang Seng advanced 1.1%. After being in the negative territory at the beginning of the trading day, the Nikkei managed to finish 0.4% higher. Mitsubishi UFJ Financial, Mizuho Financial and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group jumped, as did Fast Retailing and Softbank. Sony soared, too. Panasonic declined. In Australia, the S&P/ASX added 0.4%. The All Ordinaries gained as much. BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group were up, as were gold miners Newcrest, Regis Resources, and Evolution Mining. The Kospi jumped 0.7%. The Sensex dipped 0.2%.
