The Reserve Bank of Australia is presenting its monetary policy decision. Australia is giving June merchandise trade data. The UK is publishing July construction PMI. The Eurozone is issuing June producer price index. The US is reporting on June personal income and spending.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 3, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_August_03_2016
video.description: Stocks worldwide fell overnight, as oil dropped further into a bear market. Haven assets – gold, silver, and the yen – are all gaining.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, oil, precious metals, haven assets

content-body.text: Stocks worldwide fell overnight, as oil dropped further into a bear market. Haven assets – gold, silver, and the yen – are all gaining as investors turn away from risk.

As mentioned above, the dollar is down, under pressure from poor economic reports, while the yen is getting a boost by a smaller than expected economic stimulus package and high demand on haven trading.

The US dollar index currently stands at 95.250, well down from its July 22 peak of 97.467. The index gauges the strength of the dollar against a basket of trade weighted major currencies.

The yen is stronger today, with the USD/JPY trading at 101.12. The Japanese currency actually touched the 100 handle yesterday, marking its strongest level in three weeks. The EUR/USD pair is trending slightly downwards, but also showing strength for the common currency. One Euro currently buys 1.1201 dollars. Cable is also stronger today, with the GBP/USD at 1.3350.

Oil markets are making news, as crude prices decline. Oil has dropped more than 20% since early June, putting it into bear market territory and ending its recovery from February's 12-year low prices.

In the US, the WTI benchmark price is below $40, at $39.75 per barrel. Brent, the global benchmark, is selling for $42.06.

Supply and demand – specifically, weak demand and oversupply – are controlling the oil markets right now. While there have been recent draws on US stockpiles, inventories remain at historically high levels. The high inventory levels are not restricted to the US; oil storage facilities around the world are near their maximum capacities.

While oil moves down, precious metals are moving up. Gold has seen its sixth consecutive day of gains, and now sells at $1,363.24 per ounce. Silver is heading toward the $21 mark, with its current price at $20.68, and platinum is selling for $1,161.03. Precious metals are gaining, like the yen, on demand for safe haven assets.

In the US markets, the Dow Jones posted its seventh losing session in a row, and the S&P 500 had its first back-to-back losses since the Brexit vote. The Dow fell 0.49%, the S&P dropped 0.64%, and the NASDAQ lost 0.90%.

The losses came on the heels of Tuesday's data release showing that June incomes rose less than expected – only 0.2% – and that the savings rate fell to a one-year low. The data cast some shadows on the consumer sector of the US economy.

Tuesday's data, after last Friday's poor GDP print, have helped to push the odds of another Federal Reserve interest rate hike further down, with futures traders putting only a 40% chance of more monetary tightening this year. The gloomy outlook is a major factor behind the dollar's fall in the currency markets over the last few days.

In Japan, meantime, a lower-than-expected economic stimulus package pushed equities down and the yen up. Last week, PM Abe announced that his government would push a policy of stimulus for the faltering economy; rumors had the total amount of the plan at well over 20 trillion yen. The actual policy announcement this week, however, put the total stimulus at just 7 trillion yen, with only 4.6 trillion in direct government spending.

Markets in the Asia-Pacific region were not impressed. In Tokyo, the TOPIX is down 2.17% and the Nikkei 225 has fallen 1.88%. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong dropped 1.76%, but on mainland China Shanghai's CSI 300 index managed to squeak out a gain of 0.14%. Australia's S&P ASX is down 1.35%.

In Europe, markets were down yesterday and are opening to more losses in early trading today. London's FTSE 100 is down 0.02%, the DAX has lost 0.13%, and the CAC 40 has fallen 0.44%. These losses come as major European banks are feeling increased pressure from a combination of undercapitalization and an abundance of underperforming loans. Share prices of Deutsche Bank are down and Credit Suisse is managing to scrape out a small gain after losing more than 4% earlier this week.

Investors are waiting for Bank of England to release its interest rate decision on Thursday, the second such release since the Brexit vote. Expectations are for another cut.
Watch for Eurozone retail sales numbers, and the ADP payroll report from the US.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 4, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_August_4_2016
video.description: Stocks worldwide fell overnight, as oil dropped further into a bear market. Haven assets – gold, silver, and the yen – are all gaining.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, oil, precious metals, haven assets

content-body.text: Central banks are starting to act in response to slowing economies in the UK and Japan. The US dollar is rebounding slightly, and gold is dipping. Oil prices have edged up but remain low.

The US dollar is starting to recoup some of its recent losses, posting slight gains against the Euro, the pound, and the yen. The GBP/USD is down slightly, to 1.3289, the EUR/USD has dipped to 1.1135, and the USD/JPY ticked up to 101.42. The USD/CHF also advanced, to 0.9736.
Despite these gains, the US dollar index is basically flat since yesterday. It currently stands at 95.536, compared to yesterday's 95.563. The index is trending upwards in today's trading.

Oil markets ticked up a bit overnight, marking a reversal of recent losses. Oil broke back above $40, and WTI, the US benchmark, is trading at $40.82 per barrel. Brent, the global market benchmark, is selling for $42.97.

The gains come after data showed that US crude and gasoline stockpiles fell last week, in the largest draw since April. Some analysts believe that this may mark a reversal of oil's price decline; however, it's important to note that while US refiners are ordering more crude, and drawing from stockpiles, and that distributors are drawing from gasoline stockpiles, demand is still weak and the refiners are starting early to switch from summer fuels to winter blends. The stockpile draws may just reflect that switch; the winter gasoline blends will be used starting in the fall, and the refiners will find the same bind they are in now: low demand, and large supplies of crude. The result could be continued low prices.

Gold prices declined yesterday, and continue to fall today, mostly in response to the stronger dollar. The drop marks the end of gold's longest rally in the last two months. The metal currently sells for $1,351.89 per ounce. Silver and platinum also declined, to $20.23 and $1,155.59 respectively.

Copper, the most ubiquitous industrial metal, also fell, losing nearly 1% and dipping to $2.17 per pound. The drop comes on slowing demand is one of the increasing signs that the global economy is faltering.

The Bank of England will be releasing its interest rate policy decision today, and market watchers are widely expecting a cut of 25 basis points, to a record low of 0.25%. It is also assumed that the bank will restart its quantitative easing program of multi-million pound purchases of government bonds. The decision is expected in light of new indicators that the UK economy is on the edge of recession in the wake of the Brexit vote.

London's FTSE 100 is down ahead of the announcement, losing 0.17% in the last session. The CAC 40 also fell, by 0.16%, and the DAX posted a gain of 0.26% yesterday. The European markets are opening with modest gains in today's session.

Bank of Japan also increased stimulus policies recently, although less than expected. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 is up 1.08% and the TOPIX index has gained 0.93%. Elsewhere in the Asia-Pacific region, markets are also showing gains. The Hang Seng is up by 0.59%, and on mainland China the CSI 300 has gained 0.24%. Australia's S&P ASX picked up 0.18%. It's interesting to note that the Reserve Bank of Australia also cut rates in its most recent policy decision.

Turning to the US markets, a rise in oil prices has helped to boost the major indexes by helping out the energy companies. The Dow Jones finished yesterday with a gain of 0.23%, the S&P 500 picked up 0.31%, and the NASDAQ gained 0.43%.

Another bit of good news for the US markets came from the ADP payroll report. ADP, the largest private processor of payroll records, released its jobs numbers for July, showing that 179,000 jobs were created for the month. This was a decent print, but taken with the low GDP growth of the last two quarters, and the 140K jobs just needed to keep up with population growth, some analysts are saying that the ADP numbers show an economy treading water. In any case, the ADP print is seen as a preview of the monthly official non-farm payroll report, released by the Department of Labor. The July NFP will be released tomorrow.

Looking ahead, keep your eyes peeled for the non-farm payroll report from the US. The NFP is frequently taken as a proxy for the US economy as a whole. Analysts predict a headline figure near 180,000 jobs created while the official unemployment rate dips to 4.8%. The report will be released tomorrow morning.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 8, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_August_8_2016
video.description: The US dollar and global equities remain high today while commodities are mixed. Oil prices are edging up and precious metals remain low.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, dollar, jobs report, gold, oil

content-body.text: The US dollar and global equities remain high today while commodities are mixed. Oil prices are edging up and precious metals remain low.

The US dollar gained sharply on Friday after the NFP release, and while it has eased back slightly today it remains at high levels. The EUR/USD is trading at 1.1083, the GBP/USD is at 1.3036, and the AUD/USD has edged up to 0.7631.

The dollar has gained almost half a percent on the yen, pushing the USD/JPY to 102.29, and the USD/CHF is trading at 0.9811. It remains to be seen if falling oil prices will hurt the Canadian dollar. Right now, the USD/CAD is trading at 1.3163.

The US dollar index, a broader measure of the dollar's strength against a basket of major peer currencies, is up and trending upwards, at 96.340.

Turning to the commodity markets, gold and other precious metals took a hard hit on Friday, when the US jobs report gave a boost to investors' confidence in dollar and equity assets. Havens, like gold, suffered as demand fell and traders moved toward risk.

Gold remains low today, trading at $1,332.32 per ounce. Silver is also still down, at $19.71. Platinum showed the smallest percentage loss, but it, too, is down today, selling for $1,145.94 per ounce.

Copper, a widely used industrial metal which is used as a proxy for the industrial metal market generally, is up slightly from Friday's lows, trading for $2.17 per pound.
The bigger news in commodity markets comes in oil, where crude is still trading at 4-month low prices despite a slight tick upwards in Asian and early trading today. As usual, the main pressure on the oil markets comes from issues of weak demand and too much supply – these fundamentals have dominated oil markets for nearly two years and while there are occasional shifts the basic supply/demand picture does not look likely to change any time soon. Watch for US stockpile data, to be released tomorrow and Wednesday, as well as production reports from OPEC, for signals on the future of the oil market.

Pricewise, Brent crude is priced now at $44.74 per barrel and West Texas Intermediate at $42.30. Both benchmark grades are trending upwards.

Friday's jobs data – the monthly NFP report – showed that US employment was strong in July with 255,000 positions added compared to a forecast of 180,000. The headline unemployment rate remained stable at 4.9% and the average hourly wage increased 0.3% – above the predicted 0.2%.

It was, for the most part, a good jobs report, and it increased expectations that the US Federal Reserve will initiate another interest rate hike before the end of the year. Odds for a December hike are set at 44%, while September, before the upcoming US election, has only a 15% chance of a Fed move.

The bullish sentiment sent US stock markets to record high level on Friday. Both the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ closed at new all-time highs of 2,182.87 and 5,221.12 respectively. It was a 0.86% gain for the S&P and a 1.06% gain for the NASDAQ. The Dow closed with a respectable gain of 1.04%.

Data from Asia further underscores worries about the slowing global economic situation. Japan's current account balance for July came in at 1.65 trillion yen, about half of expectations, even though bank lending was up by 2.1%. China's trade balance beat expectations, with a $52.3 billion dollar surplus, but both exports and imports declined from last year. Exports were down 4.4% and imports down 12.5%, showing that China's trade surplus comes even as trade itself is declining.

By the numbers, the Asia-Pacific region markets took it all in stride. Equity markets followed Wall Street's Friday lead, and posted gains in today's session. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 gained 2.44% and the TOPIX added 2.00%. In China, the CSI 300 advanced 0.91% and the Hang Seng in Hong Kong picked up 1.43%. Australia's S&P ASX increased by 0.74%.

Turning to Europe, we see inflation fears stating to dominate the economic landscape. Specifically, we see fears that inflation will continue to miss the European Central Bank's 2% target rate. The impact of the Brexit vote has been less than feared, so the issue comes down to growth, which has not been strong enough to create the price and wage pressures needed to generate the target inflation. In addition, the price of oil is falling again as we move toward the end of summer, which also tend to deflate prices.

With the ECB forecasting only a 0.6% increase in consumer prices, there is increasing speculation that Bank President Mario Draghi will be forced to increase the Eurozone's stimulus measures.

Traders don't appear to be worried, as European markets are off to a good opening today after a good session last Friday. In early trading so far, the FTSE 100 in London is up 0.42%, the DAX is up 0.72%, and the CAC 40 has increased 0.46%.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 9, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_August_9_2016
video.description: The US dollar and global equities remain high today while commodities are mixed. Oil prices are edging up and precious metals remain low.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, dollar, jobs report, gold, oil

content-body.text: Monday, 08 of August 2016 was much slower day than Friday, when stocks were brought up by good employment reports from the US. On Monday, investors temporised and let stock slide in the US. Drug and consumer-focused companies dropped the lowest. Cheered up by the news that OPEC was going to have a meeting in September in order to solve the problem with oil oversupply, energy companies advanced. Major American indices suffered a minor decline: the Dow Jones industrials itched 0.1% lower; the S&P dipped as much. The NASDAQ was 0.2% down. In Europe, markets were still pervaded by joy caused by the good employment reports from America and finished in the positive territory. The FTSE gained 0.2%. The CAC was 0.1% up. The DAX appreciated 0.6%. The SMI was the only index that slipped on Monday, shedding 0.3%. Stocks in Asia climbed for the same reason: the creation of 255,000 new jobs in the US filled everyone with optimism concerning the future of global economy.
The US dollar advanced against the yen, pound, and Swiss franc. It remained the same against the Euro and Canadian dollar.

Save precious metals, other major commodities rose. Gold slid US$3.60 to US$1,336.80. Silver decreased US$0.15 to US$19.65. Platinum lost US$7.70 to US$1.142.85. Copper futures increased 0.3% to US$2.16. WTI spot crude gained US$1.08 to US$42.88. Dated Brent spot crude appreciated 0.91 US to US$45.18.

US Market. After its experiments with Opdivo medicine failed to show positive results in treatment of lung cancer patients, Bristol-Myers Squibb plummeted. Allergan presented poor second-quarter revenue and took a plunge. Having expressed a desire to purchase Jet.com for $3 billion in cash and $300 million in stock, Walmart moved into the negative territory. Thanks to slightly stabilized oil prices, energy companies -- Marathon Oil, Tesoro, and Chesapeake Energy -- ended the trading day in the green. After Steinhoff International signed a deal to buy it for $3.8 billion, Mattress Firm soared.

European Market. After it reported good consolidated net income, QSC, an American manufacturer of professional audio products, including loudspeakers, amplifiers, digital signal processors, and computer control systems, surged. Banks -- Commerzbank and Deutsche Bank – did well on Monday. Accused of fraud, bribery, and corruption by the UK’s Serious Fraud Office, Airbus Group tumbled. Crédit Agricole, BNP Paribas, and Société Générale jumped. Barclays gained, and so did Royal Bank of Scotland, Lloyds Banking Group, and Standard Chartered. Mining companies were also up: BHP Billiton, Antofagasta, Rio Tinto, and Anglo American appreciated.

Asia-Pacific Market. The Shanghai Composite advanced 0.9%, even though forex reserves and merchandise trade data were bad. The Hang Seng added 1.6%. Thanks to the easing yen, the Nikkei rose 2.4%. Exporters ended higher for the same reason. Canon, Panasonic, Toshiba, Toyota Motor, Honda Motor, and Hitachi were among the winners on Monday. Nissan Motor ended also higher. Fast Retailing and Softbank were, too. Energy stocks --Inpex, JX Holdings, and Japan Petroleum – also finished in the positive territory. In Australia, market jumped, having mining, financial, and energy stocks at its forefront. The S&P/ASP and the All Ordinaries gained 0.7%. Because iron ore prices increased to US$60, BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group increased. Macquarie Group advanced. The Kospi was 0.7% higher. The Sensex appreciated 0.4%.

China is giving a report on July consumer and producer price indices. The Reserve Bank of India is announcing its monetary policy decision. June merchandise data is arriving from Germany and the UK. The latter is also publishing June industrial production. The US is reporting on second quarter productivity and costs, and wholesale trade as well.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 10, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_August_10_2016
video.description: A poor economic report from the US pushed the dollar down in the markets, boosting gold and other haven assets.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, federal reserve, Q2 productivity, price of gold, us dollar

content-body.text: A poor economic report from the US pushed the dollar down in the markets, boosting gold and other haven assets. Oil prices remain soft as production continues to increase despite generally weak global demand.

In the currency markets, the big story is the broad weakness in the US dollar. Renewed skepticism that the Federal Reserve will hike rates again this year has pushed the greenback down in the markets. The US dollar index has dipped to 95.788, and is continuing to trend downwards.

By the numbers, the dollar is down against all of the majors. The USD/JPY has eased to 101.39, the USD/CHF slid to 0.9788, the USD/CAD eased to 1.3056. The EUR/USD moved up to 1.1148, the GBP/USD rose to 1.3049, and the AUD/USD advanced to 0.7717.

The weakness in the dollar came after Q2 productivity reports from the US Department of Labor showed a 0.5% drop, missing by far the forecast for a 0.4% increase. The poor report dampened enthusiasm generated by last week's good jobs report.

In the oil markets, prices are moving back down to the $43 handle, with WTI already below that mark. Prices are falling now on stockpile data from the US, showing an increase in stored crude at the same time that production is rising and expected to remain high through next year.

Also on the supply side, Saudi Arabia pumped out 10.67 million barrels per day in July, a new record for the world's largest oil exporter. Much of the increase in production was to meet local summertime demand, as energy use in the Middle East increases with air conditioner use in the hot months.

The increases in supply and production are simply exacerbating the existing supply/demand imbalance in the global oil markets, and pushing prices down. Brent, the global benchmark price, is at $44.45 per barrel and US benchmark WTI, as mentioned above, is below $43 at $42.21 per barrel. Both prices are trending downwards.
Gold and other precious metals, in the meantime, are edging back up, buoyed by the weaker dollar and the reduced expectations for a Federal Reserve interest rate move. The gloomy prospects for higher rates, coupled with a poor economic outlook globally, has investors moving back toward haven assets today.

The move pushed gold up about 1%, to $1,352.51 per ounce. Silver and platinum also gained, and are now selling at $20.33 and $1,183.18 per ounce respectively. Percentage wise, both white metals actually gained more than gold. Gold, however, is up 26% for the year to date, and its reputation as the traditional investing safe haven keeps it strong.

Industrial copper has also gained, improving more than half a percent to $2.17 per pound.

In equity markets, US stocks managed to finish in the green yesterday despite the poor Q2 productivity report and unease over increasing signs of faltering growth in other parts of the world economy.

The US Department of Labor reports a half-percent decline in productivity growth for Q2, missing by a wide margin the 0.4% gain which was forecast. Traders are pulling back from expectations, boosted by last week's strong jobs report, of an early Federal Reserve interest rate hike. The odds now of a hike this year are set at lower than 50%; some analysts believe that there will be no move by the Fed due to the election, and that no action can be expected before the next Presidential Administration takes office on January 20.

US markets dipped at the news, and the Dow and S&P moved into the red, but the three main indexes managed to finish the day with gains. The Dow Jones added a modest 0.02%, the S&P 500 gained 0.04%, and the NASDAQ picked up 0.24%.

In Asian trading today, the markets are in the red. Japan's Nikkei 225 is down 0.18% and the TOPIX has fallen 0.20%. China's CSI 300 is down 0.42% and Australia's S&P ASX is down 0.16%. The Hang Seng has managed to beat this trend, and has gained 0.12%.

European markets finished well yesterday, but are opening to losses in early trading in today's session. The FTSE 100 in London is down 0.07%, the DAX is down 0.22%, and France's CAC 40 has fallen 0.16%.
Watch the weekly US initial jobless claims tomorrow. In light of the last two good jobs reports, but the ongoing poor productivity in the States, those numbers will be interesting to see.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 11, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_August_11_2016
video.description: A poor economic report from the US pushed the dollar down in the markets, boosting gold and other haven assets.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, federal reserve, Q2 productivity, price of gold, us dollar

content-body.text: Markets dipped yesterday in lackluster trading, and gold eased back as investors took profits from its recent high levels. Oil continues to slip, as well, as oversupply and weak demand dominate the energy markets.

The US dollar has firmed up some after yesterday's sharp drop, and make small gains against most of its major peers.

The greenback rose overnight against the Euro, and the Canadian dollar. The EUR/USD pair stands at 1.1167, the USD/CAD edged up to 1.3058. The dollar was flat against the pound, with the GBP/USD at 1.3008. The yen, Swiss franc, and Aussie dollar all edged up against the US currency, but only slightly. The USD/JPY is at 101.25 and the USD/CHF at 0.9744. The AUD/USD is trading at 0.7716.

Overall, there was relatively little movement in the currency markets.

Oil and metals markets were a different story, however.

Crude oil prices fell in early trading today, as the markets were weighed down by a combination of supply factors. Stockpile inventories rose in the US, while the implications of increased Saudi production sank in with traders.

Data released by the US Energy Information Administration yesterday showed that oil stockpiles increased by 1.1 million barrels, beating the expectations. In addition, stocks at the Cushing, Oklahoma tank farm, the nation's largest storage facility for crude oil, increased to 523.6 million barrels, a seasonal high level that has not been seen in 80 years.

Also, Saudi Arabia reported record setting oil production in July. Much of that is to meet local demand, as energy consumption in the Middle East is highest in the hot summer months – gotta have that air conditioning! – but the Kingdom is the world's largest oil exporter, and there is no doubt that much of that oil will end up on the markets.

Still, that would just add to the glut in global markets, and there are signs that demand is simply not meeting the supply. The same report that showed US stocks increasing also showed that US refineries were using 255,000 barrel per day less than the previous week, and that US imports fell by 334,000 barrels per day. These drops come at a time when US production is declining from its recent peaks. So there is an apparent slowing demand in the world's largest oil consumer, at the same time that global supply is increasing. It's not an environment conducive to higher prices.

And in fact, prices are down. West Texas Intermediate, the US benchmark price, is selling for just $41.51 per barrel. Brent crude, the global benchmark, fell below $44, and is now at $43.93.

Precious metals also fell overnight, although in this case the cause was profit taking after a sharp increase. Gold and silver both lost 0.15%, and platinum dipped 0.02%. All three metals remain at high levels, with gold selling for $1,344.56 per ounce, silver for $20.14, and platinum for $1,176.00.
Gold's current price puts it 27% higher for the year. Gold, and the other precious metals, have found support from a variety of fear factors in the markets including the low interest rates in the States, negative rates in Japan and several European countries, and anxiety over the UK's intention to exit the EU. All of this has boosted demand for haven assets. Look for gold to remain strong despite occasional price dips like today's.

Sideways trading has been dominating equity markets, especially in the US. The American markets edged a little lower in yesterday's trading, but stayed within a narrow range. The trend to sideways movement has been so pronounced that only once in the last month has the Dow Jones average moved outside a +/- 1% range from the previous day's session.

By the numbers, the Dow finished down 0.20% yesterday, the S&P 500 was down 0.29%, and the NASDAQ lost 0.40% - all three were within 1% of the previous day's finish.

Europe's markets showed more mixed results yesterday, with the FTSE 100 gaining 0.22% while the DAX was down 0.39% and the CAC 40 lost 0.36%.

Asia-Pacific shares are wrapping up today's session, with losses in Japan and Australia but modest gains in China. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 fell 0.18%, the TOPIX lost 0.20%, and Australia's S&P ASX fell 0.64%. In China, the CSI 300 index in Shanghai picked up 0.16% while the Hang Seng in Hong Kong was gaining 0.70%.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 14, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_August_14_2016
video.description: Stocks were mixed on Friday, and the US dollar was broadly down after a set of poor data releases on US sales and consumer activity.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, stocks, dollar, Janet Yellen, Federal Reserve, gold

content-body.text: Stocks were mixed on Friday, and the US dollar was broadly down after a set of poor data releases on US sales and consumer activity. Oil prices rose after the Saudis talked up prices, and precious metals, which have rallied recently, are slowing down.

In currency markets, the US dollar was lower overall, despite gains against the pound and the Aussie.

Sterling, for reasons discussed above, dipped, pushing the GBP/USD down to 1.2920, while the AUD/USD fell to 0.7652 as commodity prices – especially metals – saw declines. Against other major currencies, the dollar sank. The EUR/USD rose to 1.1162, while the USD/JPY fell to 101.30, the USD/CHF dropped to 0.9744, and a rise in oil prices helped knock the USD/CAD down to 1.2951.

Looking at the US dollar index, a broad measure of the greenback against a basket of trade-weighted peer currencies, we see a reading of 95.722 and trending down. This compares to a recent peak, from a week ago, of 96.401. On a longer view, however, the dollar appears pretty steady. The five year chart of the dollar index (DXY) shows the greenback held steady through 2012 and 2013, and in 2014 rose from that 80 level to its current plateau in the upper 90s, where it has remained since early 2015.

Oil prices fell sharply last week, and approached the $40 level before rising again on Friday and in after-hours weekend trading. The rise came when Saudi Arabia sent out hints that it may be willing to take measure to stabilize the market – read: raise prices – at next month's OPEC discussions. In response, oil quickly bounced back to the $45 handle.

Take the Saudi hints for whatever they may be worth. The kingdom has a policy for the last two years of pushing up production and flooding markets to maintain market share, a strategy that predictably reduces prices, while at the same time trying to talk up prices in an effort to maintain cash flow.

As the weekend winds down, Brent crude is trading for $46.97 per barrel and WTI, the US trading benchmark, is selling for $44.49.

In the metals markets, technical indicators show that gold's rally – the metal gained sharply last week – may be slowing down, and investors have started pulling back and taking profits. Gold is down 0.21%, and selling at $1,335.97 per ounce. Silver, another haven asset, is also down, at $19.72. Platinum was the biggest loser in precious metals, losing over 1.4% and slipping to $1,123.25 per ounce.

In the week ahead, the three main data releases to watch for are the US crude oil inventories report, on Wednesday; the Fed's last policy meeting minutes, also on Wednesday; and the weekly initial jobless claims, on Thursday.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 15, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_August_15_2016
video.description: Oil prices are going up again, talked up by OPEC officials, and giving a boost to world stock markets. Equities have been pushed to one-year high levels.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, oil, gold, US dollar, economic stimulus

content-body.text: Oil prices are going up again, talked up by OPEC officials, and giving a boost to world stock markets. Equities have been pushed to one-year high levels overall, despite a rash of disappointing economic data.

The US dollar has made the most news lately, in the currency markets. The greenback took a dive after poor retail sales reports, losing ground to the Euro, the yen, the Canadian dollar and the Swiss franc. Dollar trading has been more volatile against the pound and the Australian dollar.

By the numbers, the EUR/USD is currently up at 1.1170, the GBP/USD remains below $1.30, at 1.2921, and the AUD/USD is still up, at 0.7668. The USD/JPY remains low, at just 101.01, the USD/CHF is down to 0.9743, and the USD/CAD is trading at 1.2936.

The US dollar index is at 95.634, basically flat from yesterday, but trending downwards.

Oil prices are climbing this week, moving up from last week's lows to reach above the $45 mark. The moves come as Saudi Arabia has been talking up the possibility of discussing production cutbacks – next month.

The OPEC nations are scheduled to hold an informal meeting in September, and the kingdom, the organization's largest oil producer and exporter, has signaled its willingness to talk about stabilizing the oil markets. That's a euphemism for boosting prices by cutting back on production. The drawback, of course, is that the Saudis need their current high production levels to maintain market share against rival oil giants Russia and Iran. Saudi Arabia, with its deep pockets and plentiful hard currency reserves, made the decision more than two years ago to keep production high and force prices low in an effort to harm the US shale producers (rivals in the oil business), Russian oil producers (more business rivals), and Iran (geopolitical foe that requires high oil prices to balance the budget). The irony, of course, is that their aggressive policy has gone on too long, and now the low prices are starting to sting the kingdom. In this environment, the Saudis are unlikely to do more than try and talk up prices, as they need their high production levels as much as they need higher sales prices.

That's not the only mixed signal in the oil markets. Worldwide, refiners are expected to bring their crude use to a record level of 80.6 million barrels per day this quarter, a quantity that may help absorb the record level production from OPEC. The US, however, is the world's largest consumer of crude oil, and stockpiles there – of crude and refined products like gasoline and diesel – are rising even as production is edging up. US refineries are entering their slowest production period of the year, when they shut for maintenance and then switch to producing winter blend gasolines.

Putting all of this into numbers gives us WTI, the US trading benchmark, at $44.66. Brent crude, the global benchmark price, is selling for $47.10. Both are starting to edge down, while remaining up from yesterday.

Oil isn't the only commodity whose price is moving around. Gold is up 27% for the year to date, but has started to lose steam. This month, the metal has lost about 1% as haven demand slowed after a strong US jobs report. Gold is currently selling for $1,340.55 per ounce. Other precious metals are also down from recent high levels, with silver selling for $19.90 and platinum for $1,129.60 per ounce. All three metals are up slightly from overnight lows.

In the US, stock indexes are at or near their all-time highs. Last week, the S&P 500 set a new record, although it has eased back since and lost 0.08% in yesterday's trading. The Dow dipped 0.20%, while the NASDAQ managed a gain of 0.09%. Trading was downbeat, but rose in the latter half of the session and all three indexes finished on a rising trend.

The picture outside of the US isn't so good. Continued lagging economies and poor economic reports have prompted central banks to push further stimulus programs, but the results have been mixed so far.

The Bank of England raised rates last week, for the first time in seven years, and embarked on a bond-buying program of quantitative easing. They ran into a headwind – a lack of buyers on the first day. Since then, the Bank has been more successful with its stimulus, and the markets have responded. The FTSE 100 is up in early trading today, with a gain of 0.18%, the DAX is up 0.30%, and the CAC 40 has picked up a more modest 0.08%.

In Japan, the government is moving to enact a large economic stimulus while the central bank is under pressure to increase monetary easing and negative interest rates to fund the government initiative. At the same time, Q2 economic growth came in at just 0.2%, well below the 0.7% forecast.

Tokyo's markets were not impressed. The Nikkei 225 is down 0.30% and the TOPIX has lost 0.50% in today's session. These drops come as the yen is strengthened due to weakness in the US dollar. Japanese stocks frequently move in the opposite direction as the yen, as a stronger currency makes Japanese exports more expensive and the Japanese economy is exquisitely export-sensitive.

Elsewhere in the Asia-Pacific region, stock were up. The Australian S&P ASX is up 0.16%, Shanghai's CSI 300 is up 3.01%, and the Hang Seng is up 0.73%.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 16, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_August_16_2016
video.description: Oil prices are going up again, talked up by OPEC officials, and giving a boost to world stock markets. Equities have been pushed to one-year high levels.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, oil, gold, US dollar, economic stimulus

content-body.text: Fed watchers are looking for some as to the US central bank's views on rate policy, while the US dollar is languishing in currency trading. Prices for oil and gold are both rebounding.

The dollar has been dipping in the currency markets, held back by downbeat Asian economic data as well as the uncertainty over the Fed's future rate policy. The US dollar index, is at 95.120, down more than 1% form earlier this month.

Looking at individual currency pairs, the USD/JPY is trading at 100.28, the yen's strongest level in more than a month. The stronger yen is one factor in Tokyo's recent stock losses.

The EUR/USD has moved up to 1.1243, and the GBP/USD is at 1.2900. The pound, under pressure from Bank of England's easing measures, fell yesterday almost to its post-Brexit vote low, but is rebounding slightly and moving up against the dollar now.

The commodity linked Australian and Canadian dollars are both benefiting from a rise in oil prices. The AUD/USD is up to 0.7710, and the USD/CAD has slipped to 1.2905.

Oil prices hit a one-month high yesterday, on a three day rally which started when Saudi Arabia hinted that it may be willing to discuss production cuts at an informal OPEC gathering next month. There's a lot of equivocation in that sentence, but oil traders are looking for any reason to hope the current low price regime may be drawing to a close.

Russia, the largest non-OPEC producer, jumped on the bandwagon, too, and hinted that it may go along with Saudi cuts. However, there are no signs that Iran has any plan to cut production; rather, Iran has signaled that it intends to keep increasing crude oil output now that international trade sanctions are lifted.

In addition to the confusing signals from major producers, market fundamentals of supply and demand still point to lower crude prices. Storage facilities worldwide are near maximum capacity, and demand is relatively weak in both the US and China, the world's largest oil consumers.

For the moment, though, crude prices are generally up. US benchmark grade West Texas Intermediate is trading at $45.36 per barrel, and global benchmark Brent is at $47.91. Both are trending down right now, on some mild profit taking as traders take advantage of these current prices.

In the precious metals markets, gold has made gains for two sessions now. The metal had fallen as investors moved toward riskier, higher returning assets, and took profits from the high prices in gold. With the gloomy data releases last week, and the Federal Reserve's policy position unclear, gold is now gaining again. The current price is $1,347.60 per ounce.

Silver and platinum are also both rising. Silver is now at $20 even, and platinum is selling for $1,123.27.

Iron ore, which had rallied strongly this year and is now priced at $60 per metric ton, may see a drop as we move toward Northern Hemisphere winter. The colder months typically see a slowdown in iron ore consumption in China, the world's largest user of the metal. With the seasonal slowdown approaching, some analysts see iron heading back to $40 per ton by year's end.

In the US, there is plenty of speculation about the Federal Reserve and its course toward future interest rate policy. Last December, the Fed raised rates by 0.25%, in first such move in nine years and marking a change from monetary easing to monetary tightening. Since then, global economic conditions have been shaky and US economic data has been mixed, making the Fed reluctant to move. In last month's meeting, the central bank hinted that there may be an additional hike later this year.

Wednesday, investors will get a look into the Fed's mind when the minutes for that July meeting are released. Investors and market watchers will look closely to see the Fed's reasoning behind the decision. Additionally, Fed chair Janet Yellen is scheduled to speak on the 26th of this month at the Fed symposium in Jackson Hole, Wyoming. Her words will be carefully parsed.

Most countries are pursuing further easing policies, with some European central banks and the Bank of Japan pushing rates into negative territory. Should the Fed continue to advocate monetary tightening and higher rates, that will be an important divergence in bank policy from the other major economies. So far, futures markets are only putting a 40 to 45% chance of one hike by this year's end.

In the US markets, the main indexes all closed at record high levels yesterday. The Dow gained 0.32% to close at 18,636, the S&P 500 gained 0.28% and closed at 2,190.15, and the NASDAQ gained 0.56% for a 5,262.02 finish.

In the Asia-Pacific region, stocks are not doing as well today. A slowdown in Japans economic growth – readings came in at 0.2%, well below the 0.7% forecast – combined with a planned government stimulus program of 28 trillion yen to fight price deflation, along with a stronger yen, have all pushed the Tokyo stock market down recently. The Nikkei 225 is down 1.62%, while the TOPIX index has lost 1.38%.

China's markets are also down, as weak economic data continues to spark concerns about the world's second largest economy. The CSI 300 index in Shanghai lost 0.55%. In Hong Kong, however, the Hang Seng managed to squeak out a small gain of 0.05%. In Australia, the S&P ASX dipped 0.14%.

In Europe, markets finished mostly in the green yesterday. London's FTSE 100 gained 0.36%, and the DAX was up 0.24%. France's CAC 40 was down slightly, with a loss of 0.05%.

Tomorrow will bring us the minutes from the Federal Reserve's last policy meeting, as well as other US data, including consumer prices, housing starts, industrial output, and oil stockpiles. Expect some market volatility as the reports hit the news.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 21, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_August_21_2016
video.description: Equity markets finished last week down in the US and Europe, and mixed in Asia. The dollar has started to stabilize after heavy losses.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: Equity markets finished last week down in the US and Europe, and mixed in Asia. The dollar has started to stabilize after heavy losses. Oil markets have been boosted by hints of an output freeze by Saudi Arabia.

In the currency markets, the US dollar has managed to pare back some of last week's losses. The dollar was hit hard by conflicting statements from the US Federal Reserve regarding future monetary policy, and by the uncertainty generated. Since then, however, the greenback has stabilized, advancing between 0.25% and 0.75% against the major currencies.

Looking at specific pairs, the USD/JPY bumped up to 100.22, after touching 99 yen. The EUR/USD dipped to 1.1325, and the USD/CHF advanced to 0.9605.

The pound offers a slightly different case. Sterling fell sharply after British PM Theresa May confirmed that her government will be invoking "Article 50" of the Maastricht Treaty, most likely by April of next year. Article 50, of course, is the legal mode by which the UK will exit from the EU, per last June's referendum results.

The pound slipped against the dollar, sending the GBP/USD to 1.3075, and also against the Euro, putting the EUR/GBP at 0.8665.

Oil prices seem to have leveled off near the $50 handle, after gaining almost 20% over the last ten days. The gain started when Saudi Arabia hinted that it would consider future production cuts at an informal OPEC meeting next month. Crude prices immediately jumped, as traders grasped at any chance for higher returns.

There's a question in this for oil traders: Why is the Saudi's statement pushing up oil prices?

The oil market fundaments – high production, soft demand, and overtaxed storage facilities – all point toward lower prices. A production cut by Saudi Arabia now will do nothing to alleviate that; the Kingdom is pumping oil at record levels – an estimated 10.9 million barrels per day this month, versus 10.67 million in July. Saudi Arabia chose to push production up and prices down two years ago, in a conscious effort to expand market share. The lower prices are hurting them, and talking up a cut is their way of trying to boost prices. It's not exactly a new trick, having been successfully applied this past April and June.

It's a question worth pondering as oil traders have to decide whether crude is really worth what they are paying. Brent is currently selling for $50.88 per barrel, and WTI, the US benchmark, stands at $48.52.

The US dollar was the only asset hit by the Fed's indecision. Gold has been pushed down by the possibility that the US central bank could raise rates. The metal rallied strongly in the first half of this year, but has slipped in recent trading sessions. It is now selling for $1,341.47 per ounce. Silver and platinum are also down, at $19.31 and $1,114.30 respectively.

In the world's stock markets, the main indexes were down in the US and Europe and at the end of Friday's trading. Asia-Pacific markets showed more mixed results. Trading was volatile during the sessions.

Looking at the numbers, the Dow Jones lost 0.24%, the S&P 500 fell 0.14%, and the tech-heavy NASDAQ dropped 0.03%. In Europe, the FTSE 100 fell 0.15%, the DAX dropped 0.55%, and the CAC 40 lost 0.82%.

Asia's trading saw some losses in China, where the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong lost 0.37%. On the mainland, Shanghai's CSI 300 managed to pick up 0.02%. Tokyo's markets benefited from the weaker yen, as the Nikkei gained 0.36% and the TOPIX added 0.38%.

video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: Monday, 22 August 2016, was an uneventful day for traders. Investors temporized unwilling to make significant moves before the Federal Reserve’s meeting at the end of the week, where new information about a rate increase is expected to be revealed. Falling oil prices also undermined investors’ enthusiasm and deflated their hopes that the crisis with oil oversupply can be diffused. Analysts claim that even if an agreement about the curtailment of oil production is achieved, this would prove to be counterproductive for OPEC, because the agreement might lead to further price gains and an increase of supply from other producers. Investors’ inactivity contributed to markets’ volatility. After having shuttled between gains and losses for the largest part of the trading day, stocks around the world eventually moved to the negative territory. Weakened by falling prices of copper and other metals, mining companies bore the brunt of losses. The US indices were mixed, The Dow Jones industrials declined 0.1%; the S&P lost as much. The NASDAQ closed 0.1% up. On Tuesday morning, the Dow Jones and the NASDAQ remained the same. The S&P was 0.06% down. Similarly mixed were European indices Monday. The FTSE shed 0.4%. The SMI added 0.4%. The CAC retreated 0.2%. The DAX edged 0.5% lower. Tuesday morning, however, brought some improvement to indices in Europe. At the beginning of the day, the FTSE rose 0.52%; the DAX added 0.63%; the CAC advanced 0.61%.

On Tuesday morning, the US dollar retreated against all of its major counterparts: the Canadian dollar, the Swiss franc, the yen, the euro, the pound, and the Australian dollar. On Monday evening, the US dollar gained against the yen, the euro, the Canadian dollar, and the Swiss franc. It lost on Monday against the pound and the Australian dollar.

At the afternoon London fixing on Monday, gold lost US$10.50 to US$1,335.90. On Tuesday morning, however, precious metal climbed. Gold appreciated US$2.77 to US$1,341.86. Silver rose US$0.16 to reach US$19.02. Platinum added US$3.77 to US$1,106.97. On Monday afternoon, Copper futures dropped 1.2% to US$2.15. WTI spot declined US$1.47 to US$47.05. Dated Brent crude was US$1.70 down to US$49.18. On Tuesday morning, however, Copper futures added 0.15% to US$2.15.

The US Market. After Pfizer offered to buy Medivation, an American biopharmaceutical company focused on rapid development of novel therapies, for $14 billion, shares of the latter jumped. The success of Medivation rubbed off onto other biotechnology companies: Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, Vertex Pharmaceuticals, and Alexion Pharmaceuticals climbed, too, as a result. Syngenta, a global Swiss agribusiness that produces agrochemicals and seeds, advanced. Negatively influenced by dipping oil prices, Marathon Oil and Halliburton sank.

European Market. Thanks to the US dollar’s higher position against the euro, automakers did well on Monday. Having shown a record half-yearly performance, Kingspan Group surged. Persimmon Homes added. After it fired its chief executive, Alex Myers, Getinge, a Swedish medical technology group, appreciated. Because commodities were low, brought down by growing dollar, mining companies had a slide: Anglo American, BHP Billiton, Glencore, and Rio Tinto dropped. Weakened by low gold prices on Monday, Fresnillo, a Mexican-based precious metals mining company, plummeted.  

Asia-Pacific Market. The Shanghai Composite retreated 0.7%, because the yuan sank to its two week low against the US dollar. The Hang Seng rose 0.3%. The falling yen helped the Nikkei gain. The index was 0.3% higher on Monday. As a corollary, exporters appreciated. Hitachi, Honda Motor, Panasonic, Sharp, Sony, and Toyota Motor ended the trading day in the green. Renesas Electronics slipped because of rumours that it is going to purchase the US chipmaker Intersil. In Australia, the S&P/ASX inched 0.2%. The All Ordinaries lost as much. Even though it revealed excellent full year profits, Fortescue Metals decreased. BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto tumbled. Due to falling oil prices, Santos and Beach Energy slid. Big banks - ANZ, Westpac, and Commonwealth – closed lower. Weakened by the falling yen, the Kospi shed 0.7%. The Sensex was 0.3% down.

The US and Japan are showing Flash August manufacturing PMIs. France, Germany, and the Eurozone are giving Flash composite PMIs. The UK is publishing the UK August CBI industrial trends survey. The US is also releasing July new home sales and August Richmond Fed manufacturing index.

video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: Trading volume was light on Wednesday, 24 August 2016. After the energetic Tuesday, investors relapsed into inactivity reluctant to make significant moves ahead of Fed Chair Janet Yellen’s speech on Friday. The possibility that Federal Reserve will increase rate weighted on investors’ minds and prevented them from enjoying trading. Material and mining companies dragged the US and European markets down. Even the banks’ upbeat performance could not redress losses in Europe. Oil prices continued dropping negatively influencing energy stocks. American indices retreated. The Dow Jones shed 0.4%. The S&P dipped 0.5%. The NASDAQ decreased 0.8%. In Europe, indices did slightly better. The FTSE sank 0.5%. The DAX edged 0.3% higher. The CAC added as much. The SMI remained the same.
The US dollar declined against most of its major counterparts: the euro, the yen, the Swiss franc, the Australian dollar, and the Canadian dollar. It gained only against the British pound.

Because everyone is cautious ahead of Janet Yellen’s Friday announcement, doubting that the economy is conducive to a rate increase, precious metals slightly went up. Gold on Thursday morning added 0.11% to US$1,325.56. Silver advanced 0.05% to US$18.57. Platinum was 0.17% higher to 1,081.13. WTI crude edged 0.30% higher to US$46.91. Brent crude rose 0.18% to 49.14. Copper was 0.41% up to US$2.09.

US Market. Glencore, a mining company headquartered in Europe, disappointed everyone with poor results. Glencore revealed a 66% decline in first-half profit and, at present, is selling off its assets in order to pay its debts. The poor performance of the company dragged other miners into the negative territory. Freeport-McMoRan and Newmont Mining slumped. Having reported low sales compared to the last year, Express also declined. Because its full year forecast was below expectations, TurboTax and QuickBooks also slid. Mylan, a global generic and specialty pharmaceuticals company, lost 5.41% as a result of price increase for its EpiPen medicine that treats allergy. Other healthcare companies also suffered a drop as a corollary of Mylan’s retreat.

European Market. Banks had a good day jumping higher. Commerzbank, Deutsche Bank, Société Générale, BNP Paribas, and Crédit Agricole ended the day in the positive territory. Glencore is about to sell a 30% stake in the Ernest Henry copper-gold mine in Australia to Evolution Mining for A$880 million. Other miners and gold-miners - Randgold Resources, Fresnillo, Anglo American Antofagasta, and Rio Tinto – followed suit and decreased. Because it demonstrated a good pre-tax profit and increased revenues, WPP Group soared. Thanks to the upbeat new home sales reports received on Tuesday, homebuilding companies continued advancing. Persimmon, Berkeley Group, and Taylor Wimpey finished the day in the green.

Asia-Pacific Market. Stocks were mixed here. The Shanghai Composite inched 0.1% lower, since monetary policy is, in all likelihood, not going to be eased by China’s Central Bank. The Hang Seng sank 0.8%. Thanks to the falling yen, the Nikkei climbed 0.6%. Nippon Electric Glass, Astellas Pharma, Advantest, and Dainippon Screen Manufacturing were up. Honda Motor, Mazda, Nissan, Toyota also appreciated. Fast Retailing again slid. In Australia, the S&P/ASX inched 0.1% higher. The All Ordinaries added as much. The big banks surged. Unlike mining companies in Europe, miners in the Asia-Pacific region added. BHP Billiton, South32, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group finished the trading day higher. After having posted an excellent full year profit, Qantas Airways jumped. Because it showed a low full year profit, Boral, a building materials firm, slipped. The South Korean Kospi depreciated 0.3%. The Sensex was 0.2% higher.

The Kansas City Fed symposium begins in Jackson Hole, Wyoming on Friday, 26 August 2016. The US is publishing July durable goods orders and weekly jobless claims along with Fed balance sheet and money supply. The UK is giving the CBI distributive trades survey. Germany is giving the August Ifo survey.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 30, 2016

video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: Stocks did well on Monday, the 29 of August 2016, in the US, but went slightly lower in Europe and Asia. In the US, trading was invigorated by highly positive consumer reports for July. The data showed that consumer spending, most essential for the economic development of the country, has steadily been growing for the last four months. And even though the same reports simultaneously pointed to an increase in the personal savings rate indicative of the possible reduction of consumer spending in future, investors considered the consumption data to be a good beginning of the third quarter. The US stocks jumped led by banks and other financial companies. Banks appreciated on Monday in the wake of the Fed Reserve’s intention to introduce a rate rise in September. All big banks -- JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, Bank of America, and Goldman Sachs - gained. The US indices finished the trading day in the green. The Dow Jones industries rose 0.6%. The S&P advanced 0.5%. The NASDAQ edged 0.3% higher. The European indices fared worse than their American counterparts. The CAC declined 0.4%. The DAX lost as much. The SMI edged 0.2% down. The FTSE was closed for the Bank Holiday. The US dollar continued raising. Crude oil prices continued sinking, brought lower by Iraq’s intention to carry on pumping more oil.

The US dollar is still up against all its major counterparts – the euro, the pound, the Swiss franc, the Australian dollar, the Canadian dollar, and the yen. Its biggest gains are against the yen, because investors are preferring to rely now more on the dollar than on the yen.

Because Federal Reserve Chairwoman, Professor Janet Yellen, implied that rates would be increased as early as in September, metals came under pressure. Overall, gold shed 2.1% in July, thereby changing its trajectory that had moved upward until May. Even though precious metals were higher on the early Tuesday than during the previous night, they were still in the red. Gold was 0.18% down to reach US$1,320.96. Silver shed 0.37% to US$18.79. Platinum edged 0.30% lower to US$1,073.98. Oil is trading slightly higher than last week, when it went even dipper, once investors realised that Saudi Arabia had self-servingly talked up oil prices and Iran would not budge and would not stop pumping. Brent Crude is up 0.55%, trading at $49.53 per barrel. WTI Crude added 0.64% to reach US47.28. Copper retreated 0.14% to US$2.07.

US Market. Herbalife’s largest shareholder denied that he had ever intended to sell his stocks. After he had bought 2.3 million shares, the company advanced 4.52%. Micron Technology also soared, adding 2.42% on Tuesday morning. Allegheny Technologies had a jump of 11.11%.

European Market. Unlike banks in the US, banks in Europe were planted in the negative territory on Monday. Having agreed to sell its Argentinian subsidiary, Deutsche Bank slipped. Because its chairman was no longer at the supervisory board, Stada, a pharmaceutical company, decreased on Monday but gained 2.12% on early Tuesday. A signed contract with Amtrak to build new high-speed trains helped Alstom’s shares go higher. On Tuesday morning, Alstom was 0.10% up. Because its Zika virus test had been authorised by the US Food and Drug Administration, Roche Holdings advanced 0.33%.

Asia-Pacific Market. Thanks to Janet Yellen’s promise to introduce a rate increase this year and the Bank of Japan’s announcement that stimulus would be expanded, if needed, the dollar-yen pair strengthened. The Nikkei grew 2.3% pushed by the good performance of exporters. Canon, Honda Motor, Toyota, and Mazda Motor were among the winners on Monday. The S&P/ASX tumbled 0.8%. The All Ordinaries lost as much. Banks did as poorly in Asia as they did in Europe. Negatively influenced by sinking prices of gold, Newcrest Mining, Norther Star Resources, and Evolution Mining depreciated. Thanks to falling oil prices and the unsolvable problem with the oil supply, energy stocks took a plunge too. Oil Search, Origin Energy, and Woodside Petroleum were in the red. The Shanghai Composite lost minor 0.28 points. The Hang Seng decreased 0.4%. The Kospi shed 0.3% due to the growing dollar. The Sensex climbed 0.4%.
The US is publishing August consumer confidence. The Eurozone is giving final EC business and consumer sentiment. Japan is revealing July household spending, unemployment, and retail sales data.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 31, 2016

video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: Global stock markets were mixed on Tuesday, 30 August 2016, with European and Asian stocks appreciating and with the US market again characterised by low-volume, unenthusiastic trading. Poorly performing technological companies arrested the US market’s upward movement caused by banks’ gains. Investors around the world continued worrying about interest rates, the timing of which increase is still disturbingly uncertain. Friday’s employment report, bound to influence policymakers’ decision, is another event that weighted on investors’ minds. The indices in the US declined. The Dow Jones was lower 0.3%. The S&P retreated 0.2%. The NASDAQ lost as much. In Europe, apart from the British FTSE that edged 0.3% lower, all other indices advanced. The CAC rose 0.8%. The DAX was 1.1% up. The SMI added 0.6%. On Wednesday morning, however, the DAX and the CAC joined the losers, shedding 0.28% and 0.05% respectively. The US dollar was again strong, while the euro showed signs of weakness. Commodities suffered from the strength of the former. European exporters capitalized on the weakness of the latter.

The US dollar was up against all its major counterparts – the euro, the Swiss franc, the Canadian dollar, the Australian dollar, the pound, and the yen. The yen still suffers the biggest decline. The pound is strengthening a bit. Other currencies, even growing slightly today, are still losing against the US dollar.

Precious metals were doing better on Wednesday morning than they did on Tuesday afternoon. On Tuesday, gold lost US$0.60 to reach US$1,318.15. On Wednesday morning, it rose US$1.85 to US$1,312.96, though it is still significantly down on the month. Silver advanced 0.73% to US$18.81. Platinum added 0.21% to US$1,059.30. WTI Crude oil was down US$0.15 yesterday and US$0.19 today in the morning, trading at US$46.20. Brent Crude lost US$0.29 on Tuesday and US$0.22 to reach US$48.15 on Wednesday morning. Copper sank 0.1% on Tuesday but gained 0.14% on Wednesday morning to US$2.07.

US Market. The deal between Mondelez and Hershey failed to materialize. Mondelez withdrew the offer to buy Hershey that he had made in summer. Mondelez gained 3.95%. Hershey decreased 10.76%. After the European Union had ordered Apple to pay back taxes ($14.5 billion) to Ireland, Apple dropped 0.77%. Having shown poor results in the second quarter and having announced that it would close 60 stores, Abercrombie & Fitch shed 20.31%. Gap was 4.31% lower. Urban Outfitters also dipped, losing 2.53%.

European Market. In contrast to their poor yesterday performance, European banks -- Deutsche Bank, Commerzbank, Société Générale, BNP Paribas, and Crédit Agricole – rose. Automakers again did well. Volkswagen, BMW, Daimler, Peugeot, and Renault stayed in the positive territory. Despite its high half-year profit and revenues, Bunzl, a company that distributes business supplies, edged 0.21% lower. Associated British Foods soared. Because its prognosis for the yearly profits is pessimistic, Braemar Shipping Services tumbled. Thanks to the growing dollar, miners suffered. Antofagasta, Anglo American, Rio Tinto, Glencore, and BHP Billiton ended the trading day in the red. Gold miners -- Randgold Resources and Fresnillo – also slipped, losing 2.17% and 1.95% respectively.

Asia-Pacific Market. As was the case in Europe, banks in Asia, including Mitsubishi UFJ Financial, Mizuho Financial and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial, had a good day and boosted the Shanghai Composite 0.2% up. They also brought Hang Seng 0.9% higher. Because July household spending and retail sales were depressingly low and because the unemployment rate was as low as it had not been in two decades, The Nikkei inched 0.1% down. East Japan Railway, Asahi Group, NTT DoCoMo, and Softbank slipped. Hitachi advanced. In Australia, the S&P/ASX added 0.2%. The All Ordinaries gained as much. Banks were mixed. ANZ, Commonwealth, and NAB appreciated. Westpac experienced a decline. Santos and Woodside Petroleum were slightly up thanks to better oil prices on Tuesday. Ramsay Health Care ended the trading day in the green. The Kospi surged 0.4%. The Sensex soared 1.6%.

The US is issuing August ADP private employment and Chicago PMI. It is also giving July pending home sales index and weekly EIA petroleum status report. Canada is posting June monthly and second quarter GDP. The Eurozone is reporting on August flash harmonized index of consumer prices and July unemployment. Germany is announcing August unemployment. Japan is issuing July industrial production.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 01, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_01_2016
video.description: Equity markets finished last week down in the US and Europe, and mixed in Asia. The dollar has started to stabilize after heavy losses.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: On Wednesday, the 31st of August 2016, global markets repeated the pattern observable on the previous day, Tuesday. The US market dropped again. Both European and Asian markets were again mixed. As it has been the case almost for the whole month of August, trading was lacklustre. Suffering from falling oil prices, energy companies were again in decline. Chemical companies dropped equally low. Disheartened by lack of clarity surrounding a promised rates hike, investors lowered their activities at markets, refusing to make moves before the publication of the employment report on Friday. The persistent problem with oil oversupply continued driving everyone out of humour. In the Asia-Pacific region, Japanese stocks performed well lifted by the weakening yen and unexpectedly optimistic US consumer confidence data. Australian stocks, undermined by the rapid selling of resource shares, limited the upside, however, and pushed the whole market lower. The Dow Jones industrials shed 0.3% on Wednesday afternoon and remained equally low on Thursday morning. The S&P dropped 0.2% on both days. The NASDAQ sank 0.2% on Wednesday but inched a bit higher on Thursday morning. In August overall, the Dow Jones lost 0.2%. The S&P was 0.1% lower. The NASDAQ was the only index that finished the month in the green, adding 1.0%. On Wednesday, the FTSE declined 0.6% but rallied on Thursday morning, adding 0.31%. The DAX slipped 0.6% on Wednesday but was 0.74% up in the morning on Thursday. The CAC first retreated 0.4% but rose 1.16% on Thursday. The SMI, likewise, had a 0.4% slide on Wednesday. For the whole month of August, the CAC remained virtually unchanged. The FTSE added 0.8%. The DAX jumped 2.5%. The SMI edged 0.9% higher in the last month of summer.

On Wednesday, the US dollar lost its leadership among other currencies maintained by it almost through the whole week and retreated against the euro, pound, and the Australian dollar. The US dollar remained unchanged against the Australian dollar and advanced against the week yen and the falling Canadian dollar.

The strong dollar continued pressurising precious metals that did poorly on Wednesday but managed to inch slightly higher on Thursday morning. On Wednesday afternoon, gold dropped US$8.90 to US$1,309.25. Copper was unchanged trading at US$2.08. WTI spot crude lost US$1.54 to US$44.81. Dated Brent spot crude shed US$1.33 to US$47.04. On Thursday morning, commodities charts looked more upbeat: apart from gold, all major commodities were in the positive territory. Silver was 0.02% up to reach US$18.73. Platinum advanced US$0.39 to US$1,502.50. WTI spot crude was 0.08% higher to US$46.91. Copper added 1.00% to US$2.08.

US Market. Because it had sold its bank business and reported losses in the first-quarter, H&R Block sank 10.50%. Having demonstrated low sales, Brown-Forman Corporation, an American company that produces spirits and wine, shed 3.54%. Thanks to the accumulation of crude oil stockpiles that already reached 2.3 million barrels this week, energy stocks tumbled. Chevron kept on dipping losing 1.10% on Wednesday. Exxon Mobil declined 0.43%. Schlumberger followed suit and finished the day 2.03% lower.

European Market. Due to falling prices of gold, mining stocks continue sinking, as did gold-mining companies. Anglo American, BHP Billiton, Fresnillo, Antofagasta, Glencore, Rio Tinto, and Randgold Resources slipped. Banks were again in the green. Commerzbank and Deutsche Bank did particularly well on Wednesday on rumours that they might merge. Société Générale, Crédit Agricole, and BNP Paribas also advanced. Barclays, HSBC Holdings, and Lloyds Banking Group soared bolstered by good reports on the healing British economy.

Asia-Pacific Market. Property stocks jumped and brought the Shanghai Composite up 0.4%. Hang Seng, by contrast, shed 0.2%. In August, the former index was 3.6% higher. The latter advanced 5.0%. Helped by the weakened yen, the Nikkei rose 1.0% on Wednesday but was slightly lower on Thursday morning (up 0.23%). Exporters gained as they usually do, when the yen falls. Canon, Panasonic, Toshiba, and Mazda Motor finished the trading session in the positive territory. After the Nikkei had said that Google was going to make a deal with Japan’s largest bank to launch its digital wallet platform, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial soared. Australian indices were in trouble hit by the stronger dollar. Both the S&P/ASX and the All Ordinaries had a 0.8% slide. On Wednesday morning, the S&P/ASX gained a bit but not enough to move out of the negative sphere, being 0.32% lower. For the month of August, both S&P/ASX and the All Ordinaries decreased 2.0%. Even though iron prices started to recover from losses, mining companies retreated. BHP Billiton, Fortescue Metals, and Rio Tinto tumbled. Gold-mining companies did too, negatively affected by low prices of gold. Newcrest Mining, Evolution Mining, Northern Star Resources, and Regis Resources slumbered. The Kospi ended the day 0.2% lower but appreciated 0.9% in August as a whole. The Sensex reached its highest level in more than a year, going 0.4% up on Wednesday. The Indian index advanced 1.4% in August.

The US is publishing second quarter productivity & costs, August manufacturing PMI, the ISM manufacturing index, and July construction spending. It is also giving weekly jobless claims, money supply, and Fed balance sheet. In Asia, China is publishing August CFLP and Market manufacturing PMIs. Japan and India are reporting on final August manufacturing PMI. Australia is giving July retail sales and quarterly new capital expenditures data. Eurozone, Germany, France, Italy, and the UK are posting final manufacturing PMIs.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 04, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_04_2016
video.description: Equity markets finished last week down in the US and Europe, and mixed in Asia. The dollar has started to stabilize after heavy losses.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: Thursday, 1 September 2016, was again a slow day charged with anxiety over the forthcoming Friday US August job reports liable to make an impact on Federal Reserve’s decision whether to increase rates this year. Trajectories of global markets were different on Thursday. Starting lower, the US stocks managed to gather strength during the day and entered the positive territory by its closure. European stocks moved in a polar opposite direction, starting the day optimistically but declining as trading progressed, negatively influenced by a bad beginning of the trading day in the US. Like European market, the Asian stocks also finished mostly in the red, even though oil prices jumped in the region and China published the best CFLP manufacturing PMI in almost two years -- it jumped to 50.4. In the US, by contrast, manufacturing data was surprisingly poor. Manufacturing activities fell from 52.6 in July to 49.4 in August. Vehicle sales were also disappointing, having dropped from 17.9 million in July to 17.0 million in the last day of summer. Indices in the US inched slightly higher, with the Dow Jones industrial adding 0.1% and with the NASDAQ jumping 0.3%. The S&P did not change. Indices in Europe slid. The FTSE shed 0.5%. The DAX dropped 0.6%. The SMI dipped 0.7%. The CAC remained the same from the day before. IBEX in Spain climbed 0.5%, even though, in all likelihood, Spanish Prime Minister will not be elected for a second term.
Thursday was a bad day for the US dollar. It slipped against all its major counterparts – the yen, the British pound, the Swiss franc, the Australian dollar, the Canadian dollar, and the euro.

On Thursday afternoon, major commodities were mixed. Gold appreciated US$0.25 to reach US$1,309.50. Copper futures remained at US$2.08. WTI spot crude declined US$1.19 to US$43.51. Dated Brent spot crude lost US$1.15 to US$45.74.

US Market. Retailers did poorly on Thursday, weakened by bad reports from Costco Wholesale and Campbell Soup. Although these two companies managed to rally on Friday, on Thursday, their shares significantly fell. Both of the companies reported weak sales in August. Salesforce.com boasted good profits but also slipped undermined by its third-quarter guidance. Energy stocks continued slipping, brought lower by falling oil prices. Only material companies were in the green, thereby reining in the market’s downward drifting. Because the Brazilian Oil company Petrobras had announced the premature termination of its contract with Diamond Offshore Drilling, the stocks of the latter sank. Thanks to its good second-quarter reports, Ollie’s Bargain Outlet Holdings appreciated. Charter Communications that had recently bought Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks also climbed.

European Market. After solid gains during the week, banks were mixed. Commerzbank continued appreciating. Deutsche Bank, by contrast, ended the day lower. Thanks to new complaints about its emission testing filed in Australia, Volkswagen lost on Thursday. E.ON dipped, and so did RWE. After it reported a 2.0% rise in full-year profit, Pernod Ricard added 1.57%. Technicolor also advanced. Having placed $650 million convertible bonds due 2023, Inmarsat climbed. Stocks of Hays retreated, after the company warned about the unstable condition of its UK and Irish markets. Low oil prices pulled Royal Dutch Shell and BP down.

Asia-Pacific Market. The Shanghai Composite shed 0.7% mainly due to the falling stocks of financial and property developers. The Hang Seng, by contrast, did well on Thursday, adding 0.8%. Thanks to the weak yen, the Nikkei rose, as always helped by exporters. Takeda Pharma, Kawasaki Heavy Industries, and Alps Electric soared. Just as they did in Europe, energy shares dipped also in the Asia-Pacific region. Inpex had a slide along with Japan Petroleum. Santos and Origin Energy finished in the negative territory as well. Australian indices tumbled. The S&P/ASX dropped 0.3%. The All Ordinaries lost as much. Mining companies retreated, just as energy shares did. Hit by iron ore prices that had sank to their four-week low, Rio Tinto slumped. Banks -- Westpac, NAB, and ANZ -- managed to reap gains. Woolworths also advanced. The Kospi edged 0.1% down. The Sensex was equally low.

The Eurozone is publishing July producer price indices. The US is giving July international trade data, and so is Canada. The US is also reporting on August employment situation and on July factory orders.

video.author: saar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 05, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_September_05_2016
video.description: Equity markets finished last week down in the US and Europe, and mixed in Asia. The dollar has started to stabilize after heavy losses.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, US dollar, oil, gold

content-body.text: On Friday, 02 September 2016, the long-awaited US report came and pushed the stocks higher but not because it brought good news. Quite the contrary, the report showed that far less than expected jobs had been created at the job market in August. There was an addition of only 151,000 jobs, which is lesser than 275,000 jobs added in July. The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 4.9%. Investors, however, shrugged the upsetting news off, explaining the insufficient growth of jobs as seasonally inevitable. August reports traditionally come out weaker than in other months. Poor employment reports failed to drive investors out of humour also because they are expected to prevent Federal Reserve policymakers from pushing rates higher in September. Investors’ nonchalant attitude to the bad job reports became more soar, however, at the beginning of the week, causing the dollar to plummet on Monday. All indices advanced on Friday. American indices appreciated 0.4% on Friday. Since the last week, the Dow Jones industrials soared 0.5%. The S&P also rose 0.5%. The NASDAQ was 0.6% higher for the week. In Europe, all indices also jumped on the last trading day of the week and remained equally high on Monday morning as well. The FTSE soared 2.2%. The CAC appreciated 2.3%. The DAX was 1.4% higher. The SMI climbed 1.9%. Since the previous week, the FTSE rose 0.8%; the CAC added 2.3%. The DAX edged 0.9% higher. The SMI was 1.5% up.
The US dollar declined against all its major counterparts on Monday morning – the euro, the yen, the Swiss franc, the Australian dollar, the Canadian dollar, and the British pound.

On Monday morning, all major commodities were in the green. Gold added US1.59 to US$1,326.80. Silver advanced 0.54% to US$19.47. Platinum appreciated 0.41% to US$1,068.25. WTI Crude Oil advanced 0.87% to US$45.31. Brent Crude rose 0.11% to reach US$46.88. Copper soared US$0.70 to US$2.08.

US Market. Oil prices rose slightly and immediately brought shares of energy companies higher. Stocks of tobacco, steel, and telecom companies were also in the green on Friday. Utilities companies also did well. Biotechnical and pharmaceutical companies tumbled, knocked down by Hillary Clinton’s new pricing plan. Mylan lost 4.65%. Companies that make household goods jumped. Colgate-Palmolive added 0.83%. Tyson Foods rose 1.27%. Reynolds American gained 1.93%. Altria Group was 0.85% higher.
