Oil prices fell on Monday pulled down by doubts over a possibility of finding a solution for oil glut that has been vexing the world in 2016. The West Texas Intermediate slipped 0.77%, trading at US$49.33 on Monday morning. Brent Crude futures lost 0.77% and traded at US$51.48. Shanghai Gold Exchange reopened today and arrested gold’s decline. Gold for December delivery rose 0.82%; silver for December delivery gained 2%; copper for December delivery advanced 0.18%. On Monday, gold traded at US$1,263.53 per ounce; silver reached US$17.74; platinum appreciated 0.45% to US$972.39; Copper was US$2.16.

European Market. Reduced oil prices negatively influenced oil, gas, and energy companies throughout Europe. In France, oil and gas company Total shed 0.43%. ENI in Italy also slid, losing 0.15%. The Norwegian Statoil was also in the red, having dropped 0.36% during Monday session. Banks also did poorly and dragged other financial shares down with themselves. BNP Paribas closed 0.89% lower. Societe Generale also retreated 1.06%. Even though it continues actively negotiating the price of the fine with the Department of Justice, Deutsche Bank plummeted. The troublesome Commerzbank also slid 2.02%. Italian and Spanish banks followed suit and moved into negative territory. Equally poorly banks did in the UK. Only HSBC appreciated on Monday. Other Banks – the Royal Bank of Scotland, Lloyds Banking, and Barclays – depreciated 1.62%, 1.68%, and 2.07% respectively. Severely criticised by investors, E.ON slumped 0.46%. After the renewables unit, Innogy, appeared at markets on Friday, RWE dropped. Miners and Gold Mining companies in London rose helped by higher metal prices. Glencore, Fresnillo, and Randgold Resources finished in the green. The first gained 0.50%; the second added 1.80%, and the third was 1.84% higher. After having cancelled all its flights to and from Greece, in the aftermath of which thousands of passengers remained stuck in airports, EasyJet tumbled 2.03%.

Asia-Pacific Market. Indian market celebrated advancement of the majority of its stocks. Metal producing companies rose and positively affected Indian market overall. National Aluminium rose 6.72%. Hindalco was 1.96% higher. What else helped the market soar is the Reserve Bank of India’s monetary policy revealed last week. Contrary to everyone’s expectations, the Reserve Bank of India cut interest rates to a five-year low. Monthly inflation data arriving on Thursday and Friday is also expected to give a boost to the Sensex. The Sensex reined in its three day retreat and edged 0.4% up. Foreign investors continue contributing to Indian market’s wellbeing. Stocks in Australia managed to close higher, even those some companies sank on Monday. Thanks to the growth of gold and other metals, mining and gold mining companies rallied. BT advanced 7.66%. Resolute Mining jumped 5.20%. Syrah Res F closed the trading day 5.14% higher. Independence Group, an Australian mining company, did badly, by contrast, shedding 4.98%. Infigen Energy experienced a 4.22% slide. Advancing Telecoms Services, however, which rose 1.05%, helped the market stay in positive territory. The Nikkei were 0.23% down. The Hang Seng also slipped 0.42%.

video.author: sa ar
video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: October 20, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review:_October_20_2016
video.description: Oil eased but still was at its record high, trading at US$51.07 a barrel. Gold was also at two-weeks high. Stocks were mixed in Europe but high in Asia and the US. The dollar is mostly up. The euro and pound were down.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, oil, the pound, the euro, the Central European Bank’s announcement, monetary policy, the Federal Reserve’s Beige Book.

content-body.text: The Federal Reserve’s latest Beige Book painted the upbeat picture of the US economy. It maintained that America had slow but definitely steady economic growth from August and October. A labour market is defined as “tight”; growth of salaries is described as “modest.” According to the Beige Book, inflation in the US is mild, retail sales are higher, and consumer spending is mixed. Energy was also characterised positively. In addition, the Beige Book praised the expansion of real estate and the improvement of commercial activities in the country. The bright picture the Beige Book presented to investors cheered them up and brought the majority of stocks higher. Oil eased slightly on profit taking but still was high, as was gold that dipped in comparison to its Wednesday price but remained at a two-week highs on Thursday morning. Both commodities positively influenced the activities at markets around the globe. European market was mixed, weakened by the FTSE’s slide. American and Asian markets, by contrast, were in the positive territory. The Dow Jones rose 0.22%. The S&P 500 was equally high. The NASDAQ edged 0.05% higher. The DAX advanced 0.21%. The CAC inched 0.07% up. Because shares of Travis Perkins that announced the liquidation of nearly 600 jobs in 30 branches tumbled 2.46%, the FTSE ended in the red. Asian markets rose. Metals and Mining companies pushed Australian stocks higher, even though the Australian dollar lost 0.5% against the US dollar, after data had shown that employment in Australia decreased by 9,800 in September. The S&P/ASX added 0.12%. Nikkei 225 appreciated 1.39%. The Hang Seng gained 0.33%.

The euro eased 0.1% and was 1.0969 versus the dollar, which is only slightly better than its price on Wednesday, when it dipped to its three-month low. The Australian dollar declined 0.5% and traded at 0.7657 per the greenback. The pound was still down. The GBP/USD dollar traded at 1.2277. The greenback also rose against its Canadian counterpart, which was 1.3169 on Thursday morning. The yen traded at 103.77 against the dollar. The Mexican peso jumped, as Clinton’s prospects to win the Presidential election strengthened.

Oil was slightly lower on Thursday morning than on the previous day. Yet it still maintained a nearly fifteen-month high position. Oil prices were supported by the drastic drop of US supplies. Last week, supplies dipped by 5.25 million barrels, thereby hitting the lowest level since January. Oil prices are held high also by the optimism voiced by Energy Minister of Saudi Arabia, who said that many countries are willing to reduce oil production. On this news, WTI crude traded at $51.07. Brent crude shed 0.95% to reach $52.17. Gold traded at two-weeks high, being $1,268.85 per ounce. Platinum decreased 0.14% to $942.07. Silver inched 0.01% to $17.66. Copper lost 0.75% to $2.09.

US Market. Having said that its quarterly earnings rose to $1.6 billion from last year’s $1.02 billion, Morgan Stanley added 1.89%. American Express, by contrast, published its worst quarterly revenue in five years, pulled down by the loss of its contract with Costco Wholesale. After its stocks slipped on Wednesday, the company managed to move into positive territory, adding 1.95% on Thursday morning. Ebay posted a 5.6% increase in quarterly revenue, which rose from $2.10 billion to $2.22 billion. Its shares advanced 2.78% on Thursday. Energy stocks did well. Transocean, Halliburton, Newfield Exploration, Noble Energy, Chesapeake Energy, and Occidental Petroleum were higher. Not sounding upbeat about its current situation, Intel tumbled 5.93%. After it had reduced its revenue forecast, Manhattan Associates plunged whooping 10.43%. Because of continuous poor sales, Cree decreased 11.07%. Also performing badly, Reynolds American closed 2.07% lower.

European Market. Investors were focused on the European Central Bank’s announcement, though they expected its monetary policy to remain almost certainly unchanged. At the center of their attention was Mario Draghi’s speech, from which investors hoped to glean information concerning the bank’s next policy moves. Financial companies were in the green on Thursday. BNP Paribas edged 0.26%. German Banks – Commerzbank and Deutsche Bank – added 0.34%. Deutsche Lufthansa increased its profit target for the year and soared 2.45%. Having announced that its sales decreased 0.4%, Publicis Groupe shed 4.98%. Stocks in London were also mostly in the red, brought lower by Travis Perkins. The supplier of building materials revealed its plan to close down more than 30 of its branches that would entail the liquidation of more than 600 jobs. After this announcement, the company slumped 2.46%. Nestle in Switzerland also lost 1.34%. Mining companies, however, arrested European market’s further decline. Anglo American gained 0.38%. BHP Billiton was 0.86% higher. Rio Tinto jumped 0.94%.

Asia-Pacific Market. Asian stocks closed higher. The MSCI Asia Pacific added 0.5%, helped by energy shares that overall increased 1.7%. Topix in Japan rose 0.8%. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong appreciated 0.33%. Bolstered by good performance of Real Estate, Banking, and Transportation Equipment companies, Japan market finished higher on Thursday. The Nikkei was 1.39% up, as the session ended, and thus reached a three-months high. Mitsui Fudosan was the best performer at the Nikkei, advancing 4.85%. Tokyo Tatemono increased 4.65%. Because two US companies decided to sell portions of their businesses to Terumo, the latter jumped. Hitachi slipped. Australian markets were planted in positive territory. The greatest news was the merger of Australia’s biggest gambling businesses -- Tabcorp Holdings and Tatts Group. Thanks to high prices of gold, gold miners Newcrest Mining and Evolution Mining surged. Due to high oil prices and hopes that OPEC countries would curtail their oil production, Woodside Petroleum, Santos, and Oil Search ended the trading day in the green.
The US is publishing the October Philadelphia Fed survey together with September existing home sales. It is also giving reports on money supply and Fed balance sheet.

video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: October 26, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: October 26, 2016
video.description: Oil dropped, trading at US$49.45 a barrel. Because of the easing dollar, gold added. Stocks mostly lost. The dollar dropped from its 9 month high. The euro and pound were still down.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, oil, the pound, the euro, the dollar, OPEC, Presidential Elections, crude stocks.

content-body.text: Activities were subdued at global markets before the US Presidential election. Trading of stocks, bonds, and metals slowed down, as investors become increasingly anxious about the outcome of the rivalry between Trump and Clinton. Stocks closed mostly in the red. US market slid, with Dow Jones losing 0.30%, the S&P 500 shedding 0.38%, and the NASDAQ closing 0.50% lower. European markets opened at a low level as well. The FTSE was 0.54% down. The German DAX slipped 0.43%. The CAC sank 0.40%. Asian stocks also pulled back, with the sole exception of the Nikkei that, boosted by the good performance of Precision Instruments, Financial Services, and Construction sectors, soared 0.15%. Weakened Energy and Consumer Discretionary sectors led Australia stocks lower. By the end of the trading day, Australian S&P/ASX declined 1.53%. Good GDP data from South Korea and the weaker yen, however, helped arrest the Asia market’s decline further.

US crude stocks piled. Nigeria increased its oil production. OPEC’s members do not seem to agree on the reduction of oil supply. Iraq asks to be permitted to pump at will, stating that it needs oil to fight the Islamic State. Libya also wants to be exempt from oil cutting, as do Venezuela and Indonesia. Pessimism about the resolution of oil glut problem strengthened among analysts and investors. All these factors conspired to bring oil prices down. Oil sank to a tree-week lows. WTI shed 1.02% to reach US$49.45. Brent Crude declined 0.77% to trade at US$50.40. Because the greenback eased slightly and investors turned their attention to the safe haven, gold jumped to a three-weeks high. It added 0.11% and traded at US$1.275.26. And yet, the outlook for gold prices remains gloomy. Despite its current growth, gold is not expected to rise for long, because there is a strong likelihood that the Federal Reserve will increase rates before the end of the year. Other precious metals were also in positive territory. Silver added 0.25% to US$17.85. Platinum advanced 0.44% to reach US$968.98. Base metals fared worse. Copper futures slipped 0.28% to US$2.13.

The dollar slid from its nine month peak but is still doing relatively well supported by expectations of a rates hike in December. Analysts give 73% to the probability of a rates increase before the end of the year. The dollar index is 0.14% down at 98.55, after it had recently reached 99.09. The greenback also retreated slightly against the yen but managed to stay at 104.13 mark. The euro gained grounds but is still low. The EUR/USD pair traded at 1.0910 on Wednesday. The British pound is still falling. It was 1.2183 per dollar in the morning. Because inflation reading was good and ruled out an interest cut in Australia, the Australian dollar surged. It reached 0.7704 mark. The USD/CAD pair was at 1.3341 on Wednesday.

Stocks fell on Tuesday in America. After it complained about the slowest sales growth in 6 years, Under Armour tumbled whooping 13.22%. Sherwin-Williams shed 10.89%, having posted small profits. Whirlpool’s results were also down, as were its shares. On Tuesday, the manufacturer of home appliances dipped 10.78%. Procter & Gamble was the only company among these losers that advanced, after it posted better results than everyone expected. The company edged 0.13% up. Baker Hughes published relatively good results and promised to cut $650 million in spending, and added 4.30% as a result. General Motors slid 4.21%, even though it boasted strong profits in the last quarter. Having improved its forecasts, Merck jumped. Apple was down 2.99% but managed to rise 0.51% on Wednesday afternoon.

European markets opened lower on Wednesday. Fresenius shed 0.31% along with Fresenius Medical Care, which was down 0.17%. ThyssenKrupp lost, and so did Salzgitter. The former was 3.22% down; the latter declined 2.80%. Orange in France did well. Having said that its profits had surged 24%, Air Liquide still fell 2.15%. After it signed a deal for high-quality thermal coal, Glencore soared on Tuesday but slipped on Wednesday morning. Anglo American tumbled 2.92%. Miners were mixed. Rio Tinto added 1.70%; Antofagasta, by contrast, dipped whooping 7.03%. BHP Billiton decreased 1.51%. Whitbread published good first-half profits but slipped nevertheless. Deploring poor earnings for the seventh quarter, Novartis closed in the red. Because it also gave a poor outlook for the fourth quarter, AMS moved to negative territory.

Stocks were also mostly low. Kyushu Railway advanced. J Front Retailing, Nippon Sheet Glass, Dainippon Screen Manufacturing, Sumitomo Mitsui Trust, TDK, Mitsui Mining & Smelting, and Mitsubishi Motors closed in the green. Hitachi, Nissan Motor, Toyota, Honda Motor, Suzuki Motor, and Mazda also appreciated thanks to the declining yen. Miners did well. NAB published its financial results and soared. Gold mining companies Regis Recourses and Evolution Mining added 2.14% and 0.92% respectively. The Shanghai Composite rose 0.1%. The Hang Seng was 0.98% down. Kospi inched 0.5% lower. The Sensex lost 0.3%.
The US is giving September international trade in goods and new home sales, October flash PMI services, and week EIA petroleum status report.

video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: October 30, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: October 30, 2016
video.description: Oil dropped, trading at US$49.34 a barrel. Gold did not change much during the week. Stocks are mixed in Europe and Asia and down in the US. The dollar was steady. The euro and pound were still down.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, oil, the pound, the euro, the dollar, OPEC, Presidential Elections, crude stocks.

content-body.text: Investors continued playing a waiting game reluctant to act before receiving more information about the Presidential elections and the Federal Reserve’s rates increase. What, however, enlivened markets on Thursday, the 27th of October 2016, was the publication of several economic reports arriving from the US. Initial jobless claims this week experienced a decline from the last week’s 261,000 to 258,000. Durable goods orders in September shed 0.1%. The pending home sales index rose by 1.5% to 110.0 in September from 108.4 in August. Economic data coming from the UK also affected investors’ mood, since it showed that the country’s economy grew faster than anyone anticipated, which suggested that interest rates’ decrease in 2017 is highly unlikely. On this news, treasury yields hit its highest level since May. The dollar also advanced against all its major counterparts. Oil rose slightly from a three-week low, because the Saudi Arabia and other Gulf countries spoke in favour of curbing oil production. Calling on OPEC members to be flexible, the Saudi Arabia promised to reduce its peak oil output by 4%. Although the Saudi Arabia’s pledge immediately influenced oil prices for the better, it is unclear whether cutting of the Kingdom’s oil production by 4% would make a difference for the elimination of oil glut. Despite the Saudi Arabia’s hopefulness, scepticism still prevails among analysts doubtful that OPEC will ever find a solution to the problem with oil oversupply. Reacting to this news, global markets were mixed on Thursday afternoon and Friday morning. The US market was mostly in the red. The Dow Jones Industrials shed 0.16%. The S&P 500 edged 0.30% lower; the NASDAQ sank 0.65%. European stocks advanced overall on Thursday, helped by the strong report on the UK gross domestic product, even though poor Chinese data and mixed earning reports checked in markets’ advance further. On Thursday afternoon, The FTSE rose 0.4%; the DAX was 0.1% higher; and the CAC added minor 1.02 points. The SMI also closed 0.4% higher. On Friday morning, however, European markets moved to negative territory. The FTSE opened 0.24% lower; the DAX lost 0.53%; the CAC slid 0.03%. Asian markets fared better on Friday and ended the trading day mixed. Japan markets advanced pushed higher by the good performance of Finance and Investment, Textile, and Marine Transport sectors. The Nikkei jumped 0.63%. The Hang Seng slumped 0.77%. Australian shares suffered losses due to the decline of the A-REITs, Industrials, and Consumer Staples sectors. At the close, the S&P/ASX dipped 0.22% and thereby hit a one month low. Two days meeting of OPEC members is starting today. Iraq is still insisting on being exempt from oil production freeze and cuts, because it says it needs oil revenue to fight against ISIS. Libya and Nigeria also asked not to be given a pumping quota. Among invited countries, Norway excused itself and said it would not come to the meeting.

Supported by the Saudi Arabia’s promise to cut its oil production by 4%, oil slightly advanced from the recent lows yet traded still below 50 dollars on Friday. West Texas Intermediate for December delivery advanced 1.1% and stabilized on Friday morning at US$49.34. Brent Crude for December advanced around 1% and traded at US$50.23 on Friday. Gold did not change much during this trading week. On Friday, it was 0.12% down to US$1.266.93. Silver also lost 0.11% to trade at US$17.62. Platinum added 0.36% to reach US$967.77. Copper appreciated 0.30% to US$2.17.

The US dollar remained strong. It added 0.7% against the yen. The USD/JPY pair traded at 105.39. The greenback also advanced 0.1% versus the euro. The euro stood at 1.0918 mark against it on Friday. Despite the strong report on the UK gross domestic product, the pound was still low, trading at 1.2137 against the dollar. The Australian dollar slipped 0.03% versus the dollar and steadied at 0.7569 mark. USD/CAD changed hands at 1.3391 and USD/CHF at 0.9942. The dollar index rose 0.2% on Thursday and remained so on Friday. It is poised for 0.3% gain this week.

Qualcomm made a deal to purchase NXP Semiconductors for US$38 billion and immediately jumped, bringing NXP Semiconductors up with itself. Qualcomm advanced 2.77%; NXP Semiconductors was 0.37% higher. Raytheon presented a disappointing outlook and was flat on Friday. Having pushed the US market higher on Wednesday, Boeing dipped on Thursday but then managed to regain its position in the positive territory, appreciating 0.24% on Friday morning. Bristol-Myers Squibb boasted good sales and large profits from its drugs Opdivo and Eliquis and climbed 0.27%. Tesla Motors extended its gains. Ford Motor complained about low quarterly profit. It slipped 0.09% as a result. GNC Holdings dipped for the same reason. After it said that more users started to twit, Twitter advanced 0.52%.

Even though its third-quarter profit decreased, BASF, the largest chemical company, was 0.02% in the green. Thanks to unexpectedly high profits in the third quarter, Deutsche Bank was 0.21% higher on Friday. Schneider Electric slipped due to a decline in the third-quarter revenue. After a good report, shares of Technip advanced 0.76%. Thanks to earnings that exceeded everyone’s expectations, Barclays climbed 0.37%. Barclays’ profits were around £1.7 billion. Lloyds fell badly on Wednesday and remained 0.03% in the red on Friday afternoon. Barratt Developments was in negative territory on Thursday but moved out of it on the last trading day of the week. On Friday, the company was 3.80% in the green. Berendsen, a provider of textile maintenance services, tumbled 4.71%. Shares of Nokia decreased 3.70%, after the maker of network equipment showed poor third quarter results.

Bad performance of Information Technology, Services, and Construction & Engineering services caused Shri Lanka market to slide. At the close, the CSE All-Share slipped 0.21%. Among the biggest losers were SMB Leasing PLC that tumbled whooping 12.50%. Kalamazoo Systems PLC followed suit and also dipped deeply, shedding 11.78%. Kelani Valley Plantations fell 11.11%. Indian markets, by contrast, did well. At close on Friday, the Sensex advanced 0.09%, helped by the Metals, Real Estate, and Auto companies. Bajaj Auto Limited was 3.35% higher. Tata Motors also closed 3.10% up. Australian markets finished in the red, by contrast. The worst performers were AMP that declined 9.13%. Ardent Leisure Group slumped 5.12%. Carsales Com also did badly on Friday, losing 4.33%. BHP Billiton slipped along with Fortescue Metals Group. Newcrest Mining reported high gold output and advanced 0.23% on Friday. Australia bank also soared.

video.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: October 31, 2016
video.name: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: October 31, 2016
video.description: Oil continued dropping, trading at US$48.39 a barrel. Gold did not change much during the week. Stocks are down in Europe and mixed in Asia. The dollar eased. The euro and pound were still low.
video.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, oil, the pound, the euro, the dollar, OPEC, Presidential Elections, FBI’s investigations.

content-body.text: Investors were in low spirits on Monday upset by two major events occurring at the end of the week: OPEC’s failure to come to an agreement concerning oil production quotas and the FBI’s resumed investigation into Hilary Clinton’s private emails while she was Secretary of State. Both events heightened investors’ uncertainty about the winner of the Presidential Elections and the resolution of oil glut problem. Another piece of news came out on Friday and was more cheerful: the first estimate of third quarter growth. GDP was higher 2.9% after it had grown 1.4% in the second quarter. Last time when the growth of GDP was that high was in the last quarter of 2014. Consumer sentiment index reading for October was 87.2, which is a decline from September’s final reading of 91.2. With investors disturbed by the FBI’s investigations and OPEC’s inability to make a progress in talks, European market slid on Monday. The FTSE shed 0.33%; the DAX retreated 0.34%; the CAC sank 0.53%. Shipbuilding, Steel, and Mining sectors pushed Japanese market lower. The Nikkei was 0.12% down. The Hang Seng inched 0.09% lower. Australian stocks were the only stocks in the Asia-Pacific region that appreciated on Monday boosted by the good performance of the Gold, Steel, and Mining sectors. The S&P/ASX rose 0.64%. The US stocked closed in the red on Friday but advanced slightly at the beginning of the day on Monday, after investors started coming to terms with the news about the renewed probe into Clinton’s email. On this news, oil prices fell. Gold jumped 0.6% on Friday and stayed more or less at this level on Monday, as investors turned to it as safe haven in times of troubles.

After OPEC members did not make a deal on country quotas, prices of oil slid 0.6%, trading at US$48.39. Earlier, in summer, when OPEC countries agreed to implement oil cuts in November, oil traded at around US$50. Once the countries sabotaged the distribution of oil quota, everyone understood that the solution of oil glut problem might not be forthcoming. Brent Crude immediately fell to US$49.37. Gold climbed 0.6% on Friday and stayed high on Monday morning, when it traded at $1,275.38. Other precious metals also advanced as well. Platinum added 0.12% to reach US$981.82. Silver gained 0.42%. Base metals did well in Asia. Strong domestic demand, high coal prices, and logistical issues pushed prices of aluminium and zinc up. Aluminium surged by 10% last week and thereby reached the highest level since September. Zinc also surged to the level it occupied last time in March. Copper shed 0.30% to US$2.18.

Having presented good results in third-quarter net profit, the Linde Group soared. Sanofi rose for the same reason. Total gave a report on net income for the third quarter which was $2.76 billion lower than last year. The company dipped on this news. With its higher than expected profit for the third quarter, BNP Paribas soared. After it showed that its organic growth was exceptionally good, Saint-Gobain, a company dealing with building materials, closed higher. Royal Bank of Scotland was down, having complained about £469 million loss for the last three months. Consolidated Airlines Group soared, even though it reduced its earnings forecast for 2016. Other airlines finished higher too. EasyJet and Carnival were in the green by the end of the trading day

American stocks were in negative territory on Friday. The Dow Jones inched 0.05% lower; the S&P dipped 0.31%; the NASDAQ was 0.50% down. On Monday morning, indices did better. Amazon published disappointing third quarter earnings and dropped. The revenue of Exxon Mobil proved to be also below expectations and declined 0.80%. Even its good third quarter results did not help the company step out of negative territory. Having reported excellent third quarter results, Chevron rose 0.27%. Hershey gained for the same reason but slid 0.39% on Monday morning. After its revenue fell about US$1.5 billion lower than everyone expected, McKesson hit a three-year low, shedding 0.81%. Other health companies followed suit and lost. AmerisourceBergen, an American drug wholesale company, and Cardinal Health closed in the red. Other companies did better. Amgen showed good third quarter results and advanced, though it slipped later on Monday. General Electric was in the middle of discussing a possible deal with Baker Hughes, when both companies gained. United Technologies and Honeywell jumped.

Having presented good results in third-quarter net profit, the Linde Group soared. Sanofi rose for the same reason. Total gave a report on net income for the third quarter which was $2.76 billion lower than last year. The company dipped on this news. With its higher than expected profit for the third quarter, BNP Paribas soared. After it showed that its organic growth was exceptionally good, Saint-Gobain, a company dealing with building materials, closed higher. Royal Bank of Scotland was down, having complained about £469 million loss for the last three months. Consolidated Airlines Group soared, even though it reduced its earnings forecast for 2016. Other airlines finished higher too. EasyJet and Carnival were in the green by the end of the trading day.

Although the Nikkei was 0.12% lower, some companies did well and prevented the index’s deeper decline. SUMCO Corp. added whooping 9.11%. Fuji Electric was 6.28% higher at the close. Dainippon Screen soared 6.28% by the end of the trading day. Other companies fared worse and outnumbered gaining stocks, bringing the Nikkei down. NGK Insulations sank 10.91%. Oki Electric Industry shed 10.56%. Isetan Mitsukoshi Holdings also dipped 7.49%. Australian markets did better than Japanese on Monday. Orocobre jumped 19.81%. Galaxy Resources were 6.06% up. OZ Minerals joined the winning parties, adding 5.51%. The Hang Seng was also down minor 0.09%. The Kospi lost 0.7% for the week. The Sensex also dipped 0.5% from the week ago, though it, together with Philippines markets, was closed for holidays on Monday.

article.name: Daily_Market_Analysis_16_6_2016
article.title: Daily Market Analysis
article.description: A brief description of four popular trading strategies in online binary options trading, to assist online traders in finding an effective trading method.
article.keywords: binary options, options trading, trading strategies, trading strategy

content-body.text: Global stock markets took a huge plunge right before the closing time on Wednesday, 15th of June 2016, undoing the gains that they had been consolidating during the trading day. The reversal in their fortune was caused by the results achieved at the central banks’ meetings in the US and Japan. Both the Feds and BoJ did not introduce changes into their monetary policy but decided to hold it steady. Although they had long anticipated that no change in the central banks’ policy would occur, investors still reacted bitterly to the expected news and allowed stocks to tumble. The only (partially) positive results coming out of the central banks’ inaction were a jump of a yen: helped by Japan’s refusal to ease monetary policy, it reached on Wednesday the highest level since August of 2014. Embittered by the stability of the banks’ policies, investors, as they usually do in the unstable times of a weak dollar, rushed to the safe haven – gold – and brought it up even higher, causing it to soar for the seventh day in a row.

Gold thus jumped to US$18.98 to $1,310.73. Other precious metals appreciated too. Silver advanced US$0.33 to 17.83; Platinum Spot rose US$10.60 to 986.59.  Copper futures lost 0.24% to reach $2.07. WTI spot crude was US$0.57 down to reach $47.44. Dated Brent spot crude finished US$0.49 lower to reach $48.48.

The US dollar moved in opposite directions on Wednesday depending on the currency with which it was paired. The pound continued sinking ahead of the Brexit meeting on June 23. Against it, the USD advanced substantially. It also rose against the Australian and Canadian dollars weakened by falling oil prices. On the other hand, the US dollar declined against the Euro, the CHF, and the growing JPY.

The American market presented a miserable picture at the end of the trading day. However vigorously it had been reaping profits during the day, the stock market reversed almost all gains just before the closure of the trading session, influenced to the worse by the announcement from the Central banks in the US and Japan. The Fed flatly stated that rates will not be raising any time soon or, if they do, their pace would be much slower than everybody had thought. Nor would rates go up sooner than in September. The Dow Jones decreased 0.2%. The S&P shed 0.18%. The Nasdaq also slipped 0.18%.

The Bank of Japan said that because of weak inflation expectation, it would not introduce additional monetary stimulus. The announcement boosted the yen and brought stock market in Tokyo down. The Nikkei dropped 3.05%. The TOPIX sank 2.78%. Other markets in the Asia-Pacific region moved to the negative territory as well. CSI 300 lost 0.70% in Shanghai. The Heng Seng declined 2.06% in Hong Kong. In Australia, S&P ASX did not change much, dipping only insignificant 0.02%.

European market had finished the trading day on Wednesday before the Central Bank announced its decision to keep rates as they are, remaining thus blissfully unaware of the general downfall in other parts of the globe. European investors, however, woke up to a totally different reality. When the trading day commenced in the morning, all stocks were in the negative territory. The FTSE declined 0.61%. The DAX sank 0.94%. The CAC retreated 0.75%.

article.name: Daily_Market_Analysis_19_6_2016
article.title: Daily Market Analysis
article.description: A brief description of four popular trading strategies in online binary options trading, to assist online traders in finding an effective trading method.
article.keywords: binary options, options trading, trading strategies, trading strategy

content-body.text: On Friday, 17th of June 2016, European and Asian markets managed to pull it off by the end of the trading day and get out of the negative territory. The US market, however, finished in the red. Several events weighted heavily upon investors’ minds and influenced the performance of stocks for the worse. One of them was the approaching Brexit’s meeting that disallowed investors to make bold moves in anticipation that the UK might exit the European Union and the chaos will ensue. Another event that drove investors out of humour on Friday was the refusal of the Bank of Japan to change its monetary policy. Other banks followed suit also maintaining status quo in their monetary policies, which did not add to investors’ optimism either. Dow Jones Industrials shed 0.33%. S&P 50 had the worst week since April losing 0.33%. NASDAQ retreated 0.92%. In Europe, the picture was slightly brighter: all major indices ended in the green. The FTSE added 1.19%. The DAX finished 0.85% higher. The CAC rose 0.98%.

Apart from Platinum, all other commodities gained. Gold advanced US$20.22 to US$1.298.65. WTI Crude oil increased US$1.77 to US$47.98. Brent Crude rose US$1.98 to reach US$47.17. Copper futures were 0.15% up to US$2.05. Silver jumped US$0.11 to US$17.52. Platinum Spot dipped US$0.80 to US$969.90.
The US dollar depreciated against all its major counterparts -- the euro, Swiss franc, the Canadian dollar, the Australian dollar, the yen, and the pound.

The decisions of four big banks were at the centre of everybody’s attention by the end of the week. Each of them gave reasons to investors to feel dissatisfied. Affected by dismal May job reports, the Federal Reserve Bank kept its interest rates at the same level. Though largely expected, this news disappointed investors most bitterly. The bank of Japan, likewise, insisted on maintaining its interest rates just as they are at present. The Bank of England refrained from changing its monetary policy, choosing to wait for the outcome of the referendum on the 23d of June. The Swiss National Bank decided that negative interest rates are conducive to the growth of the Swiss franc and left them unchanged.

Just like the four big banks, European banks -- Deutsche Bank, Commerzbank, Crédit Agricole, Société Générale, and BNP Paribas – dropped. British banks fared no better. Barclays, Royal Bank of Scotland, Lloyds Banking Group, and Standard Chartered moved to the downside. Shares of automakers proved to be disappointing, too. BMW and Volkswagen slid. RWE and E.ON declined together with Technip. UBS and Credit Suisse slipped after the announcement from the Swiss Bank has been made. Shares of some companies were luckier, however. Because of high prices of gold, gold miners -- Randgold Resources and Fresnillo – were in the positive territory. Total appreciated together with Mulberry.

The Nikkei was up, adding 1.07%. The Hang Seng advanced 0.66%. The raising yen caused exporters to lose. Hitachi, Honda Motor, Mazda, Nissan, Panasonic, Sharp, Sony, and Toyota Motor plunged. Banks in Asia, as everywhere in the world, sank. Mitsui Fudosan, Inpex, and SoftBank took a plunge. In Australia, S&P/ASX rose 0.32%. Growing copper prices led to the increase of shares of mining companies. BHP Billiton and Fortescue Metals Group jumped. High gold prices caused gold mining companies -- Newcrest, Evolution Mining, and Northern Star Resources – to move upward.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_August_7_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 7, 2016
article.description: A strong July jobs report from the US gave stocks and the dollar a boost in trading markets, while pushing down gold and other precious metals.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, jobs report, NFP, dollar

content-body.text: A strong July jobs report from the US gave stocks and the dollar a boost in trading markets, while pushing down gold and other precious metals. Oil remains weak on oversupply issues.

The dollar has pretty much recouped last week's losses, after Friday's strong jobs report. Sometimes, one big news item can make a real difference in market sentiment.

Looking at the numbers now, we see that the US dollar has posted gains against all of its major peers. The EUR/USD pair has dipped to 1.1086, the GBP/USD is down to 1.3073, and the AUD/USD had fallen back to 0.7619. The dollar gained on the yen (USD/JPY 101.82), the USD/CAD rose to 1.3172, and the USD/CHF ticked up to 0.9807. The major shifts in the exchange rates happened right after the jobs report hit the news wires, and the dollar held on to its gains thereafter.

While the dollar was rising in the markets, precious metals were taking a sharp drop. Gold fell nearly $30 and now sells at $1,336.00 per ounce, silver dropped back below $20, to $19.73, and platinum dipped to $1,145.85.

The metals lost ground as investors moved back toward riskier stocks and dollar assets in the wake of the strong jobs report.

Oil, in the meantime, continues to show weakness in the markets. Weak demand, continued high supply, and the specter of increased US production have all combined to push prices back to the $40 to $45 range, after breaking $50 in June. Right now, US benchmark grade West Texas Intermediate is selling for $41.80 per barrel and global benchmark Brent is selling for $44.27.

The biggest news to hit the global markets last Friday and over the weekend was the Non-Farm Payroll report from the US Department of Labor.

The NFP jobs report showed a strong increase in the number of jobs created in the US during the month of July, with 255,000 new positions. The number was well above the expectation of 180K, and came along with upward revisions to the June and May reports which brought the three month average up to 190,000. Headline unemployment remained level since last month at 4.9%, and hourly earnings showed an increase of 0.3%, exceeding the 0.2% forecast.

The good news from the jobs front helped to counteract the gloomy market sentiment after the Q2 GDP number came in at only 1.2%, and has boosted expectations that the Federal Reserve will implement another interest rate hike later this year. Futures traders are putting the chance of a September hike at 26%, and of a December move at 48%. The increasing odds for September are interesting, as it would require the Fed moving before the Presidential election in November.

There were some spots of gloom in the jobs report. The NFP showed that the rate of underemployment – US workers in part time jobs but looking for full time – increased to 9.7%, and that the raw number of workers in part time work for "economic reasons" – their employer cut their hours, usually – increased to 5.94 million. The number of Americans discouraged and dropping out of the workforce also increased during July.

Still, the overall news was good, and the NFP gave US stock markets a shot in the arm on Friday. The Dow Jones gained 1.04%, the S&P 500 added 0.86%, and the NASDAQ advanced 1.06%.

European markets also responded well to the American jobs report, and the FTSE 100 in London finished with a gain of 0.79%, the DAX added 1.36%, and the CAC 40 gained 1.49%. While European markets were in the green before the NFP release, they picked up their gains sharply afterwards.

Markets in the Asia-Pacific region had mostly closed by the time of the US jobs report release, but they are still worth looking at. Tokyo was flat, or showed small losses – the Nikkei 225 showed no change and the TOPIX fell 0.24%. In China, the Hang Seng gained 1.44%, while the SCI 300 on the mainland added just 0.12%. Australia's S&P ASX added a modest 0.39%.

It will be a mostly slow week in news releases, but on Tuesday we'll have UK manufacturing numbers, on Wednesday a US crude oil inventory release, on Thursday the weekly US initial unemployment claims, and on Friday US retail sales number and Chinese industrial production numbers.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_August_17_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 17, 2016
article.description: Global markets are mostly down today, and uncertainty is growing about the Fed's ability to continue monetary tightening.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, Federal Reserve, rate hike, oil, price of gold

content-body.text: Global markets are mostly down today, and uncertainty is growing about the Fed's ability to continue monetary tightening. Oil prices have slid as the fundamentals of the market remain weak.

In currency markets, the US dollar has made a slight rebound after several days of losses. Specifically, the dollar bounced up from a seven-week low to the yen.

Overnight, the greenback-yen pair touched 99, the lowest level since June. The USD/JPY currently stands at 100.84. The dollar has also firmed up against the Euro, with the EUR/USD slipping a bit to 1.1266, and the Australian dollar, with the AUD/USD at 0.7668.

The dollar continues to lose ground against the pound, however, as the GBP/USD has strengthened to 1.3042. High oil prices have boosted the Canadian dollar, pushing the USD/CAD down to 1.2881.

The US dollar index, a broad measure of the dollar versus a basket of six major peer currencies, is at 95.028, up from yesterday's low of 94.721, and trending upwards.

The price of gold has dipped in early trading today, as investors hold back before the release of minutes from the US Fed's last policy meeting. The metal slid a quarter percent to $1,342.72 per ounce. Silver and platinum are also down, at $19.62 and $1,113.70 respectively. Despite these losses, gold is still up about 25% for the year to date.

The oil markets are just plain confusing lately. Prices are up, as the Saudis have been talking again about production cuts. The OPEC nations are to meet informally next month, and oil spokesmen for the kingdom have hinted that Saudi Arabia may be willing to discuss output cuts at that time. Russia has hinted that it, too, may cooperate with cuts. At the same time, Iran and Nigeria have both said, "No cuts from us," and the active rig count in the US continues to rise. Crude oil stockpiles in the US saw a large draw, but gasoline stocks increased by 2.2 million barrels last week.

To make sense of all of this, it's important to consider the intersection of supply and demand with politics and national budgets. Globally, supply is very high while demand is weak or slowing; politically, Saudi Arabia and Russia both need higher prices to make budget ends meet, but neither can afford to cut production and risk losing market share. Iran and Nigeria are both trying to increase production to regain market share. Expect confusion in the oil markets.

Price-wise, Brent crude now stands at $48.74 per barrel, down 1% from yesterday, while in the US, West Texas Intermediate is selling for $46.15, down 0.92%..

The biggest market news today comes from the US, where William Dudley, President of the New York Federal Reserve branch stated that the Fed could choose to raise rates again next month. The statement boosted the dollar, and helped the greenback to slow its recent slide and pare back losses slightly. Dudley's statements comes despite recent economic reports showing that economic growth in the US, while real, has been uneven. Regarding US markets, the economic signals been truly mixed. The last two months' labor reports have been good, but industrial production remains and retail sales remain down.

In the wake of Dudley's speech, US stocks slipped slightly from recent record highs. Investors were taking profits and taking on a wait-and-see stance. This past December, the Fed made its first rate hike in 9 years, and markets responded with sharp drops. That, plus the unsteady global economic recovery, has both the Fed and investors on a cautious mode. Most investors doubt that there will be a rate hike as early as September, citing the US election on November 8. Futures markets put the odds of a rate hike at just 22% before the election, and only 45% in December.

Wall Street's indexes remain at high levels, despite the slight paring. The Dow was down 0.45% at the finish, the S&P 500 lost 0.55%, and the NASDAQ slipped 0.66%. All three set record highs in Monday's session.

In Europe, the markets are opening to losses after a down finish yesterday. London's FTSE 100 index has slipped 0.16% in early trading, the DAX is down 0.82%, and the CAC 40 has dropped 0.67%.

Asia's markets are showing mixed results in today's session, with losses in China buy gains in Japan and Australia. Shanghai's CSI 300 is down 0.15% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng has slipped 0.48%. In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 picked up 0.90% and the TOPIX gained 0.97%. Australia's S&P ASX squeaked out a modest 0.06% gain.

At 2pm Eastern Daylight Time, the Federal Open Market Committee – the Federal Reserve body that sets forward monetary policy – will release the minutes of its July meeting. Expect the minutes to be parsed very carefully for any hint as to the Fed's thinking on future rate hikes, especially in light of the upcoming election and Dudley's recent comments.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_August_18_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 18, 2016
article.description: US stocks rose in late trading yesterday, while the dollar tumbled. Gold, the yen, and the Swiss franc all gained on haven demand.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, haven demand, oil, gold, dollar

content-body.text: US stocks rose in late trading yesterday, while the dollar tumbled. Gold, the yen, and the Swiss franc all gained on haven demand.

The dollar and the yen made the biggest moves in exchange trading overnight, with the greenback falling across the board and the yen firming up markedly. The USD/JPY now stands at 99.92 and the USD/CHF has dipped to 0.9592. Both the yen and the franc gained on haven trading after the FOMC minutes release.

The EUR/USD rose to 1.1323 and the GBP/USD advanced to 1.3073. The Australian dollar also increased, putting the AUD/USD at 0.7710. The Aussie gained as a jobs report showed an improving employment situation Down Under. The Canadian dollar rose as well, pushing the USD/CAD down to 1.2803. The loonie has benefitted from an increase in the price of oil.

The US dollar index has hit a two-month low of 94.461. The index is down about 5% for the year so far.

Oil prices dipped overnight, but have starting moving back up again. The oil markets are full of contradictory signals – Saudi Arabia has been hinting at production cuts and US inventories fell last week, which both point to increases in price, but Iran and Nigeria have nixed the idea of cutting output and global demand remains soft, which all point to lower prices.

Right now, Brent crude stands at $49.94 per barrel, and WTI is selling for $47.13.

Precious metals have gained on the overall market uncertainties. Gold prices in early trading today are up, with the metal at $1,350.06 per ounce. Silver has risen to $19.76, and platinum is up to $1,125.51. All three have gained on haven demand.

Investors were hoping for clarity from the release of the Fed's last policy meeting minutes, but there was no joy in Mudville when the news came out. The Fed minutes were dovish in tone, reflecting a divided committee that is unsure how to proceed. The image presented a decided contrast to recent statements from New York Fed president William Dudley to the effect that there could be a further rate hike even before the November election.

The dollar tumbled during the confusion, of course, while gold and the Wall Street indexes rose as some investors moved toward higher returns and others looked to haven assets. Traders now are looking towards Fed chair Janet Yellen's scheduled speech at the Jackson Hole conference of global policy makers next week.

In the meantime, the stock indexes rallied at the end of the session yesterday. The Dow finished with a gain of 0.12% and the S&P 500 picked up 0.19%. The NASDAQ's gain was smaller, just 0.03%.

Stocks in Asia were mostly down. Reports from Japan showed that imports and exports continue to drop, an ominous sign in a trade-driven economy. Imports were down more than 24% year-over- year, marking the nineteenth consecutive month of year-over- year declines, while exports dropped 14% year-over- year for the worst showing in nearly 7 years. In short, the trade numbers were disastrous for Japan.

The trade situation isn't helped any by the strengthening in the yen. The yen has gained on haven trading as the dollar has tumbled in the markets. The result was a bad day yesterday for Japanese stocks, which normally trade inversely to the currency. The Nikkei 225 and the TOPIX were both down by 1.55%.

Other Asia-Pacific region stocks also fared poorly. The Australian S&P ASX dipped 0.49%, and in Shanghai the CSI 300 index lost a quarter percent. Hong Kong's Hang Seng was theexception, gaining 0.89%.

The European markets finished in the red yesterday, but have opened higher in early trading today. Gains on the FTSE 100, the DAX, and the CAC 40 range from 0.26% to 0.38%.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_August_22_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 22, 2016
article.description: US stocks rose in late trading yesterday, while the dollar tumbled. Gold, the yen, and the Swiss franc all gained on haven demand.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, haven demand, oil, gold, dollar

content-body.text:
Oil prices were the most hotly discussed subject among investors. After the exaltation that everyone had felt upon the announcement of OPEC’s meeting in September, everyone realized that the forthcoming talks will not bring an expected freeze of oil production. Analysts are convinced that even if Russia agrees in Algiers to curb the oversupply, the Saudi Arabia and Iran, whose hatred for each other had prevented negotiations on previous occasions, would not close a meaningful deal this time either. Other factors also contribute to the overall pessimism about the future of oil. The US increased drilling for the last couple of months; China’s export of diesel and gasoline more than doubled in July. Therefore, even in the best case scenario, when oil production indeed gets frozen in September, freezing at current level delays re-balancing by a year. The realization that the meeting in Algiers will not solve the problem of oil oversupply shed a different light also on the recent jump in oil prices. Now it is clear that the price increase was short-lived and more technical than fundamental. On Friday and Monday oil prices resumed their downward movement.

Prices of gold also dropped on Monday to its two week low thanks to the growing dollar and investors’ apprehensions that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates in September. The opinion that the US economy is healing was expressed by San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams, who added that putting off an increase further would only hurt the economy. In his statement, John Williams seconded the opinion of William Dudley expressed earlier last week. Major indices also took a plunge in the US. Dow Jones industrials declined 0.24%. The S&P shed 0.14%. The NASDAQ decreased 0.03%. The overall situation was more cheerful in Europe, where indices rose. The FTSE advanced 0.02%; the DAX jumped 0.82%; the CAC added 0.69%.

Precious metals deprecated. Gold took a deep plunge, being down 0.66% at US$1,337.35. Silver shed 1.85% to US$18.96. Platinum tumbled 0.36% to US$1,110.33. WTI Crude lost 1.69% to US$47.70. Brent Crude retreated 1.65% to US$50.04. Copper slid 0.92% to US$215.75.

Pound rebounded slightly. The US dollar, therefore, gained against the majority of its counterparts – the euro, the yen, the Australian dollar, the Canadian dollar, and the Swiss franc – except of the pound.

US Market. Having produced weakened profit forecast for the current quarter and the new fiscal year, Estée Lauder sank. After Emerson Electric closed a deal to buy Pentair’s business for $3.15 billion, both companies tumbled. Because it showed unexpectedly stronger results, Foot Locker advanced. Nike did too. Ross Stores was up as well. Applied Materials revealed higher than expected new orders and a contract backlog and immediately appreciated. Deere showed high results and gained.Olympic Steel, AK Steel, and US Steel dipped. 

European Market. Automakers had a bad day. BMW, Volkswagen, Daimler, Peugeot, and Renault had a slide. Banks did not fare better either. Deutsche Bank, Commerzbank, Crédit Agricole, BNP Paribas, and Société Générale slumped. EasyJet rose in London. Bookmaker 888 Holdings and the Rank Group declined a proposal from William Hill and jumped. William Hill also ended the day in the green.

Asia-Pacific Market. The Shanghai Composite added minor 0.1%. The Hang Seng also slid 0.4%, even though it was 0.7% higher on the last week. Thanks to the falling yen, the Nikkei advanced 0.4%. Energy stocks were leading: Inpex, JX Holdings, and Japan Petroleum jumped. Mitsui Chemicals, Fujitsu, and Sumco finished the day firmly planted in the positive territory. Obayashi, Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, Shionogi, and Astellas Pharma were in the red. In Australia, the S&P/ASX edged 0.3% higher. The All Ordinaries added as much. Despite bad profit results, BHP Billiton turned in a positive performance. Fortescue Metals Group also gained. Shares of big four banks remained virtually unchanged. The Kospi added minor 0.77 points. The Sensex inched 0.2% lower.
On Tuesday, 23 August 2016, Eurozone, Germany, and France are publishing Manufacturing, Services & Composite PMI for August. The US is reporting on July New Home Sales.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_August_24_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 24, 2016
article.description: US stocks rose in late trading yesterday, while the dollar tumbled. Gold, the yen, and the Swiss franc all gained on haven demand.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, haven demand, oil, gold, dollar

content-body.text: Tuesday, the 23 of August 2016, was much brighter day for investors than Monday, when stocks slid. New housing data demonstrated that in the US, July new home sales grew 12.4%. August flash PMI data was also good, showing that Europe was not crushed by the UK’s decision to part company with it. Quite the contrary, the new data revealed that European business conspicuously boasts signs of growth. The arrival of positive news brought investors out of sluggishness that characterized their activities on Monday. Trading became more spirited and profitable. All American indices added. The Dow Jones was 0.1% up. The S&P rose 0.2%. The NASDAQ closed 0.3% higher. In Europe, too, all indices finished the trading day firmly in the positive territory. The FTSE advanced 0.6%. The CAC jumped 0.7%. The German’s DAX soared 0.9%. The SMI surged 0.5%. On Wednesday morning, the upward trend among indices continued. All indices were on the levels at which they had closed a day before. The only fly in the ointment for investors was oil that was still inexorably falling. Oil demand is low in China; the US cannot store more oil; Saudi Arabia that recently talked oil prices up will not stop pumping. Oil oversupply is not going away but will remain a serious problem for at least a year, even if at the forthcoming OPEC meeting all countries agree to curb their oil production to the maximum.

The US dollar recovered from a recent drop. On Tuesday evening, it was still down against the yen, the pound, and the Canadian dollar. On Wednesday morning, the dollar moved up higher and gained against all its major counterparts – the euro, the yen, the British pound, the Swiss franc, the Canadian dollar, and the Australian dollar. For a year, the dollar is down 5%.

On Wednesday morning, precious and other metals plunged. Gold lost 0.04% to US$1,337.07. Silver dipped 0.62% to reach US$18.81. Platinum shed 0.09% to US$1,103.28. WTI Crude oil was 1.87% down to reach US$47.20. Brent spot crude was 1.64% to US$49.14.

US Market. Because new home sales in July rose 12.4%, showing the best results in nine years, home building companies jumped. Toll Brothers, PulteGroup, and Lennar led the way among home builders. Having presented better than expected results, Best Buy also advanced. The retailer added 19.60%, proving that its turnaround strategy was succeeding. Despite the decline of oil, energy companies did better than on Monday. Chesapeake Energy and Marathon Oil gained. After announcing a possible merger with Bayer AG, Monsanto, a publicly traded American multinational agrochemical and agricultural biotechnology corporation, also surged.

European Market. Stocks were up. Banks, automakers, and miners were at the forefront of the market in Europe. Deutsche Bank, Commerzbank,Société Générale, BNP Paribas, and Crédit Agricole ended the day firmly in the positive territory. Automakers Volkswagen, BMW, and Daimler closed higher. Intending to sell its DTN, a data service and an agriculture news, for $1.5 billion, Schneider Electric gained. Persimmon continued its upward movement for the second day, after it had demonstrated that its first-half profit exceeded 29%. Taylor Wimpey rose, and so did Berkeley Group Holdings. Because its losses were lower than those of other retailers, shares of Tesco also went higher. BHP Billiton, too, ended the day in the green. Straumann Holding, a company specializing in implant and restorative dentistry and oral tissue regeneration, also advanced.

Asia-Pacific Market. The growing yen that is now on the 100 level against the US dollar brought the Nikkei down: the index closed 0.6% lower. As is always the case, when the yen is heading upward, exporters dipped. Shares of Canon, Panasonic, Nissan Motor, Toyota, Honda Motor, and Mazda sank. Thanks to rumours that it is going to purchase Intersil, Renesas Electronics tumbled. Sharp followed suit and also slipped. In Australia, the S&P/ASX added 0.7%. The All Ordinaries appreciated 0.6%. The banks soared along with BHP Billiton and Fortescue Metals Group. After it had demonstrated that its profit for a year was three times higher, Vocus Communications, an Australian telecommunication provider, significantly advanced. Because its first-half profit had fallen 89%, Oil Search decreased. The Kospi in South Korea rose 0.4% helped by Samsung Electronics that turned in excellent performance on Tuesday. The Sensex and Hang Seng did not change much. The Shanghai Composite inched 0.2% higher.

The US is reporting on June FHFA house price index. It is also issuing July existing home sales and weekly EIA petroleum status reports. Germany is publishing a report on final second quarter gross domestic product.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_August_26_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 26, 2016
article.description: US stocks rose in late trading yesterday, while the dollar tumbled. Gold, the yen, and the Swiss franc all gained on haven demand.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, haven demand, oil, gold, dollar

content-body.text: Thursday, 25 August 2016, was as marked by uneventful, light-volume trading as was Wednesday. Investors continued procrastinating in expectations of Fed Chair Janet Yellen’s announcement at the Kansas City Fed’s monetary policy symposium in Jackson Hole. Everyone expects rates to be increased, considering recent comments by William Dudley and Stanley Fisher followed by equally hawkish observations made by Esther George, Kansas City Fed President, and Robert Kaplan, Dallas Fed President. The probability of a Fed rate increase in September is 32%. The optimism sounded in the observations of policymakers pushed financial stocks higher but not significantly enough to offset markets’ general decline on Thursday. Healthcare companies along with consumer stocks bore the brunt of markets’ losses. On Thursday evening and Friday morning, the Dow Jones industrials shed 0.2%. The S&P inched 0.1% lower. The NASDAQ lost as much. In Europe, all indices retreated as well. The FTSE slid 0.3%. The DAX was 0.9% lower. The CAC decreased 0.7%. The SMI also dropped 0.7%. On Friday morning, the FTSE was 0.01% down. The DAX sank 0.15%. The CAC finished 0.20% lower. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index dropped to a two-week low. Japanese equities suffered the biggest decline. The dollar appreciated against the yen that traded 100.43 per dollar. The British pound gained 1.1% on the week, showing that British economy proved to be unshaken by the Brexit’s victory. Crude oil price was 0.2% lower, trading $47 per barrel, which marked the end of its price hike caused by Saudi Arabia’s earlier promise to freeze oil prices and Iran’s willingness to attend OPEC’s informal meeting in Algiers in September. Zinc hit its highest level since May 2015.
On Thursday afternoon, the US dollar advanced against the yen, the British pound, and the Swiss franc. It lost against the euro and Australian dollar. It did not change against the Canadian dollar.

Precious metals were again in the green. On Friday morning, gold added 0.24% to US$1,325.09. Silver advanced 0.63% to reach US$18.61. Platinum was 0.79% higher to US$1,082.00. Copper futures rose 0.60% to US$18.61. Other metals lost. Brent Crude was 0.83% lower to US$49.26. WTI Crude Oil sank 0.38% to US$47.15.

US Market. Healthcare stocks continued experiencing losses. St Jude Medical dropped because of some problems with security vulnerabilities in the company’s cardiac devices. Shares of a software company HP finished lower having given a disappointing outlook for the present quarter, even though its results for its fiscal third quarter earnings were upbeat. Consumer companies, apart from Tiffany that showed high profits, were also in the red. Dollar Tree along with Dollar General sank. Signet Jewellers did, too. Mylan that had slipped on Wednesday due to the price increase of its EpiPen medicine treating allergy was again down, even though the company hinted that it might reduce the medicine’s price.

European Market. Stocks moved into the negative territory. Automakers Volkswagen, Daimler, BMW, Peugeot, and Renault finished the trading day in the red. Deutsche Lufthansa also declined. Merck KgaA lost, and so did Fresenius and Fresenius Medical Care. Just Eat decreased. After ITV changed its mind about its purchase offer of the company, Entertained One tumbled. As in the US, healthcare companies took a plunge. Shire, Hikma Pharmaceuticals, and AstraZeneca were among the losers on Thursday. Glencore did not move away from the negative territory. Anglo American followed suit. Among these losing companies two finished in the green. CRH in London climbed. WPP soared for the second day.

Asia-Pacific Market. The yen grew and immediately pulled the Nikkei down. The index shed 0.2%. Housing, food, utility, pharmaceutical, resource, and chemical stocks counted losses on Thursday. Financial companies did well, by contrast, and so did Nissan Motors along with Mazda Motor. Inpex and Sumitomo Metal Mining sank, as did Recruit Holdings. The Shanghai Composite dipped 0.2%, while the Hang Seng remained the same. Having posted a 7.7 billion yuan net loss, Cnooc finished lower. Because its first-half net profit was lower 98%, PetroChina tumbled. The S&P/ASX dropped 0.4%. The All Ordinaries lost as much. The Sensex depreciated 0.8%. The Kospi remained the same, shedding only 0.84 points.

Fed Chair Janet Yellen gives a speech at the Kansas City Fed symposium in Jackson Hole. Japan is posting July consumer price index. The Eurozone is giving July M3 money supply. The US is publishing second estimate of second quarter gross domestic product. It is also reporting on estimate of second quarter gross domestic product and on final August consumer sentiment.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_August_28_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 28, 2016
article.description: US stocks rose in late trading yesterday, while the dollar tumbled. Gold, the yen, and the Swiss franc all gained on haven demand.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, haven demand, oil, gold, dollar

content-body.text:
The major event happening on Friday, 26 August 2016, was Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen’s speech at the summit at Jackson Hole, Wyoming. The most leading question that weighted upon everyone’s mind last week was whether Federal Reserve was going to increase rates this year. In her speech, Professor Yellen made clear that the U.S. Central bank is going to increase rates as soon as next month. The reason why she thinks a rate hike is possible lies in the continued good performance of the labor market: there were about 190,000 jobs added over the past free months. The August job reports that are going to be published at the end of this week are expected to influence further the Federal Reserve decision to increase rates. Moreover, analysts think that the Federal Reserve will not stop at one rate hike this year but will increase rates twice or even more times. The goal of the U.S. central bank should be striking a balance between boosting up the economic growth and overheating the economy. While the most significant announcement Professor Yellen made was about the rate increase, she spent the most of the time during her speech talking about the need to develop new tools in addition to those which the Federal Reserve is using now in order to face the next recession more successfully.

Another piece of news that came off on Friday was the address of German Deputy Foreign minister, Michael Roth, to the UK. He said that the UK’s separation from the European Union will not be easy and that the UK is not going to receive the best aspects that the Union offers. He made clear that if there are restrictions for the Germans, Italians, and Polish to access Britain and if Britain itself wants to access market fully, the European Union is not going to cooperate in this.

At stock markets, shares of Saudi Arabia tumbled the most, hitting a five years low. Only this year, the Tadawul All Share Index became 14% lower. Companies in this index trade at about 11.7 times future earnings, as opposed to 12.5 for the measure set for developing countries. A continued drop of oil prices does not help the largest crude exporter in the world. On Friday, U.S crude dipped 0.32% to reach US$47.18. Brent crude fell 0.52% to US$49.41. Everyone realizes now that an agreement to curtail oil production is not going to be reached. Energy Minister of Saudi Arabia, Khalid Al-Falih, said on Thursday that there would be no meaningful intervention in the market. Because the US continues to increase the number of active rigs, already having as many as 406, oil glut remains a persistent problem for the world at the moment. The US dollar moved downwards before Fed Reserve Chair Professor Janet Yellen’s speech.

Apart from European Indices that ended the trading day on Friday in the green, other indices throughout the world were mixed. The Dow Jones sank 0.29%. The S&P shed 0.16%. Unlike these US indices, the NASDAQ appreciated 0.13%. Major indices in the Asia-Pacific region were also mixed. Even though the yen rose, the Nikkei still could not pull it off and lost 1.18%. The S&P/ASX declined 0.48%. The Hang Seng was the only index that added on Friday. It was 0.41% up. The European indices soared. The FTSE edged 0.3% higher. The CAC jumped 0.80%. The DAX advanced 0.55%. The IBEX also ended the trading Friday session higher. It was 0.70% up.

Even though the US dollar moved down ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Professor Janet Yellen’s speech, it still advanced against all its major counterparts – the euro, the yen, the British pound, the Australian dollar, the Canadian dollar, and the Swiss franc.

Like indices, major commodities were mixed on Friday. WTI Crude Oil soared 0.65% to US$47.64. Brent crude jumped 0.50% to reach US$49.92. Copper inched 0.07% higher to US$20.84. Gold declined 0.06% to US$1,321.18. Silver decreased 0.13% to US$18.72. Platinum edged 0.03% up to US$1,073.80.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_August_29_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: August 29, 2016
article.description: US stocks rose in late trading yesterday, while the dollar tumbled. Gold, the yen, and the Swiss franc all gained on haven demand.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, haven demand, oil, gold, dollar

content-body.text: The most awaited event of the previous week – Fed Reserve Chairwoman, Professor Janet Yellen’s speech – brought little surprises. Optimistic about the state of a job market and economy’s growth, Professor Yellen said that a rate increase is highly probable. Although she did not talk about a deadline for a rate hike, analysts think that rates can be increased as early as in September. Additional increases are also possible this year. Fed Reserve chairwoman’s speech did not drastically influence markets’ performance. A low-volume, unprofitable trading that characterised global markets at the beginning of the week dragged on till its end. The US indices were mostly down. The Dow Jones shed 0.3% on Friday and 0.8% for the week. The S&P dipped 0.2% on a day and 0.7% since the last week. Although the NASDAQ inched 0.1% higher on Friday, it dropped 0.4% on the week. European market presented a slightly brighter picture: all its indices managed to move to the positive territory on Friday. The FTSE advanced 0.3%. The SMI added as much. The CAC rose 0.8% on Friday and 0.9% since the previous week. The DAX was 0.6% higher on the day and 0.4% on the week. The SMI appreciated 0.5% since the last Friday. The FTSE was the only index that lost for the week, shedding 0.3%. Overwhelming pessimism about the future of oil reigned at the Asia-Pacific region and elsewhere in the world. Iran recently made clear that it was not going to reduce crude production, since it wanted to regain its OPEC market share. Iran’s insistence on pumping more oil sabotages an oil freeze that some other oil-producing countries are willing to implement. More and more people are starting to realize that an oil freeze is not going to be achieved.

On early Monday, the US dollar advanced against all its major counterparts – the euro, the yen, the British pound, the Australian and Canadian dollar, and the Swiss franc. On Friday evening, the US dollar was also up against other currencies.

On Monday morning, 29th of August 2016, apart from Platinum and Copper, all other commodities declined. Gold shed 0.15% to US$1,319.14. Silver decreased 0.64% to US$18.63. Platinum edged 0.14% higher to US$1,075.33. WTI Crude oil lost 1.64% to US$46.86. Brent Crude sank 1.60% to US$49.12. Copper added 0.14% to US$20.87.

US Market. Healthcare and technologies companies brought the market up. Phone companies and utilities limited its upside, however. Having a lesser loss than expected, Autodesk, a multinational software corporation, soared. Shares of Consolidated Edison dipped, and so did those of PG&E. Because its current quarter outlook is weak, Ultra Salon Cosmetics & Fragrance had a 6.12% slide, hitting the lowest point since November 2015. Involved in a difficult law case filed against Abbott Laboratories in order to complete their takeover deal, Alere sank. Abbott Laboratories, by contrast, remained stable, having its stocks sold for US$42.98. Herbalife declined 2.31% on rumours that its biggest shareholder was seeking to sell his shares.

European Market. Because it planned to spend $1.4 billion to compensate those dealers who had lost in its diesel cheating scheme, Volkswagen appreciated. Other automakers were also up: BMW, Daimler, Peugeot, and Renault gained. Having lost more than expected in its second quarter profits, Vivendi, a French multinational mass media company, shed 0.93%. Having promised to change its marketing strategies, Restaurant Group added 4.98% at London stock exchange. Amec Foster Wheeler added 6.03%. BAE Systems, a British multinational defence, security, and aerospace company, edged 1.10% up.

Asia-Pacific Market. The Shanghai Composite inched 0.1% on Friday. The Hang Seng rose 0.4%. On the week, the former dipped 1.2%. The latter dropped 0.1%. Because of continuously sinking oil prices, July consumer prices were again low, for the fifth month in the row. The Nikkei was down both on Friday and for the week: 1.2% and 1.1% respectively. As a corollary, exporters drifted lower – Canon, Sony, Toshiba, Mazda Motor, Advantest, Toyota, and Honda were among the losers. Capcom, a gaming company, finished the day in the green. Kao, a cosmetic company, did too. In Australia, both the S&P/ASX and the All Ordinaries retreated on Friday and for the week. The first index dipped 0.5% and 0.2% respectively. The All Ordinaries slipped 0.4% for the day and 0.3% since the last Friday. The banks moved into the negative territory. BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto slid, as did Coca Cola Amatil. Having reported that its full-year profit increased almost 4 times, Mayne Pharma did slightly better than before. Super Retail Group added 5.87%. The Kospi lost both on Friday and for the week – 0.3% and 0.9% respectively. The Sensex also sank both on Friday (0.2%) and for the week (1.0%).
Today, on August 29, Germany is posting July Retail Sales. The US is publishing a report on Personal Income and Spending in July.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_September_06_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 06, 2016
article.description: US stocks rose in late trading yesterday, while the dollar tumbled. Gold, the yen, and the Swiss franc all gained on haven demand.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Binary Options, Binary Options trading, haven demand, oil, gold, dollar

content-body.text: US markets were closed on Monday, 05 September 2016, for Labour Day. European markets ended the day mostly in the green, Asian markets did too. Among other European countries, the UK market struggled on Monday weakened by banking stocks. After Deutsche Bank had downgraded its ratings, other banks immediately slid. Although Royal Bank of Scotland managed to move into the positive territory on Tuesday morning, banks plummeted on Monday. Commodity and utilities companies who reaped profits limited the downside. STOXX 600 index hit the highest level since the beginning of the year. The CAC in France was not changed on Monday but added 0.16% on Tuesday morning. The DAX edged 0.1% lower on Monday but pared its losses on Tuesday in the morning, shedding 0.05%. The FTSE fell both on Monday evening and Tuesday morning, being down 0.22% and 0.14% respectively. In Asia, investors felt more relaxed on Monday, convinced that, judging by the US poor job reports, Federal Reserve would not increase rates in the coming months. The Nikkei advanced 0.7% on Monday and was 0.26% higher on Tuesday morning. Hang Seng was higher on both days – 1.7% on Monday and 0.56% in the morning on Tuesday. The Australian indices continued dropping for more than three days in a row.

On Monday, the US dollar was down against all its major counterparts. On Tuesday morning, it started to rebound and advanced against some of the major currencies. The US dollar particularly advanced against the yen and the Swiss franc. Now the USD/JPY pair is trading at 103.62. The USD/CHF pair is at 0.9805. The EUR/USD pair is trading at 1.1148.

On Tuesday morning, oil prices soared following the conversation between Russia and Saudi Arabia, where countries discussed a possibility of freezing oil production. Gold rose nearly 1% in the wake of the poor employment reports issued last Friday. Investors are sceptical about rates increase in September and are, therefore, investing now in precious metals. Prices of gold, silver, and platinum became higher. On Tuesday, gold was 1.67% up to reach US$ 1,332.60. Silver rose 1.52% to US$19.66. Platinum advanced 0.64% to US$1,078.10. Copper was 0.58% higher to reach US$2.09. WTI Crude Oil appreciated US$1.67% to US$45.18. Brent crude was flat trading at US$47.63.

European Market. Swiss software maker, Temenos, was one of the few companies that counted gains on Monday, though it traded slightly lower on Tuesday morning, being 0.97% down. SFR, a telecom company, added as well. Despite these gains, investors had a reason not to feel particularly upbeat. Reports had shown that business growth in Eurozone was now at its weakest point since the last August. In England, banks tumbled after Deutsche Bank had downgraded its ratings. The only companies who did well on Monday and Tuesday morning were utilities and miners thanks to growing commodities prices. Randgold Resources added 0.33% on early Tuesday. BHP Billiton advanced 1.08%.

Asia-Pacific Market. As was the case in Europe, energy companies were in the green on Monday, and so were companies dependent on commodities prices. Miners surged in Australia: BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and Woodside Petroleum were up. Japanese market finished the trading day in the positive territory helped by optimistic labour data. Nissan Motor was among the winners. South Korean Hanjin Shipping, by contrast, was the company that pulled the whole Asia-Pacific market down, even though it managed to increase 29.91% on Tuesday in the morning. Even though it continued having problems with its new Galaxy Note 7 smartphone, Samsung Electronics jumped 0.6%.

On the 6th of September 2016, the US is giving a report on August Services PMI. Eurozone is publishing gross domestic product for the second quarter of 2016. Germany is reporting on July manufacturing orders.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_September_13_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: September 13, 2016
