article.description: The US dollar retreated overnight, after comments from the Federal Reserve indicated that there will likely be no interest rate hike at the bank's September policy meeting next week.
article.keywords: HedgeStone Group, Binary options trading, currency markets, us dollar, Japanese yen, gold

content-body.text:
The US dollar retreated overnight, after comments from the Federal Reserve indicated that there will likely be no interest rate hike at the bank's September policy meeting next week. The indications are bearish for the dollar, as a continuation of the current low rates will hold down returns on investments, and traders started moving toward haven assets.

The immediate benefits of the Fed comments were felt by the Japanese yen, and in the gold markets. The USD/JPY pair has retreated to 101.94 and the EUR/JPY dipped to 114.53. The price of gold is up more than three dollars to trade at $1,330.00 per ounce.

In the oil markets, supply and demand is still dominating crude prices. US rig counts have increased for 10 of the last 11 weeks, indicating an increase in production activity, a probably future increase in output, and the shale industry's ability to adapt to a low-price regime. In addition, the OPEC cartel released estimates showing they foresee an increase in non-OPEC production this year. Within the OPEC cartel, production levels are already at record highs.

The constant production is feeding into supply glut that has pressed down on oil markets form most of the last two years, and helping strengthen the market resistance at the $50 level. Currently, the US benchmark WTI grade is selling for $45.25 per barrel and Brent, the global trading benchmark, is priced at $47.40. Both are trending downward.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_October_05_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: October 05, 2016
article.description: Oil jumped again and traded at US$49.30 a barrel. Gold rose, after falling at the beginning of the week. Stocks were mixed. The pound fell lowest in 32 years.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, Theresa May’s announcement, the pound, US dollar, oil, gold.

content-body.text: Stock markets in the US and Europe slipped on Wednesday morning, the 5th of October 2016. Asian markets advanced, helped by exporters and the yen that on Tuesday experienced its biggest decline since August. Asian emerging-market stocks, by contrast, were low, and so were their currencies. The MSCI Emerging Markets Index slipped on rumours that the European Central Banks was planning to stop quantitative easing. Federal Reserve officials also contributed to its decline by hinting that interest rates would be increased this year. In the US, shares of utilities and real estate companies decreased and pulled the whole market down. Dividend paying companies were low, because investors expect rates to rise together with the yields on bonds. Prices of oil continued growing, thanks to shrinking of American stock piles; inventories decreased by 7.6 million barrels last week. Copper, nickel, and lead extended their losses for the third day already. The New Zealand dollar tumbled to a seven-week low brought down by a fall of global dairy prices. The British pound hit its lowest level in 31 years, after British Prime Minister Theresa May said that the UK is ready to give up membership of Europe’s single market in its separation from the European Union. The Dow Jones was 0.47% lower; the S&P 500 dropped 0.50%; the NASDAQ retreated 0.21%; the FTSE lost 0.22%; the German DAX edged 0.86% lower; the CAC depreciated 1.02%; the Nikkei soared 0.50%; the Hang Seng surged 0.23%; the Australian S&P/ASX was 0.57% down.

Crude oil rose again, because inventories decreased by 7.6 million barrels last week. It traded at US$49.30. Brent crude was 0.96% higher to reach $51.36. Having tumbled to US$1,300 per ounce in the last session, gold pared its losses on Wednesday and traded at $1,271.41. Other precious metals also were lower than before. Platinum added 0.34% but still traded at relatively lower price -- $989.15 per ounce. Silver also increased 0.98%, trading at only US$17.95. Copper, nickel, and lead continued falling. Cooper shed 0.02% and traded at US$2.16.

Thanks to good manufacturing and consumer confidence data, the dollar gained versus some of its major peers. The yen fell on Tuesday and remained nearly unchanged on Wednesday morning. The USD/JPY pair traded at 102.80. The pound tumbled to 1.2677 per dollar. The Euro rose, trading at 1.1222 per USD. The USD/CHF pair were 0.9776 on Wednesday morning.

US Market. After reporting strong first quarter results and promising to buy back some of its stocks, Darden Restaurants appreciated 0.54%. Because Deutsche Bank convinced the US Department of Justice to reduce the fine more than half from initially required US14 billions, the United States-listed shares of the bank jumped. The Banks Goldman Sachs Group and JP Morgan surged 0.80% and 0.17% respectively. Having presented its new phones Pixel and Pixel XL at an event in San Francisco on Tuesday, Google added 0.30%. Apple was also higher, advancing 0.43%.

European Market. Eurozone producer prices for August shed 002%. Spain’s September unemployment hit its lowest level in seven years. Thanks to increased building of residential homes, the UK construction PMI jumped to 52.3 in September from 49.2 in the previous month. Deutsche Bank advanced after the US Department of Justice had cut its fine more than half. Volkswagen said it would pay $1.2 billion to its US dealers to compensate for the diesel emissions scandal and jumped on Tuesday, though it declined slightly on Wednesday morning. Other automakers did well, too: BMW was higher, and so was Peugeot that reported that it is working on re-entering the Indian market. Peugeot added 0.04%. LVMH agreed to buy most of stakes in Rimowa for 640 million euro and jumped, though it dipped 1.05% on Wednesday. Glencore offered to buy back its debt and rose but fell slightly – 1.86% - on Wednesday. Intertek Group finished higher, and so did Greggs, whose third-quarter sales were predictively high. Because gold was lower than usual, Randgold Resources shed 2.32%. Fresnillo lost 1.97%.

Asia-Pacific Market. Because the yen deprecated and Japan consumer confidence was higher than everyone expected, the Nikkei jumped 0.50%. Topix was also 0.57% up. For the same reasons, exporters Sony, Mazda Motor, Toshiba, Panasonic, and Honda Motor gained. The camera maker Olympus also was 0.27% higher. Mitsubishi UFJ Financial was 1.22% up. When it offered to buy Bradken for A$689 million, Hitachi Construction Machinery added 1.78%. The Reserve Bank of Australia kept its increase rate without changes at 1.5%. Low inflation and high Australian Dollar caused it to maintain an existing level of rates. Banks were mixed. Miners and energy companies appreciated. Rio Tinto added on Tuesday but dipped 1.11% on Wednesday. Santos jumped on both days, increasing 1.58% on Wednesday. The Kospi finished Tuesday 0.5% higher. The Sensex edged 0.3% up, after the Reserve Bank of India lowered the key policy rate by 25 basis points.

The US is posting September ADP private employment and ISM nonmanufacturing index. It is also reporting on August international trade and factory orders. Services PMIs are being published for the UK, India, and the US. September Composite PMIS are being released for Japan, France, Germany, and the Eurozone. Australia is reporting on retail sales for August.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_October_09_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: October 09, 2016
article.description: Oil eased and traded at US$50.32 a barrel. Gold rose slightly together with other precious metals. Stocks were mostly low. The pound stopped its downfall but was still low.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, the Federal Reserve’s rates increase, the pound, OPEC meeting, oil, gold.

content-body.text: The arrival of US job reports on Friday, 07 October 2016, cheered investors up, since they showed that labour, services, and manufacturing had improved. The reports indicated that the share of working age people in the labour market hit a six-month high in September. Wages also grew. The unemployment rate advanced 5%, however. The Vice Chairman of Federal Reserve, Stanley Fischer, sounded optimistic about the job situation, saying that the creation of new job places goes together with lower unemployment, even though this is still hindered by slow general economic development. Good labour reports immediately boosted chances of the Federal Reserve’s rate hike this year. Despite the upbeat news, there were no drastic changes at stock markets: neither dollar nor bonds altered significantly on Friday. What did experience changes on Friday was oil. After Russia expressed unwillingness to make a deal with OPEC next week in Istanbul, oil slipped 1.3%, that is, below US$50 per barrel. The pound also slowed its downward movement, though still remaining 1.5% down. Stocks dropped for the first time in four weeks. In the US, stocks were pulled lower by industrial companies, whose shares dipped after Honeywell International shed 7.51%. The FTSE, however, soared 0.9%, brought higher by exporting companies that, in their turn, benefited from the falling pound. The Dow Jones decreased 0.15%; the S&P 500 lost 0.33%; the NASDAQ dropped 0.27%; the DAX dipped 0.74%; the CAC declined 0.67%; the Nikkei had a 0.23% slide; the Hang Seng edged 0.42% lower; and the Australian S&P/ASX was 0.29% down.

Iraqi Oil Minister advised local and foreign companies that pump in Iraq to increase natural gas and oil production next year. Russia’s Energy Minister spoke about the country unwillingness to sign a deal at OPEC’s next meeting on November 30 in Vienna. These talks lowered the price of oil. Rising greenback usually also decreases oil demand. US crude lost 0.30% (15 cents) to trade at $50.29 on Friday. Brent Crude shed 0.48% to reach US$52.26. Later on, oil slipped further. Now WTI is down 1.25% and is trading at US$49.81; Brent Crude is 1.10% lower, having reached US$51.93. Precious metals rose slightly but are still low. Gold added 0.22% to US$1,257.08; silver is 1.12% up to reach US$17.58; Platinum advanced 0.32%, trading at $967.99. Copper rose 0.37%, being still low. It is now trading at US$2.16.

The worst news among currencies is the drastic fall of the British pound. Within a week, the pound tumbled 6%, hitting its lowest level in 31 years. Although it managed to rise slightly on Friday, the Sterling was still 1.5% down and traded on Friday at 1.2432 per dollar. The pound was hurt by the so-called “hard-Brexit” policy that would limit the country’s access to the EU’s single market. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index dipped 0.2% on Friday. The USD/JPY pair is trading on Sunday morning at 102.98. The USD/CHF is 0.9775.

US Market. After German Apple supplier, Dialog Semiconductor, announced its unexpectedly high quarterly revenues, thereby confirming that Apple’s new iPhone is doing well, the German supplier rose 2.81%. Apple also appreciated, edging 0.15% higher. Hit by hurricane Matthew that brought the insurance industry huge losses, Florida insurance companies slid. Having declined, some of them managed, however, to advance later. On Sunday morning, Heritage Insurance showed a 5.94% advance; Universal Insurance was 14.51% in the green. Having published poor forecast for 2018, Walmart shed 0.95%. Still haunted by accusations that it had been consistently overcharging its clients for its EpiPen allergy treatment, Mylan got reduced 2.44%. Because of reports that many companies are not that interested in buying Twitter as they had appeared earlier, Twitter sank 0.10%. Tyson Foods plunged 8.91%.

European Stocks. Factory order in Germany grew 1% in August. Because German government is trying to help Deutsche Bank to solve its problem with the Department of Justice, Deutsche Bank remains 0.81% in the green. Osram, a multinational lightning manufacturer, jumped, because there were rumours that it had a buying offer from a Chinese chipmaker. Osram, however, later shed 3.72%. Air France KLM slid in France, and so did EasyJet, after the company updated its profit outlook. EasyJet dipped 4.01%. Smith & Nephew, a multinational medical equipment company based in the UK, dropped on a broker downgrade but managed to rise 1.41% later. BTG promised that its revenue would be high, considering current currency rates, and immediately advanced 0.91%. Marks & Spenser lost 4.03%.

Asia-Pacific Market. Because US job data was good and led investors to believe that the Federal Reserve would increase rates in 2016, the majority of Gulf markets declined: riskier assets are losing their attraction. Saudi Arabia’s Tadawul All Share Index deplored its first decline (0.5%) in four days. The BGCC 200 Index edged 0.3% lower, since shares in Qatar, Abu Dhabi, Kuwait, and Bahrain composing the Index all dipped dramatically. The Nikkei lost 0.23%, even though on Thursday the Index was higher, along with Topix. Exporters Toyota Motor, Mazda, and Hitachi did well. Banks were also in positive territory. After it became known that Lenovo Group was negotiating with Fujitsu the companies’ merger, Fujitsu advanced 0.25%. Lenovo Group, by contrast, depreciated 1.14%. The S&P/ASX in Australia decreased 0.29%, even though energy stocks fared well. BHP Billiton jumped 2.80%. Fortescue Metals Group added 0.20%. The four banks moved into positive territory, after news came that the German government was talking to the US Department of Justice with the aim of helping Deutsche Bank and reduce its fine for faulty mortgages. The Kospi rose 0.6%. The Sensex in India decreased 0.4%. The Hang Seng also was 0.42% lower.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_October_13_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: October 13, 2016
article.description: Oil dropped, trading at US$50.17 a barrel. Gold advanced along with other precious, while base metals sank. Stocks were low in Europe and Asia but almost unchanged in the US. The dollar is mostly up.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, oil, the pound, Federal Reserve’s September 21 meeting, precious metals, China’s export.

content-body.text: On Wednesday, 12 October 2016, stocks were mixed, though moving closer to the downside overall than remaining in positive territory. The US stocks remained virtually unchanged during the trading day, unmoved even by the release of the Federal Reserve’s minutes from September 21 FOMC meeting. As minutes made clear, some policymakers feared that postponing the rate increase would eventually require to increase rates more speedily in future. Other Federal Reserve’s members said, by contrast, that there was no hurry to raise rates: economists needed to check whether the inflation would continue improving. As policymakers made clear, they would not increase rates in November, though they might do this in December, before the year ends. The probability of the Federal Reserve’s increase in US borrowing costs by the end of the year rose 5%, estimated now around 68%. European market slid on concerns over the Federal Reserve’s intimation that it might raise rates before the year’s end. The sell-off of Chinese stalks also weighed on investors’ spirits. A drastic decline of Chines exports - 10% from the last year – and a concomitant decrease of Chinese import were taken as signs of the poor global economy in general and of Chinese economic downfall in particular. New economic reports revealed on Thursday that China’s trade surplus slipped from $52.05 billion in August to US$41.99 billion in September. China’s currency was at its six-year low against the US dollar. Overwhelmed with the same worries, Asian market also tumbled on Wednesday. Stocks in Hong Kong hit their six-week low. The Hang Seng extended its losses for the fourth day. The Dow jones Industrials added minor 0.09%; the S&P 500 edged 0.11% higher; the NASDAQ declined 0.15%. The Euro STOXX slid 1.22% in the early morning but rose slightly as the trading progressed; it was 0.93% down in the afternoon. The FTSE in London shed 0.34%; the DAX in Germany retreated 0.96%. The French CAC plummeted 1.00%. Both indices were deeply in negative area, when markets opened. The Nikkei was 0.39% lower. The Hang Seng tumbled 1.61%. The Topix index undid its early gains of 0.9% and closed almost unchanged. Because energy and Resources companies did badly in Australia, Australian markets fell on Thursday. The S&P/ASX dipped 0.71%.

Oil prices kept on dipping, sliding below $50 per barrel on Thursday. Disagreements between OPEC members concerning the curtailment of oil output negatively affected the price of oil as did the growing amount of oil stocks. West Texas International crude retreated 0.8% to reach $49.79% per barrel. Later on Thursday, WTI rose slightly to US$50.17. Brent Crude traded at US$51.84. Precious metals advanced. Gold rose 0.32% to reach US$1.259.21. Silver appreciated 0.60% and traded at US$17.61 on Thursday. Platinum pared its yesterday’s losses and edged 0.07% higher to US$943.33. Troublesome economic data from China weakened prices of base metals. Copper slipped 0.71% to US$2.16. Nickel retreated from positive territory occupied earlier, slumping 0.9%.

The dollar rose a bit against its major peers but retreated against the yen. The yen jumped 0.4% to 103.82 per dollar. The pound remained at its record low. The GBP/USD pair traded at 1.2178. The Euro was 1.1026 per dollar. The USD/CHF traded at 1.3253. The dollar spot index was about 1.00% up by the time when Asian stocks finished their morning session.

US Market. Having presented a downbeat picture of its future gains, LM Ericsson slumped but managed to rise 0.67% on Thursday morning. Juniper Networks slid 1.92%. Cisco Systems, too, were 2.26% in the red. After it said that it would purchase Newell Brands for $1.95 billion, Stanley Black & Decker gained 2.88%. Newell Brands also was 2.15% higher. Valero Energy dipped, and so did Chevron that lost 0.86%. Best Buy appreciated 3.76%. Lowe’s also closed higher. Having announced third-quarter results that were lower than expected, Fortinet lost whooping 10.06%. Humana was 5.12% down. After reporting larger profits, Barracuda Networks was 9.17% in the green. Pharmaceutical stocks declined.

European Market. Stocks in the UK were generally low. After the news arrived that China’s export and import weakened, BHP Billiton lost 2.94%. Rio Tinto followed suit and shed 2.70%. Because some products had become unavailable, Tesco sank 2.14%. Thanks to the strengthening of the UK housing market, Taylor Wimpey and Persimmon soared. With the prices of gold rising, Randgold Resources also rose, adding 1.5%. Banks did badly in Europe on Thursday. BNP Paribas dipped 1.98%. Societe Generale was 2.45% lower. Deutsche Bank moved 2.20% into negative territory. Commerzbank also slid 1.91%. Deutsche Lufthansa finished the trading day also higher. Sanofi confessed that it expects to have US$100 million charge and tumbled 1.29%. Premier Foods announced poor second-quarter sales and plummeted but managed to add 1.02% on Thursday. Even though its sales were good, Domino’s Pizza slipped. Fresnillo advanced 2.50%. Nokia shed 2.12%.

Asia-Pacific Market. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index was 0.6% lower. It was the index’s fifth day of decline. Shares of Hong Kong closed 1.4% down. The Hang Seng decreased 1.61%. Cathay Pacific Airways hit the lowest level since 2009 and lost 5%. The Nikkei retreated, while Topix closed flat. Exporters were mostly in the red: Canon, Honda Motors, Nissan, Panasonic, Sony, Toyota, and Mazda were among the losers. Softbank, Dainippon Screen Manufacturing, Kobe Steel, Nippon Steel & Sumitomo Metal, Advantest, and TDK followed suit and dipped as well. Energy stocks and mining companies in Australia also did poorly. South32, Santos, Oil Search, and Origin Energy plunged. Samsung Electronics, because of its troubles with its latest smartphone, whose recall might cost the company US$17 billion, lost initially but managed to add 1.43% on Thursday afternoon. The Kospi edged 0.1% higher.

India is giving September consumer price data. The US is reporting on export and import prices. It is also publishing weekly jobless claims and EIA natural gas and petroleum reports. Federal balance sheet is going to be released as well in the US.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_October_27_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: October 27, 2016
article.description: Oil dropped, trading at US$49.33 a barrel. Gold remained unchanged since yesterday. Stocks are mixed in Europe and the US. The dollar dropped from its 9 month high. The euro and pound were still down.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, oil, the pound, the euro, the dollar, OPEC, Presidential Elections, crude stocks

content-body.text: Stock markets closed mixed on Wednesday. Asian stocks finished lower on Thursday, before the trading in the US began and progressed significantly in Europe. American markets shuttled between losses and gains thanks to the different performance of Apple and Boeing. Apple did badly, shedding 2.25%, and pulled all indices down. Because of it, the S&P 500 dipped 0.31%. The NASDAQ retreated 0.63%. Boeing, by contrast, added 4.69% and arrested the downward movement of the US markets, pushing the Dow Jones Industrials 0.17% up. Boeing reached the highest level this year, having showed good quarterly profits. European market was also pulled in different directions because of sinking oil prices and mixed corporate earnings results. Negatively influenced by low commodities prices, energy stocks decreased but managed to balance out their losses later, after the US EIA report indicated a drop in crude inventories. Low prices of precious metals negatively affected shares of mining and resource companies. The FTSE lost 0.85%. The DAX slipped 0.44%. The CAC was 0.14% down. Asian markets extended their losses for the second day, brought lower by weakened energy stocks. Treasuries performed badly as well, negatively affected by the new data arriving from America that showed that new home sales had been unexpectedly high in September. Apple that had dragged American stocks lower on Wednesday also contributed to Asian markets’ general decline. Australian markets followed suit and closed lower because of losing Mining, Metals, and Resources companies. The Nikkei in Tokyo slumped 0.32%. The Hang Seng led Asian markets’ retreat being 0.95% lower. The S&P/ASX shed 1.20%.

Oil dropped 1.6% on Wednesday. On Thursday morning, its prices remained unchanged, just slightly below US$50 per barrel. Everyone is now awaiting the meeting of OPEC members later this week, where countries will try to resolve differences over individual quota for oil pumping. Exemption from the cuts that Iraq, Libya, Nigeria, and Venezuela claim to be entitled to will also be discussed at the meeting. Like oil prices, gold prices remained virtually unchanged on Wednesday. Investors refrain from placing money in gold ahead of the Presidential election and a rates hike in December, whose probability is estimated as high as above 70%. Gold inched 0.12% higher on Wednesday to reach US$1,268.60. Platinum rose 0.15% and traded at US$964.34. Silver slipped 0.42% to US$17.63. Base metals depreciated thanks to a report that showed that Chinese industrial companies sank to 7.7% in September from the heights of 19.5% reached in August. Aluminum, nickel, and tin slipped. Copper traded at US$2.13. WTI Crude stood at US$49.33 per barrel. Brent Crude traded at US$50.16 on Wednesday.

Mexican peso dipped 0.5% and became the biggest loser among the major currencies on Wednesday. The yen stood at 104.11 per dollar, still dwelling at a three-month low versus the greenback. The British pound weakened 0.3% and traded at 1.2214 versus the dollar but succeeded in getting higher than the record low of US$1.2082 that it hit on Tuesday. The euro also did better than it did on Tuesday, when it plummeted to 1.0851 mark, though it still retreated 0.1% on Wednesday. The Euro/USD pair traded at 1.0908. The Australian dollar was steady. The New Zealand currency was mostly flat. South Korea’s won shed 0.7% and joined the peso at the forefront of losing currencies.

Financial companies published good results in the third quarter. KeyCorp rose along with Huntington Bancshares and Chubb. They added 2.24%, 5%, and 3.72% respectively. Banks were also in positive territory on Wednesday. Simon Property Group, the owner of real estates and shopping malls, published excellent earnings and advanced 0.56%. Boston Properties presented disappointing forecasts and slumped 0.83%. Having reported slow earnings and lowered forecast, Edwards Lifesciences also tumbled, losing whooping 17.09%. Mondelez, an American multinational confectionery, food, and beverage company, showed profits that exceeded everyone’s expectations and rose 3.65% as a result. Coca-Cola also boasted larger sales than expected and appreciated 0.78%, though it retreated 0.24% on Wednesday morning. Chipotle Mexican Grill showed poor sales and slipped. Airlines did badly on Tuesday. Southwest slumped 8.46%, American Airlines sank 0.93%, and United Airlines finished 1.19% down.

Even though it published good results in the third quarter, Bayer ended 0.17% in the red. Airbus, too, said it experienced a 21% decline in the third quarter profits and dipped 0.65%. Having reported a 10% increase in sales in the third quarter, Kering, a French luxury company, slipped 0.37% nevertheless. Cap Gemini closed 0.16% lower. Mining companies in London were firmly planted in negative territory. Antofagasta decreased 2.01%; Anglo American slumped 0.37%; Glencore edged 0.31% lower; and BHP Billiton tumbled 1.44%. Royal Dutch Shell together with BP and Tullow Oil were mixed, weakened by low oil prices. Royal Dutch Shell inched 0.04% higher. BP declined 0.06%. Tullow Oil was 0.49% down. Banks were also mixed. Lloyds Banking Group announced it ability to pay additional 1 billion pounds to its wronged customers and soared 0.26%. Royal Bank of Scotland, by contrast, sank 0.83%. Banco Santander in Madrid rose 0.47%. Whitbread plummeted 1.62%.

Cnooc, which produces offshore oil and gas in China, reported a 15% decline in sales in the third quarter and lost 3%. In its wake, Bank of China tumbled to its one week low. Even though it celebrated the highest quarterly profit since 2013, Posco dropped 4%. Despite its recent troubles, Samsung Electronics rose 0.6%. Canon led losses, shedding 3%. The Shanghai Composite was 0.5% down. The Hang Seng lost the most, sinking 0.95%. Topix gained. The Nikkei slipped 0.32%. Alps Electric, Fujitsu, Asahi Group, Komatsu, and Mitsubishi Motors finished in the red. Other companies fared better and advanced. Daiichi Sankyo, Mitsui Fudosan, and Mitsubishi Materials were among the winners. Losses in Gold, Metals, Mining, and Resources sectors pushed Australian markets down. The S&P/ASX drifted 1.20% lower. Wesfarmers published poor quarterly sales and tumbled 2.73%. Unlike European banks, Australian banks floundered. The Kospi had a 1.1% slide. The Sensex in India was 0.9% down.

The Eurozone is giving M3 money supply. The UK is publishing its first estimate of third quarter gross domestic product. The US is publishing September durable goods orders and pending home sales index along with weekly jobless claims, money supply, and Fed balance sheet.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_November_03_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: November 03, 2016
article.description: Oil rallied, trading at US$45.75 a barrel. Gold prices fell weakened by expectations of a rates increase. Stocks are lower in the US and Asia and up in Europe. The dollar decreased against the yen. The pound advanced.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, oil, the pound, the euro, the dollar, OPEC, Presidential Elections, crude stocks, the Bank of England.

content-body.text: US stocks closed lower on Wednesday, weakened by the Oil and Gas, Telecoms, and Utilities sectors. Investors’ worries over the outcome of the Presidential elections have increasingly been growing since Donald Trump’s chances to become an American president strengthened. Trump’s advance spreads panic among investors, since they know what to expect from Hilary Clinton; Donald Trump is generally considered a dark horse, whose influence on the future of the country is difficult to predict. The Federal Reserve’s inactivity further aggravated everyone’s anxiety. Although, as usual, the Federal Reserve’s officials refused to spell their intentions out, they hinted that a rate hike by the end of 2016 still remains a very strong probability. Weighted down by investors’ concerns about the election and a December rates increase, the Dow Jones Industrials closed 0.43% down and thereby hit a three-month low. The S&P 500 sank 0.65%, experiencing its longest drop since 2011. The NASDAQ decreased 0.93%. Asian markets fluctuated between gains and losses, either closing flat or slightly gaining. Shanghai Composite rose 0.5%. The Nikkei was shut for the holiday and thus avoided drifting lower because of the growing yen. The Hang Seng dropped 0.56%. Australian markets declined, brought down by the poor performance of the Utilities and Consumer Discretionary sectors. The S&P/ASX inched 0.07% lower. Unlike Asian and American stocks, European market steadied on Thursday morning and remained mostly in the green, save only the German DAX index that dipped 0.02 % lower. Investors’ attention is focused today on the statement that the Bank of England is issuing in the afternoon. As elsewhere in the world, the forthcoming Presidential Elections in the US also weighed on investors’ minds and slowed down trading. The Euro Stoxx 50 appreciated 0.10%. The FTSE in London edged 0.15% higher. The French CAC rose 0.11%.

Oil prices tumbled overnight, when a new data arrived and showed that crude supplies in the US rose by the most since 1984. Worries over the failure of OPEC’s negotiations also put investors out of humour. Investors suspect that oil cuts will never be introduced: Libya, Nigeria, Iraq, and Iran have already made clear that they would not oblige. Russia’s stand on the problem is also unclear. In the morning, however, oil prices advanced slightly, rising from five-week lows. Oil prices were pushed up by the falling dollar. WTI added 0.90% to US$45.75. Brent Crude advanced 0.96% and traded at US$47.31. Gold prices fell on Thursday, weakened by expectations of the Federal Reserve’s possible rate increase in December. In the afternoon on Thursday, gold eased 0.47% and traded at US$1,290.75. Silver fell to US$18.16. Platinum shed 0.82% to US$982.90. Copper inched 0.07% to reach US$2.23.

The dollar continued slipping in the morning on Thursday. It retreated 0.5% against the yen and its other peers, because of general worries over Presidential Elections and the FBI’s investigations of Hilary Clinton’s use of unauthorised email provider. The greenback lost 0.4% against the yen. The pair traded at 102.86. The pound rose to the highest level since the tenth of October, since it became known that Theresa May cannot start getting the country out of the European Union without a parliamentary vote. After this news, the pound stood 1.2450 against the dollar.

Investors refrained from significant moves, worried about the upcoming elections. Another source of anxiety were new reports coming today: jobless claims, productivity and costs. Friday’s nonfarm payrolls for October were also on their minds, since these payrolls may become an indicators of whether the Federal Reserve is going to increase rates this year. After the company presented quarterly results that were higher than everyone expected, Electronic Arts soared. The company added 1.64%. Brocade Communications advanced whooping 9.61%, after Broadcom offered to purchase the company for US$5.5 billion. Broadcom itself surged 0.91%. The NASDAQ declined mostly because of Facebook that lost 1.80%.

Markets were supported by financial stocks that closed in the green. French banks BNP Paribas advanced 0.75%; Societe Generale rose 4.8$%, having announced that its third-quarter revenue climbed 4%. Banks in Germany followed suit and added: Deutsche Bank gained 0.23%; Commerzbank edged 0.64% up. Banco Santander in Spain was 0.63% higher. BBVA also rallied. After reporting an eight percent growth in its key profit metric in the first nine month of this year, Vonovia soared 3.76%. The FTSE in the UK was boosted most substantially by Shire PLC that added 3.61% and thereby redeemed its earlier loses. As in other parts of the Europe, financial sectors in England did well. HSBC advanced minor 0.07%. The Royal Bank of Scotland jumped 0.66%. Barclays was also 0.80% up. Among these banks, only Lloyds Banking did poorly, sinking 0.49%. Because the FTSE depends heavily on commodities, mining shares slipped. Glencore closed 1.17% lower. Anglo American was 1.50% in the red. Randgold Resources slipped 2.17%.

Bad performance of Utilities and Consumer Discretionary pulled the Australian markets down. Among winning companies were Saracen Mineral Holdings jumped whooping 10.64%. M Pharma Fp surged 7.91%. Gains of these companies, however, were not enough to outbalance losing companies that were more numerous. Boral sank 5.37%. Fairfax Media shed 4.94%. GWA Group also lost 4.29%. Overall, the S&P/ASX drifted 0.07% lower. Unlike falling Australian markets, Sri Lanka market advanced 0.20% thanks to Information Technology, Investment Trust, and Beverages & Tobacco sectors that showed a good performance on Thursday. Arpico Finance did well, adding 9.81%. Guardian Capital Partners PLC gained 6.50%. Millennium Housing Developers climbed 5.97%. Indian stocks plunged, negatively affected by weak Oil & Gas, Public Sector Undertakings, and Real Estate sectors. The Sensex closed 0.35% lower. Adani Ports & Special Economic Zone decreased 3.75%. Oil and Natural Gas Corporation lost 3.55%. Grasim Industries followed suit and fell 3.30%. The Kospi was also 1.4% down. The Nikkei was shut for holidays.

Australia is giving September merchandise trade and retail sales data. China is issuing general services PMI. The UK and India are posting October services PMI. The Eurozone is publishing September unemployment rate. The Bank of England is announcing today its monetary policy statement and Quarterly Inflation Report. The US is publishing the third quarter productivity and costs, October services PMI and ISM nonmanufacturing index, September factory orders and weekly jobless claims, money supply and Fed balance sheets.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_November_06_2016
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: November 06, 2016
article.description: Oil rallied, trading at US$44.72 a barrel. Gold prices fell weakened slightly on Friday. Stocks are lower in the US, Asia, and Europe. The dollar dropped 1.2% over the week. It did not change against the yen. The pound advanced.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, oil, the pound, the euro, the dollar, OPEC, Presidential Elections, crude stocks.

content-body.text: Trading was low volume and largely uneventful. Global stocks extended their losses to the last day of the trading week. The last time stocks experienced such terrible sell off was in June, when Brexit won the vote and announced the UK’s separation from the European Union. Investors lost their appetite for riskier deals and temporised ahead of the Presidential Elections next week and in expectation of US job reports later today. Investors are also preoccupied with the Federal Reserve’s rates hike in December, evaluating chances of a rates increase as high as 71.5%. US shares dipped following poll results showing that Clinton is only three points ahead of Donald Trump, which is a much narrower gap between them than, say, in the middle of October. The S&P 500 Index is having the longest period of losses since 2008. Planted in negative territory on Friday, the S&P had the worst streak of losses since 1980. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index also fell the deepest in seven weeks. The Topix index sank 1.6%. After jumping to the highest peak in a month on Wednesday, gold slid 0.4%. Crude oil also tumbled 8% this week, after US oil stockpiles substantially grew. On Friday, however, Crude oil advanced 0.3% but was still unable to pare its weekly losses. The yen is heading for its biggest weekly advance since July, supported by investors’ turn to safe haven. The euro and Swiss franc also celebrated gains. Dollar’s index dropped. The Turkish lira shed 0.9% after Turkish police rounded up Kurdish lawmakers. The pound has a 2.3% weekly advance, boosted by the news that Theresa May needs an approval of the Parliament to start exiting the European Union. The New Zealand kiwi led the gains among Asian currencies. The Dow Jones Industrials declined 0.16%; the S&P 500 was 0.44% lower; the NASDAQ shed 0.92%; the Euro Stoxx 50 decreased 0.69%; the FTSE plunged 1.05%; the DAX tumbled 0.73%; the CAC slipped 0.59%; the Nikkei lost 1.34%; the Hang Seng skidded 0.18%; and the S&P/ASX slid 0.86%.

After falling for five days in a row, oil managed to add slightly on Friday. What threw prices of oil down this week were growing oil stock piles that recently hit the record amount – they grew by whooping 14.4 million barrels. By insisting on being exempt from oil cuts, some countries also influenced oil prices for the worse, since their non-cooperation casts doubts on OPEC’s ability to solve the problem with oil glut. Despite Friday gains, oil is set up for an 8% of weekly loss. WTI inched 0.13% up to US$44.72; Brent Crude also added 0.13% and traded up to US$46.41. Gold prices were lower on Friday but gold is not expected to fall deeply in such uncertain times as now. Gold futures dipped 0.29% to trade at US$1,302.45. Silver futures declined 0.78% to US$18.35. Copper retreated 0.18% from its highest level since June to reach US$2.24. Platinum lost 0.24%, trading at US$993.89. Zinc slipped from a five-year peak.

The US dollar rose on Friday from a four-week low, as investors were eagerly expecting the publication of US non-farm payrolls report. The dollar weakened 1.2% this week, dragged lower by Trump’s getting the upper hand in polls: Trump’s victory only intensifies the uncertainty of the country’s political and economic future; a narrowing gap between him and Clinton, therefore, fills everyone with anxiety. The dollar did not change much against the yen. The pair traded at 102.96. The pound rose and stood at 1.2485 against the dollar. The Euro and the USD changed hands at 1.1102. The Australian dollar strengthened thanks to good retail data and good economic forecast by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The AUD/USD pair traded at 0.7684. The Swiss franc also jumped as investors rushed to safe haven. The USD was at 0.9739 versus the CHF.

Investors are awaiting for the October employment report coming out on Friday. S&P is trying to stop its downward drift, which is the longest in eight years. Companies in this Index are not doing well. The producer of fitness trackers and other fitness gear, Fitbit, tumbled on Thursday. After it cut its outlook for 2016 and reduced its sales forecast, the company dropped whooping 33.57%. Having said that its advertising revenue stopped growing as it used to, shares of Facebook decreased 5.64%. Even though it showed strong earnings and dividend increase, Starbucks shed 2.28% on Friday morning. FireEye, a cybersecurity firm, said that its revenue rose 12.6% ($186.4 million from 165.6 million last year) and advanced 15.80%, though it slid slightly on Friday morning. CBS also boasted a 4.3% rise in quarterly revenue (from $3.26 billion a year ago to $3.39 billion this year) and gained 0.63%. Monster Beverage shed 6.6%, after it presented poor quarterly results and consequently cut its price targets. GoPro tumbled 19.2%, after its forecast for the holiday quarter proved to be lower than expected.

European market declined on Friday thanks to investors’ anxiety over the outcome of the Presidential Elections. Clinton’s diminishing chances to win triggers heightened worries about the future of the country, since, with Clinton being known in the political world, it is less difficult to foresee her influence on the US than Trump’s. On Friday, financial stocks finished lower. BNP Paribas decreased 1.24%; Societe Generale lost 0.97%. Deutsche Bank slipped 1.47%. Commerzbank followed suit and dropped 2.53%, after reporting net loss of €235 million. The FTSE in London was brought down by the poor performance of miners. Glencore edged 0.31% down. Rio Tinto plunged along with BHP Billiton and Randgold Resources. They lost 1.26%, 1.37%, and 2.39% respectively. As happened in other parts of Europe, British banks plunged. HSBC gave up 0.79%; Barclays was 1.65% down. The Royal Bank of Scotland also closed lower, dipping 1.93%. Lloyds Banking again was the only bank that stood out among these losing companies. The bank inched 0.23% higher. It was later joined by another winner, Power Betfair. Its shares advanced 3.61%, after the company updated its earning predictions.

Asian markets also tumbled on Friday, weakened by investors’ worries over the outcome of the Presidential Elections. Coming back from a day of holidays, the Nikkei sank. The index was dragged down by the decline of Insurance, Trading, and Pharmaceutical sectors. JGP tumbled 8.59%. At the close, Casio Computer slipped 7.71%, while Minebea was 7.19% lower. Among gaining companies were Tokai Carbon and Furukawa Electric. The former added 12.78%; the latter climbed 7.88% and thus hit a five-year high. Nippon Suisan Kaisha appreciated 7.19%. Dragged down by Information Technology, Power & Energy, and Footwear & Textile stocks, Sri Lanka market closed lower. CSE All-Share slid 0.11% at the close. Kalamazoo systems did badly and slipped whooping 11.59%. Paragon Ceylon PLC dropped 10.34%. Madulsima Plantations decreased 9.30%. There were also gaining companies, though they could not outnumber losing ones and did not bring the Index into positive territory. Stocks in India did not make an exception and finished the day in the red. Sensex edged 0.57% lower after the close on Friday. Real Estate, Healthcare, and Metals sectors caused the Index to decline. Sun Pharmaceutical Industries plummeted 7.08%. Dr Reddy’s Laboratories and Bharti Infratel slumped. The first gave up 5.22%; the second was 4.57% lower. Lupin joined the team of losers and depreciated 3.57%. Australian markets did badly as well. Metal and Mining, Gold, and Financial sectors led them lower. At the close, the S&P/ASX reached a three-months low. M Pharma lost whooping 14.60%. Flight Centre also closed 8.19% lower. Genworth also retreated 7.62%. The winners on Friday were less in number and could not save the market from falling. After President Park Geun-Hye replaced the prime and finance ministers, the Kospi rose 0.2%.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_03_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 03, 2017
article.description: Oil rallied, trading at US$44.72 a barrel. Gold prices fell weakened slightly on Friday. Stocks are lower in the US, Asia, and Europe. The dollar dropped 1.2% over the week. It did not change against the yen. The pound advanced.
article.keywords: Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Review, oil, the pound, the euro, the dollar, OPEC, Presidential Elections, crude stocks.

content-body.text:
It's the first full trading day of 2017, and markets are up in Asia and Europe. Tokyo doesn't reopen until tomorrow, but in Shanghai CSI 300 is up by 0.97%, in Hong Kong the Hang Seng has gained 0.68%, and Down Under the S&P ASX is up 1.19%. In Europe's trading, the first half of the session has seen strong gains in stock share prices. The DAX is up 0.11%, the CAC 40 has gained 0.60%, and the FTSE 100 has advanced 0.33%.

The Chinese markets got a boost earlier when the Caixin manufacturing index beat the forecast – of 50.7 – and came in at 51.9. The strong data point is a good omen for the world's second largest economy, and investors responded with optimism.

In the currency markets, the Chinese yuan is actually down. The People's Bank of China set the currency's trading midpoint at 6.9498, which is actually a game of catch up as the less official offshore rate is already closing on 7 yuan to the dollar.

The dollar, meanwhile, is seeing strong gains today. The USD/JPY is up to 118.14 and the USD/CHF has gained to 1.0277. The EUR/USD slid down a bit, to 1.0411 and the GBP/USD remains low at 1.2291.

In commodity markets, oil has gained on reports that Kuwait is honoring its production cutback commitments. Brent crude is up to $58.08 per barrel, and WTI, the US benchmark price, is up to $54.96.

Precious metals are up, as well. Gold is trading at $1,148.25 per ounce, and platinum is selling for $907.15. Silver is down slightly, at $15.97 per ounce. In industrial metals, copper is up to $2.54 per pound, on optimism about Chinese manufacturing. China is the world's largest single consumer of copper, accounting for 45% of the world's copper use, so a boost in their manufacturing sector will boost copper as well.

That's the trading news in a nutshell. Happy New Year!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_04_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 04, 2017
article.description: Stocks were up in the US yesterday, while the European markets are opening to losses today. The Asia-Pacific region saw mostly gains in today's session.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, gold, markets, crude oil.

content-body.text:
Stocks were up in the US yesterday, while the European markets are opening to losses today. The Asia-Pacific region saw mostly gains in today's session.

The Dow Jones is up by 0.60%. The S&P 500 and NASDAQ both gained 0.85%; it was the best showing the S&P in over a year. In Asia, the Tokyo's markets saw large gains, as the Nikkei 225 picked up 2.51% and the TOPIX index advanced 2.36%. The CSI 300 index in Shanghai gained 0.78%, but the Hang Seng in Hong Kong slipped 0.07%. Europe's major markets are the odd man out today, showing losses in the early trading. The FTSE 100 is down 0.02%, the DAX has slipped a quarter percent, and the CAC 40 is down 0.06%.

In currency trading, the US dollar is down slightly after yesterday's gains, mostly as investors took profits. The EUR/USD is up to 1.0436, the GBP/USD is up to 1.2281, and the AUD/USD is trading at 0.7263. The USD/JPY has dipped to 117.53 and the USD/CHF is down at 1.0255. The dollar has lost the most against the Canadian loonie, as that currency has gotten a boost from recent gains in oil (despite today's dip in crude prices). The USD/CAD is down 0.82%, to 1.3317.

As mentioned, oil has slipped today. Like the dollar, this is on profit taking as investors realize what they can from recent gains. Crude markets are a bit different, however, as traders are also worried that the source of those recent gains – the OPEC agreement to cut back on production in cooperation with non-OPEC countries – may be more fragile than the major producing countries want people to think. Libya and Nigeria are both exempt from the cuts, and both are trying to ramp up production, and in the US, which was never a party to the agreement, oil companies are expanding operations in the shale patches. Industry analysts are uncertain about the future of the oil markets. Right now, Brent crude is priced at $55.81 per barrel and WTI is set at $52.64.

While oil is down, precious metals are up. Gold has gained almost two-thirds of a percent, to reach $1,166.08 per ounce, silver is selling at $16.44, and platinum has gained 0.95% and stands at $945.39. These gains may be fleeting, however, as the US Federal Reserve is expected to increase interest rates three times this year. Watch for the Fed's December meeting minutes today, and see how metals react to that news.

Coming up on Friday, watch for the US jobs report from the Department of Labor. A strong report is sure to be used as justification for the Fed's projected moves on rates, and will likely boost the dollar and hurt gold.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_08_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 08, 2017
article.description: Friday brought us the official US jobs report, record high levels in Wall Street's stock markets, and gains for the US dollar.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, non-farm payroll, jobs report, crude oil

content-body.text:
Friday saw the release of the Non-Farm Payroll report in the US, the government's monthly summary of labor market conditions. Also referred to as the NFP or the jobs report, the data release by the Department of Labor showed a headline print of 156,000 new jobs created in December, and 2.2 million new jobs for 2016 as a whole. They were good numbers, but the monthly data missed expectations by 22,000 and the yearly number was a half-million lower than 2015. Unemployment ticked up slightly to 4.7%, and the labor force participation rate remained mired near 35-year high levels, at 62.7%.

Wall Street responded well to the jobs report data, with the main indexes reaching record level highs. At one point during Friday's trading session the Dow Jones average reached 19,999.63, before slipping back to finish the day at 19,963.80. The S&P 500 and the NASDAQ gained 0.35% and 0.60% respectively. Stocks also gained in Europe. The FTSE 100 in London picked up 0.33%, the DAX added 0.12%, and the CAC 40 gained 0.60%. Trading was relatively quiet in London, but more volatile on the Continent.

The Asia-Pacific region saw more mixed trading, with gains in Hong Kong and Australia but losses in Japan and mainland China. The Hang Seng picked up 0.21% and the S&P ASX gained a thin 0.04%. In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 lost 0.34% and the TOPIX slipped 0.15%. Shanghai's CSI 300 index saw a loss of 0.60% for the day.

The currency markets saw gains across the board for the US dollar. The EUR/USD slipped to 1.0532, the GBP/USD dropped to 1.2287, and the AUD/USD dropped to 0.7301. The USD/JPY showed the largest gains for the dollar, adding 1.45% to reach 117.02. The USD/CAD advanced to 1.3237, and the USD/CHF increased to 1.0180. The dollar has been consistently above parity with the Swiss franc since November 15.

Oil prices were basically stable to close out last week. The global trading benchmark grade, Brent crude, ended at $57.10 per barrel, and the US benchmark, WTI, closed at $53.99. The oil markets are getting price support from OPEC giants Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, both of which have indicated that they will comply with the recent agreement to cut back on production. The agreement was negotiated within OPEC and with other major oil producers in an effort to cut into the global oil supply glut and provide price support for the markets. Oil industry analysts are pointing to $60 per barrel as a natural price level in the current market conditions.

Precious metals rose through most of last week, but gold and silver pulled back on Friday. Gold is priced at $$1,172.63 per ounce, down 0.63% from the week's high point, while silver slipped 0.71% to $16.52. Platinum did better holding on to gains, and added 0.02% to finish last week at $968.20 per ounce.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_09_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 09, 2017
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, Federal Reserve, crude oil, gold, jobs report

content-body.text:
It's a new week, and stock markets are looking up. Shanghai's CSI 300 index has gained 0.48%, the Hang Seng in Hong Kong is up 0.22%, and Australia's S&P ASX is up 0.90%. Trading has yet to open on Wall Street or in Europe, but the futures markets are showing gains there, too. Japanese markets will be closed today for a public holiday.

The US dollar and gold have both gained in the day's early trading. The dollar index has risen to 102.330, and the trend appears upwards. The GBP/USD is down to 1.2176, a sharp loss of 0.90% for sterling, and the USD/JPY is up at 117.39, a gain of 0.32% for the US dollar. The dollar has also gained against the Canadian currency, putting the USD/CAD at 1.3258.

The Euro and Swiss franc are both basically flat today. The EUR/USD is up a slight 0.06%, to 1.0538, while the USD/CHF is stable at 1.0181.

Gold is currently priced at $1,173.98, up 0.12% from last week, and platinum has gained 0.50% to $973.00. Silver remains down, at $16.50. The gains in gold and platinum came as investors sought a hedge for uncertainty, which brings us to oil.

Oil prices are down today, by about a half percentage point. The drop comes as traders grow skeptical about the efficacy of the OPEC production cutback plan, despite Saudi and Kuwaiti adherence to the new quotas. Iran, Libya, and Nigeria – all OPEC members – were all exempted from the plan, and all three are working hard to increase production. At the same time, US shale field oil producers have increased the active rig count again, for the tenth straight week in a row. Oil market traders fear that if the lower OPEC quotas succeed in boosting prices, the US shale fields will simply take up the slack. There is real doubt about whether or not the lower quotas will hold.

All of that brought crude oil prices down. The global trading benchmark grade, Brent crude, is selling at $56.80 per barrel, and the US benchmark, West Texas Intermediate, is priced at $53.67.

Looking ahead this week, we'll have Donald Trump's first press conference since the election; several speeches from Federal Reserve officials,including Fed chair Janet Yellen, and data on December's US retail sales and China's December trade numbers. It should be an interesting week.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_10_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 10, 2017
article.description: Risk perceptions are driving markets today, prompting gains in safe haven assets and losses for the US dollar and several major stock indexes.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, Japanese yen, Swiss franc, safe have, gold

content-body.text:
Perceptions of risk are in the markets today, bringing us mixed results in stocks but gains for traditional safe haven assets such as the Japanese yen, the Swiss franc, and gold.

Starting with stocks, Wall Street saw both gains and retreats at yesterday's close. The Dow Jones slipped back from its record high, losing 0.38% for the day, while the S&P 500 fell 0.35%. The tech-heavy NASDAQ advanced 0.19%.

Starting with stocks, Wall Street saw both gains and retreats at yesterday's close. The Dow Jones slipped back from its record high, losing 0.38% for the day, while the S&P 500 fell 0.35%. The tech-heavy NASDAQ advanced 0.19%.

The Asia-Pacific region is winding down for the day, closing out a session that saw mostly losses. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 fell 0.79% and the TOPIX dropped 0.71%. Both of those indexes fell as the Japanese yen saw gains, a common pattern in that export-dependent country. In China, markets in Hong Kong and Shanghai showed a sharp divergence. The Hang Seng gained 0.83%, but the CSI 300 in Shanghai fell 0.17%. Australia's S&P ASX lost 0.80% for the day.

Among currencies, the Japanese yen and the Swiss franc posted gains on safe haven demand. The USD/JPY pair is down to 115.94, and the USD/CHF has retreated to 1.0127. The dollar slipped against Euro, too, as the EUR/USD rose to 1.0601. The pound sterling lost ground, after comments by Prime Minister May renewed concerns about the timing, pace, and effect of implementing the Brexit policy. The GBP/USD is down to 1.2139.

In the metals markets, gold is gaining ground on the same safe haven demand that his helping out the yen and the franc. Gold is currently priced at $1,184.46 per ounce. Gold dropped below the $1,200 mark on November 23. It seems that the move to precious metals wasn't transferrable to metals other than gold, as silver and platinum are down, losing almost as much overnight as gold gained. Silver is selling for $16.65 per ounce, and platinum for $970.76.

Oil prices have recovered about a tenth of a percent, after a sharp overnight drop. Brent, the global benchmark grade, is selling at $54.97 per barrel, and WTI for $52.05. Oil prices are under pressure from traders' doubts that the OPEC agreement to curtail production and boost prices will be as effective as the hype, and from increased drilling activity in the US and Canada. Additionally, the US government in a surprise move released 8 million barrels of crude from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve for sale this month. While this is a temporary factor, it is definitely bearish for the North American oil markets.

That's the trading news this morning. Have a great day in the markets!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_16_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 16, 2017
article.description: American markets are closed for a holiday, while the US dollar, Japanese yen, and gold are all up.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, Japanese yen, gold, oil

content-body.text:
In the markets today, the US dollar is generally up, mostly due to weakness in the pound and Euro. The pound is facing pressure from the upcoming Brexit; British PM Theresa May is scheduled to speak tomorrow, and she is expected to give some details on her plans for implementing the separation of the UK from the EU. Investors are worried that she'll opt for the 'hard' Brexit, a sharp and sudden break, and that markets will reach with chaos until new immigration, trade, and financial agreements are forged.

Those worries pushed the GBP/USD down to 1.2055, and the EUR/USD down to 1.0593. The USD/JPY, on the other hand, has shown weakness for the dollar – the pair has dipped to 114.16, a loss of nearly a third of a percent as haven demand boosts the Japanese yen over the US dollar. Against the other majors, the dollar is holding steady – the USD/ CHF is up to 1.0121, the USD/CAD is up to 1.3140, and the AUD/USD is down to 0.7474.

Some of these currency moves are having the expected impact in the financial markets. The weaker pound is giving a lift to stocks in London, where companies respond well to any factor that makes exports cheaper. The FTSE 100 is up 0.095 today. In Japan, however, also export dependent, the Nikkei 225 and TOPIX index have lost 1% and 0.92% respectively. Stocks are also down in China and Continental Europe. The Hang Seng fell 0.96%, the CSI 300 dipped 0.01%, the DAX fell 0.64%, and the CAC 40 is down 0.63%.

US markets are closed today, for the Martin Luther King public holiday. Wall Street's trading will resume tomorrow.

In the commodity markets, oil prices are edging down. It's becoming clear to investors that the OPEC agreement to cut production and boost prices may not hold up. Even the Saudi Energy Minister has said that the agreement is unlikely to be extended beyond six months. With that in mind, Brent crude edged down to $55.28 per barrel and WTI has slipped to $52.21.

Precious metals are picking up the slack, gaining from the same haven demand that has boosted the Japanese yen. Gold has broken above $1,200, and is now selling at $1,203.73 per ounce, silver is up to $16.85, and platinum is steady at $984.95.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_17_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 17, 2017
article.description: American markets are closed for a holiday, while the US dollar, Japanese yen, and gold are all up.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, Japanese yen, Donald Trump, Theresa May, gold, oil

content-body.text: Investors today will be watching Theresa May, Prime Minister of the UK, as she outlines her policy plans for the upcoming Brexit – Britain's departure from the European Union. While May has indicated that she will be starting the Brexit process by the end of March, she has not yet laid out a definite policy path. In today's speech she is expected to set out plans for the "hard" Brexit, that is, a sharp separation between the UK and the EU. Expect her to prioritize UK border control and a full exit from the common market – both important preconditions to negotiating new trade relations with the EU.

Tomorrow will bring a speech from Janet Yellen, chair of the US Federal Reserve. Yellen, as head of the US central bank, is responsible for setting forth the Fed's future monetary policy. While she announced in December a rate hike and intent to implement three more hikes in 2017, markets have only priced in two of the future moves. Yellen's speech is expected to clarify her stance toward monetary tightening policy going forward.

Finally, Donald Trump will take office as President of the United States on Friday. His inaugural address will carefully watched for clues to policy paths. Like May, Trump's general intent is known but he has yet to set out the details.

In the run-up to these events, global stocks are down, the dollar is down, and oil is volatile. Safe haven assets – especially the Japanese yen and gold – are on the upside. In the currency markets, the US dollar index is down to 100.630 and remains on a downward trend. Of the main currency pairs, the EUR/USD stands at 1.0704, the GBP/USD is trading at 1.2176, and the USD/JPY has fallen to 112.84.

Turning to precious metals, we see a series of gains. Gold has rallied strongly this year, posting gains in the last seven sessions, and in every January session but one. Gold is currently priced at $1,217.87 per ounce. Platinum has gained to $992.27. Silver has posted the best return of the precious metals today, gaining more than two percent to sell at $17.11 per ounce.
That's where the markets stand. Have a great week trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_18_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 18, 2017
article.description: American markets are closed for a holiday, while the US dollar, Japanese yen, and gold are all up.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, Japanese yen, Donald Trump, Theresa May, gold, oil

content-body.text: Theresa May gave the pound sterling a boost yesterday, when she said that her plans for the Brexit include a vote by both houses of Parliament before the policy can take effect. The news indicates that, while she may still pursue a "hard" exit from the EU she is also remaining open to compromise. Sterling jumped, and the GBP/USD is now trading at 1.2340.

Sterling's gain does not reflect overnight strength for the US dollar. The greenback has gained against its major peers in early trading today. The EUR/USD slipped to 1.0699 and the AUD/USD edged down to 0.7557. The USD/JPY gained almost half a percent, to 113.15, as the USD/CAD edged up to 1.3055 and the USD/CHF remains above parity at 1.0020.

The dollar's gains, while modest, are a reversal of recent sharp losses. The US dollar index reflects this, moving up to 100.52 from yesterday's 100.33. The index compares the dollar to trade-weighted basket of peer currencies.

In commodity markets, precious metals have reversed more than week of gains. Gold slipped a quarter percent to $1,213.65 per ounce, and platinum is down 0.15% to $974.50. Silver is basically flat, showing a 0.16% gain and a price of $17.18 per ounce.
European and American stocks are not yet open for trading today; all were down at yesterday's close, but their future markets are predicting gains when trading resumes.
That's the market news for today. Have a great day!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_19_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 19, 2017
article.description: Janet Yellen made a stir in the markets yesterday, after she expressed faith in the strength and future of the US economy.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, haven assets, gold, yen, US dollar, crude oil

content-body.text: Janet Yellen made a stir in the markets yesterday, after she expressed faith in the strength and future of the US economy. The US dollar promptly gained in the forex markets, and haven assets retreated.
While it has eased back slightly, the greenback is holding on to those gains. The EUR/USD is trading at 1.0664, and the GBP/USD stands at 1.2318. The USD/JPY is trading at 114.53.

The yen has dipped on the general retreat of haven assets, as have gold and silver. Gold is currently priced at $1,204.65 per ounce, and silver at $16.98. Silver has shown the largest loss of the precious metals, down nearly two percent from yesterday.

In the stocks markets, the main indexes are mixed. Tokyo's stocks are up, as is common when the yen retreats. The Nikkei 225 and the TOPIX index both gained 0.94%. China's markets are down – the CSI 300 lost 0.30% – but Australia's are up, with the S&P ASX adding 0.24%.

On Wall Street, the Dow was down 0.11% yesterday, but S&P 500 gained 0.18% and the NASDAQ advanced 0.31%. Europe's markets are opening to losses today, ranging from a tenth of a percent for the DAX to almost a half percent for the FTSE 100.

Crude oil is up, rebounding from overnight lows. Oil investors are confused, as inventory data from the US showed a large draw in crude oil stocks – more than 4 million barrels – combined with an even larger build – over 9 million barrels – in gasoline stocks. WTI, the US trading benchmark, is priced at $51.57 per barrel. Brent crude, the global benchmark, stands at $54.46.
That's today's the market news. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_22_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 19, 2017
article.description: Donald Trump took office as President of the United States on Friday, and safe haven assets jumped in the markets.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, haven assets, gold, yen, US dollar, crude oil, Donald Trump

content-body.text: Donald Trump took office as President of the United States on Friday, and safe haven assets jumped in the markets. The Japanese yen, the Swiss franc, and gold all made gains. The USD/JPY slipped to 114.62, a gain of 0.21% for the yen, while the USD/CHF fell to 1.0016, a gain of 0.46% for the franc. Gold jumped 0.45%, to sell for $1,210.32 per ounce, but platinum showed an even better gain, adding 1.95% to trade at $978.20.

While haven assets gained, stocks also did well. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones gained 0.48%, the S&P 500 added 0.34%, and the NASDAQ advanced 0.28%. Business leaders expressed optimism about the incoming administration, including hopes that President Donald Trump will follow through on promised to roll back Federal regulations, cut taxes, and encourage stimulus spending.

The European and Asia-Pacific stock markets were mostly closed by the time of the inaugural ceremonies. European stocks ended the day's session with gains on the Continent, where the DAX was up 0.29% and the CAC 40 added 0.20%. The FTSE 100 in London slipped 0.14%. Turning to the Pacific Rim, we see that shares in Tokyo were up. The Nikkei 225 added 0.34% and the TOPIX gained 0.35%, while in Shanghai the CSI 300 index was up 0.77%. The Hang Seng slipped, by 0.71%, and the S&P ASX in Australia was down 0.66%.

In the currency markets, the US dollar slipped at the end of the week, as investors shifted to stocks and haven assets. The EUR/USD moved up to 1.0703, and the GBP was up to 1.2375. As noted above, the US dollar slipped against the yen and the Swiss franc, but it was basically flat against the Canadian dollar, with the USD/CAD trading at 1.3320.

Crude oil prices rose, as OPEC and non-OPEC oil officials met in Vienna to discuss the progress of the production cutback agreement. Globally, crude oil production is down by nearly 1.5 million barrels so far this year, a good portion of the 1.8 million barrel decrease envisioned by the producers. The agreement was intended to boost prices, and has so far shown a modest success. Crude oil is selling in the $55 range, with Brent, the global benchmark grade, priced at $55.49 per barrel and WTI, the US trading benchmark, selling for $53.22.
That's where the markets stand this weekend. We'll see on the trading floor tomorrow!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_23_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 23, 2017
article.description: The week's trading is getting started with losses in stock markets, a drop in the US dollar, and gains for safe haven assets.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, safe haven, gold, Japanese yen, US dollar, crude oil, Donald Trump

content-body.text: The week's trading is getting started with losses in stock markets, a drop in the US dollar, and gains for safe haven assets.

In the stock markets, futures trading is showing Wall Street's indexes down even before the day's session gets started. Should this continue, it will put New York's markets in line with markets in Asia and Europe, were most of the main indexes are volatile today, and many are down.

Taking a look at some numbers, we see the FTSE 100 in London is up 0.33% after a shaky start, and the CAC 40 in France up 0.60% after losing a similar amount earlier. The DAX is still down, posting a loss of 0.40%.

China's markets are up. The Hang Seng has showed a gain of 0.06% and the CSI 300 index added 0.27%. In Australia and Japan, however, trading wasn't so good. The S&P ASX lost 0.77%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 is down 1.29% and the TOPIX index fell 1.23%. The losses in Japan coincide with gains in the yen, showing the familiar pattern of Japanese stocks and currency moving in opposite directions. This is common in export-dependent economies, as a cheaper currency will boost stocks by making exports more affordable overseas.

In the forex markets, the US dollar is showing losses. The Euro gained a third of a percent, and the EUR/USD climbed to 1.0740. Cable also made strong gains, of 0.77%, as the GBP/USD rose to 1.2465. The commodity sensitive Canadian and Australian dollars also gained, despite drops in the price of oil. The USD/CAD slipped to 1.3277, and the AUD/USD advanced to 0.7561. The Aussie was the weakest gainer among the major currencies; its gain was only 0.08%.

The USD/JPY has slipped to 113.47, a loss of 1%, and has been reflected in the Japanese stock markets as noted above. The USD/CHF is also down, having dipped below parity to 0.9985. This is the first time in two months that the pair has been below parity. Both the Japanese yen and the Swiss franc have made their gains on strong demand for safe haven assets.

That same haven demand also underlay gains in precious metals. Gold is up to $1,213.03 per ounce, a gain of a quarter percent since Friday, and platinum has gained a half percent to trade at $983.25. Silver is the best performer among the precious metals this morning, adding almost one percent to trade at $17.19 per ounce.

Crude oil prices are volatile today, reflecting investor confusion in the face of conflicting price pressures. OPEC's production cut agreement is putting an upward pressure on prices, but that same upward price pressure encourages US shale drillers to open more rigs, putting a downward pressure on prices. Right now, WTI, the US trading benchmark, is selling for $52.42 per barrel, a gain of two percent, while Brent crude, the global pricing benchmark, is set at $54.86, a drop of more than one percent. The oil markets will bear close watching over the next few weeks.
That's where the markets stand as trading gets started today. Have a great week!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_24_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 24, 2017
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex

content-body.text: Global stock markets are mostly down as trading starts today, on worries about the President Donald Trump's recent actions on trade agreements. The new US President has promised to renegotiate the NAFTA trade accord, and has withdrawn from the Trans-Pacific Partnership. In fairness, the TPP was never submitted by President Obama to the US Senate for ratification, and so was not binding on the US, and the Trump has told the Canadian and Mexican governments that he wants new bilateral trade agreements that will bring greater benefit to all three North American countries.

Still, Trump has succeeded in casting uncertainty over current trade arrangements. In addition to his desire it rework existing treaties, he was also promised a "border tax" on corporations that move manufacturing facilities out of the US and then reimport the finished products. Investors have responded to the new President's moves by shifting money into safe haven assets.

Stock markets have dipped in recent sessions. Wall Street and the European markets are not yet open as of this writing, but all were down at yesterday's close. Futures trading predicts more losses today in New York, and only small gains in Europe.

n Asia, today's session is winding down with losses in Japan and gains in China and Australia. The Nikkei 225 and the TOPIX are both down 0.55%, while the Hang Seng gained 0.22% and the CSI 300 in Shanghai was nearly flat, with a gain of 0.01%. Down Under, the S&P ASX was up by 0.70%.

Forex markets have also felt the turmoil, and the dollar has dropped sharply since before the inauguration of President Trump. Despite some overnight gains for the greenback, the dollar continues to show softness. The EUR/USD is trading at 1.0746, the GBP/USD stands at 1.2500, the USD/JPY shows 113.22, and the USD/CHF is just below parity, at 0.9989.

The weakness in the dollar has helped out the price of oil, which is priced in dollars becomes more expensive when the greenback declines. WTI, the US benchmark grade, is set at $53.07 per barrel, and the global pricing benchmark Brent crude sells at $55.56.
Precious metals slipped on profit taking overnight, but continue to show strength. Gold is selling for $1,214.10 per ounce, and platinum for $981.75. Silver gained 0.18%, to stand at $17.16.
That's the market news. Have a great day!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_25_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 25, 2017
article.description: Global stock markets up today, marking a shift from haven assets back toward risk as investors decide that they can live with President Trump.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, Trump, gold, US dollar

content-body.text: Global stock markets up today, marking a shift from haven assets back toward risk as investors decide that they can live with President Trump.
On Wall Street, the S&P 500 rose to an all-time record yesterday, of 2,280.07. The other indexes also gained, with the Dow adding 0.57% and the NASDAQ advancing 0.86%.

The Asia-Pacific stock markets have just wound down, and showed gains as well. The Nikkei 225 and the TOPIX both gained in Japan, getting a boost from positive export numbers. The Nikkei added 1.43% and the TOPIX gained 1.01%. Gains were more modest in China, as the CSI 300 gained 0.34% and the Hang Seng gained 0.435. Down Under, the S&P ASX added 0.77%.

Europe's markets are continuing the good run. In London, the FTSE 100 has gained 0.32%, the DAX in Germany is up 1.31%, and the French CAC 40 is up 1.03%. The British stocks were boosted by a Supreme Court ruling that the government must put the Brexit implementation policy to a Parliamentary vote; while a defeat for Theresa May, the ruling promises that the process will be accompanied by great debate and hence, greater transparency.

Currency markets are quiet today, without a lot of volatility. The EUR/USD is up, showing 1.0749. The GBP/USD has also gained, adding 0.44% to reach 1.2575. The US dollar also edged down against the yen and the Swiss franc, putting the USD/JPY at 113.56 and the USD/CHF at 0.9986.
Precious metals declined as stocks gained. Gold slipped a third of a percent to $1,204.76 per ounce, silver dropped 1.43% to $16.96, and platinum fell a slight 0.12% to sell for $994.80.

Oil prices are reacting to news of stockpile builds in the US and increased production in Libya. The API reported yesterday on a large build in inventory, and forecasts for the EIA numbers later today show an expectation for 2.8 million more barrels in stockpiles. The numbers indicate either increased US production or soft demand; in either case, supply is exceeding demand.

In Libya, which holds Africa's largest oil reserves, production is up to 715,000 barrels per day. The country is trying to rebuild its oil industry after several years of anarchy and civil war. The OPEC member was exempted from the cut agreement, and is free to pump as much oil it wants under the new quotas.
Prices in crude oil edged down overnight, with Brent crude dipping to $54.94 and WTI dropping to $52.68 per barrel. The changes represent drops of about one percent.
That's the market news. Have a great day!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_26_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 26, 2017
article.description: Stocks remain high today, and the Dow Jones hit a new all time-record in yesterday's session, breaking above the psychologically important 20,000 level for the first time.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, gold, crude oil, stocks

content-body.text: Stocks remain high today, and the Dow Jones hit a new all time-record in yesterday's session, breaking above the psychologically important 20,000 level for the first time. The Dow stood at 20,068.51 at the closing bell.
The S&P 500 and the NASDAQ also saw gains, with the S&P adding 0.80% and the tech-heavy NASDAQ picking up 0.99%. Percentage-wise, the NASDAQ saw the largest gains.

Over in the Asia-Pacific region, where today's session is winding down, the gains continued. The Nikkei 225 is up 1.81%, the TOPIX is up 1.54%, and the Hang Seng saw a gain of 1.41%. Gains were smaller in mainland China, where the CSI 300 added 0.36%, and in Australia, where the S&P ASX posted a gain of 0.38%.

At this writing, the European markets are in the early part of the session, and again, gains are the name of the game. The FTSE 100 is up 0.23%, the DAX is up 0.53%, and the CAC 40 has advanced 0.40%.

The gains in stocks, and the move back to riskier assets, helped push precious metals down. Gold is back below $1,200, after nearly two weeks above that level.
