The metal is currently priced at $1,192.50 per ounce, a loss of 0.65%. Silver is down a similar percentage, 0.68%, and is selling at $16.87 per ounce. Platinum is still holding on to gains for now, with a price of $980.65.

In the currency markets, the US dollar is starting regain some of its recent losses. The pound, Euro, and yen are all down between a quarter and one percent. The GBP/USD stands at 1.2610, the EUR/USD at 1.0720, and the USD/JPY at 114.25. Despite these gains, the dollar remains soft, with the US dollar index at 100.31. The index dipped as far as 99.81 earlier this morning.

Oil prices are volatile, but trading in a narrow range. Despite OPEC's best efforts – to reach an agreement on lower production quotas, and then to talk up adherence to those quotas – prices are not getting back up to the $60 per barrel range.

The downward price pressure comes from several sources. First, Libya, Nigeria, and Iran – all important OPEC players – were exempt from the production cut agreement, and have been increasing output for a variety of internal policy reasons. Second, US shale producers were never a party to the cut agreement and have been using the modestly higher prices to increase production. And finally, a combination of high output and weak demand has help oil stockpiles at historically high levels. A report from the US yesterday showed a build of 2.84 million barrels in inventories, putting the nation's stockpiles at a total of more than 430 million barrels of crude oil.
It's no wonder, then, that WTI oil is set at $52.90 per barrel and Brent crude is selling at $55.35. The oil markets just aren't getting traction for higher prices.

Industrial metals, however, are getting that traction. Copper, used as a proxy for the industrial metal market due to its prevalence in a wide variety of construction and manufacturing processes, is up 0.31%. The metal is currently priced at $2.72 per pound.
Have a great day in the trading markets!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_January_31_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: January 31, 2017
article.description: There's a lot going on in the markets this week. In Asia, the Chinese and Hong Kong markets are closed for the Lunar New Year holiday; they'll be back as normal on Friday.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, Trump, gold, crude oil, haven asset, safe haven, US dollar

content-body.text: There's a lot going on in the markets this week. In Asia, the Chinese and Hong Kong markets are closed for the Lunar New Year holiday; they'll be back as normal on Friday. Elsewhere in the Asia-Pacific region, the Japanese Nikkei and TOPIX both were down, by 1.69% and 1.43% respectively, and the S&P ASX slipped 0.72% in Australia.

Wall Street's markets have not opened for today's trading yet, but were down in yesterday's session. The Dow Jones slipped 0.61%, putting it back below the 20K mark it hit five days ago. The S&P 500 was down 0.60%, and the NASDAQ dropped 0.83%. The Wall Street indexes, especially the NASDAQ, will bear watching this week, as a number of major companies will be reporting Q4 earnings. Tech giants Amazon, Facebook, and Apple are among those reporting.
In Europe, also, stocks are up after today's open, with the FTSE 100 gaining 0.50%, the DAX up 0.09%, and the CAC 40 advancing 0.24%.

The Bank of Japan reported on monetary policy earlier today, and as expected, it help steady. The yen advanced slightly, but has since slipped back. The BoJ statement, while important, did not generate much market excitement.

Currency trading is mixed today. The EUR/USD is up very slightly, to 1.0702, while the GBP/USD is down a half percent, to 1.2424. The US dollar has gained on the yen and the Swiss franc; the USD/JPY stands at 113.79 and the USD/CHF is trading at 0.9958.

Crude oil has slipped, mainly as investors continue to see signs of increased production in the US offsetting the decreased production among OPEC and its partners. With US drillers continuing to add rigs, it does not look like prices will get a boost up any time soon, and crude oil remains at $55 or lower. WTI is priced at $52.40 per barrel and Brent at $55.22.

Gold and silver are both gaining, as investors look for a safe haven asset. The haven demand is fueled by uncertainty over the direction that the Trump Administration will take in regard to policy, but more on the growing believe that Trump will act erratically on every policy. Already, the new President is facing growing political protests from the American left.
In response, gold is up since yesterday, trading at $1,198.47 per ounce, and silver is up to $17.19. Platinum, oddly enough, is down slightly, at $987.08.

Keep a close eye on the US Federal Reserve this week, as the US central bank is due to release its monetary policy decision. Also, Bank of England will report on policy, and the monthly jobs report on the US labor market will be released on Friday. Looks like a busy week ahead.
Best of luck in the trading markets!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_February_06_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: February 06, 2017
article.description: Global trading markets are reacting the US government's jobs report, released on Friday. The US dollar is stronger, as are stocks and the yen.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, trading markets, US dollar, NFP, jobs report

content-body.text: Global trading markets are reacting the US government's jobs report, released on Friday. The US dollar is stronger, as are stocks and the yen, but safe-haven gold is also up. Oil markets remain volatile due to conflicting price pressures.

The jobs report – the monthly Non-Farm Payroll, or NFP, report – gave a mixed set of data for market traders to mull over. The headline numbers were good. With 227,000 new jobs reported in January, and 4.8% unemployment, the US economy looks like it is approaching full employment. The total jobs number was more than 50K above expectations, and the unemployment number, with its small increase, may indicate that the labor market is starting to tighten.

On the negative side, however, the underemployment rate – which also counts marginally attached workers and those working part-time because they cannot find full-time work – increased to 9.4%, a sign of slack in the labor market. Wage growth was also slow, with the year-over-year rate slowing to 2.5% from December's 2.8%.
Stock markets seemed to shrug off the mixed data. The Dow Jones is back above 20K, with a gain of almost 1% in yesterday's trading. The S&P 500 and the NASDAQ also advanced, by 0.73% and 0.54%.

In today's trading, European markets saw losses at the opening but quickly reversed to gain. The FTSE 100 is up 0.17% and the CAC 40 has gained 0.01%. The German DAX is back down, with a current loss of 0.38%. In the Asia-Pacific region, Australian markets dipped today, by 0.11%, while Japanese and Chinese markets gained. The Nikkei 225 picked up 0.31%, the TOPIX added 0.36%, the CSI 300 gained 0.26%, and the Hang Seng gained 0.95%.

In currency markets, the US dollar is mostly on the rise. The USD/CHF is up to 0.9952 and the USD/CAD is up to 1.3026. The EUR/USD has slipped to 1.0735, the GBP/USD is down to 1.2466, and the AUD/USD dropped to 0.7660. The exception is the yen, which has gained, putting the USD/JPY down to 112.46.

Oil markets are under a variety of pressures, causing increased volatility. Production cutbacks by OPEC are pushing prices up, while increases in drilling activity in the US shale patches are providing downward pressure. In addition, the future of China's demand situation is in doubt. The result is an increase for price in the West Texas Intermediate US benchmark grade, to $53.97 per barrel, while global benchmark Brent crude has slipped to $56.80.

Precious metals are definitely up, on safe haven demand as investors try to make sense of the market's various moves. Gold is trading at $1,225.30 per ounce, for a gain of 0.40%. Silver is up to $17.61, up 0.75% and the best performer among the precious metals. Platinum is also up, by 0.55%, and selling for $1,010.32.
Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_February_07_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: February 07, 2017
article.description: Stock markets slipped in New York yesterday and in the Asia-Pacific region today, but are showing gains as Europe starts today's session.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, gold, silver

content-body.text: Stock markets slipped in New York yesterday and in the Asia-Pacific region today, but are showing gains as Europe starts today's session.

By the numbers, the Dow is down 0.09%, the S&P 500 is down 0.21%, and the NASDAQ has slipped 0.06%. In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 and the TOPIX are down 0.35% and 0.28% respectively. Shanghai's CSI 300 dropped 0.22% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng slipped 0.07%. Australia's S&P ASX was a bright spot in its region, with a gain of 0.11%.

In Europe, shares are rising as today's trading gets started. London's FTSE 100 leads the pack, with a gain of 0.55%, the DAX is up 0.46%, and the CAC 40 has gained 015%. The gains come despite ongoing worries about the implementation of the Brexit, the never-ending Greek debt crisis, and the slowly maturing banking crisis in Italy.

In the currency markets, the US greenback is gaining ground. The EUR/USD slipped to 1.0667 and the GBP/USD is down to 1.2373. The USD/JPY is in the green, at 112.29, and the USD/CHF is moving back toward parity, at 0.9992.
The US dollar index reflects these gains. It has moved back above the 100 mark, and now stands at 100.620 and trending upward.

In the crude oil markets, prices dropped again overnight and this morning, as traders continue to see rising US production and stockpiles as offsetting OPEC's output cuts. US crude, the WTI trading benchmark, is down a quarter percent at $52.87 per barrel, and Brent, the global benchmark grade, is set at $55.60.

Precious metals have been gaining on safe demand as investors seek a hedge against uncertainty. Gold, silver, and platinum all slipped last night on profit taking, and while all three are still in the red they have turned upwards as of this writing. Gold is priced at $1,230.74 per ounce, silver is set at $17.62, and platinum is going for $1,008.60.

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_February_09_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: February 09, 2017
article.description: Stocks are up in Europe today, and showing mixed results in the Asia-Pacific region. The US dollar is generally stable in the currency markets
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, dollar, oil, stocks

content-body.text: Stocks are up in Europe today, and showing mixed results in the Asia-Pacific region. The US dollar is generally stable in the currency markets, but the haven currencies are slipping.

The European markets are mostly up today. The FTSE 100 in London has gained 0.07%, the DAX has advanced 0.30%, and the CAC 40 is up 0.54%. Spain's IBEX 35 has turned around earlier losses, to show a gain of 0.23%. Trading has been moderately volatile.
The US markets are not open yet, but were mixed yesterday. The Dow slipped 0.18%, while the S&P 500 gained 0.07% and the NASDAQ led with a gain of 0.15%.

In forex trading, the US dollar is showing gains against the safe haven currencies. The USD/JPY has advanced to 112.40, and the USD/CHF stands at 0.9977. The dollar is also showing a gain now against the Euro, but that pair has been volatile today, shifting back and forth. The EUR/USD currently trades at 1.0677.
The dollar has slipped against the other majors. The GBP/USD is up to 1.2555, the AUD/USD is flat at 0.7644, and the USD/CAD has slipped to 1.3129.

The dollar index, the broader measure of the greenback against a trade-weighted basket of its peers, is trending up. It's currently showing 100.30, and has been fairly level for the last three sessions.

Oil markets are still dealing with conflicting data and price pressures. In the latest iteration, the US Energy Information Administration reported a huge increase in crude oil stockpiles of 18.8 million barrels, but at the same time a 900,000 barrel draw from gasoline stocks against a forecast increase of 1.1 million barrels. Oil traders are having trouble making sense of the conflicting data, and prices have been range bound for more than two months. Right now, Brent crude is set at $55.67 per barrel and WTI is selling for $52.85.

Precious metals have been gaining on haven demand, as investors seek a hedge against perceived uncertainty. Gold is selling at $1,238.20 per ounce, up nearly 5% since the New Year although down today. Silver and platinum are showing stronger gains. Silver is up 0.17%, to sell at $17.74 per ounce, while platinum has gained 0.34% to sell at $1,020.42.
Have a great day in the trading markets!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_February_12_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: February 12, 2017
article.description: Markets in the US hit another record high level in Friday's session, while markets in Europe and the Asia-Pacific region showed more modest gains.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, silver, crude oil, stocks

content-body.text: Markets in the US hit another record high level in Friday's session, while markets in Europe and the Asia-Pacific region showed more modest gains. In forex trading, the US dollar made a modest advance, as did gold and silver in the commodity markets.

Looking at stocks first, the Dow Jones reached 20,269 after gaining 0.48% in the day's trading. The S&P 500 added 0.36%, and the NASDAQ gained 0.33%. London's FTSE 100 added 0.40%, the DAX picked up 0.21%, and the CAC 40 gained a modest 0.04%. The strongest gains of the day came in Japan, where the Nikkei 225 added 2.49% and the TOPIX added 2.18%. In China, the CSI 300 index gained 0.51% and the Hang Seng gained 0.21%. Australia's S&P ASX advanced 0.99%.

Gold gained a respectable 0.43% to, sell for $1,233.62 per ounce, but silver posted a stronger 1.08% gain, to reach $17.93. Silver has gained for the last seven weeks, and is showing its strongest rally in almost six years.

Oil prices gained, with crude adding about 3 cents per barrel for the day. Crude oil has been mostly range bound in trading, as the markets are facing a set of widely conflicting price pressures. Output is going down among the OPEC nations collectively, as their agreement to cut back takes hold, but crude oil production is starting to pick up in the US as the shale producers take advantage of the current prices to expand drilling activity while it is profitable. In addition, traders must still deal with global oversupply and slowing Chinese crude oil demand. Right now, Brent crude is priced at $56.70 per barrel, and WTI at $53.86.

Looking at the forex markets, the US dollar is showing modest gains. The US dollar index, which compares the greenback to a basket of trade weighted peer currencies, stands at 100.800 and is trending upwards. The EUR/USD is down, at 1.0643, and the GBP/USD also slipped, to 1.2491. The USD/CHF broke past parity to reach 1.0024, and while the USD/JPY slipped on Friday it showed a weekly gain and ended the session at 113.22.
The commodity sensitive Australian and Canadian dollars both gained on the US dollar. The AUD/USD advanced to 0.7674, while the rise in oil prices helped push the USD/CAD down to 1.3083.
That's where the markets stand. Have a great week trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_February_14_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: February 14, 2017
article.description: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, gold, silver, copper, stocks
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, silver, crude oil, stocks

content-body.text: In today's markets, stocks seem to be rolling back after yesterday's gains while the US dollar is on the rise.

American and European markets showed gains in yesterday's session, when the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ both added 0.52%, and the DAX picked up 0.92%. In today's trading, the Asian markets are mostly down – the Nikkei 225 has lost 1.13% and the Hang Seng is down 0.03%. As of this writing, Europe's markets are opening to mixed results.

In forex trading, the US dollar has eased back. The EUR/USD is up to 1.0618, the AUD/USD has risen to 0.7679, and the USD/JPY eased to 113.53. The exception is the pound sterling, which has lost 0.35% to fall to 1.2482.

Precious metals are moving up today, partly reversing some recent losses. The gains are small, but real. Gold has advanced a quarter percent, to sell at $1,228.30 per ounce. Platinum has made a similar size gain, to $1,000.89. Silver has posted the strongest gain, of 0.30%, and now trades at $17.88 per ounce.

Copper, the widely used industrial metal, is showing strong price gains, and is up to $2.80 per pound on the London markets. The gains come as a labor strike at Chile's Escondida copper mine escalates. The Escondida mine produces about 5% of the world's copper supply.
Have a great week trading, and Happy Valentine's Day!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_February_15_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: February 15, 2017
article.description: The US dollar is up in the markets today, after Janet Yellen testified before the US Senate.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, Janet Yellen, Federal Reserve, gold, stocks

content-body.text: The US dollar is up in the markets today, after Janet Yellen testified before the US Senate. The Chair of the Federal Reserve – the US central bank – sounded a more definite note than expected regarding interest rates, saying that more rate increases may be appropriate if the US economy continues to meet growth expectations.
American stocks and the greenback all rose sharply after her statements. Yellen is scheduled to speak to the US House of Representatives later today.

In the meantime, stocks are doing well around the world. Most Asian markets saw gains in today's session, with the Nikkei 225 adding 1.03% and the TOPIX gaining 0.95%. The Australian S&P ASX advanced 0.94%, and the Hong Kong Hang Seng index gained 1.23%. Mainland China's CSI 300 index, in Shanghai, was the exception, falling 0.41%. In Europe, markets are doing well for the morning. The FTSE 100 in London is up 0.42%, the DAX is up 0.22%, and the CAC 40 is up 0.47%.
US markets have not reopened for today, but the Dow finished yesterday by breaking above 20,500 after a gain of 0.45%. The S&P 500 added 0.40%, and the NASDAQ gained 0.32%.

The dollar is doing well against all of its major peers today. The US dollar index, a broader measure of the greenback against a trade-weighted basket of peer currencies, stands at 101.43 and is trending upwards.
The major pairs mostly reflect this trend. The EUR/USD has slipped to 1.0551, and the GBP/USD is also down, at 1.2409. The USD/JPY rose to 114.52, and the USD/CHF is up to 1.0094.

The moves toward stocks and the dollar reflect both investor confidence that the US Fed will raise rates at their forecast rate, and an increased appetite for risk assets. In the meantime, the traditional safe havens of precious metals are dropping. Gold is down 0.14%, to $1,226.40 per ounce, silver is down to $17.88, and platinum has lost a quarter percent to trade at $999.22.
Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_February_19_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: February 19, 2017
article.description: Stocks rose in the US on Friday, but slipped in the Asia-Pacific region and showed mixed results in Europe.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, Japanese yen, safe havens, gold

content-body.text: Stocks rose in the US on Friday, but slipped in the Asia-Pacific region and showed mixed results in Europe. The US dollar made gains in the forex trading markets, as did the safe haven yen, but precious metals, the other traditional haven investment, slipped.

Starting on Wall Street, the Dow Jones gained 0.02% to finish at 20,624.05. While most investors are happy to see the Dow so high, some analysts do warn that what goes up must come down. The S&P 500 also gained, 0.17%, and the NASDAQ was up 0.41%.
In Asia, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 was down 0.58%, Shanghai's CSI 300 was down 0.57%, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng slipped 0.31%. Australia's S&P ASX also fell, but only 0.18%.
On the European markets, the FTSE 100 gained 0.30%. The DAX was flat for the session. The CAC 40 dropped 0.65%.

The US dollar showed some strong gains in forex trading. The EUR/USD slid to 1.0616 and the GBP/USD was down to 1.2412. The USD/CHF climbed to 1.0026. The Japanese yen bucked the trend, and the USD/JPY fell to 112.84.
The yen gained where other safe havens slipped. Gold fell to $1,234.50 per ounce, and platinum to $1,003.33. Silver also slipped, but remained at a strong $18.05 per ounce.

Oil markets remain stuck between competing price pressures. Increased stockpiles in the US, combined with rising production in the American shale patch, tend to push prices down, while OPEC's efforts to cut output are giving support to the crude oil markets. The result is range bound trading and small shifts in either direction. WTI, the US benchmark, is set at $53.40 per barrel, and Brent, the global benchmark, at $55.81.
That's the market news as we head for a new week. US markets are closed for a holiday tomorrow, so expect lower trading volumes. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_February_20_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: February 20, 2017
article.description: Market trading volumes are lower today, with Wall Street closed for a public holiday.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, forex, US dollar, yen, franc, crude oil, US markets

content-body.text: Market trading volumes are lower today, with Wall Street closed for a public holiday. The US market will reopen for normal trading tomorrow.

In the meantime, traders are still active in Europe and the Asia-Pacific region. European markets have not opened as of this writing, but the futures trading is predicting modest gains in the region. In Japan, the Nikkei 225 and the TOPIX have both shown gains, of 0.09% and 0.16% respectively. China's CSI 300 index is up 1.46%, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index is up 0.62%. Australia is the odd man out in the Pacific, as the S&P ASX shows a loss of 0.18% for today.

The US dollar is easing back in the forex trading marketplace as today's session gets moving, although it has posted gains against the safe haven yen and Swiss franc. The USD/JPY is up a quarter percent, at 113.13, and the USD/CHF is up 0.01% at 1.0027.
The other majors all strengthened. The EUR/USD stands at 1.0622, the GBP/USD is trading at 1.2430, and the AUD/USD is set at 0.7682. The USD/CAD slipped slightly, to 1.3083.

Crude oil traders saw small price gains this morning, mostly on reports that OPEC is achieving a 90% compliance rate with its cutback agreement. The cartel is trying curb crude oil production in an effort to raise prices, but is running into headwinds from increasing production and stockpiles in the US. As a result, the crude oil markets are showing only small shifts within a narrow price range. Today's shift puts oil near the top of that range, with WTI trading at $53.57 per barrel and Brent at $56.02.

Precious metals are mostly down today, following the patter of the other safe havens, the yen and the franc. Silver has slipped 0.32%, to $18.05 per ounce, and platinum has lost 0.13%, to sell at $1,002.06. Gold, however, has strengthened in recent hours, and gained 0.01% to trade at $1,234.71 per ounce.
That's the market news. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_March_14_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: March 14, 2017
article.description: Market trading volumes are lower today, with Wall Street closed for a public holiday.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar,

content-body.text: Financial markets are mostly steady today, as investors are holding back and waiting for monetary policy decisions from the US Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan, and the Bank of England. All three central banks are scheduled to make announcements this week, starting with the Federal Reserve on tomorrow afternoon.

The biggest announcement of the three will be the Fed’s. The US central bank is expected to raise interest rates by a quarter percent, and to indicate whether it will pursue two or three additional rate hikes this year. The move is certain to diverge from the banks of Japan and England, which are expected to hold their policies steady in separate announcements on Thursday.

n the meantime, stock markets are relatively flat today. In the Asia-Pacific region, Japan’s Nikkei 225 and TOPIX indexes are down 0.12% and 0.16% respectively, while in Chine the Hang Seng slipped 0.01% and the CSI 300 is down 0.04%. In Europe, the main indexes are opening to larger losses ahead of the central bank statements. The FTSE 100 is down 0.20%, the DAX is 0.45%, and the CAC 40 is down 0.66%. The US markets have not opened as of this writing, but did not show much movement yesterday. The Dow slipped 0.10%, the S&P 500 gained 0.04%, and the NASDAQ added 0.24%.

In the currency markets, the US dollar is looking up, posting gains after losses in recent sessions. The EUR/USD has slipped 0.21% to 1.0631, the GBP/USD lost 0.65% and fell to 1.2140, and the AUD/USD dropped 0.18% to 0.7557. The USD/JPY is up, at 114.90. The USD/CHF added 0.18% to reach 1.0090, and the USD/CAD gained 0.29% to reach 1.3485.

The US dollar’s gains are building on expectations of the Federal Reserve move, but the Canadian dollar’s loss is worth pointing out. The loonie is getting pummeled by the price of oil, which has collapsed in recent sessions.

At the start of the year, OPEC initiated a crude oil production cutback scheme to boost prices, but the result has been increased drilling and production activity in the US, which has mostly offset the OPEC cuts. US production is at 9.09 million barrels per day, and stockpile inventories of crude oil in the US are at record high levels. As a result, oil has plunged back to the $50 handle, after spending most of the last three months in the $51 to $55 range.

West Texas Intermediate, the US trading benchmark, has lost 1.36% so far today, and is trading at $47.74 per barrel. Brent, the global benchmark grade, is down 1.11% and selling for $50.78. Both grades are trending downwards.

Precious metals should be a bright spot for investors today. With oil down, and stocks relatively flat, it would seem that gold is the logical alternative. The expectations of higher interest rates on the US dollar are taking up all the oxygen, however, and gold has slipped 0.05% this morning. The metal is priced at $1,203.71 per ounce. Platinum is down 0.08%, to $939.05. Silver, however, is up, having gained 0.02% today to sell for $17 even.
That’s the market news. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_March_15_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: March 15, 2017
article.description: Interest rates and the Federal Reserve are in the news today, as precious metals firm up and crude oil prices remain low.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, Federal Reserve, interest rates, rate hike, gold, crude oil

content-body.text: The main market headline to watch today will come from the US, where the Federal Reserve is scheduled to announce its forward monetary policy decision at 14:00 East Coast time. Fed Chair Janet Yellen will be giving a press conference shortly after the policy announcement. The Federal Reserve is widely expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, to 0.75%, and between the Fed statement and Yellen's presser investors are hoping to glean hints as to the pace of future interest rate hikes. The Fed has expressed a preference for three rate increases this year, including the one expected today, but there have been some indications that for interest rate hikes may be on the table.

The US dollar has been volatile in the markets ahead of the Federal Reserve policy meeting, losing some and then regaining in successive forex sessions. The dollar is down slightly today, with the USD/JPY dipping to 114.62, the USD/CHF down to 1.0083, and the USD/CAD slipping to 1.3453. The EUR/USD is up to 1.0631, the GBP/USD has gained to 1.2231, and the AUD/USD advanced to 0.7588.
The US dollar index, which compares the greenback to a trade-weighted basket of six peer currencies, is down today. The index stands at 101.490, compared to yesterday's 101.700.

The currency moves can mostly be explained by the US dollar's reaction to the Fed forecasts, but the Euro, the pound, and the Canadian dollar are all reacting to individual pressures. The Euro is facing some pressure from the election campaigns in the Netherlands and France, where nationalistic, anti-EU and -Euro candidates are on the rise. The pound has gotten support from Monday's Parliamentary approval of the government's Brexit plan, and PM Theresa May's consequent stronger political position. The Canadian dollar is hurt by the recent drop in oil prices, with WTI falling well below $50. The loonie is highly sensitive to the cost of crude oil.

Those crude oil markets have taken a beating recently. A record high inventory in US crude oil storage facilities, combined with increasing production in America's shale fields, has been offsetting OPEC's output cuts. The situation was not improved yesterday, when Saudi Arabia admitted that they have been cheating somewhat and overproducing. Prices rebounded slightly today when the Saudis started talking back their overproduction by insisting that the extra oil is solely for 'domestic storage.'

Oil traders will be watching the US Energy Information Administration data today, for confirmation of a possible drawdown in US crude stores. If that drawdown does happen, it will lend support to prices. Right now, WTI, the US trading benchmark, is selling for $48.53 per barrel. Brent, the global benchmark, is priced at $51.65.

Also in commodity trading, precious metals are looking up today. Investors are seeking a hedge ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate announcement, as well as several other central bank decision due out tomorrow. Precious metals are the traditional safe haven investment. While they have seen losses in recent sessions – mainly as the dollar has strengthened and expectations for a Fed rate hike have risen – gold and its allies have found support in the general desire of Money to protect itself.
As of this writing, gold is up 0.31% and selling for $1,202.86 per ounce. Silver has gained 0.10%, to sell for $16.94. Platinum is priced at $944.25, a gain of 0.70%.

In other economic news, as mentioned above the Federal Reserve is not the only central bank set to give a policy statement this week. Both Bank of Japan and Bank of England are scheduled to make announcements on Thursday. Both banks are expected to hold their interest rates steady, but for different reasons. Bank of Japan is expected to cite low inflation levels despite steady economic growth, while Bank of England may want to avoid rocking the boat now that the government's Brexit policy has Parliamentary approval.

With all of this in the financial news, it's no surprise to see stocks easing back slightly. Wall Street was down slightly in yesterday's trading session, with the Dow slipping 0.21%, the S&P 500 dropping 0.34%, and the NASDAQ dropping 0.32%.

In today's trading, the Asian markets are mostly down. The Nikkei 225 lost 0.16%, the TOPIX lost 0.23%, and the Hang Seng fell 0.15%. Mainland China's CSI 300 index gained 0.20%, and the Australian S&P ASX added 0.26%. The European markets are just opening at this writing, and showing modest gains. The FTSE 100 is up 0.26%, the DAX is up 0.12%, and the CAC 40 is up 0.19%.
That’s the market news. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_March_16_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: March 16, 2017
article.description: Stocks are up around the world on the heels of central bank monetary policy decisions. The US dollar has eased back, and the Euro and yen have gained.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, Euro, yen, interest rates, rate hike, Federal Reserve, Bank of Japan, Bank of England

content-body.text: The US dollar is down in today's trading, while the yen and Euro are up. Central bank statements and the Dutch elections have been the key influencers in the forex market moves.

Yesterday, the US Federal Reserve made the expected move and raised its key interest rate by 25 basis points, putting the rate into a new range of 0.75% to 1%. In the accompanying statement, the Fed said that the pace of additional interest rate hikes going forward will be 'gradual.' The Federal Reserve decision was both hawkish and dovish, but the markets were hoping to hear a more aggressive forward pace for increasing interest rates.

The Fed decision was the first of several central bank policy announcements this week. Bank of Japan has also released a monetary policy decision, and again made the expected move. As forecast, Bank of Japan held steady and kept is short-term rate at -0.1%. The move came as Japanese core inflation remains well below the BoJ's 2% target rate, and it underscores the way that the major central banks are diverging in monetary policy, with the US Federal Reserve embarking on a course of tightening while Japan and Europe continue to ease.

The immediate result of the Fed and BoJ decisions was a drop in the US dollar and a rise in the Japanese yen. The USD/JPY rate fell to 112.91 in overnight trading, but has since rebounded to 113.50. This compares to 114.75 on Tuesday.

The other big reaction came from the precious metals market, where gold, which has been weakening in anticipation of the Fed rate hike, jumped more than 2% after the Federal Reserve struck the unexpectedly dovish tone despite the interest rate hike. The Fed's overall stance – holding to three rate moves this year and three more next year – is seen as an intent to prevent the dollar to getting too strong in the forex markets, and investors shifted to the traditional safe haven asset of gold.

Gold is up to $1,223.95 per ounce in today's trading, after bottoming out at $1,199.12 on Tuesday. Platinum has made a similar jump, and is up to $961.01, while silver has gained 3% and is now trading at $17.43 per ounce. The increases come despite the new higher interest rate, and despite higher interest rates usually being bearish for precious metals. The gains in gold and its allies simply underscores some of the confused nature in today's financial markets.

As mentioned above, the Euro is also up in today's forex trading. The central bank decisions were not the key here, but the Dutch elections were. Heading into the polling, investors were concerned about the apparent strength of right-wing Geert Wilders' nationalistic, anti-EU, Freedom Party. The Euro gained, however, with the electoral victory of Dutch PM Rutte's party, which gained at least 29 seats in the Parliament.

Investor relief at continued stability in the Dutch government, and its implications for a similar election to be held in France next month, pushed the EUR/USD up well above 1.07 in the forex markets. The pair is currently trading at 1.0728, near a five-week high against the US dollar.

The pound sterling also gained against the US dollar overnight. The pound is holding steady now, as the Bank of England is set to give its own monetary policy decision in the next hour. BoE is expected, like Japan, to hold rates steady. Investors will be looking for any indication that the Bank will switch to a tightening policy in coming months. Right now, the GBP/USD is trading at 1.2335, well up compared to Tuesday's low of 1.2153.

In other trading, oil prices rose for the second session in a row after the official US government data on stockpiles showed an unexpected drawdown of more than 230,000 barrels. Forecasts had predicted at build of 3.7 million barrels in inventories. Not all of the oil news was bullish, however, as US production rose for the fourth week in a row and reached 9.1 million barrels per day.
That said, WTI, the US trading benchmark grade, still has not gotten back to $50. It's currently priced at $49.27 per barrel. Brent crude, the global market benchmark, is up to $52.28 per barrel.

In the stock markets, investors around the world are feeling confident after the rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The US stocks markets finished yesterday's trading with strong gains. The Dow was up 0.54%, the S&P 500 advanced 0.84%, and the NASDAQ added 0.74%.
In Europe, stocks are opening today's session with equally strong gains. The FTSE 100 in London touched a record high, and is up 0.77%. The DAX has gained 0.85%, and the CAC 40 is up by 0.69%.

The Asia-Pacific markets are also having a good day today. In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 is up a modest 0.07%, along with the TOPIX which rose 0.09%. China's CSI 300 index is up 0.52%, while the Hang Seng in Hong Kong is gangbusters, with a 2.08% gain for the day. Australia's S&P ASX gain of 0.20% is modest by comparison.
That’s the market news. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_March_19_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: March 19, 2017
article.description: The US dollar and global stock markets were mixed on Friday, while precious metals gained on safe haven trading demand.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, stock markets, gold, crude oil, Federal Reserve, interest rates

content-body.text: In the forex trading markets Friday, the US dollar showed mixed results. The dollar gained against the Euro, the Swiss franc, and the Canadian dollar, but it slipped against the Japanese yen, the pound sterling, and the Australian currency. The US dollar index, a broader measure of the greenback against a trade-weighted basket of major peer currencies, slipped to 100.300.
Turning to the major forex trading pairs, we see the EUR/USD down a quarter percent at 1.0738, while the USD/CHF is up 0.17% to 0.9982 and the USD/CAD rose 0.23% to 1.3350.

The USD/JPY is down more than half a percent, 0.54%, at 112.70. The GBP/USD rose almost a third of a percent to 1.2396, and the Australian dollar rose 0.34% to put the AUD/USD up to 0.7704 to the end the week.

In commodity markets, crude oil managed to stop its slide on Friday with a relatively flat trading session, but the fuel remains mired at prices below its most recent plateau. WTI, the US trading benchmark grade, gained 0.06% to sell for $48.78 per barrel; Brent crude, the global benchmark grade, was up 0.04% to $51.76 per barrel. It's important to note that while both benchmarks have declined in recent sessions, both have held between $40 and $60 per barrel since last April.

In the meantime, gold and other precious metals gained for the week, their first weekly gains in nearly a month. Precious metals faced heavy price pressure before in the lead up to the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision last week, as the expectation for higher interest rates on the dollar was bearish for metals. In the event, the Fed raised rates but played down the forecast for further hikes, saying that they would take a gradual approach.

The Fed's doublespeak on interest rates proved a boon for precious metals. On Friday, gold advanced 0.22% to reach $1,229.26 per ounce; silver gained 0.48% and now sells for $17.41, and platinum climbed 0.74% to sell for $964.97.

The stocks markets, like the US dollar, showed mixed trading results in Friday's session. In New York, the Dow Jones dipped 0.10%, the S&P 500 slipped 0.13%, and the NASDAQ finished flat. In the Asia-Pacific region, shares fell in Japan, where the Nikkei lost 0.35% and the TOPIX fell 0.43%, and in China, where the CSI 300 index dropped 1.03%. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong added 0.09%, however, and the S&P ASX in Australia gained 0.24%.
Europe's stock markets had a generally good day on Friday. The FTSE 100 was up 0.12%, the DAX gained 0.10%, and the CAC 40 added 0.32%.
That’s the market news. Have a great week in the trading markets!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_March_21_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: March 21, 2017
article.description: Stocks and the dollar are treading water, as investors take a wait and see position. Gold has slipped on profit taking.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, stock markets, crude oil, gold, precious metals

content-body.text: The US dollar remains soft in the forex trading markets today, as investors continue to hold back after the Federal Reserve embraced a slow and gradual stance on future interest rate hikes. The Fed is perceived as wanting two more rate moves this year, and is likely to wait until June before implementing another. Last week, the Fed initiated its third rate hike since December of 2015.

Several Fed branch presidents are scheduled to speak this week, and Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen will be giving a speech on Thursday. Dollar traders will be sure to parse the statements carefully, looking for clues to how firmly the Fed will hold to its current position.

In the meantime, the US dollar is on the defensive in the forex markets. The greenback has gained against the yen and the Aussie, with the USD/JPY up to 112.61 and the AUD/USD down to 0.7727, but it has shown declines in the other major pairs. The EUR/USD is up to 1.0792, the GBP/USD rose 0.78% to 1.2455, the USD/CHF slipped to 0.9961, and the USD/CAD is down to 1.3333.

The US dollar index, the broad measure of the greenback against a basket of trade-weighted peer currencies, is trending down and has slipped below 100, to levels last seen at the beginning of February. The index currently stands at 99.928.

Some of the Euro's support has come from European election news. Populist forces in the Netherlands failed to gain as much electoral support as predicted, and in France, independent Emmanuel Macron gave a convincing debate performance, showing that he may be a real alternative to the anti-EU, anti-Euro populist Marine Le Pen.

The pound sterling faced some pressure yesterday when it was confirmed that Theresa May's government will begin the Brexit process from the EU on March 29, but it has since rebounded, both on the knowledge that the process will be a long one with no drastic changes taking immediate effect and on optimism that both the UK and the EU want and need friendly relations.

With currencies in flux, traders and investors are seeking a safe haven asset. Precious metals are a traditional hedge in investing, and prices have gone up in recent sessions. This morning is an exception, however, as gold and its allies have dipped in early trading. Profit taking after four sessions of gains may be behind the sudden sales.
Price wise, gold has slipped 0.18% and is now selling for $1,232.04 per ounce. Silver is down 0.07% to $17.43, and platinum has posted the hardest loss, of 0.81%, and fallen to $962.75 per ounce.

In other metals, copper is also down. Copper is a widely used industrial metal, and is frequently taken as a proxy for industrial metals generally. Last month, copper saw a price boost due to labor strikes at major mines in Chile and Indonesia. With the strike in Indonesia easing, supply concerns are letting up. Copper lost 0.96% today, and is down to $2.64 per pound.

Crude oil prices have been hammered recently, mostly by increasing production and supply in the US. The OPEC nations – and partners such as Russia – reached an agreement to cut back production starting at the beginning of this year and going for six months, in an effort to boost prices. Their efforts have been only partially successful, as US production and the continued market oversupply are keeping a downward pressure on crude oil prices. In an effort to strengthen their hand, OPEC has started talking up the possibility of extending their cutback agreement past June.

The immediate reaction was a small increase in oil prices. WTI, the US benchmark grade, gained 0.75% to sell for $48.58 per barrel. Brent crude added 0.83% and is set at $52.05. Both grades are about $4 below their recent price range.

In the stock markets, investors are worried that US President Donald Trump will take longer than expected to push through tax and regulatory reform, and that he may have trouble initiating fiscal spending. Wall Street's indexes dipped lower as a result yesterday. The Dow Jones lost 0.04% and the S&P 500 lost 0.20%. The NASDAQ managed a nominal gain of 0.01%.

In Asia, the Japanese markets slipped in today's session. The Nikkei 225 is down 0.34%, and the TOPIX is down 0.16%. Australia's S&P ASX is also down, by 0.07%. China, however, has seen gains, with the CSI 300 index adding 0.49% and the Hang Seng in Hong Kong reaching a one and a half year high level after a gain of 0.37%.
The European markets opened to gains earlier today, but have scaled back slightly. The DAX and CAC 40 remain up, by 0.09% and 0.30% respectively, but the FTSE 100 is down 0.14%.
That’s the market news. Have a great week in the trading markets!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_March_22_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: March 22, 2017
article.description: Stock markets are showing sharp losses and the US dollar is down as investors take a risk-averse approach today.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, crude oil, stock markets, gold, risk, safe haven

content-body.text: Starting with the US dollar in the forex trading markets, we see that the greenback has fallen to a six-week low, with the US dollar index down to 99.73, a level last seen at the beginning of February. The drop comes as the dollar faces pressure from the Federal Reserve, which has laid out a gradual pace for future interest rate hikes, and from unexpected strength in the Euro and the pound.

The EUR/USD is above 1.08, trading at 1.0817, a level it has not seen since last November. The Euro got a boost when populist Geert Wilders made smaller gains than expected in the Dutch elections, and when centrist Emmanuel Macron gave a strong performance in a televised debate for the upcoming French Presidential elections.

The pound got a strong boost from UK inflation data, which showed a 2.3% last month, exceeding the Bank of England's target rate for the first time four years. BoE has declined to take action against the high inflation, preferring to wait and see how the data will interact with the Brexit policy set to start next week. The GBP/USD is currently trading at 1.2499.

The USD/JPY slipped, losing 0.28% and sending the pair down to 111.40. This the yen's strongest level in nearly a month, and reflects both a weaker dollar and weaker share prices in the Tokyo stock markets.

The forex news hasn't been all doom-and-gloom for the US dollar, however, as the Canadian currency slipped when the price of oil fell. The USD/CAD is up 0.07% to 1.3361 after sharp drops in the North American crude oil trading benchmark.

Oil fell as reports came in from the American Petroleum Institute, an industry group, that US crude oil stockpiles rose by more than 4.5 million barrels last week, handily beating the forecast by 1.7 million barrels. The Cushing storage depot, where the WTI trading benchmark is set, say a local build of nearly 2 million barrels.

The large stockpile builds prompted a sharp drop in crude oil prices, sending the WTI benchmark down almost 2% to $47.34 per barrel. On the global markets, Brent crude fell 0.51% and is selling for $50.70. Investors are waiting to see what the official US government crude oil stockpile data will show later today.

In the precious metal markets, gold, silver, and platinum are all showing gains. Gold is up 0.24%, giving it a price of $1,241.75 per ounce, and platinum is up 0.22% to $972.26. Silver shows the smallest gain, of 0.01%, and a price of $17.59. All three are up on demand for safe haven assets, as investors pull back from the US dollar and from stock markets.

In the stocks markets, Wall Street and Europe saw declines across the board yesterday. In New York, the S&P 500 broke a 110 day streak without a 1% decline when the index slipped 1.24% for the day. The Dow Jones fell 1.14%, and the NASDAQ lost 1.83%. In London, the FTSE 100 was down 0.69%, the German DAX lost 0.75%, and the French CAC 40 slipped a smaller 0.19%.

The Asian stock markets are showing losses in today's trading session. The Australian S&P ASX is down 1.56%. In mainland China, Shanghai's CSI 300 index is down 0.47%, while in Hong Kong, the Hang Seng has lost 1.39%. Tokyo has seen the worst losses, with the Nikkei 225 down by 2.13% and the TOPIX down 2.12%.

The immediate reaction was a small increase in oil prices. WTI, the US benchmark grade, gained 0.75% to sell for $48.58 per barrel. Brent crude added 0.83% and is set at $52.05. Both grades are about $4 below their recent price range.
That’s the market news. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_March_23_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: March 23, 2017
article.description: Stock markets are mixed as investors continue to be risk-averse. Gold has slipped, and oil is up slightly.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, crude oil, stock markets, gold, risk averse

content-body.text: Forex markets are showing small gains for the US dollar today, as it bounced off of yesterday's bottom. The US dollar index – which compares the currency to basket of its peers – is trending upwards and currently stands at 99.830.
Looking at the major currencies, we see the greenback making gains against the Euro, the pound, the Aussie, the Swiss franc, and the Canadian dollar. The yen remains strong against the US dollar.
By the numbers, the EUR/USD is down at 1.0780, the GBP/USD is down at 1.2474, and the AUD/USD has slipped to 0.7633. The USD/CHF is up slightly, at 0.9938, and the USD/CAD is up to 1.3348.
The USD/JPY remains down, having lost 0.06% today to trade at 111.09.

The slight rebound for the dollar has hurt the price of precious metals, making them slightly more expensive for non-dollar holders. Gold is down 0.19% and selling for $1,246.42 per ounce. Silver has lost 0.02%, and is selling for $17.58. Platinum has dipped to $962.95 per ounce.

Oil prices took a turn up, after more than a week of losses. Crude oil faces pressure from increasing production in the US combined with near-record US stockpile inventories. US crude oil production reached 9.13 million barrels per day last week, comparable to mid-2014 when the crude oil price slump began.
The high American production is perceived as offsetting the OPEC efforts to cut back on output, and is hampering the cartel's attempt to support prices.

Brent crude, the global trading benchmark, selling at $50.85 per barrel, and is having trouble getting away from the $50 handle. WTI, the US benchmark, is priced at $48.26, and has been below $50 since March 9.

In the stock markets, shares are mixed. Traders are taking a more risk-averse approach for the time being. Wall Street saw gains in the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ, of 0.19% and 0.48% respectively, while the Dow was mainly flat with a 0.03% loss.

n the European stock markets, shares are opening to losses in today's trading. The FTSE 100 is down by 0.73%, the DAX is down 0.48%, and the CAC 40 has slipped 0.15%. Spain's IBEX 35 is bucking that trend, with a gain of 0.17%.

The Asia-Pacific stock markets are doing better today. Japan's Nikkei 225 is up 0.23% and also in Tokyo, the TOPIX index is up 0.01%. Shanghai's CSI 300 is up 0.35%, but the Hang Seng is down 0.06%. The S&P ASX in Australia has gained 0.41%.
That’s the market news. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_March_27_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: March 27, 2017
article.description: Increased political risk is dominating the markets and driving a move toward safe haven assets. Gold is up and the US dollar is down.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, stock markets, safe haven, crude oil, gold, President Trump, Euro, Brexit

content-body.text: The US dollar is down in the early hours of forex trading today, falling on investor sentiment of higher risk concerns. The US dollar index has slipped to 99.277, a third of a percent drop since Friday's close.

Turning to the major pairs, we see the US dollar losing ground across the board. The EUR/USD has gained 0.44% to 1.0846, the GBP/USD is up 0.48% to 1.2533, and the AUD/USD advanced to 0.7632. The USD/JPY was the biggest loser, falling 0.87% to 110.37, the USD/CHF slipped 0.37% to 0.9877, and the USD/CAD slipped 0.39% to 1.3326.

The Euro got its boost from expectations that the European Central Bank may embark on monetary tightening later in the year, as well as hopes that the Euro will bear up well under the upcoming Brexit and that right-wing populist forces will fare poorly in various upcoming European elections. The Japanese yen and the Swiss franc both gained on safe haven trade demand. The yen is at a four-month high against the US dollar; the Swiss franc has been above parity since March 15.

Safe haven demand has also pushed up the prices of precious metals. Gold, silver, and platinum all saw gains in the early trading hours of the week, as investors started hedging against increased risk. Uncertainty around President Trump's ability to push his economic agenda in Congress following the failure of the health care bill and concerns over this week's Brexit initiation are both pushing up risk perceptions.

In response, gold is up 1.06% today, to $1,256.81 per ounce. Silver has gained 0.72%, to reach $17.88, and platinum is up 0.92% and is selling for $973.57. All three precious metals are trending upwards in the markets. Gold is at its highest price since February 27.

In the oil markets, prices for crude oil declined again this morning, despite a weekend meeting by OPEC and non-OPEC oil ministers in which they agreed to discuss extending the production cutback agreement beyond the original June expiration date. The oil cutback agreement was designed to provide support to crude oil prices. OPEC's efforts, however, have been hampered by rising production in the US, where crude oil output has increased to 9.13 million barrels per day, a rise of more than 8% since mid-2016. In addition, US crude oil stockpile inventories have increased to a record-high level of 533.1 million barrels, increasing traders' worries over the global oil oversupply that has been weighing down on prices. Oil traders will be watching closely for the US oil supply and production numbers scheduled for release on Tuesday and Wednesday.
Translated into price numbers, we see WTI, the US trading benchmark, down 0.63% to $47.67 per barrel. Brent crude, the benchmark on the global markets, is down 0.39% and selling for $50.60.

In the stock markets, the Asian indexes are mostly down as today's trading gets started. The Nikkei 225 has lost 1.44% and the TOPIX is down 1.24%. Australia is showing a drop of 0.12% in the S&P ASX. In China, results are more mixed, with a drop of 0.24% in the Hang Seng, but flat returns so far in the CSI 300. The US and European stock markets have not opened as of this writing. As with the other markets, investors are pulling back due to concerns over political risk.
That’s the market news. Have a great week in the trading markets!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_March_28_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: March 28, 2017
article.description: Markets have turned around today, as Asian stocks show gains and the US dollar arrests its fall.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, stock markets, gold, safe haven, crude oil, yen

content-body.text: In the world's financial and stock markets today, investors are starting to recover their risk appetite. Anxiety – specifically, nervousness that US President Donald Trump would not be able to push his pro-business economic agenda of tax and regulatory reforms through Congress after the defeat of the much hyped, Administration supported health care bill – had pushed investments into safe haven assets and put heavy price pressure on the stocks and the US dollar in recent sessions.

Asian stocks are up as today's trading session gets started, however, indicating that risk appetite may be coming back. The Nikkei 225 is up 1.04%, the TOPIX is up 1.17%, and the Australian S&P ASX is up 1.24%. The Hang Seng shows a smaller gain of 0.51%, and Shanghai's CSI 300 is underperforming the region, posting a drop of 0.19%.

The US and European stock markets have not opened as of this writing, but most of the main indexes finished in the red yesterday. Only Wall Street's NASDAQ posted a gain, of 0.20% Trading was volatile, with the indexes posting losses early and then mostly failing to recoup during the session.

The forex trading markets are seeing some mild strengthening in the US dollar. The greenback appears to be levelling out on the same sentiment that is underpinning the Asian stock markets. The US dollar index is trending upwards, and stands at 99.179, a shade above yesterday's bottom of 99.166. The index is a broad measure of the dollar against a trade-weighted basket of peer currencies.

In the major pairs, the USD/JPY has bounced off of its nearly 5-month low and is now trading at 110.58. The pair is slightly up, but trending down at the moment. The EUR/USD has slowed its gains, and is up 0.01% to 1.0865. The GBP/USD is behaving similarly, trading at 1.2569 after a gain of 0.08%. The Swiss franc continues to benefit from safe haven demand, putting the USD/CHF down 0.04% to 0.9852.
The US dollar has posted true gains against the Canadian dollar, as continued low crude oil prices pressure the Canadian loonie. The USD/CAD pair rose 0.04% to 1.3381.

The crude oil markets are showing small gains today, reacting to conflicting price pressures. OPEC has led a series of supply cuts in an attempt to boost prices, but record level storage inventories and high production in the US have offset a large portion of the cuts and pushed prices down almost 10% this month. Today's small gains come as the weaker US dollar helps provide price support.

As of this writing, the US WTI benchmark grade is up 0.52% to a price of $47.98 per barrel. The global Brent benchmark has gained 0.45% and reached $50.98. Both trading benchmarks are trending upwards. Oil traders are looking toward this week's inventory and production reports from the US as an indicator of future prices.

Precious metals posted strong gains in recent trading sessions, as they always do in times of strong safe haven demand, but are mostly down slightly today. The modest decline is partly profit-taking and partly the move of money into higher-risk assets.

Gold is down 0.03%, and selling for $1,254.53 per ounce. Silver has lost 0.18%, and slipped to $18.08. Platinum has actually continued to gain, adding 0.12% to reach $969.56 and reverse an overnight drop.
Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_March_29_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: March 29, 2017
article.description: Stock markets are showing mixed results and the Euro and pound have lost ground ahead of the formal start of the Brexit.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, Euro, pound, yen, Brexit, safe haven, gold, crude oil, interest rates

content-body.text: The big news hitting the markets today comes from the UK, where PM Theresa May will be formally starting the process of the Brexit. She will be sending a letter today to EU President Donald Tusk, informing him that the UK will be invoking Article 50 of the EU treat and exiting from the Union. The EU nations will have 48 hours to respond, and the full process of negotiating the exit is expected to take two years.

In response to May's Brexit plans, Scotland's parliament voted yesterday to push for another independence referendum from the UK. The EU is more popular in Scotland than in the rest of the UK, and the Scottish National Party has already made clear that it would prefer independence and EU membership to sticking with the British Crown.

The Euro and the pound have both slipped in early trading today, as investors are starting to get jittery about the Brexit. The EUR/USD is down 0.21% to 1.0791, and the GBP/USD is down 0.27% to 1.2416.

The US dollar is up against the safe haven Swiss franc, with the USD/CHF gaining 0.06% to trade at 0.9931. The dollar also gained against the yen in early trading, but the Japanese currency has recouped slightly. The USD/JPY currently stands at 111.12.
The US dollar index is reflecting the greenback's early gains today, and has risen to 99.856. The index is trending upwards.

In today's crude oil markets, investors are more worried about supply disruptions in Libya than stockpile numbers from the US. While rising US inventories have helped push prices down in recent weeks, crude oil gained this morning on news that the pipeline from Libya's largest oil field to the shipping ports has been but off. Libya holds Africa's largest reserves of crude oil, but the country has been mired in civil war and anarchy for the last 5 years. Libyan oil output is expected to fall from 700,000 barrels per day to 560,000.

The drop in Libyan supply has done what weeks of OPEC cutbacks couldn't do, and pushed oil prices up almost one percent overnight. Brent crude, the global market benchmark grade, is up 0.92% and selling at $51.80 per barrel. The North American benchmark, WTI, gained 0.83% to a price of $48.77.

In other news, some commodity analysts see gold extending its gains and reaching as high as the $1400 to $1500 range later this year. Gold, and other precious metals, have gained this year on risk anxiety – investors are worried that President Trump will not be able to push his economic reform agenda past Congressional opposition, and so are seeking a hedge.
In addition, the upcoming Brexit also has investors looking for safe places to park their cash. Precious metals are the traditional safe haven for investors looking to protect their money.

It's important to note that the US Federal Reserve is on track to implement two more interest rate hikes this year, and such moves will be bearish for gold. Metals do not pay out interest, and so are at a disadvantage when rates are going up. According to Bloomberg market, the median outlook for gold by year's end is only $1,230, just below today's trading price.

On the trading floors, we see that gold is currently up 0.10%, and selling for $1,253.08 per ounce. Platinum has also gained, climbing 0.17% to a price of $956.25. Silver is down, having lost 0.45% and dipped to $18.17 per ounce.

In the stock markets, yesterday saw Wall Street's second round of gains in the last nine trading sessions. The Dow Jones added 0.73%, the S&P 500 picked up the same, and the NASDAQ finished with a gain of 0.60%.

In today's trading, the European stock markets opened to gains and have mostly kept them. The DAX is up 0.49% and the CAC 40 is up 0.25%. In London, however, the FTSE 100 is spooked by the Brexit, and is starting to walk back the early gains. The index is down 0.01%.

The Asia-Pacific region is showing mixed results. The Nikkei 225 is up 0.08%, but the TOPIX is down 0.18%. The Hang Seng has gained 0.19%, but the mainland's CSI 300 has lost 0.13%. The Australian S&P ASX is up 0.90%.
That's the news; have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_March_30_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: March 30, 2017
article.description: The US dollar is gaining today, while gold is slipping from its recent one-month high.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, gold, crude oil, Federal Reserve, interest rates

content-body.text: In today’s news, the US dollar is reacting to signals from the Federal Reserve. Various Fed board members have been speaking this week, reiterating the central bank’s commitment to monetary tightening. While most speakers have endorsed the slower pace of two additional interest rate increases this year, at lead one board member has come out in favor of implementing up to four rate hikes before the end of the year.
Later today, we’ll see the final numbers on US Q4 GDP growth. If it comes in above expectations, watch for the Fed to start talking up more than two rate hikes.

In the UK, PM Theresa May gave the EU formal notice of the Brexit yesterday. Today, the government’s Brexit Minister stated that he is not expecting Britain to have to pay a talked-about exit fee of 50 billion pounds to the EU. He added that the days of the UK paying out huge sums to the bureaucrats in Brussels are over.

In Asia, stocks fell in today’s session, although Australian shares rallied on better performances by energy producers. Australia is a net exporter of raw materials, and the country’s mining industry in a major factor in the economy. The Australian currency is highly sensitive to commodity – especially mining and energy – prices.

In forex trading, the markets are seeing small gains for the US dollar today. The Euro and pound are, unsurprisingly, both edging down. The EUR/USD is down 0.27% to 1.0737, while the GBP/USD is down 0.18% to 1.2412.
The US dollar is up against the safe haven Japanese yen, gaining 0.03% to put the USD/JPY at 111.07, but it has declined 0.05% against the Swiss franc. The USD/CHF is trading at 0.9960.

The Aussie has slipped, despite the rise in Australian stock markets. The AUD/USD is down 0.12%, to trade at 0.7661. The Canadian dollar, which is even more sensitive than the Australian to oil prices, is up 0.11% as crude oil is showing gains today. The USD/CAD stands at 1.3340.

Crude oil was up slightly today at the open, but may be walking back those gains now. Oil gained overnight on news of disruptions in Libya’s oil exports, as well reports that OPEC is 95% compliant with the production cutback agreement.

US inventory data, however, has weighed on crude oil once again. Government data released yesterday showed a build of 867,000 barrels in stockpiles, to a new record high of 534 million barrels. Gasoline stocks declined, showing that demand is still there, but the markets are still spooked by the record high crude inventories. It does not bode well for relief from the global oversupply in oil markets.
WTI, the US benchmark grade, is currently down 0.10% at $49.46 per barrel. Brent crude, the global benchmark, is down more, 0.31%, at $52.28 per barrel. Both grades are trending down.

Gold and other precious metals are losing ground again today. They have slipped from the one-month high they reached at the start of the week as investors have moved back to the US dollar and other risk assets on the expectation that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again in the next few months.

Right now, gold is down 0.21% and selling for $1,250.76 per ounce. Silver has lost 0.45%, and is priced at $18.17 per ounce. Gold and silver are both trending down. Platinum – which has industrial uses that gold lacks – has gained today, adding 0.26% to $956.70.
That’s the market news. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_02_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 02, 2017
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, Japanese yen, safe haven, Brexit, crude oil, gold

content-body.text: In market news, US consumer sentiment rose for the month of March, on perceptions by the 'average consumer' that his financial state is improving. Americans are less sanguine about the long-term view, but the bottom line reading rose from February's 96.3 to 96.9. The data came from the monthly University of Michigan survey.

In the UK, Prime Minister Theresa May faces a potential stumbling block as the Brexit process starts. Nicola Sturgeon, first minister of Scotland, is insisting on another Scottish independence referendum. The Scottish parliament last week approved pursuing such a measure.

A Scottish independence drive will reduce the leverage available to the UK in the Brexit negotiations with the EU. Scotland's voters favored EU membership, and would seek to reenter the European Union should the UK fully exit and Scotland approve independence by referendum. At the same time, the UK needs its fully integrated economy to push for the best deal possible with the EU.

So far there just been verbal sparring between Westminster and Scotland. May has indicated that the UK Parliament will not be giving permission for a Scottish referendum any time soon, while Sturgeon is quick to point out the double standard of May's pressing the Brexit as an exercise in self-determination while attempting to put a clamp on Scottish moves for independence. All in all, it's some fun political theater.

The political theater, however, can impact financial markets. In forex trading, we see the pound sterling gaining ground in recent sessions at the expense of the Euro, as investors appear to be taking a sanguine view of the UK's potential negotiating position, Scotland notwithstanding. As Friday's forex trading session closed, the GBP/USD was up to 1.2550, a gain of 0.66%, while the EUR/USD ended down 0.21% to 1.0652. The Euro slipped against the pound and yen, putting the EUR/GBP down almost a whole percent to 0.8485 and the EUR/JPY down 0.68% to 118.67.

Turning to the other major currencies, the USD/JPY was down 0.47% to 111.39, but the USD/CHF was up slightly – 0.14% – to 1.0026. The dollar broke above parity with the Swiss franc on Thursday, for the first time since March 15.
The bottom line for forex trading seems to be: traders are downbeat on the Euro versus the pound, the US dollar is gaining, and the Japanese yen is gaining from its safe haven reputation.

In the crude oil markets, the stronger US dollar weighs on prices, but oil still managed its best week this year. Oil traders are optimistic that OPEC will act to extend its supply cutbacks, and US government data last week showed that gasoline stocks dropped while refinery output rose. All three factors work to boost crude oil prices.

At the same time, it's important to note that crude oil has slipped 6% in the markets this year, most of that loss coming this month, as the market remains badly oversupplied. Global output continues to outpace demand, and crude oil stockpiles worldwide are at or near record high levels.

In terms of price, we see WTI, the US benchmark, gained a half percent on Friday to end last week at $50.60 per barrel. Brent crude, the global benchmark, gained three quarters percent and finished the week at $53.53. It's the first time WTI has been above $50 since March 8.

Precious metals – gold especially – also gained, on the same safe haven sentiment that boosted the Japanese yen. Gold gained 0.53% to sell for $1,249.20 per ounce, silver added 0.27% to reach $18.26, and platinum gained 0.17% and sells for $950.35. In the industrial metal markets, copper is down 0.71% to $2.65 per pound.

In the stock markets, Wall Street finished Friday on a down note. The Dow lost 0.31%, the S&P 500 lost 0.23%, and the NASDAQ slipped 0.04%. In Europe, the UK markets were down while the Continental markets were up – in a reversal of the pattern we saw in forex trading. The FTSE 100 dropped 0.70% while the DAX gained 0.46% and the CAC 40 advanced 0.65%.

The Asia-Pacific stock markets saw sharp drops in Japan and Australia, and mixed results in China. The Nikkei 225 lost 0.81% and the TOPIX lost 0.98%; both indexes usually weaken when the yen strengthens. The Aussie S&P ASX fell 0.53%. In China, the Hang Seng lost 0.78%, but the CSI 300 gained 0.56%.
That’s the market news. Have a great week in the trading markets!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_03_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 03, 2017
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, stock markets, NFP, Brexit, precious metals

content-body.text: While Wall Street is not yet open for trading, stocks markets in other regions have opened the quarter with gains, especially the Asia-Pacific. In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 is up 0.39% and the TOPIX is up 0.29%. In China, the gains are larger: the Hang Seng is up 0.62% and the CSI 300 index is up 0.56%. Australia's S&P ASX has gained a more modest 0.13%.

European stock markets have opened the session to more mixed results. In early hours trading, the CAC 40 is down 0.09%, and the FTSE 100 in London, very sensitive to the startup of the Brexit process, is down 0.05%. Germany's DAX, however, has gained a quarter percent; Europe's largest economy is expected to whether the Brexit reasonably well.

Investors will be keeping their eyes on US data releases this week, especially related to jobs. The ADP jobs report is due out on Wednesday – it is widely seen as a preview of the official government data due to be released in the Non-Farm Payroll (NFP) report on Friday. The NFP is expected to show 180,000 to 200,000 new jobs for the month of March. That forecast is a slight decline from last month, but still indicative of a healthy job market.

In the forex trading markets, the US dollar is showing a modest gain to start the month. The US dollar index is up from Friday's 100.350 to 100.490 in moderate trading. The dollar is showing gains against the British pound, the Australian dollar, and the Canadian dollar. The Euro, and the safe haven yen and Swiss franc, are advancing.

Looking at the major pairs, we see mostly small changes. The EUR/USD rose 0.13% to 1.0666, the USD/JPY slipped 0.08% to 111.30, and the Swiss franc lost 0.07% to 1.0019. On the positive side for the dollar, the USD/CAD gained 0.14% to 1.3337.

The Australian dollar and the pound sterling posted the largest shifts, as both lost ground. The AUD/USD slipped 0.41% to 0.7598, and the GBP/USD lost 0.45% to 1.2494. The loss for the pound comes after a strong end to last week, in which the British currency gained at the Euro's expense despite the official start of the Brexit process. The Euro is currently up against both the pound and the yen, with the EUR/GBP rising to 0.8536 and the EUR/JPY advancing to 118.70.

On an interesting note in emerging markets, the South African rand is down almost 9% since March 24, when rumors began that President Zuma was intent on firing his respected finance minister Pravin Gordhan. Gordhan was summoned back to South Africa last week after starting an official junket to the UK and US, and later stated that he learned of his firing from the TV news. Zuma has replaced Gordhan, a widely respected and highly experienced financial expert with a reputation for pushing sound fiscal policy, with the Home Affairs Minister Malusi Gigaba. Gigaba has no experience in finance or business, and is expected to serve in the Finance Ministry as a 'yes man' for the President.
In the wake of this affair, the USD/ZAR has spiked to 13.6238 in the forex trading markets, reversing recent gains for the South African currency.

In commodity trading, precious metals are edging down as investors take a cautious approach this week, ahead of several important data releases. The NFP report has already been mentioned; on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve will release the minutes of its last policy meeting. Investors will be watching that release carefully for hints to the Fed's future stance on interest rates and monetary tightening. So far, the Federal Reserve has indicated that it will pursue a gradual pace of rate hikes, but there have been some dissenting voices. Higher interest rates are bearish for precious metals.

So far, precious metal prices would seem to indicate that investors expect the Fed to keep its dovish tone. Gold is down 0.20% to $1,246.70 per ounce, and silver has lost 0.28% to trade at $18.21. Platinum, however, has gained 0.24% and trades at $952.65 per ounce. It's important to note that platinum has a number of industrial uses that gold lacks.

Also in commodity trading, crude oil prices are mixed. US benchmark WTI is up 0.10% to $50.65 per barrel, while global benchmark Brent crude is flat at $53.53. Both grades are wobbling between small gains and losses in today's trading, as investors try to figure if OPEC's expected extension of the cutback program for an additional six months can outweigh rising production and inventories in the US. In the background is a global oil market oversupply that has been depressing prices for nearly three years.
That’s the market news. Have a great week in the trading markets!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_04_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 04, 2017
article.description: Stock markets were mainly down in yesterday’s trading as investors look for safe haven assets and take a risk averse stance.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, Japanese yen, safe haven, gold, stock markets, crude oil

content-body.text: Investors are taking a risk-averse stance today, and the US dollar is giving back some of yesterday’s gains. At this writing, the US dollar index, a broad measure of the currency, slipped to 100.460. The index is currently trending downward.

In the major forex trading pairs, the EUR/USD is flat at 1.0670, but trending upward. The GBP/USD has slipped 0.12% and trades at 1.2471. The dollar has lost ground against the yen, however, as the USD/JPY has lost 0.38% and fallen to 110.48.

In an interesting emerging market note, the South African rand has slipped another 0.59%, making the sixth session in a row losses. The rand has been falling since last week, when President Zuma shook up his cabinet, recalled his respected finance minister from a trip abroad, and sacked him.
