The finance minister, Pravin Gordhan, was widely respected as a financial expert and had pushed for responsible fiscal policy. He was replaced by a political yes-man without financial experience. The USD/ZAR has spiked 13.7673.

Related to the risk averse trading, gold and silver have both gained in the precious metal markets. Gold prices advanced 0.22% to $1,256.28 per ounce, while silver gained 0.57% to $18.32 per ounce. Platinum is down slightly, just 0.02%, and trading at $956.55. Chinese and Indian markets are closed today for public holidays, putting the world’s two largest gold importers aside for a day, so expect the precious metal markets to be a bit muted.

Crude oil prices have reversed most of yesterday’s gains, as investors wait to see the first set of inventory numbers from the US later today. Estimates forecast a drop of half a million barrel in US crude oil stockpiles, as well as a draw of 1.4 million barrels from gasoline stocks. If so, it would be only the third crude oil draw in the US in the last 14 weeks. Crude oil prices have been hammered by rising US production and stockpiles this year, and finished the first quarter down by almost six percent.

Stock markets are lower, with Wall Street showing losses across the board yesterday after auto sales numbers disappointed. The low car sales for March pushed auto and auto-related stocks lower, and these let the market decline. The Dow Jones lost 0.06%, the S&P 500 lost 0.16%, and the NASDAQ fell 0.29%. In Europe also, the major stocks fell in yesterday’s trading. The FTSE 100 slipped 0.55%, the DAX lost 0.45%, and the CAC 40 lost 0.71%.

In the Asia-Pacific region, stocks are currently lower in Japan and Australia, but higher in China. The Nikkei 225 is down 1.11% and the TOPIX is down 1.09%. The S&P ASX is down 0.27%. The CSI 300 in Shanghai has gained 0.56%, and the Hang Seng in Hong Kong is up 0.52%.
That’s the market news. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_05_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 05, 2017
article.description: Upbeat trade data is supporting prices in US stock markets, while a stockpile draw is boosting crude oil.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, stock markets, trade deficit, crude oil, US dollar, gold

content-body.text: Financial markets shrugged off another North Korean ballistic missile test, as investors are more interested in watching the upcoming summit meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping. The two will discuss the tensions on the Korean peninsula, of course, but the main focus of the meeting will be trade and currency exchange issues.

Upbeat trade data from the US made a greater impact in the markets, helping keep share prices in the green on Wall Street. The US Commerce Department reported a greater than expected drop in the February trade deficit, as well as a reduction in the trade gap for January. February's trade deficit was reported at $43.6 billion, $1.2 billion lower than expected. Stronger exports went a long way to the improved numbers.

In the stock markets, US shares rose yesterday. The gains were modest, with the Dow posting an advance of 0.19%, the S&P 500 adding 0.06%, and the NASDAQ picking up 0.07%. The European stock markets showed a stronger performance, with the FTSE 100 adding 0.54% in yesterday's trading, the DAX gaining 0.21%, and the CASC 40 gaining 0.30%.

n today's trading, the Asia-Pacific markets are volatile. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 is up 0.31%, and the TOPIX index is up 0.06%. In China, Shanghai's CSI 300 is up 1.21% – this index has been strong all day – but the Hang Seng in Hong Kong is currently down 0.11%. The Australian S&P ASX index is up 0.24%.In forex trading, markets are mixed. The US dollar is showing gains against the Euro, the Swiss franc, and the Canadian dollar, but has slipped against the yen, the pound, and the Australian dollar.

By the numbers, the EUR/USD edged down 0.03% to 1.0671, the USD/CHF gained 0.05% to 1.0025, and the USD/CAD edged up to 1.3402. The dollar has been holding just above parity with the Swiss franc since March 30.
On the down side for greenback, the USD/JPY has slipped 0.03% to 110.71, the GBP/USD is looking up at 1.2440, and the AUD/USD gained 0.17% to 0.7578.
At this writing, the US dollar index, which takes a broader look at the dollar in the forex trading markets, is down 0.02% to 100.520.

Crude oil prices have been staging a comeback for several sessions now, and held on to overnight gains as today's trading began. A perception that OPEC's cutback agreement may ease the overall supply glut in the long term, combined with a larger than expected draw from US crude oil stockpiles in the American Petroleum Institute numbers reported yesterday, are providing price support.

The API numbers might be the more important of the two. After 12 builds in 14 weeks, the API draw beat expectations by a long shot – data showed a draw of 1.83 million barrels, compared to the forecast 430,000.

In prices, the West Texas Intermediate benchmark grade is up 0.78% to $51.43 per barrel. Brent crude is up 0.70% to $54.55. Both grades have had trouble recently getting back to the $50 handle; both have traded in a narrow $50 to $55 dollar range for most of the last four months, and it remains to be seen if they can get above that. Oil traders will be watching the official stockpile data from the US government – to be released later today – for confirmation of the API numbers.

Precious metals are mixed today. Gold and silver are edging down, while platinum is showing gains. Gold lost 0.15% to sell at $1,254.35 per ounce, and silver fell 0.37% to a price of $18.26. Platinum is showing a gain of 0.21% and a price of $962.90 per ounce.
That’s the market news. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_06_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 06, 2017
article.description: Stock markets are lower, and the US dollar is walking back gains. Crude oil is down on US stockpile numbers.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, yen, Swiss franc, Federal Reserve, President Trump, crude oil, stock markets

content-body.text: In forex trading, the US dollar has eased back from recent gains, mainly as investors grow cautious ahead of today's meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping. The two leaders are set to discuss trade issues – President Trump has been especially vocal about perceived Chinese currency manipulation – but North Korea's recent ballistic missile test is also on the agenda. The increasing geopolitical risk is weighing on the US dollar.

Looking at the major forex trading pairs, the EUR/USD gained 0.13% to 1.0677 and the GBP/USD is flat at 1.2483. The safe haven yen and Swiss franc are both up – the USD/JPY slipped 0.12% to 110.57 and the USD/CHF is down 0.17% to 1.0032.
The dollar gained on the Australian and Canadian currencies. The AUD/USD is down 0.29% to 0.7548, while a downturn in oil prices hurt the loonie and pushed the USD/CAD up to 1.3438.
Taking a bigger picture look at the dollar, the US dollar index is trending down at 100.490. The index has held steady in a very narrow range – 100.350 to 100.560 – since March 30.

In the stock markets, share prices declined in Europe and the US in yesterday's session, dropping and reversing early gains after the release of the Federal Reserve's March meeting minutes showed that the central bank is actively contemplating slowing down the pace of interest rate hikes and monetary easing planned for this year.

On Wall Street, all of the major indexes dropped after the Fed news minutes release, with the Dow finishing the day down 0.20%, the S&P 500 losing 0.31%, and the NASDAQ dropping 0.58%. In Europe, the DAX ended the session down 0.53%, and the CAC 40 lost 0.18%. London's FTSE 100 also slipped late in the trading day, but stayed in the green and finished with a gain of 0.13%.

In today's trading, the Asia-Pacific stock markets are mostly down. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 has lost 1.04% and the TOPIX index is down 1.63%. In Hong Kong the Hang Seng has declined 0.52%, and in Australia the S&P ASX is down 0.34%. Shanghai's CSI 300 index is the odd one out, with a gain of a quarter percent today.

Precious metals, which lost ground yesterday, made gains overnight when the Federal Reserve minutes prompted investors to move toward safe havens – it was the same sentiment that boosted the yen and Swiss franc. The precious metals have since walked back some of those gains. Gold is now down 0.17% to $1,253.57 per ounce and platinum has slipped 0.41% to $957.95. Silver is the gainer here, adding 0.24% to trade at $18.23.

Once again, crude oil markets are unable to maintain traction, and have reversed recent gains. The reverse this time comes as the US Energy Information Administration reported build in US crude oil stockpiles to another record high level. This official report is the opposite of the earlier API numbers which had indicated a crude oil draw. The EIA numbers showed an inventory increase of 1.57 million barrels, and total stocks of 535.5 million barrels. The Cushing storage hub – the main US facility for storing crude oil – currently holds a record 69.1 million barrels, out of a total capacity of 77 million. In addition to the storage builds, US oil output rose last week to 9.2 million barrels.

The numbers on US crude oil storage and production have fueled investor fears that North American oil will go a long way to offset OPEC's cutback plan, and prolong the global oil market oversupply problem. WTI, the US benchmark for oil trading, fell 0.35% to $50.97 per barrel, and Brent, the global benchmark, dropped 0.29% to $54.20.
Looking ahead, tomorrow will bring us the monthly Non-Farm Payroll report, the official word on the US jobs market. Earlier this week, data released by ADP showed a much larger
That’s the market news. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_09_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 09, 2017
article.description: After airstrikes in Syria and the monthly US jobs report, stock markets and forex trading remain in flux.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, President Trump, jobs report, Syria, crude oil, gold, stock markets

content-body.text: Plenty of headlines hit the markets last week, but the two biggest were airstrikes President Trump ordered in Syria and the monthly jobs report from the US government.

Start with the airstrikes. Early last week, a chemical weapons attack was launched on civilians in northern Syria, killing dozens including a large number of young children. It is suspected that the Assad regime launched the strikes. In response, the Trump Administration tried to get the UN Security Council to pass a resolution condemning the attacks, but was rebuffed by Russia. President Trump then ordered cruise missile strikes on the airbase from which the attacks were launched.

Markets reacted immediately. Crude oil prices spiked on Thursday night and Friday morning – in the so-called Middle East premium. Precious metals also rose, as investors looked for a safe haven investment as hedge against conflict. Stock markets' volatility increased.

Markets began to settle down on Friday morning, and then the regular Non-Farm Payroll report was released by the US government. The NFP, also called the monthly jobs report, give a detailed rundown on the situation of the labor market in the US, and is frequently taken as a proxy report for the overall US economy. Let's take a look at the numbers.

The headline number, of course, was the increase is 98,000 jobs for the month of March. This was a serious disappointment, as it badly missed the forecast of 180,000 and came in far lower than February's 219,000. The unemployment number fell from 4.7% to 4.5%, a positive sign, but wage gains slowed to 2.7% on a year-over-year basis. In addition to the poor monthly number, the jobs report showed a downward revision of 38,000 jobs for the January and February. The revisions, plus March's dismal result, pushed the three month average down to 178,000.

The darkest spot in the jobs numbers came from the retails sector. Approximately 30,000 retails positions were cut last month, the same as in February, and along with store closures and company bankruptcies, underscores the fragility of the American retail sector despite an uptick in consumer sentiment. The jobs cuts in retail gave that sector its worst two months since 2009.

Turning to the markets, Wall Street finished in the red on Friday, turning down after the jobs report was released. The Dow Jones ended up with a loss of 0.03%, the S&P 500 slipped 0.085, and the NASDAQ dropped 0.02%. Losses were minimized by gains earlier in the day.
The European markets finished Friday's session with mixed results. The FTSE 100 gained 0.63% and the CAC 40 gained 0.27%, but the DAX was down 0.05%.

In the Asia Pacific region, most markets finished the week on a positive note. The Nikkei 225 gained 0.36% and the TOPIX added 0.65%. Gains were smaller in China and Australia, where the CSI 300 gained 0.10% and the S&P ASX gained 0.11%. The Hang Seng slipped 0.03%.
In the forex trading markets, the US dollar is mostly up, with the US dollar index adding half a percent on Friday to finish at 101.180.
The EUR/USD is down 0.50% to 1.0591, the GBP/USD is down 0.79% to 1.2371, and the AUD/USD is down 0.60% to 0.7500. The USD/JPY gained 0.25% to 111.09, and the USD/CHF added 0.41% to 1.0091.
The Canadian dollar also gained, advancing 0.11% against the greenback and pushing the USD/CAD down to 1.3398. The loonie gained from an increase in the price of oil.

Crude oil, for its part, gained on the prospect of increased conflict in the Middle East. The global trading benchmark, Brent crude, was up 0.64% by end of trading on Friday, to a price of $55.24 per barrel, and WTI, the US benchmark, was up 1.04% to $52.24. Both grades were lower Friday than Thursday, pointing to the continued oversupply in crude oil markets. US active rigs increased last week for the twelfth week in a row, so it may be an open question how long the increase in oil prices will last.

Precious metals spiked in the aftermath of the airstrikes, but were lower by the end of the day Friday. Silver is currently down 0.52% to $18.15 per ounce, and platinum is down 0.41% to $954.60. Gold has managed to hang on to some of its gains, and is up 0.23%, selling for $1,254.53 per ounce.
That’s the market news. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_10_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 10, 2017
article.description: The US dollar is showing strength today. Crude oil prices are up, but the oil markets still have underlying weakness.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, oil markets, stock markets, gold

content-body.text: As we start a new week, the US dollar is at its highest level since March 14 in the forex trading markets. The US dollar index is showing 101.200, up 0.02% from yesterday, and is trending upwards.

In the major pairs, the EUR/USD is down 0.05% to 1.0586 and the AUD/USD is down 0.11% to 0.7492. This is the Aussie's weakest since early January. The Euro is weaker after polls show a tightening race between centrist Emmanuel Macron and the far-right Marine Le Pen in the upcoming French elections.
The USD/JPY is gaining, adding 0.21% to reach 111.32, and the USD/CAD is up 0.13% at 1.3415.
On the downside, the dollar is weaker against the pound and the Swiss franc. The GBP/USD gained 0.14% to 1.2388, while the USD/CHF slipped 0.01% to 1.0090.

In the oil markets, prices for crude are volatile today. Overnight, oil walked back some of yesterday's gains, but has recouped this morning. Prices for West Texas Intermediate are up 0.52%, to $52.51 per barrel and Brent is up 0.43% to $55.48.

Oil markets are a bit jittery, due to the rising tensions in the Middle East. The move of a US aircraft carrier toward the Korean peninsula is also making traders nervous. Some analysts, however, are saying that last week's sharp jump in oil prices – the reflex reaction to the US airstrikes in Syria – was overdone. Syria is a minor player in oil markets, after all, and US Administration spokesmen indicated that the strikes were a one-off event.

The bigger pressure in oil markets comes from US shale field production. The number of active rigs continues to rise – last week saw the twelfth weekly increase in a row. In addition, stockpiles also continue to rise – there have been thirteen inventory builds in the last fifteen weeks, and US stocks are at an all-time high of 535.5 million barrels. All of this fuels concerns among oil traders that the global market's oversupply is simply not going away.

In precious metals, prices are down. Investors are moving away from safe haven assets and back toward stocks or the dollar. Gold has slipped 0.07% to $1,253.67 per ounce and platinum is down 0.22% to $953.53. Silver has lost the most, dropping 1.27% to sell at $17.92 per ounce.

Stocks markets dipped at the end of last week. Wall Street's main indexes finished Friday in the red, with modest losses between 0.02% and 0.08%. The US markets have not yet opened for this week's trading.
Europe's markets have opened for early hours trading. In London, the FTSE 100 is showing a gain of 0.09%, and the German DAX is up 0.12%. The CAC 40 is down 0.21%.

The Asia-Pacific markets are also showing mixed results. Japanese shares are up, with the Nikkei 225 gaining 0.71% and the TOPIX up 0.66%. The Australian S&P ASX is up 0.86%. Shares are down in China, where the Hang Seng has slipped 0.13% and the CSI 300 has fallen 0.34%.
That’s the market news. Have a great week trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_12_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 12, 2017
article.description: Stock markets are down today, while the US dollar is weaker as investors move toward safe haven assets.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, stock markets, US dollar, yen, franc, safe haven, haven demand, crude oil

content-body.text: Geopolitical risk is pushing up safe haven assets today, as tensions in the Middle East and Korean peninsula continue to make headlines. The political fallout from the recent US missile strikes in Syria has yet to make a coherent pattern, although US President Donald Trump is reaping substantial domestic and foreign benefits. In Korea, Kim Jong-Un's communist dictatorship in the north has released a statement that North Korea will use nuclear weapons to respond to any provocation. President Trump tweeted that if China doesn't fix the problem, the US will, and a US Navy carrier battle group is en route to the region.

It's a shaky set of situations, and it's had predictable results. To start with, stocks are down. Wall Street's main indexes saw declines in yesterday's trading. The Dow Jones was down 0.03%, the S&P 500 was down 0.14%, and the NASDAQ lost 0.24%. In Europe, share prices were down on the Continent, where the DAX lost 0.50% and the CAC 40 was down 0.11%, but London's FTSE 100 gained 0.23%.

In the Asia-Pacific region, the Australian S&P ASX is up 0.08% in today's session, but that's the only bright spot for equities. China's CSI 300 is down 0.26% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng is down 0.11%. In Japan, a stronger yen is putting pressure stock markets, sending share prices down. The Nikkei 225 and the TOPIX have both lost 1.04% today.

Currency markets are volatile today, following sharp drops overnight for the US dollar in forex trading. The EUR/USD is up a tenth of a percent at 1.0616, and higher oil prices are helping the Canadian dollar put the USD/CAD up to 1.3322. The Swiss franc has gained on safe haven demand, and the USD/CHF is down 0.10% to 1.0065. The Japanese yen is also higher as a safe haven asset, having broken below 110 to the dollar overnight. The USD/JPY is currently down 0.01% at 109.61.
The US dollar has gained on sterling and the Aussie. The GBP/USD is down 0.03% to 1.2487, and the AUD/USD is down 0.09% to 0.7492.
In commodity markets, crude oil is up, marking the seventh straight day of increased oil prices. Crude oil is gaining on several factors, all coming together at once.

First, there is the general geopolitical risk situation, alluded to above. Oil prices rice when such risk increases. Second, two items have come out of Saudi Arabia: the Saudi government is in favor of extending the OPEC-led production cutback to the end of the year, and Saudi oil producers have cut back production more than the deal requires of them. Finally, the American Petroleum Institute reported that there was a large draw from US stockpiles last week, of 360,000 barrels. Forecasts had called for a 316,000 barrel build.

On that final point, it's important to note that last week's stockpile numbers showed a strong divergence between API's numbers and the official US government numbers. Like this week, API reported an unexpected draw; the government numbers, however, showed a large build. Analysts are uncertain whether or not the two data sources will continue to diverge this week.

Precious metals posted very strong gains in overnight trading, on the same haven demand that boosted the yen and Swiss franc, but are walking back some of those gains this morning. Gold is trading at $1,273.58 per ounce, up nearly $20 from Monday, but down 0.10% from earlier today. Platinum is showing a similar pattern, but is down 0.42% this morning to $966.57. Silver prices are still up, with silver trading at $18.32 for a gain of 0.33%.
Copper, the widely used industrial metal that is also seen as a proxy for the industrial metal market, is down 0.94% to $2.58 per pound.
Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_13_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 13, 2017
article.description: The US dollar is easing back after President Trump said her prefers a weaker currency, and China posted strong trade numbers.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, China, President Trump, Korea, crude oil, precious metals, gold, stock markets

content-body.text: Mid-week, and some interesting news has come out in economic data releases. China has reported strong trade numbers, and considerably improved their 2017 growth outlook. Both are important market indicators for the world's second largest economy.

China saw growth in both imports and exports, year-over-year, for the month of March. Imports rose 20.3%, mainly on strong demand for commodities: copper, iron ore, coal, crude oil, and soybeans. Imports of crude oil were especially strong, hitting a record high level. Exports rose 14.8%, and China reported a trade surplus worth almost 24 billion US dollars.

In US terms, China's exports to the American markets rose 19.7%, significantly higher than the 15.1% rise in imports from the US. These trade numbers, and the nearly $50 billion trade surplus China maintains with the US, are central features of the growing talks between the Trump Administration and Beijing.

In addition to trade, the Trump Administration will be talking with China about currency issues – President Trump recently commented to the Wall Street Journal that he will not be declaring China a currency manipulator – and North Korea. A number of analysts have seen Trump's missile strikes against Syria as a message aimed at China: rein in North Korea's nuclear program, or we'll do it for you. The movement of a US Navy carrier battle group toward the Korean peninsula underscores the point. China seems to have gotten the message – Beijing has reduced coal imports from North Korea, and stationed as many as 100,000 troops along the Chinese-Korean border.

The most important point in all of this for forex trading is probably Trump's comments on the US dollar. In addition to backing off on his previous insistence that China has been manipulating forex trading exchange rates, he also said that he prefers a weaker dollar and low interest rates as being good for trade and exporters.

An immediate result of President Trump's comments was, in fact, a weaker US dollar. The greenback slipped in forex trading and the US dollar index is still down 0.58% at 100.040, a two-week low. In the major forex pairs, the dollar has gained slightly on the Euro and the Swiss franc, but lost ground against sterling, the yen, and the Australian and Canadian dollars.

The EUR/USD is down 0.15% to 1.0649, and the USD/CHF has gained 0.05% to 1.0033. On the downside for the greenback, the GBP/USD picked up 0.11% to 1.2549 and the AUD/USD added 0.89% to 0.7589. The USD/JPY slipped 0.02% to 109.01 and the USD/CAD lost 0.14% to 1.3235.

Local factors are still influencing currencies, even with Trump's comments. The Australian dollar's sharp rise comes after the Australian Bureau of Statistics reported higher than expected employment for March. The numbers, which included an upward revision for February, showed 60,900 new jobs in March against a forecast of 20,000.

In commodity trading, crude oil has been walking back recent gains. WTI, the US trading benchmark, is down 0.19% to $53.01 per barrel while global benchmark Brent crude is down 0.14% to $55.78. The losses put crude oil prices right back into the midpoint of the range they held from early December through the beginning of March.

Stronger Chinese demand helped push oil prices down. Oil imports to China rose 15% for the first quarter in year-over-year terms, reaching a new record of 8.52 million barrels per day. The strong Chinese demand numbers outweighed the unexpected draw down from US inventories, for investors, helped along by the fact that even though US stockpiles fell by more than 2 million barrels last week they are still at near-record high levels.

President Trump's comments on the dollar didn't just push the US currency down in the markets, they also lifted precious metals. With the dollar down, investors have to put their money somewhere, after all. Precious metals have been gaining in today's early trading.

Platinum is up 0.07%, to a price of $974.21 per ounce. Silver is showing a stronger gain of 1.28% and is up to $18.54. Oddly enough, gold is currently down slightly, dipping 0.05% to $1,286.09. Even with that drop, gold is at a five-month high.

In stock markets, Japanese shares are looking at their third day in a row of losses. Tokyo's equities have been hurt by the stronger yen, which like gold, is at five-month highs. The Nikkei 225 is down 0.68% and the TOPIX is down 0.76%. In China, shares are mixed. The Hang Seng is down 0.21% and the CSI 300 index is up 0.15%.

The European stock markets are opening to losses today. The FTSE 100 is down 0.44%, the DAX is down 0.29%, and the CAC 40 is down 0.54%. The US markets have not opened as of this writing, but the futures markets point toward a lower opening on Wall Street, too.
That's today's market summary. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_16_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 16, 2017
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading

content-body.text: It's a slow news weekend in the financial markets, as most trading was closed on Friday and will be closed tomorrow in observance of the Good Friday and Easter holidays. There are some important developments to point out, however, that investors should be aware of before normal trading resumes on Tuesday.

First, the US government reported some surprisingly dismal economic data on Friday. Core inflation numbers came in, showing a drop in prices for the first time in the last 13 months, and retail sales data fell 0.2% for March after a 0.3% drop in February. With consumer spending making up 70% of the US economy, a two-month drop in the retail sales numbers is a dangerous warning marker.

Second, those two data sets cast doubt on the Federal Reserve's plans to raise interest rates at least twice more this year. Policy-wise, higher interest rates and monetary tightening are used to control inflation and rein in spending, but with inflation and spending both down the Fed may not be able to pursue a tightening policy as rapidly has then have indicated.

Finally, the downbeat data and the reduced chance of a Federal Reserve rate move have depressed the US dollar in the forex trading markets. The greenback fell against all of its major peers, and the USD/JPY dropped 0.41% to hit a five-month low of 108.64. The US dollar index, which compares the currency to a trade-weighted basket of its peers, is at a ten-day low of 100.51.

Going into the weekend, the main global stock market indexes were all down. The Japanese markets, which were open on Friday, declined under pressure from the stronger yen. Prices for crude oil and precious metals were mostly flat. Silver was the exception, showing a 1.15% gain to $18.51 per ounce.
We'll see you Tuesday on the trading floor!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_19_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 19, 2017
article.description: Theresa May called snap elections in the UK, to bet a renewed voter mandate before the Brexit. The pound sterling jumped in forex trading.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, Brexit, pound, Theresa May, snap elections, US dollar, crude oil, gold

content-body.text: Two big news items are impacting markets today. The first is the sharp drop in retail sales in the US, where receipts declined in both February and March; the second is from the UK, where Prime Minister Theresa May rocked political watchers and financial markets by calling for snap elections on June 8.

In the US, the drop in retail sales was the worst since 2015, and bodes ill for the future – consumer activity makes up about 70% of US economic activity. According to economic forecasts, US growth for the first quarter of 2017 is heading for a lackluster 0.5%. In the financial markets, stocks are down about 2% over the past month, as investors have moved their money into the save haven assets such as gold.

From the UK, PM May's announcement made a bigger splash than the US' slowing economic performance. May called the election in a surprise move, citing the need for a new voter mandate to strengthen Britain's hand during the negotiation process with the EU. Her critics have charged that she is motivated more by partisan political concerns – her Tory party is the strongest in the UK, with a 17 seat outright majority in Parliament and currently polling at 42% among the electorate, while the opposition parties are smaller, weaker, and divided both within and between themselves.

May's goal is to increase her House of Commons majority and thus her leverage against the EU in the Brexit process. Investors see reason to hope that she'll be successful, as the pound sterling jumped to a six-month high after May's announcement. The GBP/USD pair is currently trading at 1.2818, despite a slight loss overnight. For comparison, the pound was trading at 1.2585 to the dollar on March April 17.
The pound's strength helped push the US dollar to an overall three-week low, with the US dollar index down to 99.59. The index hasn't been below 100 since March 29.
In the other major pairs, the US dollar is recouping some of yesterday's losses. The EUR/USD is down 0.05% to 1.0725, the USD/JPY is up 0.375 to 108.83, and the USD/CHF is up 0.06% to 0.9969.

In the stock markets, US share prices were down after yesterday's session, hurt by the weaker dollar and the poor retail sales. The Dow Jones was down 0.55%, the S&P 500 was down 0.29%, and the NASDAQ had slipped 0.12%.

In today's equity trading, the Asian and European markets are mixed. Most main indexes are down, but each region has some positives. In Asia, that's the Nikkei, up 0.07%. The TOPIX has lost 0.01%, while losses are stronger in China and Australia. The Hang Seng is down 0.34%, the CSI 300 is down 0.48%, and the S&P ASX is down 0.56%. In Europe, the DAX is up 0.19% and the CAC 40 is up 0.07%, while the FTSE 100 in London is down 0.07%.

Crude oil prices have been volatile in recent days, due to the usual conflicting price pressures. Prices were down overnight but are up very slightly this morning. WTI, the US benchmark, is trading at $52.42 per barrel, up 0.02%, while Brent, the global benchmark, has gained 0.05% to trade at $54.92.

Investors should watch closely today for the Energy Information Administration stockpile numbers from the US. Yesterday's report from the American Petroleum Institute showed a smaller than expected draw – 840,000 barrel against the 1.47 million forecast – from stocks, a surprise build in gasoline stocks of 1.4 million barrels. Should EIA confirm that draws are smaller than expected, it will increase trader anxiety about rising US crude oil output and its impact on global oversupply.

The US dollar's rebound in forex trading has put pressure on gold prices. The precious metal has eased back over half a percent today after rising sharply yesterday. Gold is now trading at $1,282.77 per ounce. Silver is also down, by 0.64%, to $18.16. Platinum is holding on to yesterday's gains and is selling at $976.28.
We'll see you on the trading floor!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_20_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 20, 2017
article.description: Safe havens are retreating as investors make moves toward risk assets. Oil prices are rebounding from a sharp drop.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, crude oil, gold, safe haven, yen, stock markets

content-body.text: Investors are pausing, and taking stock of economic and geopolitical risks. Stock and commodity markets are mixed as a result.

In the stock markets, the Asia-Pacific region is seeing mostly gains. Japan's TOPIX index is up 0.09%, China's CSI 300 is up 0.46%, and the Hong Kong's Hang Seng is up 0.97%. In Australia, the S&P ASX has gained 0.30%. The only loss comes from Tokyo, where the Nikkei 225 has slipped 0.01%.

In Europe, the stock markets opened to losses but have since turned around in volatile trading. The DAX is up a modest 0.02%, while the CAC 40 has gained 0.64%. In London, the FTSE 100 has slipped 0.12%.

In the US, markets have not opened for trading yet today. Futures trading points to modest gains at the opening bell. In yesterday's session, the Dow finished down 0.58% and the S&P 500 slipped 0.17%. The NASDAQ gained 0.23%.
In forex trading, the US dollar has slipped in today's early trading. The dollar index dipped 0.32% to 99.414. The index compares the US dollar to a trade-weighted basket of peer currencies.

Looking at the individual forex trading pairs, we see the dollar up against the Japanese yen but slipping elsewhere. The USD/JPY has gained 0.17% and managed to climb back above 109. The pair currently stands at 109.05.

The Euro and the pound are both holding on to their recent gains against the greenback. The EUR/USD is up 0.55% to 1.0770 and the GBP/USD is up 0.45% to 1.2834. The USD/CAD has slipped 0.04% to 1.3479 and the USD/CHF is down 0.35% to 0.9949.

The Japanese yen and Swiss franc have both gained recently on their reputation as safe haven assets. The confused nature of market activity lately can be seen to today's results – the yen is down and the franc is up. The other traditional safe haven, precious metals, is also showing mixed results, with some up and some down.

Gold is down. After peaking just below $1,290 earlier this week, gold is trading today at $1,279.38 per ounce and is trending downward. Silver is also down, having lost 0.01% this morning and slipped to a price of $18.16. Platinum, however, is up, gaining 0.30% and selling at $970.38. It's interesting to note that platinum has important industrial uses, and that copper, a good proxy for the industrial metals market, is also up. Copper has gained 0.69% and is selling at $2.57 per pound.

Starting this past Tuesday, crude oil prices have seen their biggest slump in the last four weeks, but are starting to rebound. As has been usual for the last several months, crude oil prices are getting tugged in different directions by different forces, and have been unable to break above the $55 handle.

This week's data tug on crude has come from the US government, whose Energy Information Administration provided the weekly official word on US crude oil stockpile inventories. According to EIA, crude stocks dropped by 1 million barrels last week, a smaller draw than expected. In addition, gasoline stocks grew by 1.5 million barrels against a forecast for a 1.9 million barrel draw. The report highlights the difficulties that market producers are having in working down the global oil supply glut and bringing supply and demand into balance.
At this writing, US benchmark WTI is up 0.44% to $50.88 per barrel. Brent crude is up 0.49% and selling for $53.42 per barrel.
We'll see you on the trading floor!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_23_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 23, 2017
article.description: Gold gained, and the US dollar index was up despite the dollar easing in the forex trading pairs. Oil retreated on supply fears.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, gold, crude oil, French election, Brexit, earnings report

content-body.text: There's a lot happening this week, with voting starting in France, the UK getting ready for an early election campaign, and corporate earnings reporting for Q1 getting started. Watch for plenty of market reaction in response.

The action starts today, when French citizens got to the polls in the first round of their Presidential election. The top two vote getters will proceed to the second round on May 7, in which the winner will become France's next President. It's a simple system, except that the four leaders in the race are all within the polling margin of error of each other, and 25% of French voters were undecided going into the weekend.

The current poll leader is centrist candidate Emmanuel Macron, who is followed by right-wing populist Marine Le Pen, Communist Jean-Luc Melenchon, and conservative candidate Francois Fillon. Investors are worried about a possible Le Pen-Melenchon face-off, as both candidates favor leaving the EU and Euro. Results will start coming in this evening, at 18:00 GMT. Once the Presidential voting is over, the French will prepare for the June 7 legislative elections.

In the UK, Prime Minister Theresa May shocked political watchers by calling for snap elections ahead of the Brexit negotiations. She had previously promised that elections would wait until the regularly scheduled polling in 2020; however, with Parliamentary skepticism growing, she called the snap elections to register voter input and hopefully increase her Conservative Party's legislative majority. Her critics charge that she is simply taking advantage of the disarray in the Labor Party. Both views are likely correct, and in either case, the Conservative Tories are likely to gain as many as 100 seats in the Commons as they are currently polling 50% compared to Labor's 25%. Elections will be held on June 8. The vote is certain to be taken as a second referendum on the government's Brexit policy.

On Wall Street, markets are getting ready for a busy first quarter earnings report season. This coming week will see a series of major companies report their Q1 profits. Watch for major reactions from the S&P 500, as 190 of the indexes members will be reporting. The high point of the earnings reports will come on Thursday, when Microsoft, Intel, Starbuck, Amazon, and Alphabet (parent company of Google) all release their Q1 earnings.

Turning to the markets, we find that stocks were mixed in Friday's trading. Wall Street saw losses, with the Dow slipping 0.15%, the S&P 500 dropping 0.30%, and the NASDAQ losing 0.11%. In Europe, the DAX was up by 0.18%, but the CAC 40 lost 0.37% ahead of the voting, and the FTSE 100 dipped 0.06%.

In the Asian markets, Japan showed strong gains. The Nikkei 225 added 1.03% and the TOPIX gained 1.07%. China's results were more mixed, as the CSI 300 added 0.13% but the Hang Seng lost 0.06%. Australia's S&P ASX posted a gain of 0.56%.

In the commodity markets, crude oil is down again after sharp losses at the end of last week. Oil had rallied earlier when the Saudi and Kuwaiti oil ministers indicated that OPEC favors extending its output cutbacks into the send half of the year. That preference will likely be codified at OPEC meeting on May 25.

The cutbacks, however, have been undermined by increasing US oil production. US government data last week showed that US crude oil production increased for the ninth week in a row, and US drillers added five additional rigs. While stockpile inventories slipped, oil market analysts were more focused on the increasing US production – if production is rising, it will be hard to lessen the global crude oil oversupply.
As a result, US WTI oil broke below $50 per barrel to end the week. WTI finished Friday's session at $49.61 per barrel, for a loss of 2.15%. Brent crude dropped 1.94%, to $51.96.

Precious metals showed mixed results, with silver and platinum both down while gold gained. Gold added 0.20% to $1,284.44 per ounce, mostly on safe haven demand and investor caution ahead of the French vote. Silver slipped 0.89% to $17.94, and platinum was down 0.69% to $972.38.

In forex trading, the US dollar finished last week down against most of the majors. Even so, the US dollar index managed a 0.20% gain to 99.977. The index was trending upward at the end of Friday's session.
In the major forex trading pairs, the EUR/USD was up 0.10% to 1.0728, the GBP/USD was up 0.03% to 1.2817, the USD/JPY was down 0.21% to 109.09, and the USD/CHF was down 0.24% to 0.9963,
We'll see you on the market floor. Have a great week trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_24_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 24, 2017
article.description: Macron and Le Pen will advance to the second round in the French election. The Euro is up, and gold is down.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, French election, Euro, yen, crude oil, China

content-body.text: Emmanuel Macron and Marine Le Pen have emerged the winners from the first round of the French election, and will advance to the runoff on May 7. This is the first time that no major-party candidate has advanced to the final of a French elections; Macron ran as an independent, and Le Pen represents the insurgent National Front party.

Macron is widely expected to win the runoff round, and the prospect has investors sanguine about the future of the Euro and the EU. The Euro currency spiked when trading opened today, boosting the EUR/USD 1.33% to 1.0871. The EUR/JPY gained 2.34% to 119.68, and the EUR/GBP added 1.16% to reach 0.8475. European stock markets also reacted well, with the French CAC 40 index gaining 4.38% in early hours trading. The DAX is also up, by 2.845, and the FTSE 100 has gained 1.85%.

Precious metals lost ground after the French election results, as safe haven demand faded. Gold slipped 1.01%, and is now trading at $1,271.43 per ounce. Silver is down 0.29%, to $17.89, and platinum is down 0.43% to $968.20.

Turning to other trading assets, we see that the US dollar slipped as the Euro rose. The US dollar index is down 1.04%, to 98.936, and the dollar lost ground against most of its major peers. The GBP/USD is up 0.10% to 1.2830. The USD/CHF slipped 0.26% to 0.9937, and the USD/CAD fell a half percent to 1.3431.
The dollar did gain on the yen, adding almost a whole percent and putting the USD/JPY pair at 110.12.

In the Asian stock markets, Tokyo is up and China is mixed. The Nikkei added 1.37% today, the TOPIX gained 0.98%, and the Hang Seng gained 0.41%. Shanghai's CSI 300 is down 1.02%. The loss in China comes as government regulating agencies increase their oversight of financial companies and trading.

Crude oil prices recovered slightly from last week's sharp drop, but remain soft. WTI, the US trading benchmark, rose 1.05% to just break above $50. The grade is now set at $50.14 per ounce. Brent crude is selling for $52.53, a gain of 1.10%.
We'll see you on the market floor. Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_25_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 25, 2017
article.description: Stock markets and the Euro continue to gain after the French election results. The Japanese yen and gold are losing ground.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, French election, Euro, Japanese yen, stock markets, crude oil, gold

content-body.text: Market players are optimistic today, now that the French election results are in, and stock markets and the Euro reflect the good feelings. Safe haven assets are weakening as demand moves back toward risk; gold and the Japanese yen have been hit hard in that respect.

In the stock markets, Asian equities are looking good. China's CSI 300 is recovering from yesterday's sharp losses, and is up 0.29% today. The Hang Seng has gained 1.31%. Japan's stock markets are getting a boost from the weaker yen â€“ the Nikkei 225 is up 1.08% and the TOPIX is up 1.07%.

Europe's markets are easing back a bit from yesterday's gains. London's FTSE 100 is up 0.18%, but the DAX's gains have slowed to 0.02% and the CAC 40 is only up 0.07%. The US stock markets have not opened as of this writing, but finished with strong gains yesterday. Futures trading predicts further gains today.

Looking forward, signs are good for the stock markets. Emmanuel Macron, perceived to be the centrist, pro-business candidate for the French Presidency, is expected to win the office in the second round of voting on May 7, and US President Donald Trump is set to announce a package of tax reforms tomorrow that are likely to contain a strong pro-business slant.

In forex trading, the Euro remains strong and continues to gain, although the gains are slowing. The EUR/USD is up 0.22% to 1.0892, the EUR/GBP is up 0.10% to 0.8502, and the EUR/CHF is up 0.08% to 1.0831. The Euro's strongest gains are against the Japanese yen; the EUR/JPY is up 0.86% to 120.31.

The US dollar remains soft in forex trading, although it is no longer dropping sharply. The US dollar index is holding steady at 98.973, its lowest point since early November. The dollar is down on the pound and the Swiss franc â€“ the GBP/USD has gained 0.11% to 1.2810 and the USD/CHF is down 0.13% to 0.9945. The greenback has posted stronger gains against the yen and the Canadian dollar â€“ the USD/JPY is up 0.63% to 110.46 and the USD/CAD is up 0.47% to trade at 1.3564.

While the French election results are having a strong influence in the forex trading markets today, local factors continue to affect all currencies. In a good example, the Canadian dollar failed to benefit from a slight gain in oil prices, a new US import duty of 20% on Canadian lumber pushed the loonie down in the markets.

As mentioned, crude oil prices gained yesterday, breaking a six-session streak of losses. Gains were modest, and held back by continuing investor concerns that the world's major crude oil producers will not be able to cut back production enough to make inroads into the global oversupply. OPEC has not been fully compliant with its cutback program, and US shale output continues to rise.
In price terms, US benchmark WTI is up 0.35% to $49.40 per barrel. On the global markets, Brent crude is also up 0.35%, to $51.78.

Gold tumbled after the French election results, losing ground as investors chose risk over save haven assets. The other precious metals also lost ground, but gold's losses have been highest. Gold is down 0.51%, to $1,269.79 per ounce. Silver is down 0.29% to $17.88, and platinum is down 0l41% to $957.38.
Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_26_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 26, 2017
article.description: Risk sentiment continues to grow, with the Euro and stocks benefitting most. The US dollar is in a holding pattern after mixed data releases.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, Euro, Japanese yen, crude oil, gold

content-body.text: In forex trading, the Euro remains near its five-month high level against the US dollar. The EUR/USD was up 0.03% overnight, reaching 1.0929. The Euro remains strong against the other majors, as well. The EUR/GBP is up 0.17% to 0.8523, and the EUR/CHF is up 0.04% to 1.0867. The common currency continues post its strongest gains against the Japanese yen, with the EUR/JPY up 0.38% to 121.83.

The US dollar is also up against the Japanese yen, with the USD/JPY advancing 0.32% to 111.45. The yen is suffering in forex trading from a general investor retreat from haven assets since the French election.

As for the US dollar, the dollar index dipped below 99 again last night, and is now at 98.916. The index is trending upward, however, and several key forex trading pairs are showing possible strength for the greenback. The GBP/USD is down 0.15% to 1.2823, the USD/CAD is up 0.04% to 1.3578, and the USD/CHF is finally gaining again, advancing to 0.9939.

The US dollar is responding to mixed messages from US economic data. New home sales reached an eight-month high in March, an important gain, but the Consumer Confidence Index lost ground, falling to 120.3 for April. Confidence may be taking a hit from weakness in the US retail sector; retail bankruptcies are at a record rate this year, and indications are that over 8,500 brick-and-mortar stores will close in the US during 2017. Large department stores are especially hard hit, but even the ubiquitous Subway sandwich chain is closing 1.3% of its US stores.

The drop in haven asset demand has hurt precious metals. Gold is down to a two-week low, losing 0.07% in early trading today. Gold is currently selling for $1,263.19 per ounce. Silver and platinum showed sharper losses, with silver down 0.28% to $17.61 and platinum down 0.29% to $953.06.

Crude oil also dropped overnight, losing ground when the American Petroleum Institute reported a build of 897,000 barrels in crude oil stockpiles, plus an enormous build of 4.44 million barrels in gasoline stocks. The data puts the total US crude oil inventories at 532.5 million barrels, near a record level, and underscores the global oversupply problems.

The US trading benchmark WTI is down 0.30%, to a price of $49.41 per barrel. Brent crude, the global benchmark, is down 0.29% and priced at $51.95. Brent is down more than $5 per barrel so far this year.

Global stock indexes are all up today, as they continue to ride the optimistic sentiment of the last few days. Wall Street's NASDAQ broke 6,000 for the first time ever, and the Dow Jones is hovering just below the 21,000 mark.
Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_27_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 27, 2017
article.description: Markets are normalizing after the investor euphoria generated by the French election results.
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis, Forex trading, US dollar, stock markets, President Trump, crude oil, gold, Bank of Japan

content-body.text: Stock markets are mainly down today, as investors were less than impressed with US President Donald Trump's tax reform proposal. His proposed package, which includes some popular measures to reduce business taxes to 15%, as notably short on specifics and was deemed likely to worsen an already serious budget deficit.

On the positive side, the White House has indicated that President Trump will not try to force an early withdrawal from NAFTA, but will rather seek to renegotiate the trade pact with Canada and Mexico.

Turning to the market numbers, we see that stocks are down in Tokyo, where the Bank of Japan today announced it was keeping its monetary stimulus policy unchanged. The Nikkei 225 is down 0.19%, and the TOPIX slipped 0.05%. Markets in China are up on news of that the country's Q1 growth rate was the fastest in nearly two years. The CSI 300 index is up a modest 0.03%, but the Hang Seng is up 0.49%.

In Europe, the main indexes opened lower today. The FTSE 100 is down 0.54%, the DAX is down 0.28%, and the CAC 40 is down 0.29%. At least some of the drop is attributable to profit taking after the large gains earlier in the week.

Wall Street's markets have not opened as of this writing, but were down at the close of trading yesterday. The Dow lost 0.10% and the S&P 500 lost 0.05%. The NASDAQ was flat, and remained above 6,000.

In forex trading, the yen didn't react much to the Bank of Japan's policy decision. The yen, which has lost heavily in recent days, remained low. The USD/JPY stands at 111.34, up 0.23%, and the EUR/JPY stands at 121.23, up 0.12%.

The Euro slipped against its other peers, losing ground after a week of large gains. The EUR/USD dropped 0.10% to 1.0893, the EUR/GBP fell 0.49% to 0.8445, and the EUR/CHF slipped 0.09% to 1.0823. Today's losses could be related to profit taking, as the Euro hit a five and a half month high against the US dollar this past Wednesday; however, the European Central Bank is scheduled to announce its policy decision later today and a reduction in monetary easing measures is expected.

President Trump's decision to negotiate on NAFTA rather than simply withdrawing from it gave a boost to the Canadian and Mexican currencies. The USD/CAD fell 0.28%, to 1.3579, partly reversing losses the loonie took due to the drops in the price oil. The USD/MXN fell 0.97% to 19.0044. The peso reached an all-time low in January, above 21 to the dollar, on fears that President Trump would push an anti-Mexico policy on taking office.

In commodity trading, crude oil dipped again today, on the usual trader fears about the glutted markets. Stockpile data from the US hasn't helped the situation; the API reported a build of more than 4.4 million barrels in gasoline stocks, indicating weak demand, as well as a continued rise in production to 9.27 million barrels per day.
The US trading benchmark, WTI, is down 0.99% to $49.13 per barrel. On the global markets, Brent crude is down 1.08% to $51.26.

Precious metals remain down. The recent moves into risk assets, and away from safe havens, has been hard for gold traders. Gold is down another 0.37% today, to $1,264.51 per ounce, just above its recent two-week low, and platinum is down 0.22% to $948.64. Silver prices are up slightly, a quarter percent, to $17.48.
Have a great day trading!

article.name: Hedgestone_Group_-_Daily_Market_Review_Apr_30_2017
article.title: Hedgestone Group - Daily Market Review: April 30, 2017
article.keywords: Hedgestone, Hedgestone Group, Daily Market Analysis,Forex trading, US dollar, GDP, stock markets, jobs report,

content-body.text: The big news coming out of last week was the lackluster US economic growth. GDP expanded at a mere 0.7% for the first quarter of 2017, for its worst showing in 3 years. The low growth numbers were far less than Q4's 2.1%, and also lower than the forecast 1.0%. Much of the drop in GDP growth came from a collapse in consumer spending.

Investors are turning their attention to the Federal Reserve and the Department of Labor. The Fed will release its regular monetary policy decision, specifically its stance on interest rates. Conventional wisdom expects the Fed to hold steady on Wednesday, but puts a 65% chance on an interest rate hike in June and an 80% chance for a hike in September.

How the Fed moves going forward may depend a lot on what the Department of Labor has to say about the jobs situation. The Non-Farm Payroll report, seen as the definitive word on the situation in the US labor market, is due out on Friday. Expectations are for 185,000 new jobs reported in the NFP, a slight increase in the unemployment rate to 4.6%, and an increase in average wages by 0.3%. After last month's miss, both policy makers and investors are hoping to see the jobs report meet or beat the forecasts.

With all of this, stock markets around the world were down on Friday. In the US, the Dow and S&P 500 both slipped 0.19% while the NASDAQ dropped a mere 0.02%. The Dow and the NASDAQ remain near their recent record-high levels.

In Europe, the FTSE 100 was down 0.46% for the day, and 1.62% for the month. The upcoming Brexit and the stronger pound have been giving British stocks a rough time, as the UK tends to be export dependent. Continental stock markets fared better, with the DAX down just 0.05% and the CAC 40 down 0.08%. French shares had a good month, especially after Macron's win in the first round of the French presidential voting. The CAC 40 is up 2.83% for April.

The Asian stock markets were also down. In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 fell 0.29% and the TOPIX slipped 0.32%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng lost 0.34%. In Shanghai, the CSI 300 lost 0.20% for the day, on its way to a 0.47% loss for the month.
In the forex trading markets, the US dollar gained slightly on Friday, as the US dollar index was mainly stable at 99.050. The index was trending down at the end of the day, however.

In the individual trading pairs, the dollar fell against the Euro and the pound, but gained on the yen, Swiss franc, and Canadian dollar. The EUR/USD was up 0.20% to 1.0895 and the GBP/USD was up 0.36% to 1.2951. On the upside for the dollar, the USD/JPY was up 111.49, the USD/CHF was up 0.05% to 0.9946, and the USD/CAD was up 0.15% to 1.3653.
The Euro also gained on the yen, adding 0.46% to 121.53, but it slipped against the pound. The EUR/GBP dropped 0.14% to 0.8413.

Crude oil prices gained slightly on Friday, trimming their overall losses for the month of April to about 3%. Oil is under pressure from rising production and near-record stockpiles in the US. Rig counts in the US increased for the fifteenth week a row to reach 697 active drilling rigs â€“ the highest number in two years. Total production tends to lag the rig count, but US output is currently more than 9.25 million barrels per day. It's expected to increase by close to 800,000 barrel per day by year's end.

The production and stockpiles in the US are offsetting OPEC's efforts to bring supply and demand back into balance. The producer cartel has cut production by nearly 1.8 million barrels per day, but has yet to make serious inroads into the global oversupply to force prices down. WTI, the US benchmark, stands at $49.33 per barrel, and Brent crude, the global benchmark, is selling at $52.05.

Precious metals, especially gold, made a monthly gain for April. Gold was up 0.31% on Friday, to $1,268.28 per ounce, posting a 1.5% gain for the month despite a retreat from haven assets after the French election. Platinum is also up, 0.30%, to $946.19. Silver slipped 0.42% to $17.26.
Markets will be closed in China, Europe, and the UK on Monday, but normal trading will resume on Tuesday.
Have a great week trading!
